headline: Celebrities lend Biden a hand in turning out the vote in Philadelphia.
abstract: PHILADELPHIA — Add Debra Messing and Kathy Najimy to the thousands of canvassers spread out across Philadelphia for the Biden campaign on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Add Debra Messing and Kathy Najimy to the thousands of canvassers spread out across Philadelphia for the Biden campaign on Saturday.

headline: The Battlegrounds Within Battlegrounds
abstract: Here are 20 counties in battleground states that are crucial for a White House victory.
lead_paragraph: Here are 20 counties in battleground states that are crucial for a White House victory.

headline: ‘They’re coming after our state,’ McSally warns Arizona Republicans.
abstract: SUN CITY, Ariz. — Don’t believe the polls. Don’t believe the media. And definitely do not believe the Democrats.
lead_paragraph: SUN CITY, Ariz. — Don’t believe the polls. Don’t believe the media. And definitely do not believe the Democrats.

headline: Kids’ Graphic Novels That Turn the Superhero Genre on Its Head
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Graphic Novels']
abstract: Bright, bold and utterly unconventional, both “Mister Invincible” and “Primer” flout all the “rules.”
lead_paragraph: When I was a kid, my local comic shop was in a strip mall about 10 minutes away from my home. It was one of my favorite places in the world. For 60 cents, I could buy a comic book — a ticket to a universe populated by modern-day gods.

headline: Got Worries? Make Newspaper Dolls to Catch Them
abstract: Whispering your fears to these little dolls made of rolled newspaper might help you sleep better.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot to worry about these days. With Covid-19 cases rising, the new darkness of standard time and the election taking place in a few days, everyone could use an extra outlet to release some anxiety. It’s the perfect week to turn your newspaper into a handful of worry dolls.

headline: Learn the Etiquette of Virtual Weddings
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Videophones and Videoconferencing', 'Parties (Social)', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: The answers to all your 2020 pandemic wedding dilemmas.
lead_paragraph: With weddings this year being delayed, downsized or split into two — video ceremony now, party next year — many guests have some only-in-2020 etiquette questions. Should you dress up? Send a present — or two? Read on for answers to all your pandemic wedding quandaries.

headline: Listen to the Globe
abstract: Radio programming from around the world is available on the internet or through apps.
lead_paragraph: Americans may not be able to travel the world because of the pandemic, but thousands of foreign radio stations are easily accessible online to bring the world to you.

headline: Tap LinkedIn for Career Opportunities
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Social Media', 'Careers and Professions', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Whether you’re looking for a new role or just trying to expand your professional network, here’s how to use the website’s services to your full advantage.
lead_paragraph: Arguably the least fun social media platform, LinkedIn used to be the online equivalent of a professional networking event — a stodgy affair that no one really wanted to hang around. But, for the foreseeable future, the pandemic has all but eradicated most other methods of sniffing out career opportunities. Now that grabbing drinks with former colleagues or hobnobbing at work conferences is off the table, LinkedIn has been promoted from obligatory to essential.

headline: Sean Connery: From Tentative Secret Agent to Suave Bond
keywords: ['Movies', 'Bond, James (Fictional Character)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Actors and Actresses']
abstract: He may be considered the ultimate 007, but it took him time to find his footing, helped by a director with a taste for high living.
lead_paragraph: In 1965, at the height of James Bond mania, Sean Connery told Playboy magazine that he had no problem with another actor assuming his signature role. “Actually, I’d find it interesting to see what someone else does with it,” he said. “Lots of people could play him.”

headline: Don’t Give In to ‘Election Stress Disorder’
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Voting day won’t bring an end to the strain of this political season, but you don’t have to let things get contentious.
lead_paragraph: From the droves of people voting by mail to the widespread protests for racial justice to the pandemic and worries about the electoral process itself, the 2020 election cycle provides “a recipe for a lot of angst” on Election Day, according to Alvin Bernard Tillery Jr., a professor of political science at Northwestern University.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 1, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 1, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An interview on Sept. 27 about Ilhan Omar, the Democratic congresswoman from Minnesota, referred incorrectly to her family’s arrival in the United States in 1995. They came to the United States as refugees. They were not granted asylum status.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Tracing Now All but Impossible as Outbreaks Tear Through U.S.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 1, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “You can swing a cat and hit someone who has got it.”

headline: This Election Week, Revisit the Constitution, Then Soothe Your Stressed Mind
abstract: Calm your nerves with a meditation guide, a night at the Seattle Symphony and a day among the sea otters at the Monterey Bay Aquarium.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Obituaries for the American Dream
abstract: If it was ever real, it isn’t anymore.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been talking about “the American dream” since James Truslow Adams coined the phrase in his 1931 book, “The Epic of America.” But what’s a dream anyway? A brimming over of the day’s repressed desires? Just a flutter of the neurons? If the American dream was ever real, it isn’t now.

headline: Vehicles flying Trump flags try to force a Biden-Harris campaign bus off a highway in Texas.
abstract: Vehicles flying Trump flags tried to force a Biden-Harris campaign bus off a highway in Texas. Trump chuckled about it at a rally later that evening.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — Multiple vehicles bearing Trump flags and signs surrounded a Biden-Harris campaign bus heading from San Antonio to Austin on Friday, forcing campaign officials to scrap two campaign events, according to reports by Democratic officials on Saturday.

headline: Trump moves Florida rally up by two hours, but it could still run afoul of a local curfew.
abstract: A Trump rally planned for late Sunday in Florida could run afoul of a local curfew.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — President Trump’s fifth and final rally on Sunday in Opa-locka, Fla., was moved to 9:30 p.m. after being scheduled to kick off at 11:30 p.m., a late hour for attendees and viewers — and a potential problem for local officials. To try to slow the spread of the coronavirus, Miami-Dade County has a nightly curfew that begins at midnight.

headline: With just two days until Election Day, all eyes are on Pennsylvania.
abstract: All eyes are on Pennsylvania, which both presidential campaigns seem to believe could determine the outcome of the race.
lead_paragraph: As the election winds to a close, President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. are converging on Pennsylvania, with both candidates holding a flurry of events in a last-minute quest for votes.

headline: 8 Pro-Democracy Politicians Arrested in Hong Kong Over Heated Meeting
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The Hong Kong politicians were arrested in connection with a contentious meeting in May, when the local legislature’s chambers were filled with protest over a battle for control over a key committee.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The police arrested seven pro-democracy politicians early Sunday over a heated meeting in May, when the local legislature’s chambers were filled with protest over a battle for control over a key committee. An eighth was arrested Monday.

headline: Halloween Stabbing Attack in Quebec City Leaves 2 Dead
abstract: The police arrested a 24-year-old man who they said was dressed in medieval garb and carrying a sword when he went on a rampage.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — The police in Quebec City said on Sunday that they had arrested a man dressed in medieval garb and brandishing a sword after a series of stabbings on Halloween night left two people dead and five others wounded.

headline: On ‘S.N.L.’, Jim Carrey Reads a Spooky Election Update of ‘The Raven’
abstract: Carrey appeared in his recurring role as Joe Biden in a Halloween episode hosted by the “Saturday Night Live” alum John Mulaney and featuring the Strokes as the musical guest.
lead_paragraph: On a Halloween night that fell on a fraught weekend before Election Day, a nation turned its lonely eyes to John Mulaney, the “Saturday Night Live” alum whose return appearances to this sketch show are usually a good omen.

headline: ‘He Managed a Smile and Thanked Charles for the Compliment’
abstract: A reunion with a well-dressed teacher, a tricky census question and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Inside One Brooklyn Restaurant’s Desperate Fight to Survive the Pandemic
abstract: Half of New York City’s 24,000 restaurants could go out of business. Gertie is fighting to avoid becoming one of them.
lead_paragraph: On the second Saturday in March, the owners of Gertie, a Jewish-American luncheonette in Brooklyn, finalized a last step in the makeover of their year-old restaurant. They hired a new sous chef, an up-and-comer who had landed hours before on a one-way flight from Detroit.

headline: Preaching or Avoiding Politics, Conservative Churches Walk a Delicate Line
abstract: Pastors can’t endorse or oppose candidates from the pulpit, and many of them don’t want to. But that doesn’t mean they’re ignoring politics.
lead_paragraph: The second weekend in October was “citizenship weekend” at Prestonwood Baptist Church in Plano, Texas.

headline: In Italy, Like Everywhere the Virus Goes, It’s the Discontent That’s Contagious
abstract: Italians are now a long way away from the days of singing on balconies and their summer fling with freedom. Just like everyone else, they’ve had it.
lead_paragraph: ROME — When the coronavirus first hit Italy, overwhelming the country’s hospitals and prompting the West’s first lockdown, Italians inspired the world with their resilience and civic responsibility, staying home and singing on their balconies. Their reward for months of quarantine was a flattened curve, a gulp of normalcy and the satisfaction of usually patronizing allies pointing to Italy as a model.

headline: She’s Moved From the Upper East Side to ‘Cobble Hill’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Television', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Cecily von Ziegesar, the author of “Gossip Girl,” is going for an adult, possibly Brooklyn-based audience in her new novel, but there will still be drama.
lead_paragraph: The inspiration for Cecily von Ziegesar’s latest novel? Lice.

headline: Meet the Ebony Anglers, Five Black Women Catching Fish and Stares
keywords: ['Fishing, Sport', 'Women and Girls', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: The team, formed in the past few months, is trying to make a mark in the mostly white, mostly male world of competitive fishing.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC BEACH, N.C. — The shooting stars that illuminated the dark sky on the journey to deeper waters had given way to a crisp morning when Gia Peebles felt her fishing rod tense.

headline: States Undercount Positive Rapid Tests, Masking the Spread of Disease
abstract: Health officials say an influx of rapid, inexpensive tests is good for the country, but caution that they are struggling to count those who test positive.
lead_paragraph: Health officials say an influx of rapid, inexpensive tests is good for the country, but caution that they are struggling to count those who test positive.

headline: A Nutmegger, a Buckeye and a Sooner Walked Into a Voting Booth...
keywords: ['Elections', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Every four years, as Election Day draws near, we embrace America’s oddball geographic nicknames.
lead_paragraph: Every four years, as Election Day draws near, we embrace America’s oddball geographic nicknames.

headline: Dwight Garner Shares From His Stash of Other Writers’ Words
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Quotations and Proverbs', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: In an excerpt from his new book, “Garner’s Quotations: A Modern Miscellany,” the Times critic explains why he’s hoarded favorite lines for nearly 40 years and why he’s sharing some with readers now.

headline: U.S. Diplomat Coughs Online, and European Allies Wonder if They Were Exposed
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: A senior State Department official who tested positive for the coronavirus after a trip to Europe has angered other diplomats and irritated foreign officials whom he could have infected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As part of a diplomatic tour through Europe in late October, the State Department’s director of policy planning briefed journalists in London about the Trump administration’s strategy toward China. A video of the virtual event showed him coughing at least six times during the hourlong discussion.

headline: Ahead of Election, Police Prepare for Violence and Disruption
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Police', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Many law enforcement officials have attempted to inject calm while warning of dire consequences for those who try to disrupt voting.
lead_paragraph: The Las Vegas Police had a quandary. They were on high alert for election-related threats, but when long lines of voters began snaking down streets and around parking lots two weeks ago, they feared that stationing patrol cars outside polling stations might drive people away.

headline: Americans Are Afraid. Not for Themselves, but for the Country.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: A feeling of alarm and fear about the future of democracy, from voters across the political spectrum.
lead_paragraph: There is much to fear this year, as campaign speeches and ads remind voters. The virus is surging, hospitals are filling again, and children are falling behind in school. Renters risk eviction, and businesses remain boarded up. Violent crime has risen and could reach your neighborhood, the president warns. And in this unsettling time, you could lose your health care, your job, your property values, or your local police department.

headline: Pastors at the Polls? Meet Ohio’s Election Protection Squad
keywords: ['Elections', 'Clergy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: After the most tense election season in generations, clergy members are being trained and deployed to defuse potentially violent encounters on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: From across Ohio, ministers, chaplains and social workers who have volunteered to deploy to the polls dialed in to a videoconference to hear nine hypothetical situations they might encounter on Election Day, from people refusing to wear masks to politicians pressuring those in line to vote for them.

headline: Can Raphael Warnock Go From the Pulpit to the Senate?
abstract: The pastor at the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta, where Martin Luther King Jr. once preached, is betting that Georgia is ready to send a religious progressive to Washington.
lead_paragraph: DALTON, Ga. — On a recent Sunday morning in northwest Georgia, the Rev. Raphael G. Warnock, the South’s most prominent Black preacher and a Democratic candidate for the U.S. Senate, was giving his stump speech, mixing a little laid-back pulpit humor with a searing, Jeremiah-like condemnation of Republicans in the age of Trump.

headline: How the Wealthy World Has Failed Poor Countries During the Pandemic
keywords: ['Poverty', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Despite pledges for debt relief and expanded programs, the World Bank and International Monetary Fund have delivered meager aid, say economists.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Like much of the developing world, Pakistan was alarmingly short of doctors and medical facilities long before anyone had heard of Covid-19. Then the pandemic overwhelmed hospitals, forcing some to turn away patients. As fear upended daily life, families lost livelihoods and struggled to feed themselves.

headline: Election at Hand, Biden Leads Trump in Four Key States, Poll Shows
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. leads President Trump in Pennsylvania, Florida, Arizona and, by a wide margin, in Wisconsin, according to a Times/Siena College poll.
lead_paragraph: [Joe Biden has won the 2020 U.S. presidential election. Read our story]

headline: Dishonesty Has Defined the Trump Presidency. The Consequences Could Be Lasting.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: Whether President Trump wins or loses on Nov. 3, the very concept of public trust in an established set of facts necessary for the operation of a democratic society has been eroded.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Born amid made-up crowd size claims and “alternative facts,” the Trump presidency has been a factory of falsehood from the start, churning out distortions, conspiracy theories and brazen lies at an assembly-line pace that has challenged fact-checkers and defied historical analogy.

headline: On Marathon Weekend, Des Linden Ran 26.2 Miles, and Then Some, in New York
abstract: The New York City Marathon turned into a virtual event, but that did not stop Des Linden from coming to New York to accomplish something big.
lead_paragraph: This was not the way Des Linden was planning to finish a marathon in Central Park this weekend, when she and 50,000 other runners were supposed to run the New York City Marathon.

headline: He Already Saw the Election as Good vs. Evil. Then His Tractor Burned.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Rural Areas', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Vandalism', 'ARSON']
abstract: In Nebraska, President Trump’s supporters hope he wins a second term, and that they get four more years of feeling like the country’s leader understands and defends them.
lead_paragraph: HENDERSON, Neb. — Jonathan Rempel has never been a loudmouth around town about his politics, but his views are clear when he asks rhetorical questions like, “Have you ever got a job from a poor person?” Or when he says that taxes are a form of extortion. They show up on Facebook, where some of his posts support gun rights and criticize a welfare state.

headline: Trump is counting on efforts to target potential supporters who sat out in 2016.
abstract: The president’s campaign to identify likely supporters among people who did not vote in 2016 is seen by Democrats as a threat in Pennsylvania in particular.
lead_paragraph: As Democrats fret their way into the final hours of the race for the White House, one possibility is high on the list of reasons President Trump might win.

headline: Mississippi City Spared Loss of Electric Service
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Credit and Debt', 'Local Government', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: Upset over high electricity bills, residents of Itta Bena, Miss., complained, only to discover the city was hundreds of thousands of dollars in debt to its power supplier.
lead_paragraph: Seeing a $450 to $600 electricity bill no longer fazes Patricia Young of Itta Bena, Miss., a city of about 1,800 people in the Mississippi Delta.

headline: Coronavirus Surge, Election Day, Sean Connery: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Why Are Republicans So Afraid of Voters?
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Absentee Voting', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)']
abstract: There is no “both sides do it” when it comes to intentionally keeping Americans away from the polls.
lead_paragraph: As of Sunday afternoon, more than 93 million Americans had cast a ballot in the November elections. That’s about two-thirds of the total number of people who voted in 2016, and there are still two days until Election Day.

headline: The Week in Business: A Nail-Biter
abstract: The election’s outcome will shape the economy — and your wallet — for years to come.
lead_paragraph: It’s basically impossible to talk about anything but the election, but here goes. (And if you haven’t voted yet, use today’s extra daylight saving hour to make a plan for the polls.) See you on the other side. — Charlotte Cowles

headline: Signs Get Snatched, Kicked, Burned as Political Battle Reaches the Front Lawn
abstract: Fights over political signs happen every year, but this year seems more intense. “It feels like a war,” one resident said.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In Illinois, Florida and Arizona, police officers have been summoned to investigate Biden signs set ablaze and Trump flags swiped in the night. Homeowners, angry over their campaign signs disappearing, have set up elaborate motion-activated cameras to catch the culprits. A sneaky few have booby-trapped signs with sharp razor blades glinting underneath.

headline: We Have Never Had Final Results on Election Day
abstract: President Trump has been trying to pre-emptively delegitimize ballots counted after Nov. 3. But states have always counted past election night.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, President Trump and his allies have been laying groundwork to challenge the results of the election if he loses. Now, in the final days of the campaign, he has settled on a blatantly ahistorical closing argument: that the votes in a fair election should not be counted past election night.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Kamala Harris, Mass Incarceration and Me’
abstract: Many progressives mistrust her for her past as a prosecutor. For Reginald Dwayne Betts — an ex-convict and the son of a crime victim — it’s not that simple.
lead_paragraph: At 16, Reginald Dwayne Betts was sent to prison for nine years after pleading guilty to a carjacking, to having a gun, and to an attempted robbery.

headline: Enzo Mari, industrial designer who kept things simple, dies at 88.
abstract: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: For Australians, geographic isolation is now something to embrace.
abstract: They used to call it “the tyranny of distance.”
lead_paragraph: They used to call it “the tyranny of distance.”

abstract: As part of a diplomatic tour through Europe in late October, the State Department’s director of policy planning briefed journalists in London about the Trump administration’s strategy toward China. A video of the virtual event showed him coughing at least six times during the hourlong discussion.
lead_paragraph: As part of a diplomatic tour through Europe in late October, the State Department’s director of policy planning briefed journalists in London about the Trump administration’s strategy toward China. headline: When parents lose their jobs, children suffer. But sometimes there’s a consolation.
abstract: Nearly 22 percent of children in the United States had an unemployed parent in April, the highest rate on record, according to Zachary Parolin, a researcher at Columbia University.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 22 percent of children in the United States had an unemployed parent in April, the highest rate on record, according to Zachary Parolin, a researcher at Columbia University.

headline: How are Americans catching the virus? Increasingly, they have no idea.
abstract: When the coronavirus first erupted in Sioux Falls, S.D., in the spring, Mayor Paul TenHaken arrived at work each morning with a clear mission: Stop the outbreak at the pork plant. Hundreds of employees, chopping meat shoulder to shoulder, had gotten sick in what was then the largest virus cluster in the United States.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus first erupted in Sioux Falls, S.D., in the spring, Mayor Paul TenHaken arrived at work each morning with a clear mission: Stop the outbreak at the pork plant. Hundreds of employees, chopping meat shoulder to shoulder, had gotten sick in what was then the largest virus cluster in the United States.

headline: How J Balvin Made His Trippy, Eye-Popping Halloween Concert in Fortnite
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Halloween', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: The video game has become a music venue as the pandemic continues to keep live shows off the road. The Latin pop star put his own colorful spin on the experience.
lead_paragraph: For J Balvin’s big entrance on Saturday night in his concert appearance on the video game Fortnite, the Latin pop star rose through a giant glowing pumpkin, just as he might emerge from the bowels of Madison Square Garden on a lift to meet thousands of screaming fans.

headline: Rescuers Race Against Time to Find Survivors After Quake in Turkey
abstract: After the deadly tremor rocked the country’s western coast, razing buildings in the city of Izmir and killing dozens of people, hope began to fade for some of those still trapped under the rubble.
lead_paragraph: The death toll from a major earthquake off the coast of Turkey reached at least 62 on Sunday, with more than 900 others injured, as rescuers continued to dig through tons of rubble in the city of Izmir in the diminishing hope of finding more survivors.

headline: Tropical Storm Eta Forms, Tying a Record Set 15 Years Ago
abstract: Eta became the 28th named storm of the 2020 hurricane season, matching a record set in 2005.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Eta, the 28th named storm of a fiercely active hurricane season, churned over the Caribbean on Sunday, gaining strength as it headed west toward Central America, the National Hurricane Center said.

headline: David Henry Hwang’s ‘M. Butterfly’ Followup: ‘M. Turkey’
abstract: The goal: a comedy about mistaken racial identity inspired by protests over “Miss Saigon.” The result: a backstage farce that never got to opening night.
lead_paragraph: David Henry Hwang’s “Face Value” arrived on Broadway on March 9, 1993. It left five days later. For Gina Torres, an actress in that production, the news came as a relief. “Because we were pushing that stone uphill for a good long time,” she said.

headline: In Russia’s Idyllic Wine Country, Dark Tales of Dreams Dashed
abstract: A verdant slice of southern Russia evokes Tuscany and produces surprisingly magical wine. But bureaucratic nightmares and police raids intrude on the aspirations of upstart vintners.
lead_paragraph: ANAPA, Russia — Russia has no shortage of innovators, risk-takers and freethinking entrepreneurs. But their country is not built for them. Sooner or later, the state security apparatus makes its unwelcome appearance.

headline: ‘We’re in for a whole lot of hurt.’ Fauci’s comments infuriate the White House.
abstract: He has been dragged into both campaign debates, where President Trump misrepresented his positions on the pandemic. He has been featured prominently — and out of context — in a Trump re-election ad. And he has been openly derided by his own boss as a “disaster.”
lead_paragraph: He has been dragged into both campaign debates, where President Trump misrepresented his positions on the pandemic. He has been featured prominently — and out of context — in a Trump re-election ad. And he has been openly derided by his own boss as a “disaster.”

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Homemade Hamburger Helper, tomato soups and grilled cheese sandwiches: Fill your days with comfort.
lead_paragraph: Time has been passing in the most extraordinary ways since the pandemic retired my commute in March. The days ran together until they were all one endless Wednesday, or Monday, never a weekend, which would then arrive like an occasional gift, only to disappear in what seemed like seconds. And now, suddenly, it’s November? Time to talk about Thanksgiving. I’ve avoided it long enough.

headline: Trump is visiting five states on Sunday, while Biden focuses on Pennsylvania.
abstract: President Trump is visiting five states on Sunday, as Joe Biden focuses his attention on Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: With less than 48 hours remaining before Election Day, President Trump was jetting across the country on Sunday to bring his closing message to five states, while Joseph R. Biden Jr. planned to concentrate his efforts in the crucial swing state of Pennsylvania.

headline: Swans Find New Home in Florida
abstract: The city of Lakeland, Fla., held a public lottery to sell some of its 86 swans. Two of them were relocated and released into a pond at Lost Lake Apartments in Jacksonville, Fla.
lead_paragraph: The city of Lakeland, Fla., held a public lottery to sell some of its 86 swans. Two of them were relocated and released into a pond at Lost Lake Apartments in Jacksonville, Fla.

headline: Florida City’s Beloved Swans Find New Homes
abstract: Lakeland, Fla., held a lottery to sell some of its 86 swans, which have thrived since Queen Elizabeth II donated a pair in 1957.
lead_paragraph: The buyers traveled from all over Florida, with crates and carriers, to bring their feathered guests home.

headline: What Voters in Battleground States Think About Climate Change
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters', 'Global Warming', 'States (US)']
abstract: In key swing states, the majority of voters are worried that rising temperatures or sea levels will affect their lives. For some, it has become a voting issue.
lead_paragraph: In key swing states, the majority of voters are worried that rising temperatures or sea levels will affect their lives. For some, it has become a voting issue.

headline: There Are Evangelicals Who Stand Against Trump. I’m One of Them.
keywords: ['Evangelical Movement', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'ABORTION', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: We can’t succumb to the president’s appeals to fear.
lead_paragraph: Like many kids who grew up as evangelicals, I was taught that abortion was the only issue when it comes to politics. When I turned 18, in the 1990s, my father took me to the Allen County Republican headquarters in my Indiana town, where I registered as a card-carrying conservative. Then we went to Fort Wayne’s Famous Coney Island for celebratory chili dogs.

headline: Can We Finally Agree to Ignore Election Forecasts?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Electoral College']
abstract: Before the election, I said we shouldn’t rely on them. The case just got overwhelming.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news events.

headline: To Trump, ‘the Polls That Matter’ Point to Victory. The Rest Are ‘Fake.’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: President Trump’s blinkered view of 2020 polling has created something of an alternate universe, even as his campaign struggles to find the voters he needs in the data it has.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump talks about polling, his focus is very much on survey-takers that he thinks are good for him. Polls that show him trailing Joseph R. Biden Jr. — virtually all national polls — are simply “fake news.”

headline: I’m a Democracy Expert. I Never Thought We’d Be So Close to a Breakdown.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Constitution (US)', 'State Legislatures', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Electoral College']
abstract: Our election systems were not built for the modern era. Looking abroad might help.
lead_paragraph: As this Tuesday’s consequential election nears, my fellow democracy experts and I have often been asked: What is the right historical analogy to America’s current crisis? The truth is, there is no precedent. We have never seen such a longstanding democracy in such a rich country break down before — never. But it could happen this year.

headline: Let’s Get Started on Fighting Climate Change
abstract: Readers suggest concrete ways we can act now. Also: The nonvoter also makes a decision.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What This Election Means for America
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Some final thoughts about the candidates and voters’ hopes and fears as Election Day looms.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Typhoon Spared the Philippine Capital. Will Manila Be So Lucky Next Time?
abstract: With climate change heightening the Philippines’ risk of natural disaster, the country is braced for the next catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The Philippines was braced for the worst. When Typhoon Goni made landfall in the disaster-plagued nation on Sunday morning, with sustained winds of 135 miles per hour, it ranked as the most powerful storm to hit the Southeast Asian nation in years.

headline: Make Some Noise and Move: A Choreographer Provides Instructions
abstract: “I really didn’t want it to be about the screen,” Yanira Castro said about adapting a work for the pandemic. Instead, she made scores to try at home.
lead_paragraph: About 50 people sat in front of their computers on a recent afternoon, banging on pots and pans with kitchen utensils. In a departure from common Zoom etiquette, everyone was unmuted and making as much noise as possible. What began as an attempt to find a synchronized beat quickly unraveled into clanging, joyful chaos.

headline: Welcome to November. For Trump, the October Surprise Never Came.
abstract: Trump’s hope that an economic recovery, a Covid vaccine or a Biden scandal could shake up the race faded with the last light of October.
lead_paragraph: President Trump began the fall campaign rooting for, and trying to orchestrate, a last-minute surprise that would vault him ahead of Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Poets and Lovers: Do Rimbaud and Verlaine Belong in France’s Panthéon?
abstract: A petition seeks to honor them, but critics ask if it’s about poetry or sexuality, and whether such rebels would be out of place in an august shrine to national heroes.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “To the great men, a grateful homeland” reads the inscription above the columned entrance to the Panthéon, France’s storied tomb of heroes, which houses the remains of idols like Hugo, Curie and Rousseau.

headline: The Atlantic Retracts Ruth Shalit Barrett Article on Niche Sports
keywords: ['Rumors and Misinformation', 'Plagiarism', 'Magazines', 'News and News Media', 'Athletics and Sports']
abstract: Ms. Barrett had been a rising young political reporter in the 1990s before accusations of plagiarism derailed her career as an associate editor at The New Republic.
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic on Sunday took the extraordinary step of retracting an article by Ruth Shalit Barrett, who was a rising young political reporter in the 1990s when accusations of plagiarism derailed her career as an associate editor at The New Republic.

headline: The New York City Marathon Was Canceled. Runners Ran the Course Anyway.
abstract: The 50th New York City Marathon would have been Sunday. Some runners still ran the 26.2-mile course despite the cancellation.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Marathon began on Oct. 17, technically at least.

headline: In San Francisco, Virus Is Contained but Schools Are Still Closed
abstract: A debate over reopening classrooms pits the mayor against the Board of Education, cutting across class, party and racial lines.

headline: Trump, Venezuela and the Tug-of-War Over a Strongman
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States International Relations', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Cuban-Americans']
abstract: How a yearslong battle over U.S.-Venezuela relations aided President Trump’s campaign in Florida — and left the Maduro regime standing.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump turned to the Capitol gallery during his State of the Union speech in February to recognize Venezuela’s young opposition leader, Juan Guaidó, it seemed like a political masterstroke.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: Assessing Goni, the 18th typhoon to hit the Philippines this year.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of resisting calls for a lockdown, Prime Minister Boris Johnson is shutting pubs, restaurants and most retail stores in England, starting on Thursday until Dec. 2. Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland had already put in place such restrictions.

headline: Don’t Eat the Breakfast Cereal. It’s Made of Plastic.
abstract: Robin Frohardt has turned a vacant space in Times Square into a colorful installation that slyly doubles as an eco-warning. Puppets have their moment, too.
lead_paragraph: Wrapping around a corner in Times Square, the storefront had been hidden in plain sight since the tail end of winter, when so much of the city’s creative life shut down, locked up and headed home to wait out the coronavirus.

headline: Trump, Biden and the Tough Guy, Nice Guy Politics of 2020
keywords: ['Men and Boys', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The 2016 election was a referendum on many things, including what Americans thought a woman could do or be. Now it’s a question of what a man should be.
lead_paragraph: Kindness. Humility. Responsibility. These traits were once “the definition of manliness,” Barack Obama told a crowd on Saturday, campaigning in Flint, Mich., for his former running mate, Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: What Happens if Neither Trump Nor Biden Concedes?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Elections (US)', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Our system offers many offramps from the road to disaster. Whether we take one is another question.
lead_paragraph: With a president refusing to commit to a peaceful transition of power, a number of commentators have been sounding the alarm about a “rickety” U.S. electoral system seen as uniquely vulnerable to a postelection crisis. Legal scholars and a group called the Transition Integrity Project have been examining the ways in which the machinery could fail, and the nightmare scenarios gamed out are hair-raising. But while looking at points of possible legal failure is a useful exercise, it neglects an important question: Who has the power to concede?

headline: Picturing Yourself with Bob Ross as the ‘Experience’ Opens in Indiana
abstract: Visitors can tour the beloved painter’s recreated studio and take Bob Ross master classes, in the city where “The Joy of Painting” was filmed.
lead_paragraph: MUNCIE, Ind. — Lexi Vann was losing her race with Bob Ross.

headline: Two Women and 10,000 Miles on the Road to Suffrage
abstract: Mapping a 1916 journey on the road to the 19th Amendment that has been largely overlooked.
lead_paragraph: With the 2020 presidential election now upon us, Americans are still mired in uncertainty. But at least one thing has already been made clear: The women’s vote will be critical to the outcome.

headline: 2 Warehouse Halloween Parties Attended by Nearly 1,000 Are Shut Down
abstract: Few people were social distancing or wearing masks, New York City authorities said. Twenty-eight people face charges.
lead_paragraph: Two Halloween parties with hundreds of guests dancing and drinking inside warehouses were broken up by New York City authorities this weekend, as officials strive to curb behavior that they worry could fuel a second wave of the pandemic.

headline: In chilly Milwaukee, young canvassers go door to door.
abstract: Amira Randolph, 15, and about 25 other young people braved strong wind and near-freezing temperatures on Sunday to encourage people in Milwaukee’s Near South Side to turn out and vote. Wearing masks, the canvassers stepped back six feet after ringing doorbells.
lead_paragraph: Amira Randolph, 15, and about 25 other young people braved strong wind and near-freezing temperatures on Sunday to encourage people in Milwaukee’s Near South Side to turn out and vote. Wearing masks, the canvassers stepped back six feet after ringing doorbells.

headline: In Texas, the Polls Open for a Graveyard Shift
abstract: Hoping to make voting easier during the pandemic, officials opened several polling sites in Harris County, Texas, for overnight balloting last week. Thousands showed up.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Felix Sylvester drove straight to the polling site after work and cast his ballot in a matter of minutes. There was no line, perhaps because it was a few minutes past 3 a.m.

headline: Tests Show Genetic Signature of Virus That May Have Infected President Trump
keywords: ['White House Coronavirus Outbreak (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Contact Tracing (Public Health)', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Research', 'your-feed-healthcare', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: The White House did not take basic steps to investigate its outbreak. We worked with geneticists to sequence the virus that infected two journalists exposed during the outbreak, providing clues to how it may have spread.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s illness from a coronavirus infection last month was the most significant health crisis for a sitting president in nearly 40 years. Yet little remains known about how the virus arrived at the White House and how it spread.

headline: Inspiring Black Voters Is Key to Biden’s Prospects in Florida
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Democratic groups are pouring money into get-out-the-vote efforts in Black precincts to try to increase turnout from 2016, in a state that is critical to President Trump’s re-election chances.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — One Saturday last month, after Democrats held a news conference in this city’s predominantly Black east side to promote the start of early voting, State Senator Audrey Gibson offered her view about why turnout among Florida’s African-Americans dropped so strikingly in 2016.

headline: Nikki McKibbin, ‘American Idol’ Finalist, Dies at 42
abstract: Ms. McKibbin, who finished third on the inaugural season of the reality talent show in 2002, died on Sunday after a brain aneurysm, her husband said.
lead_paragraph: Nikki McKibbin, a singer-songwriter from Texas best known for her third-place finish on the inaugural season of “American Idol,” died on Sunday. She was 42.

headline: Caregivers Have Witnessed the Coronavirus’s Pain. How Will They Vote?
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Nursing Homes', 'Voting and Voters', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: In Pennsylvania, deaths in nursing homes account for almost two-thirds of all virus-related fatalities. Some of the people working inside those facilities say the pandemic is shaping their politics.
lead_paragraph: At the Pennsylvania long-term care facility where Tisheia Frazier works, the coronavirus was a terror. During the most harrowing weeks of the pandemic in April and May, she said, four residents died in a matter of hours, and 70 people in an 180-bed unit died in less than a month.

headline: Deadly Taliban Attack Probably Used Drone, a Worrisome Shift
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The strike targeted the governor’s compound in Kunduz, a province that has seen heavy fighting despite peace talks between Taliban and Afghan government negotiators.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A Taliban attack, most likely carried out by a drone, killed at least four security officers in northern Afghanistan on Sunday, according to senior and local Afghan officials, representing what could be the group’s first publicly known use of the method in the 19-year war.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 2, 2020
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.

headline: Did the Pandemic Destroy Halloween? Here’s What We Found
abstract: Even as the pandemic threatened to ruin Halloween, New Yorkers dressed up, they danced, they played and they even skated from morning to night.
lead_paragraph: Even as the pandemic threatened to ruin Halloween, New Yorkers dressed up, they danced, they played and they even skated from morning to night.

headline: Texas Supreme Court Denies G.O.P. Push to Throw Out 127,000 Votes
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Supreme Courts (State)']
abstract: The Republican effort to invalidate the votes from Harris County, which includes Houston and is largely Democratic, now hinges on an effort at the federal level, where a hearing is set for Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Texas Supreme Court on Sunday denied an effort by Republicans to throw out more than 120,000 votes that had already been cast at drive-through locations in Harris County, leaving Republicans’ only remaining option at the federal level.

headline: Voting System in Maine Threatens Collins in Final Days of Close Senate Race
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The state’s new ranked-choice system could prove dangerous for Senator Susan Collins, who is running for a fifth term against Sara Gideon, a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: CUMBERLAND, Maine — Sara Gideon, her voice hoarse on a cold Friday night, stood in the center of a fairgrounds stage as the headline act at a drive-through rally, making a closing pitch to a chorus of appreciative car honks and headlight flashes for a government dominated by Democrats that would move aggressively to address climate change, economic and racial inequality and out-of-control health care costs.

headline: Steelers’ Unbeaten Streak Comes Down to Ravens’ Last, Best Play
abstract: Pittsburgh rallied from down 10 at the half to take a lead on Baltimore. That’s when Lamar Jackson and the Steelers’ defense collided.
lead_paragraph: Of the 256 games played every N.F.L. regular season, two — and only two — are as reliably entertaining as they are vicious and close, enriched with enmity, malice and a healthy dose of respect. They are the games between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Baltimore Ravens, A.F.C. North border feuds that teem with after-the-whistle skirmishes, out-of-bounds hits and postseason implications, year after year after year.

headline: Dispute Over Pissarro Painting Looted by Nazis Is Back in Court
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Art', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Museums', 'Statutes of Limitations']
abstract: A Holocaust survivor wants to revisit a settlement with an Oklahoma art museum over a painting once owned by her father.
lead_paragraph: When Léone Meyer discovered in 2012 that a painting Nazi looters had stolen from her father was in the collection of an American museum, her first instinct was to demand its return.

headline: Made a Bust
abstract: Luke Vaughn gets artsy.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes you really have to stare at a crossword puzzle to make the theme visible, even on a Monday. Newer solvers might not know to look at different parts of the theme entries to see what they have in common, and with no revealer, they might finish the entire puzzle without realizing that there is a theme there at all.

headline: Famed Iranian Artist Under #MeToo Cloud Faces Art World Repercussions
abstract: In Iran, an exhibit of Aydin Aghdashloo’s work was canceled and a prominent auction is considering dropping him. In Canada, a petition calls for an art festival to cut ties with him.
lead_paragraph: A famous and well-connected Iranian artist who has been accused by at least 13 women of sexual misconduct is starting to see signs of repercussions in the art world that once exalted him, both in Iran and Canada, where he has dual citizenship.

headline: What We Learned From Week 8 of the N.F.L. Season
abstract: Dalvin Cook shredded the Packers, the Steelers stayed undefeated and Joe Burrow and the Bengals shocked Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: A Packers home loss to lowly Minnesota. Pittsburgh toppling the Ravens in Baltimore to stay undefeated. The Dolphins and the Bengals pulling off wild upsets behind rookie quarterbacks. The theme of Week 8 was to expect the unexpected, though the Jets proved to be a stabilizing force by losing to Kansas City in as ugly a fashion as predicted.

headline: Both Candidates Agree: Trump’s Crowds Are Bigger, and They’re OK With That
abstract: While President Trump still thrills to the roar of a crowd, even during a pandemic, Joe Biden has found a new way to get audience feedback: through honking horns at his drive-in rallies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For President Trump, the only thing that really matters is the size of his crowds. For Joseph R. Biden Jr., the road to the White House is full of honking cars.

headline: A Year of Devastation in Arizona’s Wild Lands
keywords: ['Border Barriers', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Environment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Living and working along the U.S.-Mexico border has meant watching the surreal, slow-motion leveling of the fragile ecosystems I’ve spent my career fighting to protect.
lead_paragraph: Saguaro cactuses, some nearly a century old, in shards on the desert floor. Jaguars, lost, because a metal wall has blocked their migratory path. Endangered species homeless because their critical habitats have been destroyed.

headline: Trump Backers Block Highways as Election Tensions Play Out in the Streets
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Law enforcement authorities are increasingly worried, not just about what they have already seen, but also about what has been threatened, especially online.
lead_paragraph: Vehicles with Trump flags halted traffic on Sunday on the Garden State Parkway in New Jersey and jammed the Mario M. Cuomo Bridge between Tarrytown and Nyack, N.Y. Another pro-Trump convoy in Virginia ended in a tense shouting match with protesters as it approached a statue of Robert E. Lee in Richmond.

headline: On Afghan Highways, Even the Police Fear the Taliban’s Toll Collectors
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Extortion and Blackmail']
abstract: As the U.S. retreats and peace talks stall, the Taliban have increasingly taken over Afghanistan’s highways, raising millions in unofficial taxes and strengthening their negotiating position.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — When the long-haul trucker drives past this hilltop police outpost in southern Afghanistan each week, he knows exactly what to do. The officers toss down a box tied to a length of rope and like all drivers, the trucker places 5,000 afghanis — about $65 — in the box, which the officers then reel back up to their outpost.

headline: Eddie Hassell, Actor in ‘Surface’ and ‘The Kids Are All Right,’ Dies at 30
abstract: The Texas native, who moved to Los Angeles at 11 to pursue an acting career, was fatally shot near Dallas, his representative said.

Fauci after Election Day, further escalating the tension between his administration and the nation’s top infectious disease expert as the number of new coronavirus cases in the United States reaches record highs.

headline: Trump amps up uncertainty and plays down the pandemic as a chaotic campaign races to its conclusion.
abstract: Worries escalate as a historic campaign races to an uncertain close.
lead_paragraph: President Trump, adopting a double-barreled closing strategy of maximizing uncertainty over the election and minimizing the pandemic, is vowing to mount a legal challenge to Pennsylvania’s vote count while threatening to fire Dr. Anthony Fauci, the person Americans trust most to tell the truth on the coronavirus.

headline: Almost Like Clockwork, Talk of a Military Coup Follows Thai Protests
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Royal Families', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Income Inequality', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — There are certain constants in Thailand: the drenching monsoons, the grand openings of new shopping malls and the rumors that the Royal Thai Armed Forces are plotting another coup.

lead_paragraph: You’re stuck working from home, but does your career need to be stuck, too? Worried about keeping employees safe, many companies are pushing return-to-office dates deep into next year, so workers face more months toiling from spare bedrooms and kitchen tables.

headline: What These Athletes Learned From Their Pandemic Pauses
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Swimming', 'Olympic Games (2020)', 'Baseball', 'Paralympic Games', 'Basketball', 'Gymnastics']
abstract: The coronavirus disrupted lives around the world and sent the gymnast Sunisa Lee, the swimmer Rudy Garcia-Tolson, the Seattle Storm’s Breanna Stewart and the Seattle Mariners’ Kyle Lewis on unexpected journeys.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic had been blanketing countries and devastating populations for months by the time the American sports landscape was touched in mid-March. As positive cases were confirmed in professional athletes, leagues shut down completely, postponed entire seasons and, in the case of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, delayed culminating events until 2021.

headline: Many firsts for women in a very male orbit.
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'International Space Station', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Space Stations']
abstract: Women have accomplished a great deal on the space station, when they’ve been there.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, Peggy Whitson set off on her second trip to the space station and soon became its first woman commander. At the time, she was one of only three women to have lived on the I.S.S. Sunita Williams later commanded it in 2012, and Dr. Whitson had command again in 2017. They are the only women ever to take command of the station.

headline: When the Virus Came for the American Dream
abstract: Buford Highway, in suburban Atlanta, has long been a place where immigrant entrepreneurs could build businesses and get ahead. Not this year.
lead_paragraph: On April 20, 49 days after Georgia reported its first two coronavirus cases and 39 days after the announcement of the state’s first Covid-19-related death, Gov. Brian Kemp convened a news conference on the steps of the Capitol in downtown Atlanta. Speaking to an audience of masked journalists, Kemp opened his remarks by listing the most recent statistics from the Georgia Department of Public Health: 18,947 positive tests since the beginning of the pandemic and 733 deaths. “We understand that these are more than just numbers,” he said. “These are Georgians that we’re talking about.”

headline: Home Sweet Home in Orbit
abstract: A visual tour of the International Space Station, humanity’s high-tech home in the sky.
lead_paragraph: From afar, the International Space Station might look like a gangling machine, or like robot butterflies mating, but inside it is a cradle of humanity. Over the last 20 years, 141 people from 19 countries have worked, played with their food, grumbled about the toilet, drawn blood, space-walked and gazed up and down at the universe, and at Earth.

The crisis is so immediate and overwhelming that it is hard to imagine what life will be like after it’s over.

headline: ‘The Cold Millions,’ by Jess Walter: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “The Cold Millions,” by Jess Walter
lead_paragraph: Darkness came on that town like a candle being snuffed. This was my wife’s primary complaint about Spokane after two years of me copping there, what Rebecca called the “drastic dark” of autumn. We’d come from Sioux City, a town she still called home, and where I’d walked an easier beat. I found Spokane in a land-spec ad, but the piece I bought turned out to be cliff-face basalt and not arable, so we took four rooms in a brick apartment north of the river, and I got on with that roughneck police force. These were hard years, ’08 and ’09, everything about Spokane hard, bringing to mind Rebecca’s word, drastic. Steep hills, deep canyons, cold winters, hot summers, and those dark autumn evenings that made her so melancholy, when five felt like midnight.

headline: In a Hot Election, the Cool-Headed Associated Press Takes Center Stage
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: At the end of a turbulent campaign, the global news organization has a big role to play, with 4,000 reporters collecting vote counts from county clerks in 50 states.
lead_paragraph: The Associated Press will not predict a winner of the presidential election. It will not even name an apparent or likely winner. The A.P. will make the call only when it is certain — just as it has in every U.S. election since 1848, when Zachary Taylor won the White House.

Even back then I would probably have thought of a few counterexamples, the Theater of the Oppressed, say, or some conceptual stuff. But the basic parameters held.

headline: To Have and to Hone
abstract: Artisan Revere makes ultrasharp knives in Idaho using a specialty steel.
lead_paragraph: Handle these Artisan Revere knives with care. These two models are so sharp, you’ll need to keep them in their leather sheaths. David Olkovetsky, a former steel company analyst, went into the kitchen knife business with a team of like-minded partners because he was not satisfied with what was available. His knives, which took more than two years to create, are made in Idaho using aerospace-rated technology and superdurable Elmax vanadium steel. It’s a costly material that has been tested by the Cutlery & Allied Trades Research Association, an independent lab in Sheffield, England, and shown to be highly durable, resistant to nicks and dents, and able to retain a razor-fine edge better than most other high-carbon stainless knives. The chef’s knife, with a dramatic 8 ½-inch blade, full tang and comfortable, easily grasped handle, is a welcoming tool that feels lighter than it looks. The efficient paring knife, triangular like a mini-chef’s knife, has a 3 ½-inch blade. The handles are available in several colors.

headline: How Latinos Could Redefine the G.O.P. in Texas
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Minorities', 'Elections', 'Mexican-Americans', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Republican leaders are looking expectantly to the ethnically, racially and geographically diverse population that could shape the state’s conservatism for the future.

This year, hundreds of thousands of Latinos in Texas will vote for the first time, and more Texans have cast votes early than the total number who voted in 2016, giving Democrats hope that the dream is within grasp — even if they don’t win this year.

headline: Delivery That Feels Like a Five-Star Meal
abstract: The chef Jonathan Benno has teamed up with Better Than Your Mother’s for an elegant tasting menu meant to be served at home.
lead_paragraph: The chef and restaurateur Jonathan Benno has had it with brown-bag dinners, so he’s doing something about it. With Iman Kawa, a chef who runs Better Than Your Mother’s, which delivers elegant food from top chefs, Mr. Benno has created a truly fine meal for a solo indulgence. “It’s a way for us to keep the idea of fine dining alive until confidence is restored in dining out,” he said. His “Experience” starts with a lush caviar canapé, followed by tangy vegetables à la grecque and a creamy lasagna freckled with black winter truffle. Tender braised short ribs of beef, in a silken wine sauce with baby vegetables, is the main course. A chocolate-paved marjolaine cake and a chocolate butter cookie with ganache complete the meal. Meticulous reheating and plating instructions are included for each dish. And though the elegant box of food is intended for one, that depends; I found it to be enough for two of us, but then I usually prepare only three ounces of pasta each.

headline: Washington Boards Up Ahead of Election
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Businesses have been boarded up across downtown Washington as a precaution for Election Day results that could bring unrest to the city.
lead_paragraph: Businesses have been boarded up across downtown Washington as a precaution for Election Day results that could bring unrest to the city.

headline: Justice Amy Coney Barrett Hears Her First Supreme Court Argument
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Freedom of Information Act', 'Eighth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: But she did not take part in a pair of unsigned decisions in favor of a Black Lives Matter activist and a prisoner held in abusive conditions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Amy Coney Barrett heard her first Supreme Court argument on Monday, asking assured and probing questions in a case on the Freedom of Information Act.

headline: The War on Truth Reaches Its Climax
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (2017)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Trump is telling two big lies, and a third will come soon.
lead_paragraph: I began writing a column for The Times way back in 2000. My beat was supposed to be economics and business. But I couldn’t help noticing that one of that year’s contenders for the presidency was systematically making false claims about his policy proposals. George W. Bush kept insisting that his one-percent-friendly tax cuts were targeted on the middle class, and his plan to privatize Social Security just wished away the system’s obligations to older Americans.

headline: Old New York Flavor, in a Jar
abstract: Descendants of the original owners of Monte’s Venetian Room in Gowanus, Brooklyn, are bottling their family’s red sauce.
lead_paragraph: Monte’s Venetian Room, a restaurant that, in its heyday, attracted local politicians and celebrities like Frank Sinatra, is still in business in Gowanus, Brooklyn. These days, it’s just called Monte’s, though the Monte family is no longer involved. PJ Monte — a grandnephew of Nick Monte, who owned the restaurant with his brothers — is now having his family’s classic tomato sauce recipe produced in the Hudson Valley. He started selling it this year. It has a velvety texture, a modestly rich flavor and a list of ingredients you’ll find at home. Use it as a base for pasta sauce, to make a soup, enhance a stew or brighten your next Parm.

headline: A Frozen Celebration of December Holidays
abstract: Forget pumpkin spice. OddFellows Ice Cream wants you to try one of its six seasonal flavors.
lead_paragraph: This season, OddFellows Ice Cream has concocted an assortment of uncommon holiday flavors. After lighting the Hanukkah candles on Dec. 10 (first night of the holiday), there’s latke ice cream to enjoy with smidgens of apple sauce and sour cream in the mix; coquito is based on a popular Puerto Rican Christmas drink; cherry cordial has chocolate for holiday cheer; pineapple-rum-caramel, my favorite, celebrates Kwanzaa; shattered sugar cookie has red and green sprinkles; and pine needle rocky road is all about winter.

headline: Bail for Kyle Rittenhouse Set at $2 Million in Kenosha Protest Shooting
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The father of one of the men who died in the shooting said Mr. Rittenhouse was a flight risk, and “thinks he’s above the law.”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Bail for Kyle Rittenhouse, an Illinois teenager accused of killing two men during protests over a police shooting in Kenosha, Wis., was set at $2 million on Monday as Mr. Rittenhouse made a first appearance in a Wisconsin court.

headline: A Chocolate Maker Takes a New Path
abstract: Justine Pringle has left Nunu Chocolates to start North South Confections, specializing in chocolates filled with tropical flavors.
lead_paragraph: Justine Pringle has stepped away from her Nunu Chocolates in Brooklyn and has a new venture, North South Confections. (A former partner will run Nunu.) Her first assortment has dark chocolate squares with caramelized fruit fillings and abstract Jackson Pollock-style tracings. There are six flavors packaged together: passion fruit, lime, citrusy tropical naranjilla, coconut, strawberry, and graviola or soursop. The fruit fillings are soft but slightly chewy.

headline: Election Eve, Polls, W.H.O.: Your Monday Evening Briefing
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The pandemic has made the U.S. election one of the most chaotic, irregular and unsettling in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic has upended the 2020 U.S. election at nearly every turn, making it one of the most chaotic, irregular and unsettling political contests in recent memory.

headline: U.S. Cyber Command Expands Operations to Hunt Hackers From Russia, Iran and China
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Elections', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Building on a 2018 effort, Cyber Command sent teams to Europe, the Middle East and Asia to learn more about how adversaries could threaten the election this year.
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — The United States Cyber Command expanded its overseas operations aimed at finding foreign hacking groups before the election on Tuesday, an effort to identify not only Russian tactics but also those of China and Iran, military officials said.

headline: To prove his Trump credentials, Doug Collins, Georgia Senate candidate, campaigns with Roger Stone.
abstract: BUFORD, Ga. — Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia has spent many weeks, and many of her own millions of dollars, trying to prove she is a more conservative candidate than her bitter rival, Representative Doug Collins, a fellow Republican. In fact, it almost seemed that Ms. Loeffler ran out of room to run rightward when, last month, she welcomed the endorsement of Georgia’s best-known proponent of the QAnon conspiracy theory, Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican congressional candidate.
lead_paragraph: BUFORD, Ga. — Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia has spent many weeks, and many of her own millions of dollars, trying to prove she is a more conservative candidate than her bitter rival, Representative Doug Collins, a fellow Republican. In fact, it almost seemed that Ms. Loeffler ran out of room to run rightward when, last month, she welcomed the endorsement of Georgia’s best-known proponent of the QAnon conspiracy theory, Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican congressional candidate.

headline: ‘Jeopardy!’ Greats Who Battled for Top Title Get a New Game Show
abstract: On ABC’s “The Chase,” based on a British quiz show, contestants will face off against a trivia powerhouse — either Ken Jennings, James Holzhauer or Brad Rutter.
lead_paragraph: Just when television executives seemed to have exhausted all options for getting the three most famous “Jeopardy!” contestants back on television, they managed to find another way.

headline: Spirit Yourself Away for a Sip or Two
abstract: A cocktail book from Adrienne Stillman offers a heady escape, with recipes, histories and lush photography.
lead_paragraph: Most cocktail books are small, handy volumes. Not so this lavish, gift-worthy stunner. It has more than 600 recipes, most documented with history-filled headnotes, beautiful photographs and even a gold ribbon to hold your place. I loved the Old Cuban by Audrey Saunders, made with rum and Champagne, and the pre-Prohibition English cobbler deepened with black tea. The recipes are organized according to style, in categories like sours and punches, which are sometimes hard to follow. All the martinis are not in one place, for example. There is a helpful index according to spirit name and main ingredient, and another by name of drink.

headline: Florida, Man
abstract: The state is known for its vote counting. But this time, it might make news for how quickly it counts.
lead_paragraph: Hi, and welcome to this last pre-Election Day installment of On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: The Sixers Need to Be Patient. For Real, This Time.
abstract: The Philadelphia 76ers have hired Daryl Morey, who inspired the analytics movement that gave rise to the Process. But the team needs a new strategy now.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia 76ers and Daryl Morey seem like an ideal match.

headline: Joan Bingham, Catalyst in a Publishing Merger, Dies at 85
abstract: She helped produce the Grove Atlantic publishing house, then oversaw prize winners as its executive editor.
lead_paragraph: Joan Bingham, who played a key role in a merger that created the Grove Atlantic publishing house, then served almost three decades as its executive editor, acquiring and producing numerous prestigious titles, including Kiran Desai’s “The Inheritance of Loss” and collections by the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet Kay Ryan, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

headline: A record early vote, and last-minute lawsuits, mark the end of a campaign transformed by the pandemic.
abstract: A record early vote and last-minute lawsuits mark the end of a campaign transformed by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: If the final sprint to Election Day appeared superficially familiar, with President Trump and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. making their closing arguments to swing state voters, there were plenty of reminders Monday that the 2020 campaign has been anything but normal.

headline: Trump’s ‘Public Charge’ Immigration Rule Is Vacated by Federal Judge
keywords: ['Green Cards (US)', 'Welfare (US)', 'Appeals Courts (US)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The policy created a wealth test that would disqualify immigrants for green cards if they were deemed likely to use public benefits.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday ordered the Trump administration to vacate a policy that allowed officials to deny green cards to immigrants who might need public assistance, such as food stamps and housing vouchers, saying it exceeded the authority of the executive branch.

headline: A Texas manufacturing C.E.O. urges employees to vote Republican.
abstract: With Election Day imminent, a prominent Texas business leader last week appeared to urge her employees to consider voting for Donald J. Trump and other Republican candidates.
lead_paragraph: With Election Day imminent, a prominent Texas business leader last week appeared to urge her employees to consider voting for Donald J. Trump and other Republican candidates.

headline: In This Election, Mom Knows Best — Again
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “If Trump were running against a giraffe, I’d vote for the giraffe.”
lead_paragraph: Nov. 13, 1950. An Italian ocean liner makes its way into New York Harbor after a 13-day voyage from Genoa. Passengers, many of them in tears, pack the deck as the ship glides past the Statue of Liberty. After the devastation of the war, they’ve made it to America — to a country that, for the immigrants aboard, represents safety, freedom, abundance and hope in an otherwise broken world.

headline: Harry Belafonte: Trump Is Standing in Our Way
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']

lead_paragraph: Four years ago, when Donald Trump first ran for president, he urged Black people to support him, asking us, “What have you got to lose?”

Biden Jr., in two final battleground state polls conducted by Quinnipiac University and released on Monday.

headline: You’re Not Just Voting for President. You’re Voting to Start Over.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The American experiment has taken a beating, but there’s a chance to renew our democracy.
lead_paragraph: As Americans go to the polls on Tuesday, the last day of voting in the 2020 election, the health of American democracy hangs in the balance. But in this hour of crisis, the strength of democracy also is on display. As Martin Luther King Jr. said in his final speech, “Only when it is dark enough can you see the stars.”

headline: Deceptively Edited Video of Biden Proliferates on Social Media
abstract: Tech companies had a haphazard response to the post, which was shared on the feeds of President Trump and other conservative figures.
lead_paragraph: A video of Joseph R. Biden Jr. deceptively edited to make it appear as though he were admitting to voter fraud was viewed more than 17 million times on social media platforms, according to Avaaz, a progressive human-rights nonprofit that studied the video.

headline: Trump Lives in a Hall of Mirrors and He’s Got Plenty of Company
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'QAnon', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: It will take a long time to drive conspiracy-mongering back to the fringes of American politics.
lead_paragraph: If Donald Trump loses his re-election bid, there will be a lot of ruin to sort through. But his most damaging and enduring legacy may well turn out to be the promiscuous use of conspiracy theories that have defined both the man and his presidency.

headline: In the Trump Campaign, Government Agencies and Officials Have Often Provided Help
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The sustained effort by President Trump, members of his cabinet and other officials to use the powers of incumbency has gone far beyond anything done by his predecessors.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s national security adviser, Robert C. O’Brien, has hit the road in recent weeks — not touring war zones, but promoting Mr. Trump’s record in swing states.

headline: Hundreds Die at Sea Off Senegal’s Coast on a Perilous Route to Europe
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Drownings', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Those attempting to migrate from West Africa to Europe are once again taking a route so dangerous it’s known as “Barcelona or die.”
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — An estimated 150 migrants are thought to have died after the wooden boat they were traveling in was shipwrecked off the coast of Senegal on Friday, the latest in a deadly series of accidents for those trying a dangerous sea route around northwest Africa to reach Europe that had become less popular in recent years.

headline: ‘Clearly, Coloradans have lapsed’: New virus cases are setting records in Colorado.
abstract: Colorado once looked like it had gotten a grip on the coronavirus. Gov. Jared Polis, a Democrat, is a zealous mask wearer who imposed a statewide mandate. Hospitalization levels stayed low for much of the summer and fall. The state even began dismantling two emergency field hospitals it set up early in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Colorado once looked like it had gotten a grip on the coronavirus. Gov. Jared Polis, a Democrat, is a zealous mask wearer who imposed a statewide mandate.
