keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Politics and Government', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'War and Armed Conflicts']
abstract: Rights groups said at least 54 people were killed in Sunday’s attack, which underscored how relations between Ethiopia’s ethnic groups are fraying.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Dozens of people were killed in Ethiopia over the weekend, when three villages were assaulted by an armed rebel group, the government and human rights organizations said on Monday, the latest in a spate of attacks that threaten the stability of Africa’s second-most populous nation.

headline: Biden Calls Out Trump’s Record With Black Americans

headline: Some Regions Still Experience Slow Delivery of Mail Ballots
keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Absentee Voting', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In the final days of voting, the Postal Service is struggling to ensure timely delivery of ballots in parts of key battleground states like Pennsylvania and Michigan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service has continued to struggle in the days before the election to meet its standards for on-time delivery of mail ballots despite court orders intended to speed its operations.

headline: Finally, a Chance for Women to Defeat Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Women and Girls', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: How four traumatic years turned Georgia into a swing state.
lead_paragraph: After Donald Trump was elected, the first time I felt any hope was at the Women’s March. The second was when I went to Georgia to cover the 2017 special election to fill the House seat vacated by Tom Price, who’d just become Trump’s secretary of health and human services.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 3, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 3, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about the expulsion of non-Mexican children to Mexico by the United States, using information provided by the Women’s Refugee Commission, referred incorrectly to the number of children expelled in the past eight months who were not accompanied by a parent or other adult. The Mexican government has not specified the number of unaccompanied children; it is unknown if the number exceeded 200.

headline: Hurricane Eta Strengthens as It Nears Central America
abstract: The storm, set to make landfall late Monday or early Tuesday, could bring as much as 25 inches of rain to Nicaragua and Honduras. Flash floods and landslides were expected across the region.
lead_paragraph: The storm, set to make landfall late Monday or early Tuesday, could bring as much as 25 inches of rain to Nicaragua and Honduras. Flash floods and landslides were expected across the region.

headline: A Country Facing High Joblessness, Virus Rates and Anxiety Picks Its President
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Disease Rates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Voters describe a fundamental unease about America’s future.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — A nation with nearly 8 percent unemployment and mourning more than 231,000 Covid deaths, where four out of five Americans say they feel nervous about the country’s future, gets a final chance Tuesday to decide which candidate is best equipped to lead it past those daunting numbers.

headline: Despite a surge in absentee ballots, fewer than expected are being rejected, election officials say.
abstract: A surge in absentee ballots comes with a surprise for election officials: Fewer than expected are being rejected.
lead_paragraph: With absentee ballots flooding election offices nationwide, the officials processing them are tentatively reporting some surprising news: The share of ballots being rejected because of flawed signatures and other errors appears lower — sometimes much lower — than in the past.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘It’s Just Crazy’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 3, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “This is crazy. Crazy, crazy, crazy. It’s a good thing because everybody should vote, but it’s just crazy.”

headline: The One Pollster in America Who Is Sure Trump Is Going to Win
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Robert Cahaly’s polls have Arizona, Michigan and Florida in the president’s column. It’s hard to find another pollster who agrees with him. But they didn’t believe him in 2016 either.
lead_paragraph: If President Trump pieces together an Electoral College win on Tuesday, at least one pollster — and perhaps only one — will be able to say, “I told you so.”

headline: Vienna Terrorist Attack Leaves at Least 4 Dead and Many Wounded
abstract: A gunman killed by the police was an Islamic State “sympathizer,” Austria’s interior minister said. Officers were searching for possible accomplices on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A terrorist attack in the busy streets of central Vienna left at least four people dead and many more wounded by gunfire on Monday night, government officials said.

lead_paragraph: As the Biden campaign has sought to make an issue of the $750 income tax bill President Trump had in 2016 and again in 2017, he has shot back by saying he has “prepaid millions of dollars” in federal income taxes.

abstract: Amanda Chung and Karl Ni break us up.

headline: Joe Biden’s 2020

lead_paragraph: One day after a practice in early September, Isaiah Waller and his football teammates at Atlanta’s Booker T. Washington High School were told by their coach, Derrick Avery, to join a video conference call. When they logged on later that night, up popped the faces of three Atlanta Falcons players — Ricardo Allen, Alex Mack and Steven Means.

headline: 25 Years in Prison for Man Who Burned Down 3 Black Churches in Louisiana
abstract: Holden Matthews, 23, said he had set fire to the churches in order to raise his profile among ‘‘black metal” musicians, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A 23-year-old Louisiana man was sentenced on Monday to 25 years in prison for setting fire to three predominantly Black churches in what federal prosecutors say was an effort to raise his profile as a “black metal” musician.

headline: China Halts Ant Group’s Blockbuster I.P.O.
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mobile Applications', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: A dual listing in Shanghai and Hong Kong was postponed one day after Chinese regulators summoned Jack Ma and other executives of the financial technology giant.
lead_paragraph: Ant Group challenged China’s state-dominated banking system by bringing easy-to-use payments, borrowing and investing to hundreds of millions of smartphones across the country. On Tuesday, Chinese officialdom reminded the company who was really in charge.

headline: The Electoral College Explained
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Electoral College', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'States (US)', 'Constitution (US)', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: It’s the Electoral College, not the national popular vote, that determines who wins the presidency.
lead_paragraph: It remains one of the most surprising facts about voting in the United States: While the popular vote elects members of Congress, mayors, governors, state legislators and even more obscure local officials, it does not determine the winner of the presidency, the highest office in the land.

headline: In midnight vote, Biden sweeps Dixville Notch. Trump takes another New Hampshire town.
abstract: Joe Biden was the first presidential candidate to sweep the general election vote in Dixville Notch since the midnight voting tradition began there in 1960.
lead_paragraph: The results are already in from two New Hampshire towns where voters famously head to the polls just after the stroke of midnight on Election Day.

headline: America Is Going Full ‘Mad Max’ for Election Day, Late Night Says
abstract: “Right now, they’re erecting a massive protective fence around the White House in the event that things get crazy,” Jimmy Kimmel said. “It took four years, but Trump finally got his wall built.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Britain’s leader faces a growing revolt over his virus policy.
abstract: Two days after abruptly announcing plans to put England back into a lockdown, Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced a mutiny on Monday from members of his Conservative Party, who said he went too far, and scalding criticism from opposition leaders, who said he acted too late to stem a second wave of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Two days after abruptly announcing plans to put England back into a lockdown, Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced a mutiny on Monday from members of his Conservative Party, who said he went too far, and scalding criticism from opposition leaders, who said he acted too late to stem a second wave of the coronavirus.

headline: Can Biden Regain Lost Ground With Latinos?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Cuban-Americans', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Despite a recent influx of cash, Democrats worry that his outreach efforts are too little, too late among a critical segment of the electorate.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Despite a late push to court Latino voters over the last several weeks, Joseph R. Biden Jr. is ending his presidential bid on shaky and perhaps perilous ground with this diverse, essential segment of the electorate, according to interviews with Democratic officials, community activists and voters.

headline: China Envisions a New Hong Kong, Firmly Under Its Control
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Income Tax', 'Tax Shelters', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: The government hopes to turn Hainan Island into a financial and shopping destination. Matching the former British colony won’t be easy.

headline: D.C. public schools change plans for students to return after a sickout by teachers.
abstract: The District of Columbia Public Schools said on Monday that it was canceling its plan to bring some elementary school students back to schools next week, after teachers staged a sickout to protest the plan.

headline: Caregivers have witnessed the virus’s pain. How will they vote?
abstract: Few groups have witnessed more of the virus’s horrors than caregivers — frontline workers who have grappled with the public health crisis while trying to help older people at risk of isolation, distress and, in some cases, death. The deaths of almost 40 percent of all Americans killed by the coronavirus have been linked to nursing homes and similar facilities — indoor spaces crowded with vulnerable adults. The share is even higher in Pennsylvania, where deaths in nursing and personal-care facilities account for close to two-thirds of coronavirus deaths statewide.
lead_paragraph: Few groups have witnessed more of the virus’s horrors than caregivers — frontline workers who have grappled with the public health crisis while trying to help older people at risk of isolation, distress and, in some cases, death. headline: Pursuing Leisure Activities May Not Protect Against Dementia
abstract: Researchers found no association between engagement in leisure activities at age 56 and the incidence of dementia over the following 18 years.
lead_paragraph: Some studies have suggested that older people who consistently engage in leisure activities are less likely to develop dementia than those who do not, suggesting that failure to participate in such pastimes could spur cognitive deterioration. A new study suggests another explanation: Failure to participate in leisure activities may be a consequence of dementia, not a cause.

A quarter of its residents were over 65, mostly old-timers who once worked at the steel mills that hugged the Allegheny River.

headline: When He Bought the Tiny House, He Was Single. That Didn’t Last.
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Furniture', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: The one-bedroom cottage on Shelter Island was perfect for one person. For a family? Not so much.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, when Nick Gavin was still a bachelor, he found a one-bedroom, 1,700-square-foot cottage on Shelter Island that seemed like the ideal personal retreat. The previous owner, Melvin Dwork, a New York interior designer, had created a casually stylish interior with pine-paneled cathedral ceilings and a floor of lagoon-green ceramic tile that was deeply appealing to Mr. Gavin, now 39, a real estate agent at Compass, in New York.

headline: ‘White Ivy,’ by Susie Yang: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “White Ivy,” by Susie Yang
lead_paragraph: Ivy Lin was a thief but you would never know it to look at her. Maybe that was the problem. No one ever suspected—and that made her reckless. Her features were so average and nondescript that the brain only needed a split second to develop a complete understanding of her: skinny Asian girl, quiet, overly docile around adults in uniforms. She had a way of walking, shoulders forward, chin tucked under, arms barely swinging, that rendered her invisible in the way of pigeons and janitors.

headline: ‘To Be a Man,’ by Nicole Krauss: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “To Be a Man,” by Nicole Krauss
lead_paragraph: On the third day of the fires, after they jumped the borders and entered the city, the rabbi called to find out if her parents’ judgment of divorce had arrived. The telephone woke Noa. It was barely past seven, but the rabbi had probably been awake since dawn, his world a more ancient place. She put him on hold while she got up and searched through the stacks of mail that had piled up since Leonard and Monica left. Under the bills and advertisements, she found the thick brown envelope from the California Superior Court.

headline: We’ve Rarely Seen a Dinosaur Brain Like This Before

headline: When a Dance Collective Was Like a Rock Band
abstract: Wendy Perron’s book about the Grand Union explores this group of improvisers, who could transform “almost nothing” into “an unforgettable something.”
lead_paragraph: In 1970, the Grand Union came into being, and the dance world has never been the same. An improvisatory, leaderless group of artists, the Grand Union hung around for six years — a pretty thrilling six years by most accounts — during which discomfort, wit, boredom, chaos and excitement were all ingredients for creation. These performers were dance rebels who inspired the kind of adoration that rock bands did. They even had groupies.

headline: The Sovereigns of Thailand and the Skies
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Constitutions', 'Astrology', 'Royal Families', 'Buddhism', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Protesters are challenging the monarchy’s legitimacy by co-opting its celestial symbols.
lead_paragraph: Last Thursday, a transgender protester wearing the traditional garb of a queen strutted down a red carpet in a street of central Bangkok. Another protester dressed like a court page — with sneakers — followed her, holding a red umbrella aloft in the style of a royal parasol. A crowd sat on the ground, prostrate, eyes cast down, as is required in the presence of royalty.

headline: If restaurants go, what happens to cities?
abstract: By Aug. 31, more than 32,000 restaurants and 6,400 bars and nightspots that had been open on March 1 were marked closed on Yelp. In New York City — perhaps the nation’s dining-out capital — a survey by the Hospitality Alliance found that 87 percent of restaurants were not able to pay all of their August rent.

But the presidency could turn on in-person voting today in several crucial states, with Republicans expected to outnumber Democrats going to the polls on Election Day.

headline: For Some Veteran Stars, NASCAR’s Appeal Is Fading
abstract: Jimmie Johnson, the seven-time champ, is the latest big name to move on while still in his mid-40s.
lead_paragraph: AVONDALE, Arizona — When the checkered flag falls on Sunday at Phoenix Raceway for the final race of NASCAR’s 2020 Cup Series, it will also fall on the stock car career of one of its most decorated drivers, Jimmie Johnson, a seven-time champion.

headline: New York City’s underground subway businesses are in deep trouble.
abstract: Even as trains sat mostly empty and silence filledVanderbilt Hall, for one day it felt like a time capsule in a corner of Grand Central Terminal: The station’s famed Oyster Bar, which had closed for seven months because of pandemic restrictions, had reopened and 80 of its 81 reservations slots were filled.

headline: Photos From Election Day 2020
abstract: More than 50 photographers from The New York Times are capturing the final day of voting across America.
lead_paragraph: A year that began with the incumbent facing impeachment and the opponent facing a tumultuous primary has come down to this. The race between President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. will come to an end on Tuesday as voters head to the polls across the country. Those casting ballots today join the more than 100 million who did so in the preceding weeks.

headline: How will turnout compare to last time? Four states already have more votes than they did in 2016.
abstract: In Hawaii, which is running an all-mail vote for the first time, 484,000 voters had already cast their ballots, compared to 429,000 in 2016. In Texas, almost as many people voted early in person — 8.7 million — as voted in total in the last presidential election.

headline: In the Messiest Contested Election, One Man Saved the System From Itself
keywords: ['Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government', 'Inaugurations', 'Constitution (US)', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2000']
abstract: Samuel Randall went against his own party’s wishes to keep the U.S. political system from falling apart.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks leading up to Tuesday’s election, scholars and political commentators have been busy gaming out doomsday scenarios on the small, but unlikely, chance that there is a contested result. Despite the existence of laws designed to mediate such disputes, concerns abound because of the tremendous uncertainty in the constitutional and statutory framework governing federal elections.

headline: ‘Song Exploder’ and the Inexhaustible Hustle of Hrishikesh Hirway
abstract: The creator of several podcasts and a new television series is a popular investigator of the creative process. But his most personal case remains unsolved.
lead_paragraph: Making something new is like climbing a mountain without a map. Only at the end of the journey does the route come clearly into view.

headline: Two Presidential Candidates Detained as They File to Run in Uganda
abstract: Bobi Wine, a pop-star-turned-lawmaker who is a critic of Uganda’s longtime president, and Patrick Amuriat are only the most recent opposition candidates to be held or harassed during election season in a variety of African countries.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Two opposition candidates in Uganda who are preparing to challenge the country’s strongman president in an election next February were detained on Tuesday as they went to register as candidates, the latest indication of a tough fight to come as they seek to unseat President Yoweri Museveni, who has been in power since 1986.

headline: A staggering 100 million Americans voted early, suggesting a record turnout.
abstract: More than 100 million Americans had cast their ballots even before the polls opened on Election Day, a record early vote that showed that many people had taken advantage of the changes many states made to voting safer during the pandemic and suggested that the nation was on pace to set a record for turnout.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 million Americans had cast their ballots even before the polls opened on Election Day, a record early vote that showed that many people had taken advantage of the changes many states made to voting safer during the pandemic and suggested that the nation was on pace to set a record for turnout.

abstract: The Netflix show about a female chess prodigy in the 1950s and ’60s is one of the best screen adaptations of the game yet. But there are a few wrong moves.

headline: Rolls Rice Opens With Rice Rolls Inspired by Classic Asian Dishes
abstract: An Austrian ski lodge on the Upper East Side, a downtown pop-up from Chikarashi Isso, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Soft, traced with sauce and enclosing various fillings, Cantonese steamed rice noodle rolls (cheung fun) have a devoted following in New York. Along with two partners, the chef Richard Chan has come up with his own interpretation, investing it with creative twists. His rolls pay homage to seven different parts of Asia, including, for Singapore, rolls slathered with typical chile crab sauce; Taipei’s Taiwanese braised pork and Chinese greens; Malaysian chicken curry; and a Hong Kong roll filled with dried shrimp, Chinese sausage, shiitake mushrooms and greens. Mr. Chan is also thinking beyond Asia, with an Italian cheung fun on the horizon. Before this, he owned a Singaporean restaurant, Yummy Tummy in Flushing, Queens, where he specialized in the food of his home country, but it closed because of the pandemic. Customers at this counter-service nook meant for takeout can also assemble their own, with a choice of fillings, sauces and garnishes.

abstract: Her husband early voted days ago, but Mrs. Trump voted on Election Day at a community center about two miles north of Mar-a-Lago.

headline: How Long Is This Going to Take? Americans Settle In to Wait
abstract: Patience is a virtue that municipal leaders, meditation experts and anyone who has glanced in passing at various Election Day scenarios keep urging voters to embrace. Fine. But easier said than done.
lead_paragraph: They warned us. They said it would not be over right away. They said it could take days for all the votes to be counted. They told us to wait for the slow gears of democracy to grind toward a conclusion.

headline: A judge ordered an immediate sweep of 12 postal districts to look for undelivered ballots.
abstract: A Federal District Court judge ordered an immediate Election Day sweep of 12 postal districts to search for ballots that may not have been delivered.
lead_paragraph: A Federal District Court judge on Tuesday ordered an immediate sweep of 12 postal districts searching for undelivered ballots after the Postal Service said in court that some 300,000 ballots it had received had not been scanned for delivery.

headline: A Vegetarian Chef’s Flavor-Packed Quarantine Snack
abstract: Amy Chaplin, best known for her plant-based cookbooks, shares a recipe for onigiri, something she often makes for herself.
lead_paragraph: At her home in New York’s Hudson Valley, chef Amy Chaplin keeps replanting her rainbow carrots. It’s not the rabbits and deer that get into her crop, though — it’s her 1 1/2-year-old son, Ezra, who’s in the “very active” phase familiar to so many parents of toddlers. “He’s totally into everything in the garden, ripping up the plants,” she says. Fortunately, there’s plenty for him to explore. Since late March, the family has been living in Chatham, in a renovated 18th-century Colonial house that once served as a general store, and that provides easy access to the sort of fresh, wholesome foods (grains, beans, nuts and seeds) and seasonal produce Chaplin is known to favor. This is what many people eat or aspire to eat today, but Chaplin, who grew up on a farm in New South Wales, Australia, and honed her skills as a private chef and at restaurants including the now-closed Angelica Kitchen in Manhattan, is able to transform her healthful ingredients — often with the help of fermented garnishes — into complex, craveable dishes, examples of which fill her two award-winning cookbooks, “At Home in the Whole Food Kitchen” (2014) and “Whole Food Cooking Every Day” (2019).

headline: Dr. Philip Lee Is Dead at 96; Engineered Introduction of Medicare

lead_paragraph: Dr. Philip R. Lee, who as a leading federal health official and fighter for social justice under President Lyndon B. Johnson wielded government Medicare money as a cudgel to desegregate the nation’s hospitals in the 1960s, died on Oct. 27 in a hospital in Manhattan. He was 96.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘We Call Ourselves the Smalls’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: In 1966, I saw Ken at New Haven’s only gay bar on Halloween. We ate hamburgers and then went back to his room at Yale, where we made out in front of his fireplace. I stepped on his glasses, then tried to hide that I had broken them by pushing them under a chair. I remember snuggling into him (he is a head taller than me) and feeling safe for the first time in my life. This Halloween marks 54 years together. I say it was love at first sight, even though Ken had trouble seeing me. — Ronald Kirchem

keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Quarantines', 'Small Business', 'Shopping and Retail', 'E-Commerce', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Small businesses are fighting what they say is unfair competition from Amazon and big retailers as a nationwide lockdown takes effect.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The blueprint for France’s second national lockdown, which started Friday, sounded straightforward enough: Shutter restaurants, bookstores and other “nonessential” businesses, but let supermarkets, electronics chains and online retailers like Amazon keep operating so consumers can work and shelter at home.

headline: After 2016 Shock, Wisconsin Democrats Picked Themselves Off the Floor
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Courts and the Judiciary', 'Supreme Courts (State)']
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s narrow loss refocused the party’s efforts to reclaim support and power after years of Republican statehouse dominance.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — If there is a symbol of the Wisconsin Democratic comeback following the shock of President Trump’s 2016 victory and nearly a decade of being beaten into submission by the Republican state legislature, it is Jill Karofsky.

headline: Tracking Live Results on Election Night
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: If you’re looking for a guide to finding the latest U.S. election results from The New York Times, this is it.
lead_paragraph: Election Day has arrived, and you may be eager, maybe even a little anxious, to get the latest election results — and fast. The results will begin to flow in after the first polls close at 7 p.m. local time. Some states will have results to report as soon as voting ends. Here is how to track the results with The New York Times:

headline: With Winter Coming and Trump Still in Charge, Virus Experts Fear the Worst
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Regardless of the election results, President Trump will be the one directing the government’s coronavirus response as infections climb.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Regardless of the election’s outcome this week, President Trump will be the one steering the country through what is likely to be the darkest and potentially deadliest period of the coronavirus pandemic, and he has largely excluded the nation’s leading health experts from his inner circle.

headline: Escape the Boredom Trap
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Parenting', 'Brain', 'Boredom', 'Research', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: No one likes it when their kid is bored out of her skull. But tedium can be an opportunity, too.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to this pandemic, I am now the proud (and not-so-proud) owner of the following things: a boomerang, a hula hoop, a water balloon pump, a hippity hop jumping ball, a punching bag, a remote control helicopter, a drum set, a rope tree swing, a 50-pack of rocket balloons, two fishing rods, assorted fishing tackle and the toys from roughly 37 Kinder Surprise eggs.

headline: Photos From The 1960s: Black Americans Voting For the First Time
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']
abstract: As the nation awaits results in what has turned out to be a historic election in a historic year, we look back to the elections after the Voting Rights Act.
lead_paragraph: Today marks the conclusion of a fraught political season like no other, with the denouement coming amid deep divisions over the future of the country and a coronavirus pandemic that has claimed more than 230,000 American lives. It also has come in the wake of a number of police killings, which sparked tremendous unrest and demonstrations against systemic racism and police brutality.

headline: These kids are (way) too young to vote. But they made us smile.
abstract: Our photographers spotted some tiny people at the polls. So, of course, they took their pictures.
lead_paragraph: Our photographers spotted some tiny people at the polls. So, of course, they took their pictures.

headline: The Way We Vote in America
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers discuss voter suppression, differing state rules, mail-in ballots and what this election is really about.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: An armed man is arrested outside a North Carolina polling place.
abstract: The Charlotte Mecklenburg Police Department said they arrested an armed man Tuesday who returned to a polling place after being banned from the site earlier in the day.
lead_paragraph: The Charlotte Mecklenburg Police Department said they arrested an armed man Tuesday who returned to a polling place after being banned from the site earlier in the day.

headline: Despite Fears of Violence, Election Day Proceeds Smoothly as Millions Line Up to Vote
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters', 'Threats and Threatening Messages']
abstract: There were reports of robocalls providing misinformation meant to keep people from the polls, but none of the widespread intimidation that had been feared.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite fears of widespread intimidation or disruptions at polling places, voting for a vast majority of Americans proceeded smoothly on Tuesday, with sporadic reports of robocalls, text messages and some live calls meant to confuse and deter voters, or scattered incidents, but few major problems.

headline: Robert Fisk, Intrepid War Correspondent, Dies at 74
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'War and Armed Conflicts']
abstract: “You cannot get near the truth without being there,” he said. Working for British newspapers, he ranged across the Middle East, Bosnia, Northern Ireland and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Robert Fisk, a dauntless journalist who was widely praised by colleagues and competitors alike for relentlessly chronicling the Middle East’s many agonies, but who was also faulted by some critics as insufficiently tough at times on despots, died on Friday in a hospital in Dublin. He was 74.

headline: Kanye West votes for himself as a write-in candidate.
abstract: Kanye West, the hip-hop artist and fashion designer who launched an independent presidential bid earlier this year, cast a vote for himself on Tuesday in what he said on Twitter was his first time voting in a presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Kanye West, the hip-hop artist and fashion designer who launched an independent presidential bid earlier this year, cast a vote for himself on Tuesday in what he said on Twitter was his first time voting in a presidential election.

headline: North Carolina says it will keep a handful of polls open late.
abstract: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Election officials in North Carolina decided on Tuesday to extend voting at four precincts beyond the scheduled 7:30 p.m. close of the polls, which will delay the release of the state’s results.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Election officials in North Carolina decided on Tuesday to extend voting at four precincts beyond the scheduled 7:30 p.m. close of the polls, which will delay the release of the state’s results.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The U.S. has a pivotal day for the virus.
lead_paragraph: Today may be a pivotal day in the United States, and we’re not talking about the election.

headline: The Pandemic’s Future — and Ours
abstract: “Apollo’s Arrow,” by Nicholas A. Christakis, looks at the coronavirus from several angles and suggests some possibilities in the months and years to come.
lead_paragraph: APOLLO’S ARROWThe Profound and Enduring Impact of Coronavirus on the Way We LiveBy Nicholas A. Christakis

headline: In ‘Knife’s Edge’ Pennsylvania, Trump’s Fortunes Rely on His Rural Base
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters', 'Absentee Voting']
abstract: If President Trump is able to outperform the polls in the battleground state of Pennsylvania, it will be because he re-energized white, blue-collar voters in places like Butler County.
lead_paragraph: [President-elect Joe Biden’s victory prompts spontaneous celebrations.]

headline: The first races are called for Trump and Biden as the country waits on swing state results.
abstract: There are two big questions tonight as this long campaign comes to an end. The first, obviously, is whether President Trump survives a challenge from Joseph R. Biden Jr. and wins a second term in the White House.
lead_paragraph: There are two big questions tonight as this long campaign comes to an end. The first, obviously, is whether President Trump survives a challenge from Joseph R. Biden Jr. and wins a second term in the White House.

headline: The lead-up was chaotic, but voting has been going pretty smoothly.
Democrats are on track to hold their House majority as Republicans see early victories.
abstract: House Democrats are poised to maintain their majority but faced a series of early blows Tuesday night as Democrats in rural districts faced headwinds and Republican incumbents in suburban districts held their own.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats are poised to maintain their majority but faced a series of early blows Tuesday night as Democrats in rural districts faced headwinds and Republican incumbents in suburban districts held their own.

headline: With 101 million votes cast early, the U.S. heads toward its highest turnout in over a century.
abstract: With more than 101.1 million early votes cast in person and by mail before the polls even opened on Election Day, the 2020 presidential campaign was shaping up to be one for the record books, on pace to attract the highest turnout in more than a century.
lead_paragraph: With more than 101.1 million early votes cast in person and by mail before the polls even opened on Election Day, the 2020 presidential campaign was shaping up to be one for the record books, on pace to attract the highest turnout in more than a century.

headline: Republicans fight to maintain their majority in a tough environment.
It’s Not Just Adults Who Are Stressed. Kids Are, Too.
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Parenting', 'Babies and Infants', 'Grief (Emotion)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Identifying your child’s emotional and behavioral reactions to stress is crucial, experts say, especially when anxieties are high.
lead_paragraph: Families are under an extraordinary amount of pressure right now, and the next few months will provide little relief. The trials of 2020 include economic uncertainty, winter dread, an emotionally charged presidential election and a worrying rise in coronavirus cases. Then there’s the disrupted school year, remote learning and few (or no) options for child care. (That’s an abbreviated list.)

headline: Betty Dodson, Women’s Guru of Self-Pleasure, Dies at 91
abstract: She was a second-wave feminist who taught consciousness raising with a twist, and her workshops on masturbation, buoyed by the internet, have inspired millions.
lead_paragraph: Betty Dodson, a feminist sexologist and evangelist of self-pleasure who taught generations of women how to masturbate in workshops, books and videos, seeing the do-it-yourself climax as a liberating social force, died on Saturday at a nursing home in New York City. She was 91.

headline: In Detroit, Kamala Harris makes a final pitch.
abstract: [Read our profile of Kamala Harris, the first woman elected U.S. vice president.]
lead_paragraph: [Read our profile of Kamala Harris, the first woman elected U.S. vice president.]

headline: 2 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: This week’s highlights include “Wave of Light,” eight hypnotic works from Minoru Yoshida at Ulterior Gallery, and “Crichoues Indignation,” Caitlin Cherry’s prismatic paintings at the Hole.
lead_paragraph: Minoru Yoshida grew up playing the piano, studied painting in Kyoto, Japan, and briefly ran a kimono-dyeing firm before joining the avant-garde artists group Gutai in 1965. In 1970 he moved to New York, where he spent eight years staging futuristic performances — think synthesizers and plexiglass — before returning to Japan, where he continued performing and making art until his death in 2010.

headline: As Counting Begins, a Flood of Mail Ballots Complicates Vote Tallies
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Battleground states will use quite different methods to count the record number of mail-in ballots. But they may be the way of the future.

headline: Vienna Reels From a Rare Terrorist Attack
keywords: ['Vienna, Austria, Shooting (Nov, 2020)', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The gunman, who killed four people and wounded 23, had been arrested for trying to join ISIS, raising questions about whether he should have been closely watched.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — He was armed with an automatic rifle, a pistol, a machete and a dummy suicide belt. For nine minutes, the 20-year-old gunman turned the cobbled streets of central Vienna into a war zone, firing so many shots from so many places that the authorities initially believed there were multiple attackers.

headline: Bobby Ball, Half of a Hit British Comedy Duo, Dies at 76
abstract: Their TV show “Cannon & Ball,” part goofy comedy and part earnest musical numbers, drew up to 20 million viewers on Saturday nights in the 1980s. Mr. Ball was infected with the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: H. Jesse Arnelle, Pathbreaker in Corporate Law, Dies at 86
abstract: Thirty years after he led the Penn State basketball team to the Final Four, he and a friend started one of the few Black-owned firms catering to blue-chip clients.
lead_paragraph: H. Jesse Arnelle, who helped start one of the first minority-owned corporate law firms in the United States three decades after gaining acclaim as a two-sport star and the first Black student body president at Penn State University, died on Oct. 21 at his home in San Francisco. He was 86.

headline: Election Day, Austria, Comic Relief: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Jaime Harrison urges South Carolina voters to help him ‘shock the world’ and unseat Lindsey Graham.
abstract: FLORENCE, S.C. — Jaime Harrison, the former chair of South Carolina’s Democratic Party who is running for Senate, visited the polls in Florence, S.C., on Tuesday, urging voters to help him “shock the world” by unseating the Republican incumbent, Senator Lindsey Graham.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, S.C. — Jaime Harrison, the former chair of South Carolina’s Democratic Party who is running for Senate, visited the polls in Florence, S.C., on Tuesday, urging voters to help him “shock the world” by unseating the Republican incumbent, Senator Lindsey Graham.

headline: This Is It. Here’s What I’m Watching.
abstract: We made it to election night, together. I’ll be keeping an eye on a few key places to get an early sense of how the results are unfolding.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to On Politics. We made it to election night, together. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Biden Says Trump Is ‘Not Who We Are.’ Do Voters Agree?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Election Day came to a close with no clear winner, but it affirmed the persistence of deep national divisions.
lead_paragraph: From the start of his 2020 campaign, Joseph R. Biden Jr. insisted that President Trump was an aberration, his norm-breaking, race-baiting tenure anathema to the national character.

headline: San Francisco Reinstates Winning Design for Maya Angelou Monument
abstract: Last year, officials selected and then rejected Lava Thomas to design the sculpture, opening a rift between public leaders and local artists.

headline: Here is what we’re watching for tonight in terms of timing.
In These Suburbs, Long Lines Were Good News for the President
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Suburbs', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Absentee Voting']
abstract: President Trump is counting on strong turnout in staunchly Republican neighborhoods to counter growing Democratic support in the suburbs.
lead_paragraph: UPPER ARLINGTON, Ohio — In an affluent pocket of Upper Arlington, a suburb of Columbus, dozens of voters, masked and socially distanced, spanned the length of Jones Middle School and the block behind it by the time the polling place opened Tuesday morning.

headline: Russian internet trolls are amplifying election fraud claims, researchers say.
abstract: Social media accounts tied to a group of Russian trolls are amplifying claims of election fraud, according to researchers at the Election Integrity Partnership, a coalition of misinformation experts.
lead_paragraph: Social media accounts tied to a group of Russian trolls are amplifying claims of election fraud, according to researchers at the Election Integrity Partnership, a coalition of misinformation experts.

headline: New Yorkers Have Had Enough of ‘Donald From Queens’
abstract: An exhausted city heads to the polls.
lead_paragraph: An anxious quiet settled on New York City like a blanket of fog.

headline: With election and jobs report as a backdrop, the Fed will get its turn this week.
abstract: Sandwiched between Tuesday’s election and the Friday’s October jobs report, the Federal Reserve is set to announce its November policy decision.
lead_paragraph: Sandwiched between Tuesday’s election and the Friday’s October jobs report, the Federal Reserve is set to announce its November policy decision.

headline: Armed Man Arrested Outside North Carolina Polling Site
abstract: The police arrested an armed man seated outside of a polling place in Charlotte, N.C. Tuesday. The man, identified as Justin Dunn, returned to the polling place after being barred from the site earlier in the day.
lead_paragraph: The police arrested an armed man seated outside of a polling place in Charlotte, N.C. Tuesday. The man, identified as Justin Dunn, returned to the polling place after being barred from the site earlier in the day.

headline: Trump Ally Tweets Misleading Images of Philadelphia Voting
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Photography', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: Many of the misleading or false claims about voting on Tuesday have focused on swing states like Pennsylvania, just as they did in the weeks before the election.
lead_paragraph: Many of the misleading or false claims about voting on Tuesday have focused on swing states like Pennsylvania, just as they did in the weeks before the election.

headline: How long will vote counting take? Here are the estimates and deadlines.
abstract: As states continue to count the votes, here is a guide to how long it might take to have complete tallies in different states.
lead_paragraph: Although many winners may quickly be evident on election night, the increase in mail voting because of the pandemic is expected to push back the release of full results in many key states.

headline: A Florida feat: One precinct in Orlando reports 105 percent turnout.
abstract: Every registered voter at a precinct in the University of Central Florida in Orlando cast a ballot in the election. And then a few extra people showed up.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — In the rarest of feats, every registered voter at a precinct in the University of Central Florida in Orlando cast a ballot in the election, according to the Orange County supervisor of elections’ office.

headline: Why the Social Media Rage Machine Won’t Stop
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Political Advertising', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: Tech companies aren’t going to dismantle the systems that are making them billions.
lead_paragraph: It’s Election Day 2020, and Silicon Valley cannot save us.

headline: Polls have begun to close in much of Florida.
abstract: MIAMI — The first polls in Florida closed at 7 p.m. Eastern time. (Remember that the Panhandle is on Central time, so the polls there close at 8 p.m. Eastern.)
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The first polls in Florida closed at 7 p.m. Eastern time. (Remember that the Panhandle is on Central time, so the polls there close at 8 p.m. Eastern.)

headline: Polls are closed in Georgia, which faces competitive House and Senate races.
abstract: Polls closed at 7 p.m. in Georgia, where there are two competitive House races in the Atlanta suburbs and two competitive Senate races — a sign of the increasingly competitive nature of a once-solidly red state that is now up for grabs.
lead_paragraph: Polls closed at 7 p.m. in Georgia, where there are two competitive House races in the Atlanta suburbs and two competitive Senate races — a sign of the increasingly competitive nature of a once-solidly red state that is now up for grabs.

headline: Feel Inspired, America
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: There is much to celebrate about our democracy, from record voter turnout to creative volunteerism.
lead_paragraph: In 2016 Scott Duncombe, a software developer in Portland, Ore., saw on the news that Cleveland residents had to wait hours in long lines to vote. His heart went out to them. In Oregon, there are never any lines because everybody votes by mail. So he called up a pizza place in Cleveland and ordered a bunch of food to raise their spirits.

headline: Either Trump or Biden Will Win. But Our Deepest Problems Will Remain.

headline: Estimates for Florida, Georgia and North Carolina are now live.

headline: The Coronavirus, Raging in Battleground States, Looms Over Election Day
abstract: From Wisconsin to North Carolina, the latest surge of the coronavirus is spiraling, especially in battleground states.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — They voted from cars and at outdoor tables. They stood in lines spaced far apart. They strapped on masks and pumped sanitizer into their palms. All across America on Tuesday, voters cast ballots in a presidential election in which the uncontrolled coronavirus pandemic was both a top issue and a threat.

headline: At the End of a Chaotic Campaign, an Election Day That Defied the Worst Fears
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Absentee Voting', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Postal Service and Post Offices']
abstract: There were glitches and partisan skirmishes as voters went to the polls, but for the most part the system held up.
lead_paragraph: The worst fears about a chaotic end to a chaotic campaign failed to materialize on Tuesday as the final day of voting went off with little more than sporadic glitches and confrontations even as the tension over the outcome and aftermath remained undiminished.

headline: What Are Your Reactions to the Results of Election 2020?
abstract: As the votes are counted, we invite teenagers to post reactions and have conversations here. What does this election mean for our nation?
lead_paragraph: Please keep in mind that this forum is for teenagers only. While there are many places on NYTimes.com for adults to comment, this is the only dedicated spot for the voices of young people.

headline: Mitch McConnell wins re-election as Republicans fight to maintain their majority.
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican and majority leader known for his take-no-prisoners tactics, was elected to a seventh term Tuesday, defeating Amy McGrath, a Democrat who struggled to gain ground despite an outpouring of financial support from her party’s supporters around the nation.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican and majority leader known for his take-no-prisoners tactics, was elected to a seventh term Tuesday, defeating Amy McGrath, a Democrat who struggled to gain ground despite an outpouring of financial support from her party’s supporters around the nation.

headline: Democrats Battle for Senate Control as They Maintain Grip on House Majority
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The two parties grappled for advantage in the fight for the Senate majority as Democrats aimed to add to their majority in the House.
lead_paragraph: Democrats were on track early Wednesday to maintain a firm grip on the House, but their path to seizing the Senate majority from Republicans was rapidly narrowing as the two parties continued to fight for control of the levers of power in Congress with the fate of the presidency still uncertain.

headline: Daniella Levine Cava will be Miami-Dade County’s first female mayor.
abstract: MIAMI — Daniella Levine Cava declared victory on Tuesday in the race for mayor of Miami-Dade County, the second most powerful executive position in the state, after the governor.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Daniella Levine Cava declared victory on Tuesday in the race for mayor of Miami-Dade County, the second most powerful executive position in the state, after the governor.

headline: Exit Polls Showed the Vote Came Down to the Pandemic Versus the Economy
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The coronavirus dominated voters’ thinking, but those concerned about rising infections sided with Joseph R. Biden Jr. while those who wanted the economy open went for President Trump.
lead_paragraph: As the country faces a dual national crisis — a monthslong pandemic and economic devastation — voters were deeply divided on what mattered more: containing the coronavirus or hustling to rebuild the economy, according early exit polls and voter surveys released Tuesday.

headline: Hickenlooper Ousts Gardner in Colorado, Handing Democrats Crucial Senate Seat
abstract: Senator Cory Gardner, a first-term Republican, had trailed throughout the race as his state increasingly tilted toward Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. John Hickenlooper defeated Senator Cory Gardner on Tuesday in the high-profile fight for Colorado’s Senate seat, securing a victory essential to Democrats’ push to take the Senate majority.

headline: Madison Cawthorn Wins in North Carolina, Becoming Youngest Republican Elected to House
abstract: The 25-year-old kept the solidly conservative seat in G.O.P. hands after his race had become unexpectedly competitive when he was accused of sexual misconduct and racism.
lead_paragraph: Madison Cawthorn won North Carolina’s 11th Congressional District on Tuesday, defeating the former Air Force colonel Moe Davis and keeping the conservative seat in Republican hands after a race that became unexpectedly competitive when Mr. Cawthorn was accused of racism and sexual misconduct.

headline: Democrats’ path to Senate control narrows as Republicans hold onto critical seats.
abstract: Democrats’ path to seizing the Senate continued to narrow Wednesday as Republicans held onto a cluster of seats in critical states and the two parties continued to fight to control the upper chamber of Congress in close contests across the country.
lead_paragraph: Democrats’ path to seizing the Senate continued to narrow Wednesday as Republicans held onto a cluster of seats in critical states and the two parties continued to fight to control the upper chamber of Congress in close contests across the country.

headline: Hickenlooper becomes the first Democrat to flip a Senate seat tonight.
abstract: Former Gov. John Hickenlooper of Colorado defeated Senator Cory Gardner on Tuesday, becoming the first Democrat to flip a Senate seat this cycle in the party’s quest to retake the Senate majority.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. John Hickenlooper of Colorado defeated Senator Cory Gardner on Tuesday, becoming the first Democrat to flip a Senate seat this cycle in the party’s quest to retake the Senate majority.

headline: Trump’s path is much narrower if he loses Ohio. Early tallies in the state give Biden reason to hope.
abstract: With more than 60 percent of the vote total for Ohio reported, some Democrats are cautiously optimistic about Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s chances in the state, a critical bellwether. Democrats are paying particularly close attention to several counties in the state, including Delaware County north of Columbus and Mahoning County on the Pennsylvania border, both of which — at this stage — look more promising than expected for Mr. Biden.

headline: Recreational Marijuana Legalized by New Jersey Voters
abstract: Voters approved a constitutional amendment to legalize cannabis in New Jersey, putting pressure on neighboring states like New York.
lead_paragraph: After years of legislative failures, New Jersey voters on Tuesday authorized the legal use of recreational marijuana in a year when supporters rallied around the disproportionate number of arrests for the drug in minority communities.

headline: Options When Picking Locks

headline: Lindsey Graham Hangs On, Overcoming a Steep Democratic Challenge
abstract: Mr. Graham, a Republican, fended off Jaime Harrison, a Democrat, whose campaign captured liberal energy — and dollars — from across the country.
lead_paragraph: Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, fended off the most difficult challenge of his career on Tuesday, turning back a Democrat backed by a record-setting onslaught of campaign cash to win a fourth term, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Why The A.P. called Virginia for Biden when early results showed him behind Trump.
abstract: The race call seemed to fly in the face of the numbers. Why did The Associated Press declare that Joseph R. Biden Jr. had won Virginia, even though early results showed him trailing President Trump by double digits?

lead_paragraph: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York sailed to an overwhelming victory on Tuesday over a first-time Republican challenger who, despite his long-shot credentials, raised more than $10 million to make the race the second most expensive House contest in the country.

headline: Voters who saw containing the coronavirus as the most important issue favored Biden
abstract: While President Trump had attempted to focus on anything other than the pandemic during the campaign, it remained the defining issue: More than 40 percent of voters said it was the most important issue deciding their vote, far more than any other issue.

headline: A QAnon Supporter Is Headed to Congress
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'QAnon', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Marjorie Taylor Greene’s victory in Georgia underscores an uncomfortable truth for Republicans: The 2020 election brought QAnon into their party.
lead_paragraph: QAnon scored its first national political victory on Tuesday when Marjorie Taylor Greene, a supporter of the convoluted pro-Trump conspiracy theory, won a House seat in Georgia, bringing into the halls of Congress an online movement that has inspired real-world violence and been branded a potential domestic terrorism threat by the F.B.I.

headline: Sarah McBride wins her State Senate race in Delaware, a landmark for transgender legislators.
abstract: Sarah McBride won her State Senate race in Delaware on Tuesday, making her the first openly transgender person to be elected to that position nationwide. When she is sworn in, she will become the nation’s highest-ranking transgender elected official.

headline: 2020 Will Not Be Decisive

abstract: The pandemic campaign was a test of whether our system can produce governing majorities. It looks like it can’t.
lead_paragraph: An election is supposed to be a reality check. It promises the finality of decision, in which the back-and-forth of political argument gives way to the undeniability of a particular outcome on a particular day.

headline: Dan Crenshaw, Star Republican Freshman, Holds On to Texas House Seat
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Mr. Crenshaw defeated Sima Ladjevardian, an Iranian-born immigrant who had been an adviser to former Representative Beto O’Rourke, in his Houston-area seat.
lead_paragraph: Representative Dan Crenshaw, Republican of Texas, won a second term in Congress on Tuesday, fending off a Democratic challenge in his Houston area from Sima Ladjevardian, an Iranian-born immigrant who had been an adviser to former Representative Beto O’Rourke.

headline: Houston-Area Sheriff Fights Off Democratic Challenge in Longtime Republican Stronghold
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Troy Nehls defeated Sri Preston Kulkarni, maintaining Republican control of a sprawling suburban district long represented by the former House majority leader, Tom DeLay.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — Troy Nehls, a popular sheriff and military veteran endorsed by President Trump, was elected Tuesday to represent a sprawling Houston-area suburban district, defeating Sri Preston Kulkarni, a former Foreign Service officer, who had hoped to become the first Indian-American from Texas elected to Congress.

headline: Mississippi voters approve flag with magnolia instead of Confederate symbol.
abstract: And about 70 percent of voters approved the new flag, which had to include the words “In God We Trust.”
lead_paragraph: Mississippi voters on Tuesday approved a new state flag with a magnolia flower and red, yellow and blue stripes, replacing the one from 1894 that featured the Confederate battle emblem and was decommissioned by lawmakers in June.

headline: Randy Feenstra Wins, Keeping Steve King’s Iowa Seat in G.O.P. Hands
abstract: Mr. Feenstra, a state senator who defeated Mr. King in the primary, shares many of the incumbent’s policy views but not his history of incendiary and racist remarks.
lead_paragraph: Randy Feenstra, a Republican state senator, won election to represent northwest Iowa in Congress on Tuesday, five months after his primary victory over Representative Steve King, whose history of racist comments had made him an embarrassment to the party.

headline: Big gains among Latinos in the Miami area power Trump to victory in Florida.
abstract: President Trump has been declared the winner in Florida after pulling off a remarkable turnaround from 2016 in the Miami area, wooing conservative Cuban-American voters and other Latino groups in numbers sufficient to overcome Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s middling gains with white Floridians.

headline: Joni Ernst Wins in Iowa, Frustrating Democrats’ Push for Senate Majority
abstract: The first-term Republican overcame a steep challenge from Theresa Greenfield, denying Democrats a crucial pickup in their path to reclaiming control of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Senator Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa, won re-election on Tuesday, overcoming a serious and well-financed Democratic challenge and pockets of discontent with President Trump to score a victory that bolstered her party’s efforts to save its Senate majority.

lead_paragraph: Representative Ann Wagner, Republican of Missouri, held onto her St. Louis-area House seat on Tuesday, defeating a steep challenge by Democrats to deliver her party a victory in a nationwide battle for political dominance in the suburbs.

headline: Which Battleground States Did Trump Win in 2016?
abstract: A look at the president’s performance in the previous election.

headline: As America Awaits a Winner, Trump Falsely Claims He Prevailed
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Absentee Voting', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Voting and Voters', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'States (US)']
abstract: The president made his unfounded claim even though no news organizations declared a winner between him and Joseph R. Biden Jr., and a number of closely contested states still had millions of mail-in ballots to count.
lead_paragraph: With no winner declared in the 2020 presidential race, President Trump appeared in the White House just after 2 a.m. on Wednesday to brazenly claim he had already won the election — and to insist that votes stop being counted even though the ballots of millions of Americans had yet to be tallied.

headline: Trump, attacking the democratic process, falsely says he won.
abstract: With millions of votes still left to be counted, President Trump early Wednesday falsely declared that he had won his race for re-election, warning that he would go to the Supreme Court to try to prematurely shut the election down.
lead_paragraph: With millions of votes still left to be counted, President Trump early Wednesday falsely declared that he had won his race for re-election, warning that he would go to the Supreme Court to try to prematurely shut the election down.

headline: Incumbent Democrats Win in N.J. House Races; Van Drew Is Narrowly Ahead
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Impeachment']
abstract: Voter turnout was on track to set records, complicating the counting process. Mail ballots may be counted for up to a week after the election.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic incumbents in two of New Jersey’s closest congressional races were declared winners just after midnight on Wednesday in an election that was conducted mostly by mail and that yielded a voter turnout likely to set records. But no winner emerged yet in the state’s most closely watched House race.

headline: Republicans Oust Collin Peterson in Minnesota
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Rural Areas', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The long-serving chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, who had bucked political trends in his conservative district for years, succumbed to a challenge from Michelle Fischbach.
lead_paragraph: Representative Collin C. Peterson, Democrat of Minnesota, the chairman of the Agriculture Committee who has represented his large agrarian district for three decades, lost his re-election bid early Wednesday, handing Republicans a pickup in the House.

headline: Lucy McBath Wins Georgia Rematch, Holding House Seat for Democrats
abstract: The victory by Ms. McBath, who upset a Republican, Karen Handel, in 2018 and was challenged by her again, underscored the changing demographics and antipathy to President Trump in Atlanta’s suburbs.
lead_paragraph: Representative Lucy McBath, a Democrat who in 2018 narrowly upset the Republican Karen Handel in a Republican stronghold, won re-election early Wednesday in a rematch that underscored the changing demographics — and anti-Trump fervor — in Atlanta’s suburbs.

headline: Daines Holds Off Bullock in Montana, Keeping Key Senate Seat in G.O.P. Hands
abstract: Steve Daines faced a tougher-than-expected re-election race, but Steve Bullock, the popular two-term Democratic governor, could not overcome Republican advantages in the state.
lead_paragraph: Senator Steve Daines, Republican of Montana, beat back a strong challenge from Gov. Steve Bullock on Tuesday to win a second term, keeping a crucial seat in Republican hands as Democrats pressed to try to wrest control of the Senate.

headline: Bob Good, Stressing Religious Conservatism, Holds Virginia House Seat for G.O.P.

headline: Brady, Brees and Roethlisberger Just Won’t Go Quietly. Luckily for the N.F.L.
abstract: Those quarterbacks, as well as Philip Rivers, are showing signs of wear and tear but still thriving in the twilight of their careers. They have the Steelers, Saints, Buccaneers and Colts on course to make the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: With a combined age of 85 years and 30 days, Tom Brady and Drew Brees will be the oldest pair of starting quarterbacks in N.F.L. history when the Tampa Bay Buccaneers host the New Orleans Saints in Sunday night’s marquee matchup. The previous record of 84 years and 243 days was set by Brady and Brees when the Saints and Buccaneers squared off in the regular season opener. The pair will set another record in the likely event that they meet in the playoffs.

headline: This French Onion Tart Is a Straight-Up Classic
abstract: The legendary chef André Soltner made it for decades at his Manhattan restaurant Lutèce — and it’s still perfect.
lead_paragraph: Before the pandemic hit, Prune was in the midst of a yearlong series of celebratory lunches to mark our turning 20. Each lunch featured a guest chef who’d had a strong influence on my cooking career, and though all the lunches were wildly different, each had its special excitement. There was an elegant, erudite lunch with Mimi Sheraton, at which we served the stuffed cabbage and dried-fruit compote from her Eastern European Jewish repertoire. There was an avant-garde one with Elizabeth Falkner, who served platters of spicy Sichuan rabbit heads complete with instructions on how to crack the skulls. And there was the one we cooked with Marc Vetri, my brother-from-another-mother, who drove in from Philly with flour he had milled himself from local wheat to make his chicken-liver pasta for us.

lead_paragraph: A young archaeology graduate student at Harvard is bludgeoned to death by the professor with whom she’s having an affair. The murder weapon is a stone tool from the university’s Peabody Museum. Under cover of darkness, the professor steals into the museum with the woman’s corpse and conducts a macabre funeral rite, draping her body in ancient jewelry and sprinkling it with red ocher powder.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Was Just the Beginning. Hollywood Loves Broadway, Again.

Basketball hoops kissed the ceiling. Rubber matting and webs of cables carpeted the floor. Beside the snack tables, James Corden, Kerry Washington and Meryl Streep, in a wig the red of a cocktail cherry, practiced a dance number, sashaying through the same steps at not quite the same time.

headline: From Stage to Screen: 5 Shows That Got It Right (And 5 That Didn’t)
abstract: Our theater experts provide a guide to some of the successful (and failed) cinematic adaptations of plays and musicals — all for your streaming pleasure.
lead_paragraph: “Cabaret” and “Cats” are pretty much acknowledged as the zenith and nadir of movie musical adaptations. But “Cabaret” is so excellent, and “Cats” so execrable, that neither tells us much about what went right or wrong with the process. The same goes for play adaptations: “Chimes at Midnight” (1965) stands proudly next to any stage rendition of Shakespeare — and “Gnomeo and Juliet” (2011) doesn’t. Below, an opinionated guide from theater experts to the cinematic successes and failures that can still show Hollywood how it ought (and ought not) to be done.

headline: Haworth, N.J.: A ‘True Hometown’ 20 Miles From Midtown Manhattan
abstract: Residents praise the two-square-mile Bergen County borough for its slow pace and friendliness: ‘It’s the cutest little place.’
lead_paragraph: Like many newcomers, Jessica Shreefter and Corey Hennig had been unaware of Haworth, a densely wooded borough in northern Bergen County, N.J. There are no apartments, chain stores or industry — just 1,150 single-family homes, a duck pond, a red-brick school, two traffic lights, a couple of country clubs, four churches and a one-block business district.

headline: Practicing Self-Care in Uncertain Times
abstract: Sleep won’t fix what’s broken in the world, but it will prepare you for what lies ahead.
lead_paragraph: I’m writing this newsletter before Election Day, obviously with no certainty about how things will turn out. I don’t know whether I’ll wake up today relieved, devastated or in limbo. What I can tell you for sure is that I will be tired. My sleep has been absolute garbage for a few weeks now, and the political anxiety and rising coronavirus cases on top of an already destabilizing pandemic year — along with a 4-year-old we’re trying to get out of nighttime pull-ups — means I am exhausted and extremely frayed.

headline: Election Night on TikTok: Anxiety, Analysis and Wishful Thinking
abstract: Their parents are watching cable news in the other room, but many younger people are gathering online for a more communal experience.
lead_paragraph: On election night, tens of millions of Americans turned to their cable networks of choice for returns and projections. Meanwhile, millions of young viewers — some first-time voters and many too young to cast ballots — turned instead to TikTok for virtual watch parties, political analysis and a bit of manifesting.

headline: The view in Pennsylvania: Democrats are confident, even as the Trump team considers legal challenges.

headline: Review: ‘Crave’ Is a Timely Ticket for a World on Fire
abstract: Sarah Kane’s 1999 play, performed live at the Chichester Festival Theater and available to stream this week, meditates on power and powerlessness, and makes specific devastation feel universal.
lead_paragraph: Ready for the most shocking part of Sarah Kane’s “Crave,” a throat punch of a play livestreamed by the Chichester Festival Theater through Saturday? Here it is: a live audience. In the minutes before “Crave” began, remote spectators could watch as actual (masked) theatergoers took socially distanced seats. Earlier this week, I turned my computer volume up, the better to listen to the endangered language of hushed conversations and rustling programs, my personal pathway to A.S.M.R.

headline: Gap widely mocked for tweet depicting half-blue, half-red sweatshirt.
abstract: Gap, which has since deleted the tweet, said the sweatshirt was not actually a product for sale.

headline: Collins Wins in Maine, Denying Democrats a Crucial Senate Pickup

headline: Ancient Remains in Peru Reveal Young, Female Big-Game Hunter
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Archaeology and Anthropology', 'Research', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: Scientists are divided on broader implications of the find for ancient gender roles.
lead_paragraph: The discovery of a 9,000-year-old female skeleton buried with what archaeologists call a “big-game hunting kit” in the Andes highlands of Peru has challenged one of the most widely held tenets about ancient hunter gatherers — that males hunted and females gathered.

headline: Spider Silk Is Stronger Than Steel. It Also Assembles Itself.
abstract: Scientists are figuring out the chemical triggers that turn the liquid stored in silk glands into a solid that’s tougher than Kevlar.
lead_paragraph: Pound for pound, spider silk is stronger than steel and tougher than Kevlar. But it doesn’t start out that way.

abstract: A bill that awaits Governor Cuomo’s signature would bolster freedom of speech in the state.
lead_paragraph: Among the more obnoxious ways the rich and powerful can intimidate and silence critics is filing what is known as a Strategic Lawsuit Against Public Participation, or SLAPP, whose goal is not to pursue a legitimate grievance but to harass and bankrupt opponents. New York State, long a laggard in putting an end to SLAPPs, finally has a worthy bill waiting only for Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s pen.

headline: The View From Another Window
abstract: A new perspective is a click away.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. Through the window where I work these days, I see the backs of several apartment buildings, terraces and fire escapes, tall old trees taken over by vines and the twin spires of the Gothic Revival-style church on the corner. As views go, it’s performing its job well: form and function in equal measure, beautiful and a little ragged, too, enough sky to see the storms move in and recede, the sun or moon when things clear up.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Dusty-Danger Dog
abstract: Feeling election stress? These two stories about a man and his dog may help.
lead_paragraph: Timothy Braun was on a run in the Texas heat. When he stopped at a local animal shelter for a drink of water, he was taken by a dog who stared at him with pointy ears and mismatched eyes — one brown, one blue. He had no intention of adopting a dog, but “out of curiosity, or God knows what,” he looked into the dog’s folder. It said that he had been abandoned by an old woman. Her reason? “Dusty keeps following me around the house.”

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: No matter who wins the U.S. election, Mr. Trump will lead the virus response for the next few months.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Legacy of Same-Sex Marriage Case
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The justices considered whether a city may exclude a Catholic social services agency from its foster care system because it refuses to work with gay couples.

headline: Voters in Jersey City Embrace a New Tax to Finance the Arts
keywords: ['Art', 'Taxation', 'Referendums', 'Property Taxes', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Theater', 'Dancing', 'City Councils', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Officials had worried that a new arts tax may be too much to ask in a place still reeling financially from the pandemic, but 64 percent of voters approved of the idea.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Jersey City could not be blamed for worrying a bit on Tuesday about the referendum they placed on the ballot to create a new tax to help the arts. After all, New Jersey is still suffering from the financial impact of the pandemic, and there were so many other pressing concerns for voters, like a presidential election riven by extreme partisanship and the question of whether to legalize marijuana in the state.

headline: Republicans Claim Voter Fraud. How Would That Work?
keywords: ['Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Absentee Voting', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Stealing a presidential election requires an unrealistic level of planning, coordination and good luck.
lead_paragraph: Even before Election Day, Donald Trump cast doubts on Pennsylvania’s mail-in ballots. The Supreme Court’s decision permitting the state to accept absentee ballots for several days after the election, he tweeted, “is a VERY dangerous one. It will allow rampant and unchecked cheating.” As soon as the election is over, he told reporters on Sunday, “we’re going in with our lawyers.” Republicans are already in court, challenging the count of some mail-in ballots in Pennsylvania.

abstract: With a historic vote, its people staked their claim to statehood.
lead_paragraph: Like all Americans, the people of Puerto Rico went to the polls on Tuesday. But unlike their fellow citizens, Puerto Ricans cannot vote for the president, or for senators or representatives (except for one nonvoting “resident commissioner”). Instead, voters there were asked whether they wanted Puerto Rico to become the 51st state of the union: “yes” or “no.” They chose “yes.” With this historic vote, Puerto Ricans have staked their claim to admission as the 51st state in the Union.
