The map appeared in the Upshot article “The Thanksgiving Recipes Googled in Every State?” — originally published on Nov. 25, 2014. There, you can see each state’s top ten side dishes that are most distinct relative to the rest of the country.

headline: Newton’s Daunting Masterpiece Had a Surprisingly Wide Audience, Historians Find
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Physics', 'Gravitation and Gravity', 'Mathematics', 'Space and Astronomy', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: The discovery suggests that “Principia” had a stronger impact on Enlightenment science than previous research suggested.
lead_paragraph: It had a reputation for unreadability. As its author walked by, a student at the University of Cambridge in England was said to have remarked: “There goes the man that writt a book that neither he nor anybody else understands.” Its hundreds of equations, diagrams and obscure references didn’t help, nor that it was written in Latin, the scholarly language of the day.

headline: How George Benson Turned an Early ‘No’ Into a Career of ‘Yes’
abstract: The 77-year-old guitarist talks about musicians who shaped him and how he learned to respond to critics as he releases his first live album in 30 years.
lead_paragraph: George Benson is many things to many different people, but he’s a jazz musician at heart. The 77-year-old guitarist and singer has traversed the worlds of pop, R&B, soul and, of course, jazz, tasting success while also learning how to field any criticism that came from changing his sound along the way.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: Hong Kong’s opposition is almost totally gutted.
lead_paragraph: After the mass resignation of pro-democracy lawmakers in Hong Kong’s legislature, pro-Beijing legislators quickly announced that they would make full use of their new dominance to advance a slew of priorities that otherwise would have met fierce resistance.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: I used to spend long hours after school at my town’s small public library, losing myself among stacks of books that felt as capacious and as mysteriously assembled as the universe itself. This week’s list of recommended titles offers something of that experience, with a poetry collection nestled up to a history of World War II refugees, a consideration of tomboys next to an account of the science behind gene editing. Where to begin? Probably in the same place I did as a student, with the fiction: Take your pick between Shirley Hazzard’s sparkling short stories or Bryan Washington’s debut novel about the vagaries of families and love. After that, the universe.

headline: ‘A Black Eye’: Why Political Polling Missed the Mark. Again.
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 1948', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: As politics becomes a high-stakes spectator sport, pollsters are reviewing their latest failures. But is part of the problem the public’s overly high expectations of precision?
lead_paragraph: Senator Susan Collins did not lead in a single publicly released poll during the final four months of her re-election campaign in Maine. But Ms. Collins, a Republican, won the election comfortably.

headline: Republicans Should Be Defending Georgia’s Election Process
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The G.O.P. is trying to scapegoat Brad Raffensperger for Trump’s apparent loss in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: There has hardly ever been a tougher time to be the chief election administrator of a state. In most states, that role is held by the secretary of state, and running an election is just one of the many responsibilities that commands that person’s time and attention. Yet these public servants have ably run an election amid a pandemic, especially Brad Raffensperger, the secretary of state of Georgia.

headline: Jerry Rawlings, From Coup-Plotter to Ghanaian Statesman, Dies at 73
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Politics and Government', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: After leading the country with brutal crackdowns, he helped Ghana blossom into a stable democracy.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Rawlings, a former Ghanaian Air Force officer who led two military coups before steering his country toward democracy with an authoritarian hand, died on Thursday in the nation’s capital, Accra. He was 73.

headline: Rep. Max Rose Is Defeated as Republicans Take Back N.Y.C. Seat
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Nicole Malliotakis, a Republican state assemblywoman, flipped a district that is considered the most conservative in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Overcoming a swell of anti-Trump sentiment in New York City, Nicole Malliotakis, a Republican state assemblywoman, defeated Representative Max Rose to give her party a lone seat in the city’s House delegation.

headline: The Word at MoMA Is ‘Rotation, Rotation, Rotation’
abstract: On Saturday, the museum opens with changes to 20 of its 60 permanent collection galleries. A critic’s guide to the standouts on each floor.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art’s permanent collection is on the move. It’s not leaving the building but it’s in motion as never before. On Saturday, MoMA will unveil what it calls the Fall Reveal, a rehang of about a third of its holdings, or 20 of 60 galleries. This is the first phase of an ambitious plan to regularly rotate the entire collection. In short, the result bodes extraordinarily well.

headline: Behind the Announcement of the 10 Best Books of 2020
abstract: Book Review editors revealed this year’s list in a live virtual event — that also featured a celebrity guest.
lead_paragraph: Every year, book lovers look forward to the publication of the 10 Best Books list, chosen by the editors of The Times Book Review. But this year, Times subscribers got the chance to know these titles before other readers did.

headline: The Vatican Report on Clerical Abuse
abstract: A Catholic priest says the report documents the failure of the hierarchy, and a need for civil authorities to take the lead in finding the truth. Also: Happy to fly the flag again.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: France Will Not Loosen Covid-19 Restrictions Despite Fewer Cases
abstract: The surge of coronavirus cases in France appears to be slowing, however, the prime minister, Jean Castex, said Thursday that he country will maintain the lockdown for the next 15 days.
lead_paragraph: The surge of coronavirus cases in France appears to be slowing, however, the prime minister, Jean Castex, said Thursday that he country will maintain the lockdown for the next 15 days.

headline: ‘Are We Getting Invaded?’ U.S. Boats Faced Russian Aggression Near Alaska
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Territorial Disputes']
abstract: Russia has escalated its provocative encounters in the North Pacific this year, harassing boats in U.S. fishing waters and sending bombers toward Alaska’s shores.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — The crew of the Bristol Leader was laying out its long cod-catching line well within U.S. fishing territory in the Bering Sea when a voice crackled over the VHF radio and began issuing commands: The ship was in danger, it said, and needed to move.

headline: Here’s What Will Happen Between Election Day and Inauguration Day
abstract: President Trump’s attempts to overturn the election results have made the arcane steps that formalize the will of the people a matter of unusual public importance.
lead_paragraph: The people have spoken. Now what?

headline: Video of Corpse in Hospital Bathroom Alarms Italy as Covid Spreads
abstract: The video of a man who died in the bathroom of the emergency room from what may have been Covid has sparked outrage.
lead_paragraph: A video showing a man lying dead on the floor of a bathroom inside a packed Naples emergency room sparked outrage as it spread across Italy on Thursday, prompting government officials to call for “immediate intervention” as the coronavirus pandemic ripples across the country’s vulnerable south.

headline: What to Know About Bird-Feeders
abstract: Along with bread-baking, board games, gardening and Zoom, bird feeding is enjoying a pandemic uptick.
lead_paragraph: Along with bread-baking, board games, gardening and Zoom, bird feeding is enjoying a pandemic uptick.

headline: Why the Arizona and Georgia Races Are Essentially Over, but Not Officially Called
abstract: Many networks are still resisting making a projection.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has closed to within around 11,000 votes in Arizona, but there is no longer a realistic path for him to erase the rest of the gap.

headline: Twitter says it labeled 0.2% of all election-related tweets as disputed.
abstract: Twitter is the first social media platform to publicly disclose how it performed during the election.
lead_paragraph: Twitter said on Thursday that it had labeled as disputed 300,000 tweets related to the presidential election, or 0.2 percent of the total on the subject, even as some users continued sharing misleading information about the outcome.

headline: Brexit Hard-Liners Lose Battle as Aide to U.K’s Johnson Quits
abstract: A Downing Street feud could indicate the prime minister is ready to make the compromises needed to strike a deal with the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An abrasive, plain-speaking former tabloid reporter, Lee Cain was part of a tight-knit team of Brexit campaigners who tied their fortunes to Boris Johnson and were rewarded with plum jobs in Downing Street when he became prime minister last year.

headline: Overlooked No More: Anya Phillips, Fashion Influencer in New York’s Punk Scene
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Design', 'Music', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Biographical Information']
abstract: She helped give pulse to the movement’s anti-establishment credo, dressing musicians like Debbie Harry of Blondie and James Chance and becoming a downtown “It girl.”
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: No, the ‘Pallets Full of Ballots’ song is not true.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Social Media', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Music', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A country-inspired song about the election has gone viral on social media, but its claims of election fraud are false.
lead_paragraph: The country song has a jaunty, folksy cadence and offers the false narrative that the Democrats stole the election. It has also gone viral on social media, turning the ditty by a 27-year-old singer-songwriter from Pensacola, Fla., into a protest anthem for President Trump’s supporters.

headline: Trump rebuffs Biden transition team as virus, national security hang in the balance.
abstract: President Trump’s refusal to allow President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his transition staff access to government offices, secure communications and classified briefings prompted growing warnings on Thursday, including from Republicans, that keeping Mr. Biden in the dark potentially endangers the country.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s refusal to allow President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his transition staff access to government offices, secure communications and classified briefings prompted growing warnings on Thursday, including from Republicans, that keeping Mr. Biden in the dark potentially endangers the country.

headline: New Unemployment Claims Dip, but Economic Pain Persists
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Unemployment', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: “Technically it looks like we’re in a recovery,” one economist said, “but we’re still so much in the hole.”
lead_paragraph: New claims for benefits continued to flood state unemployment offices last week as the coronavirus pandemic inflicted further economic damage.

headline: One America News spreads debunked elections claims.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: President Trump has tweeted about some of the statements made on the conservative cable network.
lead_paragraph: President Trump tweeted on Thursday about a report from One America News Network that repeated debunked claims about election software by Dominion Voting Systems.

headline: Aileen Passloff, Dancer, Choreographer and Teacher, Dies at 89
abstract: Ballet, modern, postmodern: She embraced all forms of dance, pushing students to find “the courage,” as one said, to know themselves through movement.
lead_paragraph: Aileen Passloff, whose career as a dancer, choreographer and broadly influential teacher spanned ballet, modern dance and postmodern dance, died on Nov. 3 in Manhattan. She was 89.

headline: Sweet, Sweet Fantasies, Baby
abstract: There’s a difference between our dreams for America — and our fantasies.
lead_paragraph: With the election (nearly) resolved, we have a moment to step back and look at what fantasies our country is built upon. From the role of president, to the threat of another civil war to the soul of the country itself, we’re all harboring some kind of fantasy that we should probably interrogate.

headline: Pearl Chin Dies at 71; Her Knitting Store Was a Haven and a Hub
abstract: Knitty City was more than a Manhattan supply shop for yarn; it was an urban sanctuary and a springboard for social activism (or, as she and others called it, “craftivism”).
lead_paragraph: Pearl Chin, the founder of Knitty City, a yarn shop on the Upper West Side of Manhattan that became an inclusive sanctuary for urban knitters — even offering a men’s night — as well as a hub for social activism through the craft arts, died on Oct. 27 in Manhattan. She was 71.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Take a look behind the curtain at Pixar … or into Scientology. Or check out a beautiful new six-part series about child development.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: Progressives Press Biden to Limit Corporate Influence in Administration
keywords: ['Presidential Transition (US)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Consultants', 'Corporations', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As the president-elect begins making personnel choices, the left of the Democratic Party is demanding ethics rules that would ban lobbyists and some consultants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The alarm bells sounded immediately among some progressives when President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. released the list of advisers this week who will help him with the transition at the White House’s Office of Management and Budget, which oversees the $5 trillion federal budget and shapes regulations on everything from labor standards to air pollution.

headline: Syria Seeks Return of Refugees, but They Fear Leader’s Wrath
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Politics and Government', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'War and Armed Conflicts']
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad said the millions of citizens who fled during the war have been blocked from coming back. But he left out the main reason they are staying away: Mr. al-Assad himself.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government hosted a lavish conference in the capital, Damascus, this week aimed at trying to get the more than six million refugees who fled the country’s civil war to come home.

headline: A Famous Santa and Rudolph Are Heading to Auction
abstract: If you can spare $250,000, two stars of the 56-year-old Christmas special “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer” could be yours.
lead_paragraph: Of course you do. Burl Ives sang that question decades ago in “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer,” the 1964 TV special. Now that very Rudolph — and Santa — are up for grabs.

headline: Economic Risks Are High as Chances for Quick Stimulus Narrow
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Unemployment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The Federal Reserve chief warned that a vaccine was still too uncertain to count on, and lawmakers signaled that more support was not imminent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two of the world’s most powerful central bankers said on Thursday that economic risks from the coronavirus remain high, and they cautioned against putting too much faith in a quick fix from a vaccine, delivering a sober message as U.S. lawmakers signaled that another stimulus package was unlikely before year’s end.

headline: Leaders of Global Economy Urge Caution Over Vaccine and Recovery Prospects
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, and Christine Lagarde, the head of the European Central Bank, said it was “too soon” to assume that the global economy was out of danger despite the prospect of an imminent coronavirus vaccine.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, and Christine Lagarde, the head of the European Central Bank, said it was “too soon” to assume that the global economy was out of danger despite the prospect of an imminent coronavirus vaccine.

headline: Rosanna Carteri, Soprano Who Retired at Her Peak, Dies at 89
abstract: The graceful singer, celebrated in Verdi and Puccini, was only in her mid-30s when she left the stage to tend to her family.
lead_paragraph: Rosanna Carteri, an Italian soprano whose meteoric career came to an early end when she chose to retire in her mid-30s at the height of her artistry, died on Oct. 25 in Monte Carlo, Monaco. She was 89.

headline: 5 Messages Voters Sent in the 2020 Election
abstract: Biden may have won, but the “battle for the soul of the nation” will only intensify.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Justice Dept. Finds ‘Poor Judgment’ but No Misconduct in 2006 Jeffrey Epstein Inquiry
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Human Trafficking', 'Prostitution', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'United States Attorneys']
abstract: The results of an internal investigation into Miami prosecutors’ handling of child trafficking allegations against the disgraced financier prompted criticism that the department evaded responsibility.
lead_paragraph: A former top federal prosecutor in Miami “exercised poor judgment” by allowing the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein to evade federal child trafficking charges more than a decade ago, a Justice Department review revealed on Thursday, but it found no other wrongdoing, prompting criticism that the department dodged responsibility for its light treatment of Mr. Epstein, who died last year of an apparent suicide after his arrest on similar charges.

headline: Biden Transition, Coronavirus, Barack Obama: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Georgia Will Begin Recounting Votes, With Biden Still Favored
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Elections', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: While the review of ballots in Georgia is technically an audit, not a recount, elections officials said it was unlikely to change the outcome in the state, where Joe Biden leads by over 14,000 votes.
lead_paragraph: Georgia’s 159 counties were poised on Thursday to begin recounting nearly five million ballots in the presidential election, but confusion surrounded the proceedings even as county officials raced to get ready.

headline: Nobel Peace Prize: A Growing List of Questionable Choices
keywords: ['Nobel Prizes', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: From Aung San Suu Kyi to Abiy Ahmed, the Nobel Peace Prize has been awarded at least six times in the past three decades to recipients whose recognition is being second-guessed.
lead_paragraph: One ordered his country’s armed forces to crush a defiant region’s resistance. Another ignored genocidal killings of a minority. Some had pushed for peaceful outcomes, but the achievements exalted at the time proved flawed or ineffective in hindsight.

headline: California’s Coronavirus Caseload: 1 Million and Counting
abstract: More than half of California’s nearly 40 million residents live in counties now under the most restrictive measures for businesses and public gatherings.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — California residents have become accustomed to receiving cellphone alerts about earthquakes and approaching wildfires. But phones lit up across Los Angeles on Tuesday with a different emergency: Coronavirus cases were on the rise after months of remaining steady. The public safety alert, the first time a virus-related one had been sent to the city’s residents since March, urged those who had symptoms or suspected they had been exposed to head to a testing site.

headline: Disney+ Passes 73 Million Subscribers as Streaming Takes Center Stage
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Television', 'Movies', 'Company Reports', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: The company has experienced deep losses in its theme park division because of the pandemic, but investors don’t seem to care at the moment.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Disney on Thursday reported an 82 percent decline in quarterly operating income, the result of steep losses at its coronavirus-devastated theme park division and the postponement of major movie releases.

headline: Trump Bars Investment in Chinese Firms With Military Ties
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Blacklisting', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The ban, which affects companies including Huawei, China Mobile and China Telecom, is the administration’s first major move toward decoupling American financial markets from China.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump issued an executive order Thursday barring Americans from investing in a list of companies with ties to the Chinese military, arguing that such investments pose a risk to national security.

headline: Stagehand Falls to His Death at the Winter Garden Theater
abstract: The 54-year-old man fell from a ladder above the stage at the theater that most recently hosted “Beetlejuice.”
lead_paragraph: A stagehand died Thursday morning after falling from a ladder on the fly floor above the stage at Broadway’s Winter Garden Theater.

headline: At Least 74 Drown in Wreck Off Libya, U.N. Agency Says
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Drownings', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A rubber raft crowded with at least 120 migrants sank in the Mediterranean Sea on Thursday. The craft was on a notoriously dangerous route for refugees trying to reach European shores.
lead_paragraph: At least 74 people drowned on Thursday when a rubber raft carrying migrants sank off the coast of Libya, the latest in a series of disasters in the world’s deadliest sea crossing, according to a United Nations agency.

headline: A Time to Reflect, and Look Forward
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: We asked for your thoughts after this chaotic election. You saw hope, sadness, determination, hopelessness … and reasons to carry on.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Layoffs at Police Watchdog Agency Prompt Claims of Retaliation
keywords: ['Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The agency said it was restructuring to hire more investigators, but employees said the officials were all critics of the agency’s performance.
lead_paragraph: Four senior officials at the New York City agency that examines allegations of police misconduct were laid off abruptly on Thursday in what officials described as a restructuring meant to expand its investigative muscle.

headline: David Easton, Architect for an American Gentry, Dies at 83
abstract: He was noted in the ’80s for his English-style manors, catering to an opulent clientele with a taste for grandeur.
lead_paragraph: David Easton, an architect and interior designer who created English-style palaces for an American aristocracy, died on Oct. 29 at his home in Tulsa, Okla. He was 83.

headline: Film Club: Two Short Animated Films About Childhood
abstract: What are your most vivid childhood memories?
lead_paragraph: This week, we feature two short, beautifully made animated films by the filmmaker Jeff Scher that capture the wonders, joys and fleetingness of childhood. In the two-minute 2009 film, “You Won’t Remember This Either” (above), Mr. Scher creates a poetic visual portrait of his son, Oscar, from his first week until he was a few years old. “You Might Remember This,” made two years later, captures his elder son, Buster, from ages six to 10. Each piece, in the words of the filmmaker, is a “collection of fleeting glimpses and little moments that would otherwise escape forever.”

headline: Flash Floods Cause Deaths and Severe Damage in North Carolina
abstract: At least six people died, and two others were missing, after flash floods swept through North Carolina on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: At least six people died, and two others were missing, after flash floods swept through North Carolina on Thursday.

headline: Mirror Images: Jose Abreu and Freddie Freeman Win M.V.P. Awards
abstract: The slugging first basemen, Abreu for the White Sox and Freeman for the Braves, have plenty in common, including thriving in M.L.B.’s pandemic-shortened season.
lead_paragraph: Jose Abreu is a right-handed slugger in the American League, and Freddie Freeman is a left-handed slugger in the National League. Otherwise, the two might as well be the same player.

headline: How Biden Could Steer a Divided Government
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: A pathway to a successful presidency.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to imagine ways Joe Biden’s presidency might open very badly. Covid-19 may still be spiking. The economy could slip back into recession. Mitch McConnell might still control the Senate, blocking every major Biden proposal. Donald Trump will be unleashed as National Narrator blasting everything that happens.

headline: A Republican Senate Would Be Bad for Business
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Economy', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: What’s bad for America would be bad for corporations, too.
lead_paragraph: So the blue wave fell short of expectations. Joe Biden will be the next president, but unless Democrats pull off an upset in the Georgia Senate runoffs — which, to be fair, they might, given the remarkable strength of their organizing efforts there — Mitch McConnell will still be the Senate majority leader.

headline: Ivy League Cancels Winter Sports and Stalls Spring Sports Over Coronavirus
abstract: The conference said it would not stage sports like basketball and hockey as coronavirus infections rise to record-breaking levels.
lead_paragraph: The Ivy League announced on Thursday that it was canceling winter sports and postponing its spring sports, citing spiking coronavirus cases across the United States and a desire to protect student safety.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Looking at the worst-hit places in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: The United States is reeling as infections and hospitalizations soar to all-time highs. Outbreaks are emerging from coast to coast.

headline: Trump Rebuffs Biden Transition Team, Setting Off Virus and National Security Risks
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Some Senate Republicans said the president-elect should be given intelligence briefings, and transition team members found workarounds for the president’s stonewalling.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s refusal to allow President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his transition staff access to government offices, secure communications and classified briefings prompted growing warnings on Thursday, including from Republicans, that keeping Mr. Biden in the dark potentially endangers the country.

headline: Small Cracks Emerge in G.O.P. Support for Trump’s Baseless Fraud Claims
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Elections, Senate', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Trump retains a powerful hold on his party. But a growing number of Republican elected officials and party leaders have signaled they will indulge his conspiracy theories for only so long.
lead_paragraph: The first small cracks have begun to appear in the Republican wall of support for President Trump and his unfounded claims of voter fraud in the 2020 election, with a growing number of elected officials and party leaders signaling on Thursday that they would indulge Mr. Trump’s conspiracy theories for only so long. A few were willing to openly contradict him.

headline: Argentina to Allow Medicinal Marijuana to Be Grown at Home
abstract: The new regulation also orders insurance providers to cover cannabis products prescribed by doctors. Some of the strongest champions of the government’s move were mothers of sick children.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina on Thursday authorized people to grow marijuana at home for medicinal use, delighting supporters of cannabis who have fought for years to make it widely available to patients suffering from a broad range of ailments.

headline: Tom Metzger, Notorious White Supremacist, Dies at 82
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Discrimination', 'Hate Speech', 'Neo Nazi Groups', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Whites']
abstract: Mr. Metzger, a former Klansman and the founder of the White Aryan Resistance, was one of the most influential leaders of the white power movement.
lead_paragraph: Tom Metzger, a notorious white supremacist and anti-Semite who cultivated a generation of neo-Nazi skinheads as the founder and leader of the White Aryan Resistance, died on Nov. 4 in Hemet, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Imprisoned Nearly 15 Years, but Now Cleared of a Murder He Didn’t Commit
abstract: A Nashville judge vacated the conviction of Joseph Webster after a collaborative investigation produced new witnesses and evidence.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Joseph Webster lunched on grilled salmon, which he had longed for while spending almost 15 years in prison for a murder he did not commit. There was also steamed broccoli and Diet Coke. “It was delicious,” he said by phone on his way to a local TV news station for an interview.

headline: Trump Floats Improbable Survival Scenarios as He Ponders His Future
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Presidential Election of 2024', 'Presidential Transition (US)']
abstract: There is no grand strategy. President Trump is simply trying to survive from one news cycle to the next.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting on Wednesday at the White House, President Trump had something he wanted to discuss with his advisers, many of whom have told him his chances of succeeding at changing the results of the 2020 election are thin as a reed.

headline: Tiger Woods Starts Strong at the Masters as Paul Casey Leads an Incomplete Round
abstract: Casey shot seven under par on Thursday, and Woods was four under, after rain delayed the start of tournament and left many golfers with unfinished rounds.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — At ease as he played his 87th round at the Masters, Tiger Woods stalked the Augusta National Golf Club on Thursday with the aplomb of someone sauntering through his living room in search of his favorite recliner, foot stool and coaster, for the cool drink in his hand. Shot by shot, the path was so familiar he could have negotiated it in the dark.

headline: Aldo Tambellini, Avant-Garde Filmmaker and Video Artist, Dies at 90
abstract: A fixture of the Lower East Side’s ’60s art scene, he had an abiding interest in black. “‘Black,’” he wrote, “is not the opposite of white; it is a state of being.”
lead_paragraph: Aldo Tambellini, a sculptor turned avant-garde filmmaker, pioneer video artist and veteran practitioner of multimedia installations, died on Thursday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 90.

headline: At Least 11 Killed as Flash Floods Ravage North Carolina
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Floods', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Rescuers evacuated 31 people from a campground an hour north of Charlotte, which accounted for at least four of the fatalities, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The death toll in North Carolina rose to at least 11 people on Friday after several days of heavy rains triggered flash flooding that swamped residential areas and swept away roads and bridges, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 13, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 13, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about new officials at the Pentagon and the National Security Agency misstated Ezra Cohen-Watnick’s role in preparing intelligence reports for Representative Devin Nunes of California. A lawyer for Mr. Cohen-Watnick said he did not provide the material to Mr. Nunes, although he did help compile it. The article also misidentified Kashyap Patel’s hometown. He is from Garden City, N.Y., not New Jersey.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Vaccine Will Travel Complicated Route From Lab to Masses
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 13, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “The challenge, of course, that’s out there is: Are people going to go get vaccinated? It would be a shame that we did all this work, and then we don’t have the public trusting that there’s a safe vaccine.”

headline: Election Officials Directly Contradict Trump on Voting System Fraud
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Voting Machines', 'Computer Security', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Absentee Voting', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A group of federal, state and local officials working with a Department of Homeland Security agency declared flatly that the election was the most secure in the nation’s history.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours after President Trump repeated a baseless report that a voting machine system “deleted 2.7 million Trump votes nationwide,” he was directly contradicted by a group of federal, state and local election officials, who issued a statement on Thursday declaring flatly that the election “was the most secure in American history” and that “there is no evidence” any voting systems were compromised.

headline: Countless
abstract: Emily Carroll and Erik Agard get together with us on a Saturday.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Emily Carroll’s first Saturday grid, and now she’s got a Times puzzle for every day of the week. Both she and Erik Agard, her collaborator, inject a great deal of humor into their clues and word lists, so you can expect to have fun while pulling your hair out, solving three spans and some smaller puns.

headline: Straight Shooter?
abstract: Sawyer Tabony and Ashton Anderson power us into the weekend with a fast and furious puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Maybe it’s an after effect of two double-up theme puzzles in a row, but I noticed a lot of twinsies in this grid, entries that seemed to play off each other, and since there are also two constructors today there’s an almost conversational tone to me. It’s a very enjoyable and smooth solve, I think. I didn’t recognize either name behind it, although you may remember Ashton Anderson, who constructed 11 daily puzzles for The New York Times between 2009 and 2017. Sawyer Tabony makes his Times debut and provides a very sweet back story in the notes.

headline: Pfizer Vaccine, Brexit, U.S. Presidential Transition: Your Friday Briefing
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Reconsidering Melbourne’s Public Housing Lockdown
abstract: Why the harshest example of an already-harsh lockdown had left many with a lingering sense of discrimination.
lead_paragraph: When we moved from Los Angeles to Australia in 2017, one of the first things my then-14-year-old son noticed was his peers’ attitudes about wealth — and housing in particular. When someone asked him where he lived in Melbourne, my son used a large public housing tower at the end of our street as a landmark, saying “I live a block behind those commission flats.” His classmates immediately started teasing him, jeering that he actually lived in public housing.

headline: Biden flips Arizona, further cementing his presidential victory.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has narrowly won Arizona, capturing the state’s 11 electoral votes and strengthening his Electoral College margin as President Trump continues to make baseless attacks on the vote counts favoring Mr. Biden.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has narrowly won Arizona, capturing the state’s 11 electoral votes and strengthening his Electoral College margin as President Trump continues to make baseless attacks on the vote counts favoring Mr. Biden.

headline: How I Got Caught Up in a Global Romance Scam
abstract: Some guy was using my image to con women online, so I messaged him. It didn’t go as expected.
lead_paragraph: This past spring, my inboxes began filling with messages from heartbroken women. The first came through Instagram: “Hey, I am Lina. I live in Germany. Someone is using your pictures for scamming!”

headline: What to Expect on Day 2 of the 2020 Masters
abstract: Thursday’s rain delay means many players will have to scramble to finish the second round of the tournament, which Paul Casey leads at seven under par.
lead_paragraph: Thursday’s morning rainstorm at Augusta National sufficiently muddled plans at the 2020 Masters. But after a nearly three-hour delay that thwarted Bryson DeChambeau’s strategy for domination — he rebounded from a double-bogey on the par-5 13th hole to shoot a two-under-par 70 — play resumed with 27 of the 48 players who had finished their rounds breaking par for the day. Among them was the reigning champion, Tiger Woods, who logged a four-under 68 on Day 1 to finish three strokes behind the leader, the Englishman Paul Casey.

headline: The Apocalyptic Politics of the Populist Right
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right']
abstract: By refusing to concede, Trump has sent a message to his fellow strongmen that this is a fight for survival.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Donald Trump’s victory in the 2016 presidential election was experienced by many right-wing populists in Europe as a momentous turning point. It was their version of 1989, when the fall of the Berlin Wall made liberalism appear unstoppable and triumphant. Right-wing populists from Hungary to Britain believed that if Mr. Trump could become president of the United States, the future belonged to them. President Trump’s 2020 defeat may trigger the rise of a much darker vision.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Has a Name for Trump’s Refusal to Concede: ‘Squattergate’
abstract: “Why don’t we just make him president of Alaska?” Kimmel said Thursday. “He’d love it. It even sounds like the names of his wives and daughters: Melania, Ivana, Ivanka — Alaska.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Travel Travails
abstract: What story does this image inspire for you?

headline: Europe Keeps Schools Open, Not Restaurants. The U.S. Has Other Ideas.
abstract: Science increasingly suggests classrooms can be kept open safely. But dining rooms pose a different problem.
lead_paragraph: Across much of Europe, even as coronavirus cases rise anew, governments are keeping classrooms open while forcing restaurants and bars to shut their doors. But in some American cities, officials have opted to keep students home even as dining rooms bustle with customers.

headline: For Aging Masters Champions, Pandemic Cannot Mute Augusta’s Call
abstract: Despite the coronavirus crisis, many of the older men who won the Masters reunited at the tournament that helped make them famous. Some are even playing.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The men met for dinner at Augusta National Golf Club on Tuesday night. They donned their green jackets, asked after grandchildren, cracked wise, drank wine and thought back to the long-ago shots that were their meal tickets now.

headline: Uneasy Under Lockdown, Pubs in England Count the Days Till Christmas
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Quarantines', 'Curfews', 'Restaurants', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Small Business', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: In October, pubs had a new pitch to lure in customers: They became work spaces. Less than a month later, they were forced to shut again. Now, they hold out hope for December.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At the Crooked Well, a neighborhood pub in south London that prides itself on its food, the Christmas menu is already decided. There will be venison and beef stews. But whether the stews will actually be served is another question.

headline: A Solution to Pandemic Hunger, Eyeballs and All
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Seafood', 'Maori', 'Food', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: A Maori community center in New Zealand is distributing bags of donated fish heads to families in need. But it’s more than just charity; it’s a model for reducing food waste.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — Leo Mulipola found a lifeline in a load of fish heads.

headline: China Congratulates Biden on Presidential Victory
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States International Relations', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: “We respect the choice of the American people,” a spokesman for the country’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said, ending days of conspicuous silence about the election result.
lead_paragraph: After days of silence, China on Friday congratulated Joseph R. Biden Jr. on his election as president of the United States, signaling a start to its relations with the incoming administration after years of hostility and distrust under President Trump.

headline: From ‘Street Kid’ in India to Top Toronto Chef
abstract: After a rugged childhood, Sash Simpson realized his dream last year when he opened a high-end restaurant. Within months, the pandemic struck.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Sash Simpson made his name as a chef for Canada’s rich, preparing them chardonnay-poached lobster and $27 foie gras-smothered burgers.

headline: Considering Malcolm X and the Perfect Black Man
abstract: Michael P. Jeffries reviews Les Payne and Tamara Payne’s book, “The Dead Are Arising: The Life of Malcolm X,” in this week’s issue. In 1992, Michael Eric Dyson wrote for the Book Review about a select group of books that examine Malcolm X’s life.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Busted in New York’ and ‘Little Darlings’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: THE BOOK OF EATING: Adventures in Professional Gluttony, by Adam Platt. (Ecco, 272 pp., $17.99.) Gout, expandable belts, diets, countless bottles of antacid tablets: Platt, the longtime food critic for New York magazine, dishes up a painfully honest account of what it’s like to eat for a living. “He’s maniacally self-deprecating,” Dwight Garner wrote in The Times last year. “He serves good stories because he doesn’t over-batter them.”

abstract: Do you think public call-outs are an effective way to hold others accountable for their harmful actions? Or is it better to call them in and work toward a resolution?
lead_paragraph: When you hear the terms “canceled” or “cancel culture,” what comes to mind?

headline: They Traveled the World Together, Long Before Their First Date
abstract: Drs. Sarah Siu and David Yang were friends for years before they started dating. They pushed their wedding up after he got the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Drs. Sarah Y. Siu and David X. Yang were on what they call their “negative-fifth date” when they first broached the subject of marriage.

headline: Is It Possible to Outgrow A.D.H.D.?
keywords: ['Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Parenting']
abstract: The challenges of the diagnosis make it unclear whether the condition is outgrown or simply becomes better managed, experts say.
lead_paragraph: When my 15-year-old son was given a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder at age 7, I was told that it was a lifelong chronic condition.

headline: She Married the Priest
abstract: Jonathan Morris and Kaitlyn Folmer met at the Vatican. He was a priest. Some things changed along the way.
lead_paragraph: Unforgettable. That’s the word that brought the worlds of Kaitlyn Folmer and Jonathan Morris back into the same orbit after a brief but indelible encounter more than seven years earlier.

headline: Just How Dishonest Are Most Students?
abstract: Many are tempted to cheat, but honor codes are surprisingly effective in curbing the problem.
lead_paragraph: I teach philosophy to college students, and there was no way I was going to give them exams this semester, with our classes being held online. Why not? Simple — cheating. It is nothing personal with these particular students, but I have read enough psychological research to know that it would be very hard for them to resist looking for help in places where they are not supposed to, such as their notes, their friends and the internet.

headline: Singing My Dad Back to Me
abstract: For a moment, songs let us share the same space in our minds, though it’s only as temporary as the memory occupying his.
lead_paragraph: As Alzheimer’s disease lowers its veil over my father, one of the few ways to penetrate through his fog is music. Luckily, he prepared for that decades ago by encouraging my love of singing. As a child, I was classically trained as an opera singer. My career took me in the direction of words rather than music, so these days I sing just for friends and family, which has turned out to be surprisingly useful in connecting with my father.

headline: What Does the MAGA Hat Mean Now?
keywords: ['Hats and Caps', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-fashion']

headline: Padma Lakshmi: Vice President-Elect Kamala Harris Moved Me to Tears
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Indian-Americans', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Imagine how wide the ripples of impact can be when a woman of color is vice president.
lead_paragraph: I was on a hike in Garrison, N.Y., when I heard the news of Kamala Harris and Joe Biden’s victory. I felt elated. Then suddenly I felt this heat welling up from my chest into my throat and it burst out of me in tears I could not control. At first I didn’t even know why I was sobbing.

headline: What Happened in California Is a Cautionary Tale for Us All
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Automobiles']
abstract: A voter-approved measure strips gig workers of basic protections enjoyed by employees in other businesses.
lead_paragraph: What happened in California? Despite the state’s liberal reputation, voters there last week approved Proposition 22, a ballot initiative exempting many gig companies from state workplace laws and stripping their workers of basic, essential protections.

headline: The Loud, Biased, Lovable Celtic
abstract: Tommy Heinsohn, who died on Monday, was a resounding figure in Boston sports, known for his love of the Celtics and disdain for referees.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Celtics have produced some of the biggest names in basketball history: Bill Russell, Red Auerbach, Larry Bird. But among all those icons, Tommy Heinsohn was Mr. Celtic.

abstract: Plus: Ending reply-all abuse once and for all.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

abstract: The “war on childhood obesity” has only caused shame.
lead_paragraph: I was in the fourth grade, sitting in a doctor’s office, the first time my face flushed with shame. I was, I had just learned, overweight.

headline: Before ‘I Have a Dream,’ Martin Luther King Almost Died. This Man Saved Him.
keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']

lead_paragraph: The bar in Showman’s Jazz Club, a Harlem destination for visitors from just down the block to Japan and back, stretched from the front door to the stage. The owner, Al Howard, liked to sit at the curve near the entrance.

headline: ‘There Is a Real Opportunity Here That I Think Biden Is Capturing’
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Green New Deal', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president-elect is making the climate a top priority.
lead_paragraph: During the months that Joe Biden and President Trump were campaigning against each other, vast sections of the American West caught on fire. More than five million acres burned, and the air in California, Oregon and Washington was sometimes more harmful to breathe than in the pollution-clogged cities of India.

headline: ‘Women’s Work’ Can No Longer Be Taken for Granted
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Discrimination', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: New Zealand is pursuing a century-old idea to close the gender pay gap: not equal pay for equal work, but equal pay for work of equal value.
lead_paragraph: Last week, as Americans were obsessing over the results of the presidential election, a New Zealand law aimed at eliminating pay discrimination against women in female-dominated occupations went into effect. The bill, which takes an approach known as “pay equity,” provides a road map for addressing the seemingly intractable gender pay gap.

headline: What Biden’s Election Could Mean for Student Loans
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'For-Profit Schools', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Student Loans', 'Law and Legislation', 'Personal Finances', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Personal Bankruptcies', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The incoming administration has proposed a series of changes that could affect more than 42 million student loan borrowers. Here’s what to expect.
lead_paragraph: The federal government is the primary lender for students who borrow money for college and graduate school, and the Education Department directly holds more than $1.4 trillion in student debt. President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s administration will have the ability to make changes that can directly affect millions of borrowers’ monthly bills.

headline: The Work Diary of Blair Imani, ‘Herstory’ Historian
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Her “Smarter in Seconds” Instagram videos feature bite-size lessons — and a kaleidoscopic array of hijabs.
lead_paragraph: Blair Imani thinks and speaks at a mile a minute. That speed comes in handy when the historian and social activist is creating her “Smarter in Seconds” Instagram videos — a series of bite-size tutorials that nimbly address such subjects as consent, cultural appropriation and gender expression for her audience of more than 300,000 followers, known as Smarties.

headline: Liberal New Yorkers Threw Money at Doomed Candidates All Over the U.S.
abstract: Donations went to glamorous but unwinnable Senate races. Meanwhile, a representative in Brooklyn may lose to a first-time candidate and QAnon supporter.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, as the champagne virtually uncorked itself in New York City in celebration of what looked like the end of Trumpism, an alternate history was unfolding in the southern stretches of Brooklyn. A Republican named Mark Szuszkiewicz was leading in a race against an incumbent for a State Assembly seat in and around Coney Island that had been held by a Democrat for decades.

headline: As Soon as Trump Leaves Office, He Faces Greater Risk of Prosecution

abstract: The president is more vulnerable than ever to an investigation into his business practices and taxes.

headline: A Blue Moon Wedding for Two Goth Romantics
abstract: Vivienne Vermuth and Jason Perkins met in 2012 when she was performing at a burlesque show in Dallas. Although polyamorous, they decided to marry because they are “the center of each other’s lives and love.”
lead_paragraph: On Halloween night, under a blue moon, Vivienne Vermuth and Jason Perkins, both dressed in black, were married after a dating life that Mr. Perkins describes as more layered than an onion.

headline: When It Comes to Living With Uncertainty, Michael J. Fox Is a Pro
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Writing and Writers', "Parkinson's Disease", 'Actors and Actresses', 'Celebrities']
abstract: In his fourth memoir, “No Time Like the Future,” the actor and activist opens up about his newfound, uniquely upbeat brand of pessimism.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Michael J. Fox had surgery to remove a benign tumor on his spinal cord. The actor and activist, who had been living with Parkinson’s disease for nearly three decades, had to learn to walk all over again.

headline: A College Crush From Afar Gets Real Two Decades Later
abstract: Annette Blum recognized Michael Pearson on Bumble. Both had been at Emory University 20 years ago. When she saw his profile, she messaged him, “My freshman year self is really excited right now.”
lead_paragraph: When Annette Blum recognized Michael Pearson on Bumble in 2016, she reacted in a way that only a tech company employee would: He must be there to test the user experience, she thought, as he was in a relationship.

headline: The E Train Brought Them Together, the G Train Nearly Did Them In
abstract: Susanna Guffey and Ross Brady had been friends for years. Then they ran into each other on the subway, and their relationship took a romantic turn.
lead_paragraph: Susanna Helene Guffey and Ross Wilson Brady didn’t meet the first time they crossed paths. Both were at a bar in Manhattan’s Yorkville neighborhood in June 2012 with their respective friend groups, and Ms. Guffey hit it off with one of Mr. Brady’s friends and eventually started dating. A few weeks later, they were introduced at a karaoke bar by Mr. Brady’s friend, and within a month became good friends.

headline: A Record of Horseback Riding, Written in Bone and Teeth
abstract: Close examination of horse remains has clarified the timeline of when equestrianism helped transform ancient Chinese civilization.
lead_paragraph: The advent of horseback riding transformed our ancestors’ lives, irrevocably changing how they migrated, fought wars and traded. Now, researchers have found the oldest direct evidence of horseback riding in China, which could help unlock the historical timeline of how the civilization was affected by a newfound ability to get around on four legs.

headline: Progress in Kidney Care Starts at Home

headline: Until a Vaccine Arrives, a Worrisome Road Ahead

headline: He Put the Boston Marathon Pic in His Profile. It Worked.
abstract: Jessica Jeffrey, an avid runner, was drawn to Billy Pitman’s online dating profile after seeing a photo of him participating in the Boston Marathon.

headline: Biden’s Education Department Will Move Fast to Reverse Betsy DeVos’s Policies
keywords: ['Education', 'Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: They Met in Touchy-Feely 101 at Stanford
abstract: Irene Yuan and Colin Evran went on a shopping trip after she criticized his clothes in an interpersonal dynamics class. A makeover, friendship and romance soon followed.

headline: Wild About Him, but Not the Bike He Rode In On
abstract: Sarah Miller decided that despite the fact that Ron Jacobson rode a motorcycle to their first date, it would not be a deal breaker.
lead_paragraph: Ron Jacobson recalled the moment when he knew he would marry Sarah Miller, whom he met through the dating app Coffee Meets Bagel in November 2017 in New York.

headline: How a Designer of Outdoor Spaces Spends His Sundays
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Design']
abstract: Todd Haiman will often go for a hike outside of the city or visit the Brooklyn Botanic Garden for inspiration.
lead_paragraph: Since the onset of the pandemic, the landscape designer Todd Haiman has received “a ton” of calls from New Yorkers with terraces, yards and balconies and the means to transform them into wondrous fresh-air escapes.

headline: A Non-Transfer of Power
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Trump’s refusal to concede the election is holding up the traditional transition process. What risks does that pose?
lead_paragraph: A concession speech and preparations for the transfer of power have become a ritual of the days after an American presidential election. But long after it became clear that President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. was the winner of this year’s election, there has been no sign from President Trump that he will concede. The transition is at a standstill.

headline: Once the Disease of Gluttonous Aristocrats, Gout Is Now Tormenting the Masses
abstract: It can be tempting to ascribe the affliction’s prevalence to our current climate of indulgence, but that’s not the full story.
lead_paragraph: IT HAS COME for genius and aristocrat, conqueror and king. Like a succubus, it descends at night, first as a fevered dream, then pain in darkness, the body turned rude animal, reduced to its lowest, humblest extremity: the foot, red and swollen, throbbing like a heart. You are left to hobble, if that; the flutter of a bedsheet over the distended foot is anguish enough, let alone the full weight of the body bearing down. To take a step is to see the abyss. Often the pain is concentrated in the big toe, ridiculous, stubby and chubby, Napoleonic, the fat piggy sent to market. So acute is the sensitivity of this bloated hallux — “so exquisite and lively,” in the words of the 17th-century English physician Thomas Sydenham, chronicling his bouts with the disease — that the faintest footfall of a sympathetic visitor is a gunshot straight to the nerve. The American poet and novelist Jim Harrison, writing in 1991, likened his throes to those of “a wolf with the steel teeth of a trap buried in its paw.” It will not help, at such a moment, to recall that Alexander the Great, Charlemagne, Leonardo da Vinci, Isaac Newton and Henry James reportedly suffered thus, and that you have joined, in your abasement, the noblest ranks.

headline: Working in Luis Barragán’s Shadow
abstract: Two doors down from the architect’s home in Mexico City, a fashion designer pays tribute to the country’s hand-hewn legacy.
lead_paragraph: FOR 16 YEARS, on her annual trips from New York to Mexico City to spend time with her husband, Guillaume Guevara’s, family, the fashion writer Olivia Villanti would visit the offices of her in-laws’ business, Gilly e Hijos — a fabric importer for some of Europe’s top textile mills — in the middle-class neighborhood of Ampliación Daniel Garza. By the time Villanti, who grew up in Rhinebeck, N.Y., and Guevara, both 39, moved down to Mexico City in 2019, the once-thriving business was in decline, a victim of fast fashion. Guevara’s 61-year-old uncle, Bruno Gilly Armand, who had taken over the company in 2011, tried selling bespoke shirting, but most of the people gathered on the street outside had come instead to tour the architect Luis Barragán’s legendary 1948 residence down the block.

headline: A Bold Bulgari Necklace That Reimagines a Late-’60s Design
abstract: Two years ago, the house reacquired one of its own iconic pieces, which inspired a magnificent new creation.
lead_paragraph: Bulgari opened its first jewelry shop on Via Sistina in Rome in 1884 and soon became known for its bold combinations of precious and semiprecious stones. Many of the house’s most arresting designs were created in the ’50s and ’60s, including the 1969 sautoir necklace — a heart-shaped emerald pendant, weighing over 127 carats, surrounded by cabochon-cut gems of ruby, citrine, amethyst, turquoise and topaz. Shortly after it came off the workbench, the piece — which converted into two bracelets — was shot for American Vogue, its magnificent links draped across the model Veruschka’s scarf-covered head. It was then bought by a Genevese collector, who purchased it for his wife. Decades later, Bulgari came across a 1975 oil portrait of a woman wearing what looked to be the very same necklace. Two years ago, the house bought back the piece when it came up for auction at Sotheby’s and returned it to its archives.

headline: A Bride Changes Her Mind
abstract: The Atlanta-based artist Dawn Williams Boyd shares one of her vivid, life-size textile works, this one inspired by a wedding ceremony gone awry.
lead_paragraph: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at a work by Dawn Williams Boyd, who began her four-decade career as a classically inspired portrait painter before swapping oils for fabric. (She realized, she has said, that “European visual art is not the only standard of ‘good art.’”) Today, she makes large-scale works from intricately layered and stitched-together textile pieces, a practice informed in part by the art of quilting.

headline: Love Letter: Confronting an Impostor
abstract: Plus: A priest decides to marry.
lead_paragraph: Widespread loneliness, anxiety and uncertainty have created the perfect environment for scammers to take advantage of hopeful singles online. After receiving several messages from women who had fallen prey to his internet impostor, Michael McAllister, the author of this week’s Modern Love essay, confronted the man who had used his Instagram photos to lure women into an international romance scam.

headline: Send Joy During a Stressful Year With a Holiday Card
keywords: ['Greeting Cards', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Photography', 'Christmas', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Handicrafts', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: You can still connect with loved ones near and far with a holiday card, and referencing the pandemic is OK. Just be mindful of your tone.
lead_paragraph: It was only October, and an unseasonably hot and sunny day to boot, but Rovonne Staten’s front steps in Grapevine, Texas, brimmed with Christmas-y props. For her family’s holiday-card photo shoot, there were poinsettias and wreaths, tinsel and tartan, an oversized ornament emblazoned with the letter “S,” a plate of cookies for Santa — and a sign reminding him to please stay outside.

abstract: On a planet full of humanoid sea creatures, Mando gets a taste of a broader struggle among his people.
lead_paragraph: Last week on “The Mandalorian,” Baby Yoda scarfed down several unfertilized frog-creature eggs, sparking arguments across the internet about whether the kid’s uncontrollable impulse to have a little snack was funny or appalling. Well, this week Baby Yoda — sealed inside his own floating metallic “egg” — gets swallowed whole by a sea monster. Could this be some kind of poetic justice?

headline: The ‘Inn’ Is Out at the Beatrice, but History Still Holds Sway
abstract: The chef, Angie Mar, will move the New York institution right next door, reconnecting the restaurant with the family who ran it for 50 years.
lead_paragraph: The Beatrice Inn has been at 285 West 12th Street for nearly 100 years in one form or another, drawing generations of New Yorkers down the steep, narrow stairs and into a dimly lit speakeasy, an Italian restaurant, an impossible-to-get-in-the-door club and a buzzy chophouse owned by the former Vanity Fair editor Graydon Carter.

headline: Paul Hornung, Midcentury Football’s ‘Golden Boy,’ Is Dead at 84
abstract: His dazzling play at Notre Dame, a Hall of Fame Career with the Green Bay Packers, matinee-idol looks and a playboy image made him a national celebrity in the ’50s and ’60s.
lead_paragraph: Paul Hornung, one of the most versatile and glamorous football stars of the modern game, the “Golden Boy” quarterback from Notre Dame who won championships as a running back with Vince Lombardi’s Green Bay Packers but whose image was tarnished by gambling and carousing, died on Friday in Louisville, Ky. He was 84.

headline: Scientists Destroyed a Nest of Murder Hornets. Here’s What They Learned.
abstract: Officials vacuumed the country’s first nest of so-called murder hornets last month in Washington State. The invasive insects could multiply and kill native bee populations, endangering crops and ecosystems.
lead_paragraph: Asian giant hornets — better known as murder hornets — inspired menacing headlines throughout the summer amid warnings that the invasive insects could decimate American honeybee populations. Last month, after various sightings across the Pacific Northwest, officials in Washington State discovered and removed the first known murder hornet nest in the United States.

headline: Getting Outside of Your Head and Your House
abstract: While the skies are clear, be out under them.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. It’s been a rainy week in New York City, a stay-inside, low-sun week and, in the absence of anywhere pressing to physically be, a week in which it’s been easy to default to staying indoors. While we’re safest and coziest at home these days, static scenery can really make a week drag. If the skies are clear where you are this weekend, make a point to be out under them.

headline: Morocco Launches Military Operation in Western Sahara Buffer Zone

headline: Arsène Wenger and the Gift of Time
abstract: The former Arsenal manager is still consumed by soccer, and how it is played and taught. It is just that now, he does not have anything to distract him from the big questions.
lead_paragraph: Those mornings, there was never enough time. For years, you could set your watch by Arsène Wenger. Punctuality is a rare trait in soccer, but Wenger was fastidious about it. His weekly news conference at Colney, Arsenal’s training facility just outside London, always started at 9 a.m. And it started at 9 a.m. sharp.

headline: Celebrate “Tiny Love Stories” With the Times

headline: China’s New Testing Policy for Travelers Is Problematic, Experts Say

headline: Wall Street Carried to Record by Biden Win and Vaccine Hopes

headline: Does Elon Musk have the coronavirus? After four tests, he still doesn’t know.
abstract: Elon Musk, the SpaceX chief executive, has tested positive twice, and negative twice, for the coronavirus after taking four rapid virus tests, he revealed in a disgruntled tweet early Friday morning. The announcement came just days before his company’s much-anticipated launch of a Crew Dragon capsule that will carry four astronauts to the International Space Station.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the SpaceX chief executive, has tested positive twice, and negative twice, for the coronavirus after taking four rapid virus tests, he revealed in a disgruntled tweet early Friday morning. headline: Nigeria Goes on Offensive Against Youth Protesting Police Brutality
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police Reform', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Young people staged the biggest anti-government uprising in a generation, triggered by relentless police brutality. Rattled, politicians are promising reforms, but using repressive tactics, large and small.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Nigeria’s leaders have made a show of responding to the demands of a massive youth-led uprising over police brutality that recently brought the country to a standstill and captured global attention.

abstract: The president-elect has chosen proponents of stronger regulation to begin reviewing financial agencies.

President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. appears ready to shift things in the opposite direction, bringing back stricter oversight of the financial industry.

headline: How Do Canadians Remember World War II 75 Years Afterward?
abstract: We spoke with a leading historian who argues that too much of the focus has been on disgrace and defeat.
lead_paragraph: Although this year was the 75th anniversary of the end of World War II, the pandemic diminished the national Remembrance Day ceremony in Ottawa. Instead of thousands of people filling the streets around Confederation Square, a few hundred people came and stood or sat socially distanced around the National War Memorial.

headline: The Sounds of a Divided America
abstract: We listened in on the country’s partisan echo chambers. Plus, the music behind Modern Love.
lead_paragraph: Hey everyone, we made it to Friday (though after last week, this one felt like a breeze). If you missed any episodes in your post-election daze, here’s a recap. On Monday we listened to the sounds of a divided nation; on Tuesday we investigated why the polling industry was wrong (again); on Wednesday we analyzed the ongoing battle for the Senate; on Thursday we answered your questions about the recent coronavirus vaccine breakthrough; and on Friday we looked at President Trump’s refusal to concede.

headline: 35 Years After MOVE Bombing That Killed 11, Philadelphia Apologizes
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Attacks on Police', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Helicopters', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A police helicopter dropped an explosive charge onto the roof of a rowhouse during an armed standoff in 1985. The resultant fire destroyed 61 homes in a West Philadelphia neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia City Council this week formally apologized for the decision in 1985 to drop an improvised bomb on a rowhouse occupied by the MOVE separatist group, a desperate action that resulted in a fire that killed 11 people and destroyed 61 homes.

headline: Watching the U.S. Election While Irish
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “John King is back on shift!” gasped my sister Caoimhe. “It must be close.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the polls closed on Election Day in America, my family group chat thrummed with anticipation. Maps were shared. Probabilities mocked. We argued over exit polls, safe seats and swing votes, breaking off occasionally to ask what, precisely, the Electoral College was.

abstract: Israeli agents shot Abu Muhammad al-Masri on the streets of Tehran at the behest of the U.S., officials said, but no one — Iran, Al Qaeda, the U.S. or Israel — has publicly acknowledged the killing.
