headline: Federal Prosecutors Push Back on Barr Memo on Voter Fraud Claims
keywords: ['United States Attorneys', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: The prosecutors, assigned to monitor this month’s elections, said they had found no evidence to back any “substantial allegations” of voting irregularities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Career Justice Department prosecutors pushed back this week against a memo by Attorney General William P. Barr that opened the door to politically charged election fraud investigations, saying in a pair of messages that Mr. Barr thrust the department into politics and falsely overstated the threat of voter fraud.

headline: Biden Implores Trump to Confront a Surging Pandemic
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'States (US)', 'Disease Rates']
abstract: President Trump broke his near-total silence on the coronavirus on Friday with an appearance in the Rose Garden in which he threatened to deny New York access to a vaccine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. demanded on Friday that President Trump do more to confront the coronavirus infections exploding across the country, calling the federal response “woefully lacking” even as Mr. Trump broke a 10-day silence on the pandemic to threaten to withhold a vaccine from New York.

headline: Partial Owners of Washington’s N.F.L. Team Seek Path in Court to Sell Their Stake
abstract: Three limited partners said in a federal court filing that Daniel Snyder, the team’s majority owner, was trying to block the sale of their combined 40 percent stake for $900 million.
lead_paragraph: The increasingly bitter battle for control of the Washington Football Team took a significant turn on Friday when three of the team’s limited partners, who together own 40 percent of the club, asked a federal judge to allow them to sell their shares as a group.

headline: Examine Ballot. Recite Name. Sort Into Bin. Repeat 5 Million Times.
abstract: A hand recount got underway in Georgia on Friday, with hundreds of poll workers rechecking ballots in a state that President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. won by about 14,000 votes.
lead_paragraph: MARIETTA, Ga. — By the time President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. was declared the winner of Georgia’s 16 electoral votes on Friday afternoon, hundreds of county poll workers across the state were several hours into the arduous slog of recounting nearly five million ballots by hand.

headline: Christopher Krebs Hasn’t Been Fired, Yet
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Krebs’s government agency contradicted President Trump’s false claims that the election was rigged. At this point, Mr. Krebs, a former Microsoft executive, still has a job.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Christopher Krebs is a 43-year-old former Microsoft executive who had the unenviable government job of protecting the nation’s election machinery from manipulation by Russia or other foreign hackers. It turns out, though, that some of the most dangerous interference has come not from the Kremlin but from the White House, where the president called the election “rigged” before a single vote was cast.

headline: Iota, Now a Hurricane, Is Season’s 30th Named Storm
abstract: A Category One storm, Iota was expected to strengthen into a major hurricane by Monday as it approached the coast of Central America, according to the National Hurricane Center.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Iota strengthened into a hurricane early Sunday as it continued to carve a path through the Caribbean Sea, days after becoming the 30th named storm in the record-breaking 2020 Atlantic hurricane season.

headline: Bryson DeChambeau’s Ball Search Pushes Him Out of Masters Hunt
abstract: After predictions that he would dominate Augusta National, DeChambeau had a meltdown on the third hole Friday that put him below the projected cut line with six holes of his second round left to finish on Saturday morning.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — It was almost a given that Bryson DeChambeau would do something memorable at this year’s Masters tournament. It did not figure to be a booming tee shot so high in the Georgia sky that it landed clear out of sight.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Baseball First: A Woman Rises to Run a Team
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 14, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “When I got into this business, it seemed unlikely a woman would lead a major league team, but I am dogged in the pursuit of my goals.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 14, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 14, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about contenders for the cabinet of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. misstated one of Michael J. Morell’s past government positions. He is a former C.I.A. analyst, not a former Foreign Service officer.

headline: Without Augusta’s Famed Roars, the Masters Goes Quiet
abstract: The swell of the tournament’s spectators has long provided a dramatic soundtrack to the Masters’ most memorable finishes. In its absence, golfers will play their final rounds a cappella.
lead_paragraph: The swell of the tournament’s spectators has long provided a dramatic soundtrack to the Masters’ most memorable finishes. In its absence, golfers will play their final rounds a cappella.

headline: Trump Is Not Doing Well With His Election Lawsuits. Here’s a Rundown.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Absentee Voting', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The president has suffered a string of defeats in pursuing legal action seeking to delay certification of his loss to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: It is difficult to overturn an American election result, as President Trump has been reminded over and over again in the past few weeks. His campaign and his allies lost in courts and dropped cases in every battleground state where they filed them — Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. Judges have been unpersuaded by “strained legal arguments without merit and speculative accusations,” as a federal judge in Pennsylvania wrote in the latest blistering ruling against the campaign on Saturday.

headline: A Woman Is Stabbed, and Two 15-Year-Olds Are Charged With Murder
abstract: Nyla Bond, 20, became friendly with one of the teenagers last year. Now she is dead, and questions swirl around the motive for the killing.
lead_paragraph: Nyla Bond, 20, met Anmerie Morales, 15, about a year ago. Despite their age difference, they became friends and often spent time together at the Bronx apartment where Ms. Bond lived with her mother.

headline: Time to Take a Pledge: No Stocks if You’re a Member of Congress
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Mutual Funds', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Owning actively traded shares can create conflicts of interest. Georgia’s Senate candidates agree. Will others? Mutual funds could be good for them.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s balance of power is at stake as both senators from Georgia face runoff elections in early January. The campaigns have been bitter, and they stand to get more so.

headline: A Lack of Fans at the Masters Strains Those Who Would Sell the Experience
abstract: Passes to the Masters are some of the most expensive tickets in sports. But with fans barred from Augusta National Golf Club and other venues this year, many resellers are under pressure.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — For about two decades, James DiZoglio has run a bazaar to sell some of the most cherished tickets in sports. His scalping locale has always been the same: near the TBonz Steakhouse and the Augusta Best Inn down the street from the site of the Masters.

headline: How a Human Rights Angel Lost Her Halo
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners', 'Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Ten years after she left house arrest and vowed to fight for justice, Myanmar’s civilian leader has instead become a jailer of critics and an apologist for the slaughter of minorities.
lead_paragraph: When Daw Aung San Suu Kyi emerged from years of house arrest a decade ago, having never used a smartphone or Facebook, she held court in the office of her banned political party, the smell of damp emanating from the human rights reports piled on the floor.

headline: Rome Tracks Down the Man Behind All That Graffiti. No, It’s Not Banksy.
abstract: The tagger known as Geco is not as famous as the British provocateur, but he has made a name for himself in Italy.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The post on the Rome mayor’s Facebook page was triumphant: The police had tracked down a man “once considered uncatchable,” she said in announcing that after a yearlong investigation, the authorities had discovered the real identity of the elusive tagger known only as Geco.

headline: Razzle Dazzle, Part 2: Broadway Triumphs Again
abstract: Michael Riedel’s “Singular Sensation” tracks the blockbuster successes of the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: SINGULAR SENSATION The Triumph of BroadwayBy Michael Riedel

headline: Leggings Take a Victory Lap
abstract: Everyone is still wearing leggings during the pandemic, including Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President-elect Kamala Harris called to congratulate Joseph R. Biden Jr. on winning the election last Saturday, she was wearing what women everywhere in the United States seem to be wearing during the pandemic: leggings.

headline: Savannah Guthrie Is Feeling Lucky
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'News and News Media', 'Television', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Since she held President Trump’s feet to the fire at a crucial turning point of the campaign, her future at NBC News appears bright.
lead_paragraph: “Nobody’s sorry to see someone say something nice,” said Savannah Guthrie, the 48-year-old co-host of the “Today” show. “But I also see people say things that aren’t nice. I try not to let any of it in. It’s not reality.”

headline: Rory McIlroy Aims for Balance, and a Green Jacket
abstract: McIlroy, still seeking a Masters win for a career Grand Slam, struggled in the first round at Augusta National but rebounded in the second.
lead_paragraph: Rory McIlroy watched the flight of his ball in dismay on Friday morning. “That’s so bad,” he said. “Oh my God.”

headline: The Pandemic Is Showing Us How Capitalism Is Amazing, and Inadequate
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Public-Private Sector Cooperation', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why big business needs big government and vice versa.
lead_paragraph: The bananas news cycle of November 2020 included a fascinating public spat that is essential for understanding modern capitalism.

headline: Missing From State Plans to Distribute the Coronavirus Vaccine: Money to Do It
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'States (US)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Finances', 'Public-Private Sector Cooperation', 'Medicine and Health', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The government has sent billions to drug companies to develop a coronavirus shot but a tiny fraction of that to localities for training, record-keeping and other costs for vaccinating citizens.
lead_paragraph: With the prospect that a coronavirus vaccine will become available for emergency use as soon as next month, states and cities are warning that distributing the shots to an anxious public could be hindered by inadequate technology, severe funding shortfalls and a lack of trained personnel.

headline: Democrats Work to Defy History in Georgia Runoffs That Have Favored G.O.P.
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The special elections were devised by white lawmakers to dilute the power of Black voters. But those involved in earlier contests say demographic change and Democratic energy could allow the party to finally beat the odds.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A first-term senator in Georgia narrowly bested his opponent, outrunning his party’s standard-bearer only to face voters again a few weeks later under a quirky system that briefly made the state the center of the political universe after a hard-fought presidential election.

headline: ‘It’s Traumatizing’: Coronavirus Deaths Are Climbing Once Again
abstract: Deaths are far below the rate of the spring, when as many as 2,200 people were dying every day, but experts warn they are rising fast.
lead_paragraph: By the time Doug Raysby’s wife was allowed to enter his hospital room, it was too late to be sure whether he even knew she was there. After a feverish fight with the coronavirus, he lay unconscious on the bed. His wife cried through an N95 mask, while a computer tablet flashed a video stream of his children saying goodbye.

headline: ‘You Cannot Say No’: The Reign of Terror That Sustains Belarus’s Leader
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Political Prisoners', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Despite hundreds of thousands protesting against him for months, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko has been able to cling to power thanks to an all-pervasive security system.
lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — Appalled by savage police violence at the start of Belarus’s would-be revolution, the host of a popular morning show on state television quit his job in protest and declared that his country’s veteran leader, no matter how brutal, would never “force Belarusians back into the box they existed in for these 26 years.”

headline: When the White House Was Full of Claws, Scales, Stripes and Tails
abstract: The long tradition of presidential pets is set to resume this January with two German shepherds belonging to President-elect Joe Biden. Their predecessors weren’t always cats and dogs.
lead_paragraph: Residents of the White House have had fur and feathers, claws and hooves, scales, stripes and prehensile tails. Some were found on the property, many came with the new tenants and others were delivered by foreign leaders. But for most of modern U.S. history, the president has had a pet.

headline: Thousands rally in Washington as clashes erupt.
abstract: Thousands of supporters of President Trump protesting the outcome of the election rallied in Washington on Saturday, earning a brief drive-by visit from the president himself, in a day of orderly demonstrations that devolved into violence as the night wore on.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of supporters of President Trump protesting the outcome of the election rallied in Washington on Saturday, earning a brief drive-by visit from the president himself, in a day of orderly demonstrations that devolved into violence as the night wore on.

headline: Sainted Too Soon? Vatican Report Cast John Paul II in Harsh New Light
keywords: ['Beatifications and Canonizations', 'Popes', 'Priests', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The former pope was fast-tracked for canonization immediately after his death. But a tarnished legacy in dealing with the church’s sex abuse scandals has left critics to wonder whether it was too fast.
lead_paragraph: ROME — At the funeral of Pope John Paul II at St. Peter’s Square, banners rose from the sea of mourners reading “Santo Subito,” or “Saint at Once.” He was a giant of the church in the 20th century, spanning the globe, inspiring generations of believers with his youthful magnetism, then aged infirmity, and, as the Polish pope, he helped bring down Communism over his more than 26-year reign.

headline: Lynn Kellogg, who found the spotlight in ‘Hair,’ dies at 77.
abstract: Lynn Kellogg Simpers, a singer and actress who, as Lynn Kellogg, played Sheila, the uptight debutante who turns into a free-spirited hippie in the original 1968 Broadway production of “Hair,” died on Thursday in St. Louis. She was 77.
lead_paragraph: Lynn Kellogg Simpers, a singer and actress who, as Lynn Kellogg, played Sheila, the uptight debutante who turns into a free-spirited hippie in the original 1968 Broadway production of “Hair,” died on Thursday in St. Louis. She was 77.

headline: Economic Demands Test Biden Even Before Inauguration
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'Recession and Depression', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With the recovery slowing and coronavirus cases surging, Democrats must decide whether quick action on federal aid is more important than its scale.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s first economic test is coming months before Inauguration Day, as a slowing recovery and accelerating coronavirus infections give new urgency to talks on government aid to struggling households and businesses.

headline: Do I Really Have to Quarantine if I Visit Family for Thanksgiving?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Indoor gatherings with family and friends are still considered a high-risk activity, but there are ways to reduce your quarantine time.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’m planning to visit family in Arlington, Va., over Thanksgiving. It’s a nonstop drive, and I’ll be staying with relatives who have been very careful. Do I really need to quarantine when I return to my Manhattan co-op? I can’t imagine it’s any riskier than having dinner with family in Brooklyn or New Jersey.

headline: Lee Hyo-jae, Champion of Women’s Rights in South Korea, Dies at 95
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Ms. Lee was a prominent activist and a founder of women’s studies programs. She also stood up to the country’s dictators.
lead_paragraph: When Lee Hyo-jae learned of a university colleague’s research into the Korean “comfort women” who were taken by the Japanese military for use as sex slaves during World War II, she came to view them as victims of one of history’s most brutal war crimes.

headline: Detroit’s Famous Lemon-Glazed Poundcake
abstract: Double the glaze.
lead_paragraph: This weekend make Otis Lee’s poundcake, adapted by CC Allen, from Mr. Fofo’s Deli in Detroit (above), Melissa Clark’s pumpkin sticky toffee puddings for two or Aaron Hutcherson’s brussels sprouts with honey and miso. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: ‘Yogurt Ladies’ of South Korea Deliver More Than Dairy
keywords: ['Yogurt', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Women and Girls', 'Food Trucks and Vendors']
abstract: They were among the country’s first women to work outside the home, helping establish South Korea’s taste for dairy products. And these beloved “yakult ajummas” are still making their rounds.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — An hour before dawn, Kang Hye-jeong was already ​out cruising on her battery-run mobile refrigerator, briskly moving through alleys in Cheongdam-dong, a district of southern Seoul.

headline: This Coronavirus Surge Does Not Have to Be So Horrific
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Quarantines', 'Masks', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: America is entering a difficult period. But the outcome is not foregone.
lead_paragraph: In the spring, when the coronavirus was spreading across the planet, Americans took steps — slow and uneven as they might have been — to bring the first U.S. outbreaks under control. Houses of worship and nonessential businesses closed. People resigned themselves to wearing masks in public. They worked from home if they could, to reduce the risk to those who could not.

headline: Goodbye, Golden Goose
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Time for Donald Trump to head down Sunset Boulevard.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Many see a wannabe despot barricaded in the bunker, stubby fingers clinging to the levers of power as words that mean nothing to him — democracy, electoral integrity, peaceful transition, constitutionality — swirl above.

headline: The Coronavirus Saved My Life
abstract: If I hadn’t gone in for a test, I wouldn’t have learned I had stage four metastatic lung cancer. I guess that’s a perverse kind of luck.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — This summer, I walked into an urgent care clinic for a coronavirus test and walked out with stage four metastatic lung cancer.

headline: What Democrats Are Up Against in Georgia
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Senate contenders face not just Republicans but also the state’s political history, which shows that change doesn’t come easy.
lead_paragraph: We are all Georgians now. Or at least that’s how it feels with the eyes of the nation focused on Georgia and its two U.S. Senate runoff elections on Jan. 5, which will determine party control of the Senate. Raphael Warnock, a Democrat, will face off against the Republican Senator Kelly Loeffler, and Jon Ossoff, a Democrat, will attempt to unseat the Republican Senator David Perdue.

headline: Mold, Possums and Pools of Sewage: No One Should Have to Live Like This
abstract: Before she died of Covid-19, Pamela Rush opened her home to show the world what poverty looks like.
lead_paragraph: My story starts in Lowndes County, Ala., a place that’s been called Bloody Lowndes because of its violent, racist history. It’s part of Alabama’s Black Belt, a broad strip of rich, dark soil worked and inhabited largely by poor Black people who, like me, are descendants of slaves. Our ancestors were ripped from their homes and brought here to pick the cotton that thrived in the fertile earth.

headline: A Girl Raised in Isolation Stumbles on an Exit
abstract: “Cleo Porter and the Body Electric,” a lighthearted adventure written before the pandemic, imagines a post-virus world eerily like the one we now inhabit.
lead_paragraph: CLEO PORTER AND THE BODY ELECTRICBy Jake Burt

headline: Biden Asked Republicans to Give Him a Chance. They’re Not Interested.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Joe Biden promised not only to win, but to “restore the soul of the nation.” But the deep divisions that animated President Trump’s tenure show no signs of receding.
lead_paragraph: MASON, Texas — The change at the Sunday prayer service was so subtle it went unnoticed by several congregants. Tucked in between calls for divine health and wisdom, the Rev. Fred Krebs of St. Paul Lutheran Church, who rarely brings up politics, fleetingly mentioned this month’s presidential election.

headline: As a G.O.P. Playbook on Voter Fraud Falls Flat, Some Ask: What’s Next?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Absentee Voting', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting and Voters', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In dozens of lawsuits, Republicans tried to make voting and counting votes harder. After a record turnout and a Democratic presidential win, some wonder if that’s the party’s best strategy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was an election where Republican charges of fictitious voter fraud took center stage before, during and after the count, backed by a barrage of lawsuits intent on making it harder to cast or tally votes.

headline: To Celebrate Diwali Is to Celebrate the Light
abstract: Diwali is a celebration of light. It reminds me that we can help one another get through the darkest times. And it comes at an especially grim time in our country.
lead_paragraph: Diwali became my American holiday.

headline: Trump Waves to Supporters Protesting Election Results
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Demonstrators gathered in Washington on Saturday, echoing President Trump’s unfounded claims of election fraud. He waved to some of them from his motorcade as he was en route to his private golf club in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators gathered in Washington on Saturday, echoing President Trump’s unfounded claims of election fraud. He waved to some of them from his motorcade as he was en route to his private golf club in Virginia.

headline: It Took a Century to Open a Mosque in Athens. Then Came the Pandemic.
abstract: The first purpose-built Muslim place of worship in the Greek capital since the Ottoman occupation arrived after decades of delay — just in time for a second coronavirus surge.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The mosque that took more than a century to open, surviving legal, political and financial challenges, has closed in less than a week, a temporary victim of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Joanna Harcourt-Smith, 74, Dies; Lived a ‘Psychedelic Love Story’
abstract: For an adventurous globe-trotting time, she was by the side of the LSD guru Timothy Leary, only to be left traumatized by the experience.
lead_paragraph: Joanna Harcourt-Smith was a 26-year-old European socialite in Switzerland in 1972 when she met Timothy Leary, the psychedelic Pied Piper to the flower children of the 1960s.

headline: Variety: Jelly Roll
abstract: Eric Berlin returns with another sweet and twisted new venture.
lead_paragraph: JELLY ROLL — As far as I can tell, this is Eric Berlin’s second new variety creation for us in 2020, another example of his gift of weaving sets of entries together in interesting ways. This puzzle looks like a spiral, but instead of solving two sets of clues in two directions, you solve everything reading from the outside of the spiral in. In that respect, it’s easier and less confusing, but there’s an additional layer of intricacy that makes it a nice challenge.

headline: Trump Twittertorium
abstract: A reader suggests an alternative to the traditional presidential library.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Divided Country: What Can Be Done?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers criticize Democrats for being too “woke” and not communicating their ideas better, urge a pardon of the president, suggest separation into two different countries, and more.

headline: Giuliani adds fuel to discredited theories about voting machines.
abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the president’s personal lawyer, continued on Saturday his effort to delegitimize votes cast through electronic voting machines, citing several conspiracies connected to the companies that make the machines and the software they run in a post on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the president’s personal lawyer, continued on Saturday his effort to delegitimize votes cast through electronic voting machines, citing several conspiracies connected to the companies that make the machines and the software they run in a post on Twitter.

headline: Western Sahara Independence Group Ends Truce With Morocco
keywords: ['Territorial Disputes', 'War and Armed Conflicts', 'Politics and Government', 'Secession and Independence Movements']
abstract: One of Africa’s longest-simmering conflicts erupts back into the open.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The leader of a pro-independence group in Western Sahara declared war Saturday on Morocco, shattering a three-decade-long cease-fire and threatening a full-blown military conflict in the disputed desert territory in northwest Africa.

headline: As if We Didn’t Have Enough to Worry About …
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Transition (US)']
abstract: Trump shuffles the Pentagon leadership, raising anxieties more.
lead_paragraph: A presidential transition can be a perilous time in the world. That’s particularly true when the departing president denies that he is departing and fires America’s top defense officials.

headline: Au Revoir but Not Adieu
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: For 12 years as a columnist I wore my “heart out after the unattainable.”
lead_paragraph: When I was a younger man, a quarter-century ago, I clambered into the armored Land Rover provided by this newspaper to cover the Bosnian war. It was, at the best of times, an unbalanced vehicle. At the worst, it would shudder as if possessed. I was headed from Sarajevo back to Paris to see my third child born. There was no other way home. The airport, under fire from Serbian artillery, was closed.

headline: Iran Denies That Al Qaeda Leader Was Killed in Tehran
abstract: The denial came in the wake of a New York Times report that quoted intelligence officials as saying the terror group’s No. 2 leader was killed on the street in Tehran in August.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s Foreign Ministry on Saturday denied a report that Israeli agents had fatally shot Al Qaeda’s second-ranking leader on the streets of Tehran, likening it to a “Hollywood” scenario manufactured by “American and Zionist” officials.

headline: Theme Shmeme
abstract: Caitlin Reid just couldn’t stay away, on a Sunday.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Caitlin Reid, it’s been too long! That’s right — we had a collaboration just last weekend, with Evan Kalish and a theme; you know, a regular Sunday. Now, Ms. Reid is solo, no net, no nothing — just a ton of crisp, interesting cluing, long entries and some great debuts in a big open grid.

headline: Masters Mentorship Puts Tournament Rookies on Top
abstract: On Saturday, 14 first-timers made the rain-delayed cut, a Masters record. Many of them benefited from pretournament sessions with seasoned Masters veterans.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — By the time he reached Augusta National Golf Club’s 17th tee during Monday’s practice round, Cameron Champ had talked with his stand-in coach and tour guide about his upcoming wedding and how to navigate the course’s greens.

headline: Largely Out of Sight in Washington, Kamala Harris Preps for White House
keywords: ['Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Transition (US)']
abstract: Ms. Harris has barely appeared on the public radar since her acceptance speech last Saturday in Wilmington, Del., where she declared “a new day for America.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a chic cafe in the West End neighborhood here, a young waiter knew that the incoming vice president lived “upstairs,” as he noted by gesturing to an upscale condominium building overhead, but said he had not actually seen her lately.

headline: Dustin Johnson Widens Masters Lead and Eyes Scoring Record
abstract: The No. 1-ranked golfer played in one lead-up event before the Masters after a positive coronavirus test felled him in October. Despite the rust, he leads the field by four strokes after three rounds.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Perhaps it is fitting that the player leading the biggest golf tournament of 2020 prepared for the event last month by self-isolating in a hotel room for 11 days after a positive coronavirus test result.

headline: Disappearance and Death of Louisiana Teen Raises Questions About Police Response
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Search and Seizure', 'Missing Persons', 'Children and Childhood', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Autopsies', 'Photography', 'Amber Alert', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: Quawan Charles was found dead in a field in rural Louisiana days after he had vanished. Now his family is asking whether his death could have been prevented with a faster response.
lead_paragraph: Days after his family had reported him missing, Quawan Charles, 15, was found dead in a sugar cane field, more than 20 miles from his home in Baldwin, La., his face badly disfigured.

headline: Quotation of the Day: States Aren’t Ready to Distribute Shots
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 15, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “This is going to be a phenomenal logistical feat, to vaccinate everybody in the country. We absolutely have zero margin for failure. We really have to get this right.”

headline: Cook Up Some Scallion Pancakes or Horror Stories
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Dancing', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Art', 'Writing and Writers', 'Music', 'Books and Literature', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Theater', 'Museums', 'Pancakes', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Handicrafts', 'Scallions']
abstract: Spend the week getting swept up in classic dance, admiring a sloth or listening to Soccer Mommy.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Not Traveling for the Holidays? ReLAX With an Airport-Related Game
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Airports', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Puzzles']
abstract: Airport codes will finish the Thanksgiving-themed phrases, and the boarding passes reveal a secret image and holiday message.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans won’t be visiting relatives for Thanksgiving this year in light of the pandemic. With this puzzle you can still experience the thrill of travel, minus the crowds. Fill in each Thanksgiving-related phrase on the departure board using airport codes from the boarding passes.

headline: Break the Cycle of Insomnia
keywords: ['Sleep', 'Insomnia', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Meditation']
abstract: If you are not sleeping well these days, you’re not alone.
lead_paragraph: It’s 3 a.m. and you’ve been struggling for hours to fall asleep. Morning draws nearer and your anxiety about being exhausted the next day intensifies — yet again. If this sounds familiar, you’re not alone.

headline: Take the Edge Off With Video Games
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Unlike loud, stress-inducing shoot-’em-ups, these ones are meant to calm the mind and offer moments of quiet and clarity.
lead_paragraph: Take a deep breath. Hold it for five seconds. Exhale. Breathe in for three seconds. Repeat. How does that feel? A little better? Good. We’re living in stressful times, and any moment of calm is welcome.

headline: Take a Break From Political Comedy With These Podcasts
abstract: Now that the election is in the rearview mirror, release the last of the tension with funny audio shows on the lighter side of things.
lead_paragraph: Having trouble sleeping lately? Racing thoughts? Agita? Perhaps you are looking to ease the emotional hangover from that nail-biter of a presidential election. Utterly apolitical podcasts are just the ticket. These shows are not current events- or pop culture-based. They are not trying to teach you anything. They do not seek to challenge you, or stretch your brain in any way. Instead, the hosts of these shows have one goal: to make you laugh. Tuning in to any of these goofy podcasts to relax, unwind and giggle.

headline: It’s Time to Tackle the Garage
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Lighting', 'Orderliness and Clutter', 'Storage', 'Garages (Residential)']
abstract: There is supposed to be room for cars and you’re probably never going to use that old paint. Here’s how to bring order to your home’s last messy place.
lead_paragraph: Days spent at home have moved even the most muddled people to organize. The spice rack now displays alphabetically ordered bottles in neat rows. The closet has sections for formal and informal wear, subdivided by season. Pots and pans are arranged by type, the silverware drawer is a model of organizational excellence. But the garage is still overflowing with who-knows-what, piled here, there and everywhere. Time to organize.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 15, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 15, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the musical “Lone Star Love,” relying on information from one of the show’s producers, described incorrectly the timing and purpose of an $81,000 payment. The producers Ed and Eleanor Burke made the payment as severance to members of the show’s company before it closed, not to pay a fine by Actors’ Equity against Randy Quaid.

headline: China-Led Trade Pact Is Signed, in Challenge to U.S.
keywords: ['Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'International Relations', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: The deal sealed on Sunday stands as a potent symbol of Beijing’s growing economic sway in Southeast Asia at a time of uncertainty over Washington’s economic ties with the region.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — After eight years of talks, China and 14 other nations from Japan to New Zealand to Myanmar on Sunday formally signed one of the world’s largest regional free trade agreements, a pact shaped by Beijing partly as a counterweight to American influence in the region.

headline: In ‘A Promised Land,’ Barack Obama Thinks — and Thinks Some More — Over His First Term
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former president recounts his political ascent and offers close-up views of the major issues he faced during his first years in the White House.
lead_paragraph: [The Best Books of 2020: View our full list.]

headline: ‘It Was Hard Not to Eavesdrop on the Two Men at the Next Table’
abstract: At lunch in a busy restaurant, a homework assignment on the roof and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Her Abuse Was a ‘Family Matter,’ Until It Went Live
keywords: ['Domestic Violence', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Politics and Government', 'Immolation']
abstract: The grisly death of a farmer, whose attack was streamed online, has shocked China, with many asking why the legal system failed to protect her.
lead_paragraph: Lhamo, a Tibetan farmer in southwestern China, lived her life mostly outdoors and shared it online, posting videos of herself cooking, singing and picking herbs in the mountains around her village. By this fall, she had about 200,000 followers, many of whom praised her as cheerful and hardworking.

headline: A Watchdog Accused Officers of Serious Misconduct. Few Were Punished.
abstract: An analysis by The New York Times found that the N.Y.P.D. has reduced or rejected recommendations for stiff discipline of officers in about 71 percent of 6,900 serious misconduct charges.
lead_paragraph: One New York City police officer was accused of pepper-spraying a woman, then denying her medical treatment while she was handcuffed in a Bronx holding cell.

headline: Readers Have Been Eagerly Waiting for Barack Obama’s New Memoir. Struggling Booksellers Have, Too.
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Small Business']
abstract: “A Promised Land” is a potential lifeline for booksellers whose sales have plummeted during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after President Barack Obama left office in 2017, in the aftermath of a contentious election that cost his party the presidency, he sat down with a yellow notepad and began writing an account of his time in the White House.

headline: Want a Preview of President Biden? Look to the Campaign Trail
abstract: He is returning to a Washington he knows well. And the path he took to get back offers a road map for how he’ll govern.
lead_paragraph: Like President Bill Clinton, Joseph R. Biden Jr. is an empathetic extrovert with a sprawling network of friends. Like President George W. Bush, he maintains strict personal discipline (for Mr. Biden, that meant Peloton rides and protein shakes this year, to offset an ice cream habit).

headline: To Survive the Pandemic, Savile Row Cuts a Bespoke Strategy
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Seamstresses and Tailors', 'Coats and Jackets', 'Suits (Apparel)', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: With formal events and travel canceled, the tradition-bound tailors are gently embracing technology — and finding leverage on their landlords.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One morning in early November, a tailor on Savile Row took the measurements of a client 5,500 miles away with the help of a robot. The tailor, Dario Carnera, sat on the second floor of Huntsman, one of the street’s most venerable houses, and used the trackpad on his laptop to guide the robot around a client who stood before mirrors in a clothing store in Seoul. Mr. Carnera was visible and audible to the client through an iPad-like panel that doubled as the robot’s face.

headline: Staying Apart, But Praying Together
abstract: As the coronavirus surges again, houses of worship in New York struggle to serve their communities safely.
lead_paragraph: Emilio Arteaga, the beloved longtime deacon at St. Agatha’s, a Roman Catholic church in Brooklyn, died from Covid-19 on Good Friday this year. It was not until 10 days later that just a handful of priests and nuns were able to mark the occasion by reciting a single prayer over his casket, in the middle of 49th Street.

headline: Swing State Voters Look to the Future
abstract: In the days after the election, Times reporters went to four swing state counties with some of the tightest vote margins to see how people were feeling. The answer? Still pretty divided.
lead_paragraph: In the days after the election, Times reporters went to four swing state counties with some of the tightest vote margins to see how people were feeling. The answer? Still pretty divided.

headline: With Trench Warfare Deepening, Parties Face Unsettled Electoral Map
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'States (US)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Voters delivered a convincing victory for Joe Biden, but a split decision for the two parties. Now Democrats and Republicans face perhaps the most up-for-grabs electoral landscape in a generation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America’s two major parties had hoped the 2020 presidential election would render a decisive judgment on the country’s political trajectory. But after a race that broke records for voter turnout and campaign spending, neither Democrats nor Republicans have achieved a dominant upper hand.

headline: Reinventing the Newspaper, Week After Week
abstract: What can you make out of The Times? Catapults, roller coasters and piñatas for starters, thanks to the At Home team.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: After a Writing Break, She Returned as a Booker Finalist
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Man Booker Prize']
abstract: Tsitsi Dangarembga’s debut novel, “Nervous Conditions,” made her part of the African literary canon. Decades later, “This Mournable Body” has made her a contender for one of the world’s top book prizes.
lead_paragraph: When Tsitsi Dangarembga’s debut novel “Nervous Conditions” was published in 1988, it was hailed as one of the 20th century’s most significant works of African literature.

headline: Biden Faces Early Test With Immigration and Homeland Security After Trump
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The Department of Homeland Security was molded in President Trump’s image, and not just on immigration policy. President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will have work to do to remake it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has said that one of his first priorities will be rolling back his predecessor’s restrictive immigration policies. To do it, he may have to overhaul the Department of Homeland Security, which has been bent to President Trump’s will over the past four years.

headline: Coronavirus Surge, 2020 Election, the Masters: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: The Vaccine Boost
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy', 'Science and Technology', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: Markets rallied around promising vaccine trials, but soaring infection rates show that the worst may be yet to come.
lead_paragraph: Greetings from the four walls of my apartment, which I don’t plan to leave until I drive to my parents’ house for Thanksgiving. Forecasters are predicting a drop in travel by at least 10 percent for the holiday, but health officials hope even more people stay put. Be safe and enjoy those early Black Friday sales from your couch. — Charlotte Cowles

headline: The 2020 Masters: Dustin Johnson Sets Scoring Record
abstract: Dustin Johnson won the Masters at 20 under, five strokes ahead of Australia’s Cameron Smith and Sungjae Im of South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Dustin Johnson won the 2020 Masters and set a scoring record at 20 under par, two strokes better than the former record, held jointly by Tiger Woods and Jordan Spieth. Johnson, who grew up an hour away, in South Carolina, became the first world No. 1 to win the event since Woods in 2001.

headline: A Chagall Curtain Needs a New Home With a Tall Ceiling
abstract: A 65-foot-tall stage curtain that the artist created for the Metropolitan Opera in the 1960s will go up for auction Tuesday at Bonhams.
lead_paragraph: Wanted: art lover with deep pockets and a high ceiling — a very high ceiling. A 65-foot-high ceiling, 20 feet taller than the Hollywood sign, 25 feet taller than a telephone pole and 46 feet taller than a full-grown giraffe.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Hard Times’
abstract: How the folk duo Gillian Welch and David Rawlings held onto optimism.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2018, Hanif Abdurraqib, the author of today’s narrated story, saw the folk duo Gillian Welch and David Rawlings perform live at an outdoor show in Virginia.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $675,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: It’s time to start planning for Thanksgiving — we can help! — but, in the meantime, keep it simple with a lemon-garlic-kale salad and huli huli chicken.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Thanksgiving planning begins in earnest today, even if you’ll be serving only yourself on the day. It’s self-care of a sort to clean out the refrigerator and freezer to make room for your disks of pie crust; your unbaked biscuits; your make-ahead stock. It’s self-care to shop for the dry goods you’ll need, the wines you want to drink. The work is soothing and intentional. It has a little hope to it, too: that together, apart, despite the pandemic, we’ll somehow make something special of the holiday this year, sacrificing our usual excess in the name of Thanksgivings to come.

headline: When a Leader Just Won’t Go
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Wisdom from Shakespeare to Dickens to ‘Seinfeld’ on President Trump’s long non-goodbye.
lead_paragraph: In Nancy Mitford’s comic 1960 novel “Don’t Tell Alfred,” the wife of the new British ambassador to Paris arrives at the embassy to find that she has a vexing problem: Her predecessor has refused to move out.

headline: They Once Ruled Ethiopia. Now They Are Fighting Its Government.
abstract: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed’s two-year feud with the rebellious ruling party of the Tigray region has exploded into a war, with bombings, massacres and ethnic divisions, that threatens to upend the entire Horn of Africa.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — When it comes to mountain warfare, the people of Tigray — an ancient kingdom in the far north of Ethiopia, spread across jagged peaks and lush farmland — have decades of hard-won experience.

headline: With Progressive Politics on March in New Zealand, Maori Minister Blazes New Trails
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Maori', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Nanaia Mahuta, the new foreign minister, brings a reputation as an honest broker to Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern’s cabinet, the most diverse in the country’s history.
lead_paragraph: Nanaia Mahuta entered New Zealand’s Parliament as the youngest Maori woman to ever gain a seat. More than two decades later, she has become the country’s minister of foreign affairs, another trailblazing first. So when she was asked at a recent news conference about another woman of color breaking barriers halfway around the world, she broke into a wide smile.

headline: After War Between Armenia and Azerbaijan, Peace Sees Winners and Losers Swap Places
keywords: ['Peace Process', 'War and Armed Conflicts', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Territorial Disputes']
abstract: A deal brokered by Russia ended the fighting for now over Nagorno-Karabakh, leaving Armenians to pack up and burn their houses as they retreat, while Azerbaijanis plan a return to long-lost lands.
lead_paragraph: KELBAJAR, Azerbaijan — The cars, trucks and vans jamming the mountain roads deep into the night on Saturday brimmed with all the possessions that the fleeing Armenians could rescue: upholstered furniture, livestock, glass doors.

headline: Egypt Unearths New Mummies Dating Back 2,500 Years
keywords: ['Egyptian Civilization', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Coffins', 'Mummies and Mummification', 'Archaeology and Anthropology']
abstract: More than 100 painted wooden coffins, many with bodies, were found in the necropolis of Saqqara, officials said. After several recent finds at the site, it’s the largest discovery there this year.
lead_paragraph: Archaeologists in Egypt have unearthed more than 100 delicately painted wooden coffins, some with mummies inside, and 40 funeral statues in the ancient burial ground of Saqqara, the Egyptian antiquities authorities said, calling the discovery the largest find at the site this year.

headline: When Politics Drives a Wedge Within Families
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Environment', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers share experiences and a historical perspective. Also: Environmental justice.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: We’re Friends at the Office. Remember the Office?
abstract: Readers reflect on the change brought on by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sex-Abuse Claims Against Boy Scouts Now Surpass 82,000
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The deluge of sex-abuse filings, coming ahead of a bankruptcy deadline, far surpasses the number of claims filed in Catholic Church cases.
lead_paragraph: More than 82,000 people have come forward with sex-abuse claims against the Boy Scouts of America, describing a decades-long accumulation of assaults at the hands of scout leaders across the nation who had been trusted as role models.

headline: Peru’s President Steps Down After Just 6 Days, Leaving Country Adrift
abstract: Manuel Merino took power after Congress pushed out Peru’s popular president. In office less than a week, he faced mounting opposition from protesters.
lead_paragraph: Facing widespread opposition, Peru’s interim president stepped down on Sunday, his sixth day on the job, plunging a country already facing an economic tailspin and a devastating pandemic into a constitutional crisis.

headline: Doctors Are Calling It Quits Under Stress of the Pandemic
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Telemedicine', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'your-feed-healthcare', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: Thousands of medical practices are closing, as doctors and nurses decide to retire early or shift to less intense jobs.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Dr. Kelly McGregory opened her own pediatric practice just outside Minneapolis, where she could spend as much time as she wanted with patients and parents could get all of their questions answered.

headline: Erdogan’s Visit to Northern Cyprus Stokes Decades-Long Dispute
abstract: The Turkish president visited the island’s Turkish-occupied north, angering Cypriot and Greek officials and inflaming tensions.
lead_paragraph: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey on Sunday visited disputed territory in northern Cyprus that is occupied by Turkish forces, angering Cypriot and Greek leaders and stoking a decades-long conflict.

headline: Catch the Vibe: Club Culture Comes to Life at Lincoln Center
abstract: The choreographer Ephrat Asherie unveils her short film “UnderScored,” which pays homage to the history of the underground scene and its veterans.
lead_paragraph: It’s more than just another dance film born during the pandemic, because it is more than a dance. It’s a celebration of a culture: the underground scene of New York City.

headline: A Pianist Loses Himself in a Musical ‘Labyrinth’
abstract: David Greilsammer’s new recording charts a fantastical and disorienting adventure through works spanning centuries.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, in the underground crypt of a church in Harlem, I watched the pianist David Greilsammer perform “Labyrinth,” a program that daringly juxtaposed pieces from across centuries. As a young man, Mr. Greilsammer had a dream that strange, alluring sounds were guiding him through a labyrinth. This recital was his attempt to share that sensation.

headline: When the Critic Is Also the Star. And the Audience.
abstract: Connection or isolation? Intensity or escape? This spate of shows that put the watcher to work are rewarding, but often in contrasting ways.
lead_paragraph: Could we get a volunteer up here?

headline: Your Monday Briefing
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: China and 14 other countries sign huge regional trade deal.
lead_paragraph: China and 14 other nations from Japan to New Zealand signed one of the world’s largest regional free trade agreements on Sunday. The pact, which took eight years to negotiate, could help further cement China as the dominant economic power in its neighborhood.

headline: Dustin Johnson Wins 2020 Masters in Record Fashion
abstract: Johnson, the No. 1-ranked golfer in the world, won with a score of 20 under par, the first player to reach that total at Augusta National.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — For 10 years, Dustin Johnson’s chase for career-defining, major championship titles was tinged with ruthless angst, misfortune and calamitous setbacks.

headline: Where Is the Smithsonian Museum for American Latinos?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Museums', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'National Mall (Washington, DC)']
abstract: Our stories still don’t have a permanent home in our nation’s capital.
lead_paragraph: The National Mall in Washington is where we inaugurate presidents, march for change and learn about America’s history at monuments and the Smithsonian Institution museums. And yet, even as Latinos have helped shape this great nation, our stories don’t have a permanent home in the capital.

headline: Did It Hit 3%? Why Parents and Teachers Are Fixated on One Number
abstract: Weeks after he managed to reopen the New York City school system, Mayor Bill de Blasio is facing fresh questions about if and when to close it.
lead_paragraph: [Read more on NYC school closings due to Covid-19]

headline: The four astronauts are minutes from launching to orbit.
abstract: Four astronauts — three from NASA, one from JAXA, the Japanese space agency — will be sitting inside a SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule, boosted to orbit on top of a Falcon 9 rocket. The mission is known as Crew-1, and the astronauts named their capsule Resilience. They are headed to the International Space Station for a six-month stay.
lead_paragraph: Four astronauts — three from NASA, one from JAXA, the Japanese space agency — will be sitting inside a SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule, boosted to orbit on top of a Falcon 9 rocket. The mission is known as Crew-1, and the astronauts named their capsule Resilience. They are headed to the International Space Station for a six-month stay.

headline: When is the launch and how can I watch it?
abstract: The Crew-1 mission is scheduled to launch on Sunday at 7:27 p.m. Eastern time from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. NASA Television will broadcast coverage beginning at 3:15 p.m. Or you can watch it in the video player at the top of this page.
lead_paragraph: The Crew-1 mission is scheduled to launch on Sunday at 7:27 p.m. Eastern time from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. NASA Television will broadcast coverage beginning at 3:15 p.m. Or you can watch it in the video player at the top of this page.

headline: Victor Glover will be the first Black crew member on the space station.
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'International Space Station', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Engineering and Engineers']
abstract: NASA, which has worked to spotlight the “hidden figures” in its history, but has so far sent only 14 Black Americans to space.
lead_paragraph: In the 20-some years that people have been living aboard the International Space Station, its extended crew has never included a Black astronaut. Victor J. Glover, a Navy commander and test pilot who joined the astronaut corps in 2013, will be the first.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 16, 2020
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.

headline: Tiger Woods Faced Disaster at the Masters. He Stuck Through It Anyway.
abstract: After a horrific appearance at No. 12, the five-time Masters winner did not fade — even with no hope of another green jacket and almost no one around to watch.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods had just birdied three holes on Sunday at the Masters when he stood at the tee box at No. 18. A few of the men sitting around the 17th green did not bother to watch.

headline: Succeed in Life
abstract: Jennifer Nutt’s Monday puzzle puts us through our paces.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — This is a really fun grid to start the week! I think the theme builds like a midweek construction; its author, Jennifer Nutt, has made puzzles for Mondays through Wednesdays in the past. One thing that makes it a Monday puzzle is the revealer, with a clear explanation of what you’re looking for; I feel that there’s a thematic Easter egg in the downs, though, and I just love that.

headline: Your Guide to Black Friday Shopping
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Watch out for “deals” that aren’t really deals.
lead_paragraph: Black Friday, once a one-day blowout sale, has steadily ballooned over the past few years. Black Friday is now, in essence, Cyber Month — it’s not uncommon to see Black Friday sales promoted weeks ahead of the day itself.

headline: The Hot New Covid Tech Is Wearable and Constantly Tracks You
keywords: ['Wearable Computing', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Sensors', 'Mobile Applications', 'Workplace Environment', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Contact Tracing (Public Health)', 'Bluetooth Wireless Technology', 'Innovation']
abstract: Sports leagues, large employers and colleges are turning to devices that could usher in more invasive forms of surveillance.
lead_paragraph: In Rochester, Mich., Oakland University is preparing to hand out wearable devices to students that log skin temperature once a minute — or more than 1,400 times per day — in the hopes of pinpointing early signs of the coronavirus.

headline: Barreling Toward Central America, Iota Becomes a Category 4 Hurricane
abstract: The storm, the second hurricane to strike Central America in less than two weeks, was expected to produce catastrophic winds and up to 30 inches of rain all week.
lead_paragraph: PUERTO CABEZAS, Nicaragua — Iota was upgraded to a Category 4 hurricane early Monday morning, the National Hurricane Center said, warning that the storm was likely to bring catastrophic winds, life-threatening storm surge and extreme rainfall to Central America, an area still recovering from Hurricane Eta less than two weeks ago.

headline: Roger Jepsen, Senator From Iowa and Reagan Ally, Dies at 91
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A voice for farmers, he lost a re-election bid after it was disclosed that he had joined a health spa that was shut down on prostitution charges.
lead_paragraph: Roger W. Jepsen, an Iowa Republican and Reagan administration ally who served one term in the Senate before losing a 1984 re-election bid after it was revealed that he had joined a private health spa that was later shut down on prostitution charges, died on Friday in Bettendorf, Iowa. He was 91.

headline: Giants Make a Case to Win the Grim N.F.C. East
abstract: Daniel Jones threw accurate passes and had a 34-yard touchdown run as the Giants (3-7) moved a half-game back of Philadelphia in the once-grand division.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The N.F.L. isn’t going to disband the N.F.C. East, that wretched assemblage of teams galloping toward collective infamy. Nor, at last check, does it plan to rescind the division’s automatic postseason berth as punishment for producing such unsightly football week after week after week.

headline: Hiker Rescued From Mount Rainier Makes ‘Miraculous’ Recovery
abstract: When Michael Knapinski arrived at a Seattle hospital, his heart stopped for 45 minutes and he was put on life support. Two days later, he was walking.
lead_paragraph: Michael Knapinski was hiking in Mount Rainier National Park last Saturday when he got lost in blinding snow and freezing conditions.

headline: Behind Trump’s Yearslong Effort to Turn Losing Into Winning
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Absentee Voting', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'States (US)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Even before he was elected in 2016, Donald J. Trump was building a conspiracy theory about voter fraud that took on new energy this year, as his political fortunes ebbed during the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The trouble broke out inside the main counting room in Detroit late on the morning of Nov. 4.

headline: ‘Rumble in the Bronx’ Fight Club Drew 200. The Sheriff Shut It Down.
abstract: The fight club would have been illegal even before the pandemic. Parties in Manhattan and Brooklyn this weekend were also closed down for violating pandemic rules.
lead_paragraph: More than 200 people stood shoulder to shoulder shouting as two men sparred at the center of a Bronx warehouse. Some people hung over the barricades, social media showed, craning their necks for a better view. When one man knocked out the other, the crowd erupted in a thunderous roar.

headline: Trump, the Absolute Worst Loser
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: He has spent his life gaming the system, so it’s no surprise that he can’t accept defeat.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump lost the election. He knows it. But he won’t admit it.

headline: The New World Order That President Biden Will Inherit
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty', 'United States Politics and Government', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The importance of vision, expertise, honesty and simple decency in the management of world affairs cannot be overstated.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joe Biden has signaled that he will move swiftly to restore dignity to the badly sullied image of the United States; respect for the professionals of America’s diplomatic, intelligence and military services; and a more predictable, nuanced and sympathetic approach to foreign relations. That message of a restoration of norms is likely to resonate in many capitals around the world, as it did with an electorate that gave Mr. Biden a decisive victory over Donald Trump.

Two faculty members at the private school where she teaches were required to quarantine. And in the last few days, so were two of the  students she advises.

The fourth season has fallen into that mid-season trap a little, sacrificing the thematic purposefulness of the early episodes for a little too much plate-spinning. It needed an audacious, standalone hour like this week’s episode to reassert itself again.

headline: Living Near Drilling Is Deadly. Why Don’t California Lawmakers Care?
keywords: ['Drilling and Boring', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Environment', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Politics and Government', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Asthma', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: The state may be phasing out gas-powered cars, but it’s still legal to put an oil well right next to an elementary school.
lead_paragraph: California famously prides itself on environmental leadership — but what about when its lawmakers overlook problems in their own constituents’ backyards? It’s still legal to drill for oil there right next to schools and hospitals — despite well documented health risks to anyone nearby. In the video op-ed above, Josiah Edwards explains what it was like to grow up breathing in the toxic chemicals expelled by drilling. He traces the asthma that plagues his entire family to decades of redlining in Los Angeles County, which consigned Black and brown communities like theirs to live next to active oil wells. Even today, politicians keep rejecting legislation that would help protect Californians from these poisonous emissions. You may not have an oil drill in your backyard now, but if you live in California, there’s nothing stopping one from moving in tomorrow.

headline: Was It Worth It, Jared and Ivanka?
abstract: The glossiest grifters become Vuitton vagabonds.
lead_paragraph: Just five short years ago Jared and Ivanka were dinner-party royalty here in Manhattan. It’s that kind of place. They had money, they had youth, they had celebrity. They were thin. I’m told that their manners were impeccable, so you’d never know that his father was an actual felon and her father a de facto one. Besides, you can’t hold family against someone, can you? We don’t choose how we’re born.

headline: Recipes to Alter Your Mood
abstract: Get out of your head, and make something new, whether its barbecue chicken pizza, mozzarella in carrozza or a lentil-sweet potato salad.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. “Tomorrow was another day, at least by the calendar,” the novelist Patrick O’Brian wrote in “Blue at the Mizzen,” “but the two could hardly be told apart: the heat, the faintly drifting cloud, the ship pitching heavily with no way on her, the flaccid sails, were all the same.” It’s been like that for a lot of us lately, stuck on our ships in the doldrums of lockdown, marking the passage of time with meals that take on an unrelenting sameness: a breakfast, a lunch, a dinner, repeat.

headline: Academy Museum Gives Debbie Reynolds Her Due as a Costume Conservator
abstract: When the “Singin’ in the Rain” actress was alive, the film academy turned up its nose at her fabled costume collection. Now it has gone to her son with hat in hand.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For decades, Debbie Reynolds begged Hollywood to help her preserve and exhibit her vast collection of golden age costumes. “These pieces are cultural touchstones that still carry the energy of the stars who performed in them,” she once said, referring to legends like Elizabeth Taylor and Judy Garland. “There is magic in every thread, button and bow.”

headline: How Accurate Was ‘The Good Lord Bird’?
abstract: Here’s everything you need to know about John Brown’s actual raid at Harpers Ferry, dramatized in Sunday’s series finale of the Showtime historical drama.
lead_paragraph: “The Good Lord Bird,” the Showtime mini-series about the incendiary career of the 19th-century abolitionist John Brown (its seven-episode run ended Sunday night), offered a stylish, consciously cockeyed view of America on the brink of the Civil War — more Lin-Manuel Miranda than Ron Chernow. But its fantastical-seeming story, based on the National Book Award-winning novel of the same name by James McBride, is more factual than casual students of American history might assume.

headline: How Does Ina Do It?
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Social Media', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Thanksgiving Day']
abstract: Ina Garten, a.k.a. the Barefoot Contessa, has a loyal, diverse and growing fan base that follows her anywhere — even through quarantine and a Thanksgiving lockdown.
lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — Ina Garten’s house, on a side street in the stately, manicured village of East Hampton, was just the way you’d want it to be on a sunny morning in October. By which I mean the lawn was a beautiful rumpled green, and the garden was full of cherry tomatoes, and she was wearing a loose button-down shirt and smiling as she brought me coffee in a hotel-style silver carafe. All appeared just as it does on her television show, “Barefoot Contessa,” that has been shot here since 2002.

headline: One Plate to Serve You and Feed the Homeless
abstract: Sales of these limited-edition dinner plates provide meals for the hungry in New York City.
lead_paragraph: If your Thanksgiving this year is an intimate dinner for two, why not pile the turkey and stuffing on a couple of striking plates? Or buy just one for the pie or to give this holiday season? Each 10 ½-inch porcelain plate sold benefits the Coalition for the Homeless, which can provide a meal for 75 people. There are 50 designs in editions of 175 plates, each by artists like Cecily Brown, Yoshitomo Nara, Adam Pendleton, Carmen Herrera, Julie Curtiss and Wade Guyton.

headline: A Cookbook From the Heart of Manhattan’s Chinatown
abstract: “The Nom Wah Cookbook” tells the story of a century-old restaurant on Doyers Street.
lead_paragraph: Nom Wah, the dim sum parlor tucked into the elbow of Doyers Street in the heart of Chinatown since the 1920s, has had its ups and downs. Recently, with Wilson Tang in charge, the trajectory has been up. And Mr. Tang has now written a cookbook that gives a thoughtful history of the place he co-owns, as well as a survey of the evolution of Chinatown and snapshots of places like Po Wing Hong grocery and Aqua Best Seafood. The recipes will not plunder your Sichuan larder as they hew closely to the traditions of Guandong Province from which earlier Chinatown immigrants came. But you will have to stock up on dumpling wrappers to attempt many of the restaurant’s dim sum items. Other, larger-format recipes — like glossy braised shiitake mushrooms, succulent Cantonese-style beef fillet and Mr. Tang’s take on Bolognese sauce over noodles, giving the dish a bit of dan-dan style — were also winners.

headline: A Taste of Paris in Midtown
abstract: Angelina Paris, a staple on the Rue de Rivoli, has brought its confections and tea to New York City.
lead_paragraph: These days, a visit to the Rue de Rivoli across from the Tuileries Gardens in Paris is but a dream, a wish. In the meantime, Angelina — a famous Paris tearoom known for hot chocolate, and an attraction at No. 226 for more than 100 years — has come to New York, with the company’s first American branch. (There are already locations throughout Europe, Asia and the Middle East.) At the entrance to the pale, lightly gilded space, there’s a broad counter for coffee, chocolate and pastries, including the store’s Mont Blanc chestnut confection. Noémie Tessier, a pastry chef from Paris, is now in New York, where she has created a creamy Paris-New York pecan pastry. Sandwiches and packaged goods are sold for take away, and many Angelina products like chocolates, cookies and teas are also available. Some day, the dining room, where breakfast, lunch, tea and dinner will be served at marble tables, will seat 60. For now, it’s about 15. Throughout, the rooms are decorated with Cezanne-esque murals of the South of France.

headline: Postal Service Takes ‘Operation Santa’ Letter Campaign National
abstract: The program encourages postal customers to adopt letters and buy gifts for the children who send them. This year, because of the pandemic, customers will review the letters exclusively online.
lead_paragraph: For more than a century, it was a simple way of making a child’s dreams come true during Christmas. Volunteers could go to the post office, sift through piles of letters that children had sent to Santa Claus and pick one — or more — that tugged at their heartstrings. Gifts were then acquired, wrapped and shipped to families whose space beneath the tree might otherwise be bare.

headline: An Artist Who Paints in Cryptic Pastel Symbols
abstract: Caroline Kent’s canvases explore the power and limits of language — and challenge the modernist canon of abstraction.
lead_paragraph: Even as a child, Caroline Kent was immersed in the language of abstraction. The Chicago-based artist — whose large-scale black canvases evoke cosmic unknowns — grew up alongside her identical twin sister, Christine Leventhal, with whom she shared special methods of communication. Their conversations can still be so elliptical and condensed that they perplex others.

headline: Groupthink Has Left the Left Blind
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'News and News Media', 'Hispanic-Americans']

This month, Donald Trump once again stunned much of the liberal establishment by dramatically beating polling expectations to come within about 80,000 votes of another Electoral College victory.

headline: A Weekend Bakery Sets Up Shop
abstract: The baker Nora Allen sells her burnished sourdoughs on Ludlow Street.
lead_paragraph: After baking in Washington, D.C., at Roberta’s in Brooklyn and the Standard hotel in the East Village of Manhattan, Nora Allen has gone out on her own, with the help of the chef Flynn McGarry. Her rustic little bakery and shop sits on a peninsula at the start of Ludlow Street. But to buy her breads and other items, like croissants and cookies, means dealing with limited weekend openings; the rest of her time is taken up with filling wholesale orders. Her emphasis is on unusual, locally grown grains like teff, spelt, einkorn and emmer, which she mills in her downstairs kitchen. All her breads are sourdough, handsomely burnished and crusty. “I believe that using these grains helps the farmers and the environment,” she said. “Each flour has unique flavor and properties.” Her sturdy baguette is excellent. For now, the bakery is open only on Saturdays and Sundays, 8 a.m. to 3 p.m., but Ms. Allen said she planned to expand her retail hours on Dec. 16.

headline: Ramen From the Masters, Shipped to Your Home
abstract: Sun Noodle’s Ramen Lab returns with an all-star lineup of ramen, ready to be assembled in your kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Big bowls of soup, and ramen noodles with a pedigree, are now available to cook at home from Ramen Lab, the Lower East Side brand owned by Sun Noodle, a wholesale supplier, and the name of their now-closed restaurant. The company has enlisted chefs from five New York-area restaurants to create different ramen, sold frozen and ready to heat and serve in minutes. The participants are Nakamura, Ivan Ramen and Ramen Lab in Manhattan; Za-Ya Ramen in Brooklyn; and Ani Ramen, with several locations in New Jersey. The broths, nicely populated with other ingredients, are rich and complex, but adding a few other items, like fresh greens, scallions, mushrooms or eggs, would not be a mistake.

headline: Heated Car Seats Are an Antidote to Our Grief
abstract: They deliver a pleasure both maternal and sensual, cocooning you like a child in the lap of some warm, benevolent bear.
lead_paragraph: I come from Britain, a middling, gray island of middling, gray weather. Like the national temperament, the climate rarely tends toward the extreme or the spectacular. I’m not inclined to romanticize British sogginess in its actuality — all those leaden skies and damp socks — but I do cherish the language it has produced. “Mizzle” and “dibble” and “smirr” and all those other regional words for precipitation have a gloriously humdrum quality.
