headline: He Finished His First Marathon. Then His Arm Felt Weak.
keywords: ['Exercise', 'Muscles', 'New York City Marathon', 'Marathon Running', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Soon after the race, he could barely straighten one arm. How could running have caused this?
lead_paragraph: It started to drizzle just moments after the 24-year-old man crossed the finish line of the 2017 New York City Marathon. It was his first marathon, and he felt both elated and exhausted as the medal given for completing the brutal race was draped around his neck. A goody bag containing an energy drink was put in his left hand. It felt strangely heavy. His whole body ached and trembled with fatigue, but somehow that left arm felt even more tired. Unconcerned, he switched the bag to his right hand and went in search of his partner.

headline: Poem: A Yearning to Wrinkle
abstract: Even our clothes suffer when they're stuck at home. In this poem, a shirt dreams of the wider world.
lead_paragraph: [The Best Books of 2020: View our full list.]

headline: Four Years of the Trump Administration in Court. One Word Stuck in My Head.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A succession of Trump policies reflected the administration’s spite and heartlessness.

headline: ‘Gram, Are You Sad?’ This Year, We’re Spending the Holidays Alone
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Loneliness', 'Grandparents']
abstract: None of our grandchildren will be at our table for Thanksgiving or Christmas. But the pandemic winter still leaves room for the imagination.
lead_paragraph: As Covid-19 cases in my city climb to record levels and county officials warn the vulnerable among us to shelter in place, I feel as if I’m living in the cursed kingdom of Narnia, in C.S. Lewis’s children’s fantasy “The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe.” In Narnia, it’s “always winter and never Christmas.”

headline: Why 3rd Grade Matters
abstract: Well, many reasons. But Harvard economist Raj Chetty says that’s the age at which America’s “Einsteins” are identified — and lost.
lead_paragraph: Fill out a survey about how you listen to “Sway” at nytimes.com/swaysurvey.

headline: How Do I Make Thanksgiving Grocery Shopping Safer?
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Content Type: Service', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Gloves', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Disease Rates', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Food']
abstract: With coronavirus cases raging across the U.S., holiday food shopping just got more complicated. We asked the experts for advice.
lead_paragraph: So you’ve canceled your Thanksgiving travel plans, quarantined the college student and created a scaled-back, family-only holiday menu. Good job.

headline: Zillow Surfing Is the Escape We All Need Right Now
abstract: Scrolling through real estate listings in far-flung destinations is a way to visualize an alternate life, whether you’re trying to move or not.
lead_paragraph: Millions of people have spent far more time at home than they expected to this year. It’s made many of them daydream about what it might be like to live somewhere else, often while scrolling through listings on Zillow.

headline: A Lifelong Rock Critic Goes Back to the Actual Classics
abstract: In “A Sound Mind,” the British journalist Paul Morley discovers the wonders of classical music.
lead_paragraph: [The Best Books of 2020: View our full list.]

headline: Parents Adjusting to the U.S., Then to Remote Learning
abstract: Families found support after the coronavirus pandemic disrupted their children’s education.
lead_paragraph: Jansy Molina de Maldonado’s son couldn’t speak.

headline: Postpone Thanksgiving and Save Hundreds of Lives
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Giving thanks and getting together safely can be done with far less risk six months from now, an economist says.
lead_paragraph: Let’s postpone Thanksgiving until May 27. By then Americans should have a lot more to be thankful for, including the likely availability of at least two highly effective vaccines, perhaps the freedom to get together with friends and possibly the end of the current economic slump.

headline: David Fincher’s Impossible Eye
abstract: With ‘Mank,’ America’s most famously exacting director tackles the movie he’s been waiting his entire career to make.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Who Will Succeed Mayor de Blasio? New York’s Future May Ride on the Answer
keywords: ['Elections, Mayors', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The pandemic has reshaped the 2021 mayoral race, with the city’s economic and health challenges casting a shadow over social justice issues.
lead_paragraph: As much of New York City was consumed by the presidential election, a campaign for another critical race was already underway.

headline: Anthony Hopkins Makes It Look Simple. (And Maybe It Should Be.)
abstract: In the dementia drama “The Father,” the 82-year-old actor turns in a career-capping performance and yet claims, “No acting required.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Had I misheard Anthony Hopkins?

headline: With Senate Control Hanging in Balance, ‘Crazytown’ Cash Floods Georgia
abstract: After the state went blue in the presidential race, more than $135 million in TV ads have been booked in two Senate runoff elections.
lead_paragraph: The two Georgia runoff elections that will determine control of the Senate, and much of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s ability to enact a Democratic agenda, are already drawing enormous sums of cash, with more than $125 million pouring into the state in only two weeks.

headline: It’s Official: Every Celeb Now Has a Beauty Line
abstract: Some new celebrity brands make sense, some don’t. What’s driving the trend?
lead_paragraph: When Selena Gomez introduced her makeup brand Rare Beauty earlier this year, she was unable to promote it in person because of Covid. Instead, Ms. Gomez took on a role often delegated to a makeup artist: For Sephora, the brand’s exclusive retailer, she filmed all the education and training videos herself, iPhone in selfie mode, duct-taped to her bathroom mirror at home in Los Angeles.

headline: As the Virus Surges, How Much Longer Can New York Avoid a Full Shutdown?
abstract: The state is banking on a variety of less disruptive mandates, even as public health experts and other officials warn that such measures may not be enough.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — Michigan shut down indoor dining and in-person classes at high schools and colleges. Washington banned indoor gatherings with anyone outside your household without a weeklong quarantine. And officials in Oregon closed offices to the public and are limiting the number of people in grocery stores.

headline: Vermont’s Ski Season, on the Brink
abstract: Just as winter was about to start, the state instituted a stricter quarantine and test requirement for visitors, and the snow-sports economy is bracing for the impact.
lead_paragraph: In some ways, it looked as though the pandemic could be good for Vermont’s ski season. With international destinations out of reach and domestic air travel feeling risky, the state had the biggest ski market in the nation — New York and the Northeast corridor — at its doorstep.

headline: Why Covid Caused Such Suffering in Italy’s Wealthiest Region
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hospitals', 'Privatization', 'Medicine and Health', 'Doctors', 'Disease Rates', 'Contact Tracing (Public Health)']
abstract: Lombardy has been overwhelmed by the pandemic, in part because of a poorly executed medical privatization program.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Dr. Chiara Lepora had never imagined being deployed in her home country of Italy. As a physician for the international relief agency Doctors Without Borders, she was accustomed to caring for people in countries like Yemen and South Sudan, amid extreme poverty and war.

headline: Why Charges Against Protesters Are Being Dismissed by the Thousands
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Freedom of Assembly', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Prosecutors declined to pursue many of the cases because they concluded the protesters were exercising their basic civil rights.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Matt Kaufmann loved bringing real-world issues into his classroom, but he never expected he would become a lesson himself. The headlines, however, made it hard to avoid: “Kentucky High School Teacher of the Year Arrested,” blared the local news after he was detained on May 31.

headline: So, Did ‘Bad Things Happen’ With the Election in Philadelphia?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Despite President Trump’s message, the evidence shows no signs of fraud.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden’s lead in the presidential election results in Pennsylvania has now surpassed 81,000 votes, far exceeding Donald Trump’s 44,000-vote victory margin there four years ago. Yet the Trump campaign continues to claim in court huge but incalculable levels of fraud, particularly in Philadelphia.

headline: Will These Two Classic New York Eateries Survive the Pandemic?
abstract: Outdoor dining and takeout may not pull most restaurants through another lockdown. Here’s how the owners of two are making do as they wait for the city to act.
lead_paragraph: It’s never just about the food.

headline: They Championed Venezuela’s Revolution. They Are Now Its Latest Victims.
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: In an effort to complete his consolidation of power, Nicolás Maduro is cracking down on the leftist activists who once supported him, but have begun to speak up against his administration’s corruption and cronyism.
lead_paragraph: GÜIRIA, Venezuela — The host of a popular radio show, “The People’s Combat,” had always diligently praised Venezuela’s governing Socialist Party, even as millions sank into penury under its rule. But when acute gasoline shortages paralyzed his remote fishing town this summer, he strayed from the party line.

headline: ‘Reach Out to Trump Supporters,’ They Said. I Tried.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Muslim Americans']
abstract: I give up.
lead_paragraph: Seventy-three million Americans voted for Donald Trump. He doubled down on all his worst vices, and he was rewarded for it with 10 million more votes than he received in 2016.

headline: N.Y.C.’s Schools Shutdown, Explained
abstract: The mayor may wait until community spread of the virus stabilizes at a lower rate before reopening the buildings.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: States that imposed few restrictions now have the worst outbreaks.
abstract: Coronavirus cases are rising in almost every U.S. state. But the surge is worst now in places where leaders neglected to keep up forceful virus containment efforts or failed to implement basic measures like mask mandates in the first place, according to a New York Times analysis of data from the University of Oxford.
lead_paragraph: Coronavirus cases are rising in almost every U.S. state. But the surge is worst now in places where leaders neglected to keep up forceful virus containment efforts or failed to implement basic measures like mask mandates in the first place, according to a New York Times analysis of data from the University of Oxford.

headline: An Angel on the Shoulder of Your Teenage Driver (or at Least a Snitch)
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Speed Limits and Speeding', 'Parenting']
abstract: Many automakers offer systems that keep an eye on how fast or how far your teenager is traveling.
lead_paragraph: Technological advances have made cars safer in many ways. There are systems that brake if a collision is imminent; warn the driver and take control if the car leaves the lane, and issue alerts when pedestrians are about to step into the road. To those, add systems that will warn parents if their teenager is misbehaving behind the wheel.

headline: An Arms Race in Car Stereos
abstract: Seventeen speakers, meticulously engineered? That can be just the start in luring audiophile car buyers with plenty of cash to spend.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the lengthy era B.B. — Before Bose — the choices for a music-loving car buyer ranged from primitive to over the top.

headline: Introducing ‘Some Kind of Heaven,’ a Film From The Times and Magnolia Pictures
abstract: Behind the gates of a palm-tree-lined fantasyland, three residents and one interloper at America’s largest retirement community strive to find happiness.
lead_paragraph: “Some Kind of Heaven,” Lance Oppenheim’s feature documentary debut, examines the meticulously crafted suburban bliss of The Villages, a self-described “Disneyworld for Retirees” in Sumter County, Fla. Every day is meant to be a good one for the The Villages’ almost 120,000 residents, who occupy their days with group activities ranging from synchronized swimming and cheerleading to tai chi and golf cart parades. Featuring manicured lawns, wide streets, lavish facilities and even a Fountain of Youth, The Villages offers a utopia for residents to live out their golden years.

headline: The Pandemic Economy in 7 Numbers
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: As several areas in the U.S. start to reimpose coronavirus restrictions, we look at some landmark figures that illuminate the depth of the recession and the prospects for recovery.
lead_paragraph: There are several ways to tell the story of the American economy right now.

headline: Virus Words vs. Actions
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: The ebb and flow of coronavirus cases over the last year has obscured a basic truth: We know a lot about how to control the virus’s spread.

headline: ‘Run’ Review: Bad Medicine
abstract: Sarah Paulson plays a menacing parent in this enjoyably ludicrous thriller.
lead_paragraph: If it’s not one thing, it’s your mother. Balancing on the backs of umpteen matriarch-from-hell movies, the director Aneesh Chaganty brings us “Run,” a nifty little thriller whose title pleads for an exclamation point.

headline: ‘Sound of Metal’ Review: When the Music Stops, the Healing Begins
abstract: Riz Ahmed is touchingly credible as a musician who loses his hearing in this unusual drama.
lead_paragraph: Propelled by a distinctive style and a potent lead performance, Darius Marder’s “Sound of Metal” builds a singular tension between silence and noise.

headline: ‘The Twentieth Century’ Review: The Great Weird North
abstract: In Matthew Rankin’s visually exuberant film, a candidate for prime minister copes with fascism and fetishism in a bizarro-world version of Canada’s past.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Rankin’s loony debut feature, “The Twentieth Century,” presents a feverish reimagining of turn-of-the-20th-century Canada. An exuberant feat of visual design, it’s meticulously weird and full of rambunctious humor.

headline: ‘Embattled’ Review: Hitting Back
abstract: This macho drama concerns a mixed martial arts fighter and the son he continues to abuse — in the cage.
lead_paragraph: A testosterone substitute in drama form, “Embattled” practically peacocks onto the screen. The camera starts on its side and rotates upright (big, unconventional shot, suckers!). It then tracks Cash Boykins (Stephen Dorff), a mixed martial arts fighter, as he saunters cage-ward for his latest match. In his first lines, Cash banters about how well-endowed he is. Soon he’s pummeling the skull of a Russian opponent. “Embattled” goes so hard, it puts the ending of “Rocky IV” up front.

headline: ‘The Princess Switch: Switched Again’ Review: A Who’s Who of Hudgens
abstract: A holiday game of musical thrones keeps Vanessa Hudgens whirling through costumes and accents.
lead_paragraph: Who wouldn’t like to spend the winter holidays with good friends at a lavishly decorated palace in the kingdom of Montenaro, where glittering cascades of snow shower the beautiful people almost every time they step outside?

headline: ‘The Last Vermeer’ Review: A Lost Masterpiece Is Only the Beginning
abstract: The Danish actor Claes Bang plays an army officer in the aftermath of World War II, investigating paintings that have fallen into Nazi hands.
lead_paragraph: The dark haired, strapping Danish actor Claes Bang played a museum curator in 2017’s “The Square.” In last year’s “The Burnt Orange Heresy” he played a jaded art critic. In “The Last Vermeer” he plays a Dutchman, working with the Canadian army, after the fall of Germany in World War II, repatriating paintings and sculptures stolen by the Nazis.

headline: ‘Vanguard’ Review: Jackie Chan, More Avuncular Than Action This Time
abstract: Playing a chief executive, Chan mostly observes rather than takes part in this movie’s death-defying stunts.
lead_paragraph: In the 2018 picture “Bleeding Steel,” the daredevil performer Jackie Chan pulled off a remarkable action sequence on top of the Sydney Opera House. Thrilling, and a little surprising. The man turned 66 this year. He’s broken a lot of bones to entertain us during the course of a multidecade career and owes us nothing. But he’s still an international star. If he’s not going to kickbox atop high places, what should he be doing in movies?

headline: ‘Team Marco’ Review: Bocce Will Save Our Youth
abstract: An obnoxious youth is taught the ways of the bocce court in this Staten Island family drama from Julio Vincent Gambuto.
lead_paragraph: In the middling family drama “Team Marco,” 11-year-old Marco (Owen Vaccaro) lives with his mother, Anna (Anastasia Ganias), in Staten Island. His father, Richie (Louis Cancelmi), left them, going west to chase the technological gold rush. Richie talks only about tech and coding, and he encourages Marco’s obsession with video games. Marco in turn rejects offers of friendship, hates the outdoors and is as absent from his own social life as his father is from Marco’s life.

headline: ‘Mangrove’ Review: A Restaurant’s Radicalism
abstract: The first episode in Steve McQueen’s “Small Axe” anthology dramatizes protest and police brutality in 1960s London.
lead_paragraph: The opening sequence of Steve McQueen’s “Mangrove” follows Frank Crichlow (Shaun Parkes) out of a basement gambling parlor and along a few blocks of the west London neighborhood of Notting Hill to the restaurant that gives the film its name. (He’s the owner.) It’s 1968, and the streets are splashed with graffiti attacking immigrants and praising the racist politician Enoch Powell. Those grim omens are balanced by vibrant street life and the buoyant sounds of “Try Me” by Bob Marley and the Wailers on the soundtrack.

headline: ‘Soros’ Review: A Philanthropist in the Spotlight
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Philanthropy', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: This documentary on the Holocaust survivor and successful investor isn’t an objective portrait and doesn’t aspire to be.
lead_paragraph: Opening with a montage in which the financier George Soros is shown as the object of unrelenting anti-Semitic conspiracy theories, the documentary “Soros” positions itself as a corrective. The movie highlights Soros’s life as a Holocaust survivor, successful investor and, mainly, philanthropist. It lays out how Soros contributed to such causes as fighting apartheid, aiding democratizing forces in the Soviet Union and, lately, a closing title card says, helping Covid-19 relief efforts.

headline: Biden Turns Up the Heat on the G.S.A.
abstract: The Trump administration holds out in blocking the transition: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration presses for a recount in Wisconsin, while Nancy Pelosi braces for a thinner majority. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: The surge in coronavirus cases is helping speed up the development of vaccines.
abstract: The surge in coronavirus cases worldwide is helping researchers measure more quickly how well their vaccines protect against Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: There is a slender silver lining to the out-of-control pandemic: It is hastening the testing of vaccines that could eventually end it.

headline: Boeing’s 737 Max is approved to fly again, but there’s more to be done before airlines can start using it.
abstract: It will take weeks, if not months, for American, United and Southwest to get the plane back into service — and reassure travelers about its safety.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration lifted its ban on Boeing’s 737 Max on Wednesday, allowing the plane to return to the skies after being grounded for more than 20 months following crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia that killed 346 people.

headline: What We Learned From the DealBook Online Summit
abstract: LeBron James, Senator Elizabeth Warren, Dr. Anthony Fauci and more spoke about topics like voting rights, Washington’s future and the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to all who joined us at this week’s DealBook Online Summit. If you missed any of the sessions, you can watch them here. Our next event, the DealBook D.C. Online Strategy Forum, will be held on Dec. 2-3. More details to come.

headline: Dublin Zoo Pleaded for Pandemic Help. Supporters Gave $1.2 Million in Hours.
abstract: The zoo, a popular tourist spot that’s regarded as a national treasure, warned that it might have to close permanently as Ireland endures its second coronavirus lockdown.
lead_paragraph: Amid a second pandemic lockdown in Ireland, many businesses are struggling to stay afloat, with funds dwindling and no end of the coronavirus in sight.

headline: Deadly Protests Erupt in Uganda After Arrest of 2 Opposition Figures
abstract: At least 16 people were killed in protests over the arrests. One of the detained presidential candidates, the popular musician-turned-lawmaker Bobi Wine, was accused of breaking coronavirus restrictions at campaign rallies.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The national police in Uganda said Thursday that at least 16 people had been killed and hundreds arrested in protests that erupted across the country after two presidential candidates were arrested while campaigning ahead of a highly anticipated January election.

headline: The culling of minks in Denmark prompts a political crisis.
abstract: The slaughter of minks in Denmark to prevent the spread of a potentially dangerous new strain of the coronavirus has prompted a political crisis in the country, with the minister of agriculture forced to step down and the government in danger of collapse.
lead_paragraph: The slaughter of minks in Denmark to prevent the spread of a potentially dangerous new strain of the coronavirus has prompted a political crisis in the country, with the minister of agriculture forced to step down and the government in danger of collapse.

headline: When Will We Throw Our Masks Away? I Asked Dr. Fauci
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Masks', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: In a new interview, he tells us how to survive the coming months, and confesses how stunned he is when people still insist the virus is “fake news.”
lead_paragraph: As a health journalist, a physician and a former foreign correspondent who lived through SARS in Beijing, I often get questions from friends, colleagues and people I don’t even know about how to live during our current pandemic. Do I think it’s safe to plan a real wedding next June? Would I send my kids to school, with appropriate precautions? When will I trust a vaccine?

headline: Hospitals and Health Care Workers Issue a Call to Arms for Wearing Masks
abstract: With the pandemic raging in the U.S., a new ad campaign features frontline medical personnel pleading for everyone to mask up.
lead_paragraph: “Our shields are worn. Our resolve is being tested.”

headline: Should We Rethink Thanksgiving?
abstract: In year of a pandemic, racial reckoning and a tense election, how should we celebrate? How should teenagers hold the complicated history of this holiday alongside the devastation and loss of this year?
lead_paragraph: What does Thanksgiving mean to you? Is it a time to come together with family? Is it a special meal with delicious food? Does Thanksgiving make you think of long days stuck in traffic or suffering through tense conversations with family members?

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Thanksgiving Myth Gets a Deeper Look This Year’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn how some Native Americans are re-envisioning Thanksgiving during a year of racial reckoning and Covid-19 deaths.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “The Thanksgiving Myth Gets a Deeper Look This Year” by Brett Anderson

headline: A Jewish group denounces the White House for appointing a speechwriter who gathered with white nationalists.
abstract: A prominent Jewish group criticized the White House on Wednesday for appointing to a commission that monitors Holocaust sites a speechwriter whom the White House had fired in 2018 for attending a gathering with white nationalists.
lead_paragraph: A prominent Jewish group criticized the White House on Wednesday for appointing to a commission that monitors Holocaust sites a speechwriter whom the White House had fired in 2018 for attending a gathering with white nationalists.

headline: Trump plans three executions before Biden, who opposes the death penalty, takes power.
abstract: In the final weeks of President Trump’s term, his administration intends to execute three inmates on federal death row, the last scheduled executions by the Justice Department before the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., who has signaled he will end federal use of capital punishment.
lead_paragraph: In the final weeks of President Trump’s term, his administration intends to execute three inmates on federal death row, the last scheduled executions by the Justice Department before the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., who has signaled he will end federal use of capital punishment.

headline: Confrontations in swing states escalate as Trump continues to attack the election process.
abstract: President Trump’s false accusations that voter fraud denied him re-election are causing escalating confrontations in swing states across the country, leading to threats of violence against officials in both parties and subverting even the most routine steps in the electoral process.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s false accusations that voter fraud denied him re-election are causing escalating confrontations in swing states across the country, leading to threats of violence against officials in both parties and subverting even the most routine steps in the electoral process.

headline: What to Know About California’s Covid-19 Restrictions
abstract: Thursday: Here’s where the state’s efforts stand. Also: A call for your adapted Thanksgiving traditions.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Money pours into Georgia ahead of runoff races that will determine control of the Senate.
abstract: The two runoff elections in Georgia that will determine which party controls the Senate are already drawing enormous sums of cash, with more than $125 million pouring into the state in only two weeks.
lead_paragraph: The two runoff elections in Georgia that will determine which party controls the Senate are already drawing enormous sums of cash, with more than $125 million pouring into the state in only two weeks.

headline: As if Thanksgiving Weren’t Stressful Enough This Year
abstract: Now there’s a bad boyfriend in the mix.
lead_paragraph: I was just informed that my sister’s boyfriend will be joining us for Thanksgiving. They’ve been going out for two years. I don’t like him and my other sibling downright hates him. Any other year, we could deal with this fairly easily; we have a big extended family. But this year, only immediate family members are coming to dinner because of Covid-19. I’d love to get past this in the spirit of family togetherness, but a big cause of the problem is my sister’s condescending attitude toward our other sibling and me when she’s with her boyfriend. Any suggestions other than strong holiday drinks?

headline: ‘Collective’ Review: When Tragedy Consumes a Nation
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Politics and Government', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'News and News Media', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The shocking Romanian documentary “Collective” revisits a 2015 fire that killed scores of people and brought down the government.
lead_paragraph: There’s no letup in the staggering documentary “Collective,” no moment when you can take an easy breath, assured that the terrible things you’ve been watching onscreen are finally over. The story begins with a tragedy in Romania that consumed the country and toppled the government. The villains and heroes involved — the bureaucrats and doctors, journalists and politicians — seem too much like Hollywood types to be true. But the story and its outrages are real, from the venal pharmaceutical company owner to the whistle-blowers who had all the receipts.

headline: A Manhattan Rental Recovery?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Renters seem to be returning to Manhattan after a pandemic exodus resulted in record vacancy rates.
lead_paragraph: One of the big questions the coronavirus pandemic has raised in New York is whether the Manhattan rental market can ever fully recover. Eight months in, there may be some light at the end of the tunnel.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Williamsburg, Morningside Heights and Forest Hills.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Williamsburg, Morningside Heights and Forest Hills.

abstract: Japanese strawberries, a Bohemian Baja-based hotel — and more.

headline: Derek Fordjour, From Anguish to Transcendence
keywords: ['Art', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Woven into his new work at Petzel Gallery are lessons drawn from his own journey to art stardom, and from a year of Black grief.
lead_paragraph: In a bare room upstairs from his art studio inside an industrial building in the South Bronx, Derek Fordjour watched as three puppeteers brought a character drawn right out of his paintings to three-dimensional life. The artist was forging yet another branch of his multiform practice: a live show, inspired by Japanese puppet theater, to complement work in his upcoming gallery exhibition.

headline: Palestinians consider ending prisoner payments in a bid to win favor with Biden’s administration.
abstract: In an effort to refurbish their sullied image in Washington, the Palestinians are laying the groundwork for an overhaul to one of their most cherished but controversial practices: compensating those who serve time in Israeli prisons, including for violent attacks.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to refurbish their sullied image in Washington, the Palestinians are laying the groundwork for an overhaul to one of their most cherished but controversial practices: compensating those who serve time in Israeli prisons, including for violent attacks.

headline: The House minority leader says Trump ‘will still be a player’ in the Republican Party.
abstract: For all the drama around the presidential race, the biggest surprise of the 2020 election may have been in the House, as Republicans gained eight seats and cut into the Democratic majority after a campaign in which officials in both parties expected the G.O.P. to come up short.
lead_paragraph: For all the drama around the presidential race, the biggest surprise of the 2020 election may have been in the House, as Republicans gained eight seats and cut into the Democratic majority after a campaign in which officials in both parties expected the G.O.P. to come up short.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘The Great’
abstract: I’m the editor of The Times’s Arts & Leisure section. I also have a newborn. Here are five things I’m watching, listening to or reading.
lead_paragraph: I’m the editor of The Times’s Arts & Leisure section. I also have a newborn. Here are five things I’m watching, listening to or reading.

headline: How Sidney Powell inaccurately cited Venezuela’s elections as evidence of U.S. fraud.

headline: A Canadian Town Is a Festive Anywhere, U.S.A., Onscreen
abstract: With its mix of 19th-century historic buildings and a ’50s diner, Almonte in Ontario has been the go-to location for holiday movies set in Vermont, Alaska and even Milwaukee.
lead_paragraph: “Fatman,” the recently released action-comedy featuring Mel Gibson as Santa Claus, plays out in the rural backwoods of Alaska. “The Christmas Setup” (Dec. 12 on Lifetime) focuses on a budding same-sex romance between high school buddies reunited in Milwaukee. The story of a mysterious key left on a doorstep in “Unlocking Christmas” (Dec. 13 on Hallmark) is set somewhere in the United States.

Among them is Glenn Ligon’s text sculpture “Aftermath,” on the corner of 56th Street. It reads, “Nov. 4, 2020” — the day after the presidential election.

headline: Don’t Get Between a Caterpillar and Its Milkweed
abstract: Before metamorphosis, monarch butterflies will aggressively head butt each other for access to their favorite food.
lead_paragraph: In the 1969 children’s book “The Very Hungry Caterpillar,” the tiny protagonist spends a week snarfing his way through a smorgasbord of fruits, meats, sugary desserts and, finally, a nourishing leaf. This family-friendly tale was missing one crucial and far less G-rated plot element: the pure, unadulterated rage of an insect unfed.

headline: Many Employers Avoid Coronavirus Tests Over Cost, Not Availability
abstract: A survey sheds light on why many companies aren’t testing workers. There is also “confusion and uncertainty as to how tests work,” a researcher said.
lead_paragraph: A surge of Covid-19 cases this fall has brought reports of new challenges in getting coronavirus tests. But for employers, testing availability and turnaround times do not appear to be the main obstacles.

headline: Live Webinar: How to Teach Review Writing With The New York Times
abstract: Join us on December 3 as we introduce our Student Review Contest and share mentor texts and strategies for teaching review writing.
lead_paragraph: Book reports and literary essays have long been staples of language arts classrooms, but our curriculum unit on writing reviews encourages students to learn how to critique art in other genres as well. Beginning with our informal writing prompts and culminating in our review contest, we encourage students to post their work for a global audience of both teenagers and adults to read.

headline: Apple, After Outcry, Makes ‘Peanuts’ Holiday Specials Available on PBS
keywords: ['Apple TV', 'Television', 'Public Broadcasting', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']

lead_paragraph: It was all too fitting that an anti-commercialism Christmas classic, broadcast over the public airwaves every year since 1965, would be sidelined in 2020 to a paid streaming service operated by a tech giant.

headline: Ken Spears, Partner in an Animation Powerhouse, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Spears and Joe Ruby were best known for “Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!,” perhaps the most spun-off series in the history of television.
lead_paragraph: Ken Spears, who helped create “Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!,” the series starring a gang of mystery-solving teenagers and a hapless, hungry dog that became one of the most lucrative franchises in the history of animation, died on Nov. 6 in Brea, Calif. He was 82.

headline: It’s Time to Put the Noble Grapes in Their Place
abstract: Given a chance, many varieties, once scorned or dismissed, have proven they can shine. Why constrain our thinking about them by creating hierarchies?
lead_paragraph: The way people talk about wine often reflects their other beliefs about the world.

headline: Dutch Police Urge Public to Stop ‘Pedo-Hunting’ After Vigilante Violence
abstract: A man’s death in the Netherlands last month after an attack by a group of teenagers has prompted the authorities to clamp down on vigilantism.

headline: 3 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Leilah Babirye’s luminous sculptural figures, Luigi Ghirri’s vintage photographs, and Paul Chan’s Wittgenstein drawings
lead_paragraph: Leilah Babirye’s sculptural figures and heads succeed where many fail: They build convincingly on universally revered traditions from the past — in this case the sculptural styles of West Africa. Ms. Babirye carves wood, which she then burns and waxes to achieve a luminous matte surface that gentles down her sometimes brusque forms. Or she translates this vocabulary into clay, using celadon green glazes and round Buddha faces reminiscent of Chinese art.

headline: No, judges don’t overturn elections because of isolated irregularities.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Courts have set the bar extremely high for throwing out election results, and the discrepancies cited by the Trump campaign don’t come anywhere close.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s approach to challenging the election has been scattershot and contradictory, as his campaign demands that courts stop ballots from being counted in certain places while insisting that a more thorough review is necessary in other places.

headline: Arecibo Observatory, a Great Eye on the Cosmos, Is Going Dark
abstract: The radio telescope in Puerto Rico has to come down before it collapses.
lead_paragraph: One of the great icons of human curiosity, the Arecibo radio telescope, is going to be torn down, the National Science Foundation, its owner, announced today. From its perch in the mountains of Puerto Rico, the observatory has served for decades as the vanguard of the search for alien civilizations and guarded the planet against killer asteroids.

headline: ‘Belushi’ Finds the Sensitive Man Inside the Wild Persona
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Television', 'Movies', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Actors and Actresses']
abstract: The new Showtime documentary aims to present a more complex view of John Belushi, the tragically fated star of “Animal House,” “The Blues Brothers” and “S.N.L.,” beyond the stunts and hard partying.

headline: Nina Chanel Abney Imagines a Queer Black Utopia
abstract: The artist’s new body of work depicts life outside of the city, in a rural idyll free of the white gaze.
lead_paragraph: By the beginning of this year, the artist Nina Chanel Abney’s studio, a 1,500-square-foot space in a multiuse building in Jersey City, N.J., that she’s rented since 2018, had begun to feel like a storage room. Stacks of boxes filled with books and products she’d made, as well as paintings — both her own and ones she’d purchased — lined the walls, and the countertops of the kitchenette were barely visible beneath the countless cases of spray paint piled on top of them. When the pandemic hit New Jersey in March, and the state went into lockdown, Abney — who also lives in the building, in an apartment a few flights below — became even more aware of her spatial confines. And so, in May, she bought a bike and a rack for her car and began taking road trips to rural areas outside of the city to find some relief from all the time spent indoors. Inspired in part by these excursions, Abney’s new body of work conveys a sense of expansiveness — one that she also found in the form of an additional studio that she rented in the same building this fall. This larger temporary space, with a view of the Manhattan skyline, gave the artist enough room to finish the 22 paintings — ranging from 2 feet by 2 feet to 8 feet by 8 feet — that are currently on display in “The Great Escape,” a solo exhibition at Jack Shainman Gallery in New York.

headline: San Francisco’s School Plan Could Offer Other Districts Hope
abstract: With relatively low virus rates, the city faces a dilemma over a return to in-person instruction.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When the coronavirus came here in March, local leaders seemed to do things right. They issued the nation’s first shelter in place order, promptly shut down schools and businesses and made masks routine. It worked: The city has experienced some of the lowest test positivity rates in the country.Now, city officials are forging ahead with a tentative school reopening plan hatched earlier this month, and it couldn’t have come at a worse time. The coronavirus has entered a frightening new stage nationwide — triggering school districts around the country to shutter, including in New York City and the entire state of Kentucky — and putting San Francisco on the horns of a dilemma.The district’s goal of opening some schools could bring relief to thousands of parents and students, but their plan was written for another reality. Virus rates are suddenly spiking, prompting Gov. Gavin Newsom of California on Thursday to issue a nighttime curfew affecting nearly every county in the state, though San Francisco is below the threshold. As a result, officials here face pushback from some unions, teachers and parents.Whether San Francisco ultimately proceeds can be a bellwether: If schools cannot reopen here where virus rates remain comparatively low, what hope do other cities have for a return to something resembling normalcy?There is mounting evidence that prolonged distance learning could have long-term effects on schoolchildren and their families, including higher dropout rates and lower income in later years. Parents and caretakers have suffered, too, as homebound schooling has caused many to alter their work lives, disproportionately affecting women, minorities and the underprivileged.

headline: Trump Targets Michigan in His Ploy to Subvert the Election
abstract: In a brazen step, the president invited Republican state leaders in Michigan to the White House as he and his allies try to prevent the state from certifying Joe Biden’s clear victory there.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Thursday accelerated his efforts to interfere in the nation’s electoral process, taking the extraordinary step of reaching out directly to Republican state legislators from Michigan and inviting them to the White House on Friday for discussions as the state prepares to certify President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. the winner there.

headline: She Stood In for My Mother. Could I Do the Same for Her?
abstract: When my mother died young, her mother held loss for me. Now I fear losing her, too.
lead_paragraph: I used to hate going clothes shopping with my grandmother. We would go to a store, pick out an array of jean skirts and sports bras, and head to the dressing rooms, where my siblings and I would overhear her chatting with the attendant, knowing that at some point, like clockwork, she would say, “Their mother died. I’m just the grandma.”

headline: How Steve Bannon and a Chinese Billionaire Created a Right-Wing Coronavirus Media Sensation
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Social Media']
abstract: Increasingly allied, the American far right and members of the Chinese diaspora tapped into social media to give a Hong Kong researcher a vast audience for peddling unsubstantiated pandemic claims.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Li-Meng Yan wanted to remain anonymous. It was mid-January, and Dr. Yan, a researcher in Hong Kong, had been hearing rumors about a dangerous new virus in mainland China that the government was playing down. Terrified for her personal safety and career, she reached out to her favorite Chinese YouTube host, known for criticizing the Chinese government.

headline: A Bright Spot in the Pandemic Gloom: Jazz Is Everywhere in New York
abstract: Musicians are playing al fresco all over the city to earn money and boost morale.
lead_paragraph: Every night after her shift this spring, Bridget Queral would leave the hospital where she worked as a nurse to find her husband, Luis, waiting to walk her home. As they ambled through an eerily silent Central Park, Ms. Queral would shed the baggage from treating patients during the pandemic’s intense peak. The stroll became a highlight of the couple’s coronavirus routine, even with the lawns devoid of their usual crowds.

abstract: Not long after Skeeter Barker began dating Amanda Sayre Caskey eight years ago, she announced, “Someday, I’m going to marry you.”

headline: End the War on Drugs Now
abstract: After a half a century of failure, the U.S. and Mexico have an opportunity to find a new way forward on narcotics policy.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — On June 17, 1971, President Richard Nixon stood in front of the White House press corps and made his historic declaration of a new type of war.  “Public Enemy No. 1 in the United States is drug abuse,” he said. “In order to fight and defeat this enemy, it’s necessary to wage a new all-out offensive.”

headline: Is This Where We Are, America?
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Student Loans', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Some people oppose student loan forgiveness because they want others to suffer, too.
lead_paragraph: I took out my first student loans more than 20 years ago. I had dropped out of college just before the start of my junior year. I took a couple of years off, and when I went back I had to pay for my final two years myself. I understood the responsibility I was assuming, but I was working minimum wage jobs at the time — retail, telemarketing, bartending. Repayment seemed like a vague, distant concept in large part because I could not fathom being able to repay such staggering amounts of money. I went to graduate school and got two more degrees, and though those programs were funded, I took out student loans because it was impossible to live on the meager stipends we were given.

headline: Climate Change Is Making Winter Ice More Dangerous
abstract: A new study has found that cold-weather drownings are increasing sharply in warmer parts of the Northern Hemisphere.
lead_paragraph: New research on the connection between climate change and winter drownings has found that reported drowning deaths are increasing exponentially in areas with warmer winters.

headline: A Quick End to a Dangerous War
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'War and Armed Conflicts', 'United States International Relations', 'Armenians', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The feud between Armenia and Azerbaijan has only been put on hold.
lead_paragraph: The cease-fire brokered by Russia in Nagorno-Karabakh has silenced the guns and driven off the drones. That is good. But the deep-rooted feud between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the remote South Caucasus enclave has only been updated for an altered balance of power, not resolved. The burning houses of fleeing Armenians promise that it will erupt again. And in the demonic logic of conflicts which touch on elemental religious and cultural narratives, every eruption of violence adds another layer of mortal grievances, pushing a lasting peace further beyond the pale.

abstract: He terminated emergency-lending programs that will limit the new administration’s options — and upset the Federal Reserve, too.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has embraced a terrible idea that has been circulating among senior officials in Washington over the past few weeks. Citing improving economic conditions, Mr. Mnuchin has essentially declared “mission accomplished” for programs that have contributed to the economy’s recovery so far and is allowing them to expire at the end of the year.

headline: Dividends Are Down, but They Are Vastly Better Than Expected
keywords: ['Dividends (Finance)', 'Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Recession and Depression', 'Corporations']
abstract: After predictions of cuts of 20 percent or more, stock dividends have been surprisingly resilient. Low interest rates have helped to keep companies flush with cash.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a horrendous year for so many things: public health, employment, civil discourse, political norms, cultural and sports events, restaurants, small businesses of nearly every sort. Make your own list. There are plenty of choices.

headline: I Traced My Covid-19 Bubble and It’s Enormous
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Contact Tracing (Public Health)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Thanksgiving Day']
abstract: And if you have kids, yours probably is, too.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to include additional information on the writer’s plans.

headline: This Is How the Outbreak Is Resurging Across New York City
abstract: The positive test rates have gone up in the city in the last month, leading to what many experts say is a second wave.
lead_paragraph: At first, New York officials tracked the resurgence of the coronavirus to a few neighborhoods in the city with large populations of Orthodox Jewish residents.

headline: Walking Down the Automotive Aisle
abstract: “Every time I smell a tire or see a car battery now, I’m going to think about getting married,” said Evan Sloan, who married Mary Kate Vollmer at a country store in Montgomery, Ill.
lead_paragraph: Mary Kate Vollmer and Evan Sloan didn’t intend to cause a ruckus with their Nov. 2 wedding in the automotive aisle of Blain’s Farm & Fleet, a country store in Montgomery, Ill. They were just trying to bring Mr. Sloan’s 90-year-old, coronavirus-stricken grandmother, Beth Stanley, some peace.

headline: A Perfect Introduction for Two Latin Lovers
abstract: Kelly Mulrow and Kevin Quinn recited the first lines from the Latin textbook “Ecce Romani I” on their first date.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Ellen Mulrow and Kevin Matthew Quinn like clockwork recited  the opening lines of the Latin textbook “Ecce Romani I” during their first date in May 2017 at Ampersand, a cocktail bar in the Gramercy neighborhood of Manhattan.

headline: A First Date Unspoiled Even After He Lost His Phone and Wallet
abstract: Aliza Aber and Jeb Browning quickly connected. Both were divorced and both had two young daughters. Together, they’re a happy family.
lead_paragraph: Aliza Aber and Jonathan Browning had a marathon of a first date.

headline: Overcoming Cancer, Postponements and a Hurricane
abstract: Yoelvis Valdez and Anabel Santeliz, who met in 2012, faced numerous obstacles before finally marrying in the backyard of friends in Manalapan, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A hurricane ruined Yoelvis Valdez’s plans to propose to Anabel Santeliz. And their wedding was first postponed because of a cancer diagnosis, then because of the coronavirus. But when two friends came to the rescue, the couple finally got their wedding in a backyard tent drenched in pink roses and candlelight.

headline: If Biden Wants to Be Like F.D.R., He Needs the Left

abstract: The pandemic has made it impossible to invite people over, fundamentally changing the way many of us like to use our homes.
lead_paragraph: Lela Rose’s dining table can accommodate dozens of guests and is a marvel of social engineering.

headline: After a ‘Covid Semester,’ the University of Michigan Gets Tougher on the Virus
abstract: Like many big state universities, it tried to open with some semblance of normalcy. Outbreaks ensued.
lead_paragraph: The University of Michigan’s flagship campus in Ann Arbor opened the fall semester with great expectations. Thousands of students were welcomed back to the dorms in August. Nearly one in three classes offered in-person instruction. Even Big Ten football eventually kicked off its season after some early doubts.

headline: Wisconsin Medical Examiner Prepared for the Worst. It Wasn’t Enough.
abstract: Patty Schachtner took masks to funeral homes and installed showers for sheriff’s deputies. No amount of preparation could ready her for what followed.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic was a faraway nightmare — a catastrophe on the coasts — when Patty Schachtner, the medical examiner in St. Croix County, Wis., began preparing.

headline: She Seemed Destined for Olympic Glory. Brain Injuries Ended That.
keywords: ['Skeleton (Sport)', 'Sports Injuries', 'Traumatic Brain Injury', 'Migraine Headaches', 'Chronic Condition (Health)', 'Concussions', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Ellie Furneaux looked like she was going to become Britain’s next star in the sledding sport skeleton. But a series of concussions took a heavy toll.
lead_paragraph: Ellie Furneaux has a headache, every day. Even worse, once a month, a migraine grips her.

headline: What 635 Epidemiologists Are Doing for Thanksgiving
keywords: ['Thanksgiving Day', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Those who are gathering with family or friends are taking precautions or rethinking their holiday rituals altogether. Most are staying home.
lead_paragraph: The family of one epidemiologist plans to celebrate Thanksgiving in a garage, with tables 10 feet apart and the doors rolled up. Another epidemiologist’s family is forgoing a traditional meal for an outdoor hot cider toast with neighbors. A third is dining in an outdoor tent, with a heater, humidifier and air purifier running.

headline: A senior Defense Department official is infected with the virus, and others were exposed.
abstract: Anthony J. Tata, a senior Pentagon official, has tested positive for the coronavirus after meeting with a visiting Lithuanian official who also met with the acting American defense secretary and other high-level U.S. military officials.
lead_paragraph: Anthony J. Tata, a senior Pentagon official, has tested positive for the coronavirus after meeting with a visiting Lithuanian official who also met with the acting American defense secretary and other high-level U.S. military officials.

headline: Trump officials object, but school doors are closing across the country.
abstract: The Trump administration stressed its opposition on Thursday to closing schools as a means to combat the coronavirus, even as some of the largest districts in the United States were closing anew or postponed reopening.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration stressed its opposition on Thursday to closing schools as a means to combat the coronavirus, even as some of the largest districts in the United States were closing anew or postponed reopening.

headline: A Chinese drugmaker reports progress on a vaccine candidate.
abstract: As China rushes to keep up with the global race to find a coronavirus vaccine, a state-owned drugmaker is reporting promising results for a candidate after administering doses to nearly a million people in the country.
lead_paragraph: As China rushes to keep up with the global race to find a coronavirus vaccine, a state-owned drugmaker is reporting promising results for a candidate after administering doses to nearly a million people in the country.

headline: The W.H.O. rejects the antiviral drug remdesivir as a Covid-19 treatment.

lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization on Thursday recommended against using the antiviral remdesivir, a drug that had generated intense interest as a treatment for Covid-19.

headline: A Holocaust Survivor Lifts Neighbors in Dark Times
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jazz', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Simon Gronowski escaped the Nazis as a child and went on to write and speak widely about his experiences. In April, he began brightening lives by playing jazz tunes from his apartment window.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Simon Gronowski had committed many acts of bravery and generosity in his 89 years of life, and opening a window in April wouldn’t ordinarily have counted among them, but this was no ordinary April.

headline: When the Pandemic Came to Rural Wisconsin
abstract: As the coronavirus spread, a public servant tried to prepare her conservative community for the worst-case scenario. Now it’s here.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic struck, Patty Schachtner was glued to the news — she watched closely for updates coming out of coronavirus-ravaged China and Italy. She thought about what she would do if the virus hit her corner of the world in rural Wisconsin.

headline: The Books of the Year
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Every November, after the editors of The Times Book Review have wrapped up their big end-of-year issues, they immediately turn their attention to the following year. They start by creating a working list of nominees for the next iteration of 100 Notable Books — the one that will be published almost a year later.

headline: The Patriarch of the Serbian Orthodox Church dies after presiding over a packed funeral.
abstract: The leader of the Serbian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Irinej, died of the coronavirus on Friday, according to the church, three weeks after he attended a packed funeral for a senior bishop who had died after contracting the virus.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the Serbian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Irinej, died of the coronavirus on Friday, according to the church, three weeks after he attended a packed funeral for a senior bishop who had died after contracting the virus.

headline: ‘Run’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Aneesh Chaganty narrates an escape sequence from his film, featuring Kiera Allen.
lead_paragraph: The director Aneesh Chaganty narrates an escape sequence from his film, featuring Kiera Allen.

headline: She Helped South Korea in Its Time of Need. In the Pandemic, It Repaid Her.
keywords: ['Volunteers and Community Service', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Decades ago, a young American woman served an impoverished South Korea as a Peace Corps volunteer. Now the country is an economic powerhouse, and it decided to send her a token of its gratitude. ​
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Sandra Nathan spent 1966 to 1968 in a South Korean town as a young Peace Corps volunteer, teaching English to high school girls. Fifty-two years later, Ms. Nathan, now back in the United States, received a care package from South Korea that nearly brought her to tears.

headline: ‘The Real Right Stuff’ Review: A Movie Still Waiting for Liftoff
abstract: This Disney+ space race documentary is a bland chronology of successful launches and minor mishaps.
lead_paragraph: Project Mercury’s mission to blast the first American astronauts into space was fastidiously undramatic. NASA’s founding administrator T. Keith Glennan — still introducing the agency by its initials like a proper debutante — aimed to send his seven pilots up and down in a metal pillbox that even a chimp couldn’t crash. From engineering to public relations, there was no room for human malfunction. It took two decades for the journalist Tom Wolfe’s “The Right Stuff” to reveal the frizzed wires underneath the capsule’s smooth exterior: the ego clashes, the stress and depression, and the wives who took tranquilizers so they could serve cheery can-do-isms to Life Magazine.

headline: How an Online Attack ‘Brought Twitter to Its Knees’
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A teenager from Florida is accused of breaching one of the most high-profile internet platforms in the world. Watch how Twitter was hacked in a new Times documentary airing tonight on FX at 10 p.m. and streaming on Hulu.
lead_paragraph: It seemed like an inside job.

headline: Kiera Allen of ‘Run’ on Upending Disability Stereotypes
abstract: “This is one of the best representations of a disabled character I’ve ever seen,” Allen said.
lead_paragraph: Kiera Allen makes her feature debut this week, playing opposite Sarah Paulson in the Hulu suspense film “Run.” It is a rare instance of a wheelchair user starring in a thriller.

headline: A Cal Football Player Opted Out Because of the Virus. Then Came the Tuition Bill.
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: A committee found that the athletic department broke an N.C.A.A. rule by revoking Henry Bazakas’s summer scholarship. His fight to get it back showed the cutthroat side of college football.
lead_paragraph: Henry Bazakas embodied everything the University of California wants in a football player.

headline: Trump’s Latest Gambit
abstract: The president appears to meddle in Michigan’s electoral process: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Trump summons Michigan Republicans to the White House to plan — but time is running out before states certify their results. It’s Friday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

lead_paragraph: With Christmas arriving in the middle of a surging pandemic, it may not be the most wonderful time of the year for an in-person visit with Santa Claus.

headline: A Lie and a Pizza Shop: Why Australian Officials Reversed a Lockdown
abstract: South Australia imposed tight statewide restrictions based on what a man had said about his relationship to a restaurant. And then the authorities learned the truth.

abstract: The director Aneesh Chaganty narrates a sequence featuring Kiera Allen, who plays a wheelchair-using teenager with a secretive mother.

headline: With federal assistance programs in doubt, millions of Americans face financial hardship.
abstract: As the United States confronts an outbreak of the coronavirus that shows no sign of slowing and local governments move to reimpose restrictions on businesses in an attempt to get some control over the epidemic, millions of Americans face the prospect of losing federal funds that had been providing a lifeline.
lead_paragraph: As the United States confronts an outbreak of the coronavirus that shows no sign of slowing and local governments move to reimpose restrictions on businesses in an attempt to get some control over the epidemic, millions of Americans face the prospect of losing federal funds that had been providing a lifeline.

headline: Could Limiting Corporate Candidates Hurt Biden’s Diversity Push?
keywords: ['Presidential Transition (US)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Narrowing the candidate pool may not lead to the diverse representation the incoming administration is seeking.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joe Biden has made assembling a diverse team a priority. He also faces pressure from the progressive wing of his party to limit corporate influence on hires for his administration, avoiding candidates from Wall Street or company boardrooms. But narrowing the candidate pool that way won’t help create a more representative administration, some suggest.

headline: It’s Never Been Harder to Be the New Kid on the Block
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Moving and Moving Industry', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Loneliness']
abstract: Moving to a new place is never easy. It’s even harder, and lonelier, when no one is supposed to come within six feet of you.
lead_paragraph: Bhumika Choudhary, 24, knew that moving during the pandemic wouldn’t be easy, but she figured she would be able to make friends with her co-workers at the Boston office of the law firm where she recently started a new job. Or maybe she could meet a neighbor or two in her large apartment building in downtown Boston.

headline: The Best Video Games to Get Lost In This Holiday Season
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Content Type: Service', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'PlayStation 5 (Video Game System)', 'PlayStation 3 (Video Game System)', 'PlayStation 4 (Video Game System)', 'Xbox (Video Game System)', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)', 'Nintendo Switch (Video Game System)']
abstract: A ninth-century Viking adventure, a game about robots that literally feels good to play and an escape from hell: Here is what’s new across gaming systems to satisfy players of all stripes.
lead_paragraph: November is the season for blockbuster video games — not even the pandemic has changed that. In fact, the video game industry has seen record spending and profits in 2020. At the same time, the decision to set aside as much as $60 (and, often, 60 hours) to play might be tougher this year, as the economic downturn affects purchasing decisions. Nonetheless, the perennial question persists: With a new slate of big games, as well as new video game consoles, what’s worth it?

headline: A Michigan Republican who will meet with Trump has said he would not override Biden’s victory.

abstract: The Instagram hit battle, broadcast from an Atlanta strip club, was more tense than usual, but ended on a note of apparent reconciliation between the two star rappers.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two million people watched live on Thursday night as two Southern rap heavyweights, Gucci Mane and Jeezy, leaned into, and then seemingly set aside, 15 years of bad blood during the latest edition of the pandemic streaming hit battle Verzuz.

abstract: More than 500 readers sent in their predictions, but only one correctly forecast the exact Electoral College count.
lead_paragraph: In late October we asked readers to make their election predictions and published a sampling of the more than 500 responses. Many readers predicted a Joe Biden landslide, others thought that President Trump would win the Electoral College and some rightly guessed that the results would be too close to call on Election Day.

keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Under the pandemic relief program, taxpayers can deduct up to $300, even if they take the standard deduction. And even if $300 doesn’t sound like much, it’s “a big deal” to the needy.
lead_paragraph: Thinking of making a donation to a charitable cause before the end of the year? This is a good time to do it, as the pandemic rages again. Plus, you can take a deduction for contributions in 2020, even if you don’t itemize on your income tax return.

headline: Making Financial Decisions When You Don’t Have All the Facts
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Content Type: Service', 'Income Tax', 'United States Politics and Government', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Wills and Estates', 'Family Business']

headline: In Brooklyn, Grand Army Plaza Gets an Intervention
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The Memorial Arch, a granite monument to soldiers and sailors in the plaza, is about to get desperately needed restoration work.
lead_paragraph: In the moments after the Presidential election was called in favor of Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Nov. 7, a jubilant crowd gathered spontaneously in Brooklyn’s Grand Army Plaza, whooping and dancing around the Soldiers’ and Sailors’ Memorial Arch, atop which the bronze allegorical figure of Columbia, representing America, thundered forth in her horse-drawn chariot, flanked by trumpeting figures of winged Victory.

He also faces pressure from the progressive wing of his party to limit corporate influence on hires for his administration, avoiding candidates from Wall Street or company boardrooms. But some business leaders suggested to the DealBook newsletter that narrowing the candidate pool that way wouldn’t help create a more representative administration.
