headline: Players Have Been Kneeling for Months. Now What?
abstract: In protests and meetings, Black players have pushed M.L.S. for better representation. Now, as the playoffs open, and with the league’s help, they are focused on follow through.
lead_paragraph: It was the final day of Major League Soccer’s regular season and — right on schedule — the moment for kneeling arrived.

headline: Georgia certifies Biden’s victory, hours after premature announcement.
abstract: ATLANTA — Georgia officials on Friday certified President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory in the state, hours after a staffer mistakenly sent out a statement saying the process had been completed — a surreal last-minute glitch in a critical and closely watched battleground state.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Georgia officials on Friday certified President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory in the state, hours after a staffer mistakenly sent out a statement saying the process had been completed — a surreal last-minute glitch in a critical and closely watched battleground state.

headline: How Britain Is Reacting to ‘The Crown,’ Season 4
abstract: There has been praise for Emma Corrin and a cheeky mouse and complaints about the depiction of Margaret Thatcher and the queen’s salute as the series explores a divisive time in British history.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Asking British people their views on “The Crown” is like asking what they think of the real-life royal family; like them or loathe them, everyone has an opinion.

headline: Trump allies are among the frequent purveyors of election misinformation.
abstract: The who’s who includes the conservative activist Charlie Kirk, Jim Holt of Gateway Pundit, Eric Trump — and the president himself.
lead_paragraph: President Trump and his allies have continuously amplified false and unsubstantiated claims about voting as they wage a multi-front assault on the legitimacy of the 2020 election.

headline: A Night at the Sock Hop
abstract: In this new painting, Honor Titus explores a bygone era.
lead_paragraph: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at a painting by Honor Titus, whose work has been shown at Henry Taylor’s studio gallery, and who will have his first New York solo exhibition at Timothy Taylor Gallery in January 2021. He draws from a range of influences, including music, and used to sing in a punk band.

headline: At Wharton, a New Leader Confronts the Culture Wars
keywords: ['Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Business Schools', 'Executives and Management (Theory)']
abstract: Erika James recently took over the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. Already, she is enmeshed in debates about race, politics and the role of business in society.
lead_paragraph: As the nation’s oldest business school, the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania has had an outsize influence on shaping the culture of corporate America. For more than a century, Wharton has taught aspiring capitalists how to break into new markets, trounce the competition and mint profits.

headline: Kiernan Shipka Is Relaxing with Tony Soprano and a Margarita
abstract: The actress, who stars in Netflix’s “Chilling Adventures of Sabrina,” shared her essentials ahead of the show’s final season.
lead_paragraph: Kiernan Shipka knows a thing or two about growing up onscreen: The actress was 6 when she first appeared on “Mad Men” as Sally Draper, the role that first brought her acclaim, and had turned 15 by the time the series ended in 2015.

headline: With ‘Sylvie’s Love,’ Eugene Ashe Returns With a Big Hollywood Romance
abstract: For his second feature, Ashe, the writer and director of the Amazon film, was influenced by the photographer Gordon Parks and the singer Nancy Wilson.
lead_paragraph: The sweeping romance returns. A staple of the 1950s and ’60s, these movies that took audiences on an epic love journey (often starring Audrey Hepburn) have been a little less common in the past few decades. But the writer and director Eugene Ashe is exploring the genre anew with “Sylvie’s Love,” arriving on Amazon Prime on Dec. 25.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Thanksgiving is Thursday, and now might be the perfect time to start planning and shopping.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. This is the final weekend before next week’s run-up to Thanksgiving, a holiday feast that some of us, even our best kitchen sharpies, may be cooking for the very first time.

headline: Abolitionist Is Earliest Black Londoner Honored With Blue Plaque
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Ottobah Cugoano, who became a writer and campaigner after surviving slavery in the West Indies, has been honored by a heritage program that long focused on white men.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An 18th-century antislavery campaigner and author, Ottobah Cugoano, has become the earliest Black figure to be honored with one of London’s iconic blue plaques, the heritage organization that manages the program said on Friday.

headline: Who Postpones Black Friday? This Year, the French
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Politics and Government', 'E-Commerce', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Discount Selling', 'Small Business', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Spurred by small retailers’ anger over Amazon’s grip on sales, especially during lockdown, France has delayed the start of holiday discounts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French government on Friday declared it was postponing Black Friday, as it moved to quell a nationwide rebellion by shopkeepers who say that Amazon has been stealing business from them during France’s coronavirus lockdown.

headline: Miley Cyrus and Dua Lipa’s Retro Rock, and 8 More New Songs
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Jazz', 'Folk Music']
abstract: Hear tracks by Megan Thee Stallion, Steve Earle, Bleachers featuring Bruce Springsteen and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: As Winter Looms, Outdoor Schools Face Tough Decisions
abstract: With coronavirus cases surging, educators who moved classes outside are now grappling with how to keep kids safe from both the virus and the elements.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 8, five inches of snow fell on Boulder, Colo., just three days after the city had experienced a record-breaking heat wave. Nobody was expecting this weather whiplash, certainly not JJ Morrow, head of school of Mackintosh Academy Boulder, an independent school that had always taken students outdoors for at least some parts of the day, but had committed to nearly all outdoor learning this year to minimize the risk of spreading the coronavirus.

headline: Senator Rick Scott of Florida is the latest member of Congress to test positive.
abstract: Senator Rick Scott, Republican of Florida, said Friday he had tested positive for the coronavirus, the latest prominent lawmaker to contract the rapidly spreading virus that has infected at least eight members of Congress over the past week.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rick Scott, Republican of Florida, said Friday he had tested positive for the coronavirus, the latest prominent lawmaker to contract the rapidly spreading virus that has infected at least eight members of Congress over the past week.

headline: A Designer’s Endlessly Adaptable Nigerian Stew
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Niyi Okuboyejo makes his efo riro with turkey and yams, but you should feel free to experiment. It’s a dish, he says, that rewards improvisation.
lead_paragraph: In “One Good Meal,” we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.

headline: In the Wake of Ferguson, a Style-Blurring Album
keywords: ['Opera', 'Classical Music', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Protests over police brutality inspired the composer Joseph C. Phillips Jr. to write “The Grey Land,” a mono-opera.
lead_paragraph: On his last album, “Changing Same,” the composer and bandleader Joseph C. Phillips Jr. took up a challenge that had once been extended by the writer Amiri Baraka.

headline: After Trump’s Embrace, Saudis Brace for a Chillier Tone From Biden
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'Arms Trade', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s leaders counted on President Trump’s unwavering support, but President-elect Biden has vowed to take away the kingdom’s “dangerous blank check.”
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For the last four years, President Trump’s close relationship with Saudi Arabia meant that there was seemingly nothing its de facto ruler, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, could do to earn a rebuke from the White House.

headline: A City Put Up Candle-Like Christmas Lights. ‘Some People See Other Things.’
abstract: The Belgian city of Oudenburg’s holiday display has made international headlines for the wrong reasons.
lead_paragraph: The Belgian city of Oudenburg was getting into the Christmas spirit, and it prepared to unveil a lights display on scores of columns set up to look like festive candles scattered around one of its districts.

headline: Which Classic Thanksgiving Character are You?
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Knowing exactly who is gathered around the dinner table could make for a lower-stress holiday.
lead_paragraph: Nothing this year has been normal. Weddings have happened over Zoom. Home runs have soared through empty stadiums. You are now, bizarrely, a person with a favorite mask. For eight months, the world has felt unfamiliar. Thank goodness, then, for Thanksgiving! If there’s anything our collectively beleaguered psyche needs, it’s a holiday embracing gratitude and mashed potatoes.

headline: These Algorithms Could Bring an End to the World’s Deadliest Killer
abstract: In rural India and other places where tuberculosis is rampant, A.I. that scans lung X-rays might eliminate the scourge.
lead_paragraph: In some of the most remote and impoverished corners of the world, where respiratory illnesses abound and trained medical professionals fear to tread, diagnosis is increasingly powered by artificial intelligence and the internet.

headline: Is Trump Trying to Take the Economy Down With Him?
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Municipal Bonds', 'Local Government', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: His Treasury secretary is shackling the nation’s central bank and closing an emergency program for local governments.
lead_paragraph: Consumed by Election Day, Congress effectively abandoned the country when it failed to reach an agreement in October on a desperately needed relief bill. Now, its energy is geared toward the partisan mess of the presidential transition and two Senate runoffs in Georgia.

headline: Soumitra Chatterjee, Globally Acclaimed Indian Film Star, Dies at 85
abstract: His roles in classic movies directed by Satyajit Ray won him admiration from cinephiles and made him a hero to his fellow Bengalis.
lead_paragraph: Soumitra Chatterjee, an Indian actor who incarnated the beauty and fragility of youthful idealism in films by the director Satyajit Ray and helped solidify Mr. Ray’s place in cinematic history, died on Sunday at a hospital in Kolkata, India. He was 85.

headline: ‘Belushi’ Review: A Comic in Full
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: R.J. Cutler’s biographical documentary about the comedy legend hits home hardest as a kind of love story, thanks to candid letters and audio interviews with colleagues.
lead_paragraph: John Belushi’s entrances onstage raise a grin with the promise of unruly energy. But his early exit from life after a drug overdose in 1982 left a legend that tends to seal his tomb. So it’s touching to learn something new from “Belushi,” R.J. Cutler’s warmly told documentary: the man who once impersonated a zit also wrote soul-baring (and sometimes adorable) love letters.

headline: 2 Companies Say Their Vaccines Are 95% Effective. What Does That Mean?
abstract: You might assume that 95 out of every 100 people vaccinated will be protected from Covid-19. But that’s not how the math works.
lead_paragraph: The front-runners in the vaccine race seem to be working far better than anyone expected: Pfizer and BioNTech announced this week that their vaccine had an efficacy rate of 95 percent. Moderna put the figure for its vaccine at 94.5 percent. In Russia, the makers of the Sputnik vaccine claimed their efficacy rate was over 90 percent.

headline: Another Transition: Audrey Pence Weds
abstract: The vice president’s youngest child marries Daniel Tomanelli Nov. 1 in a small outdoor ceremony in Washington.
lead_paragraph: During the most painful and difficult days of Daniel Tomanelli’s life, he continued to take care of Audrey Pence.

headline: Elders and an Artist Bring a Social Sculpture to Life
keywords: ['Art', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Umbrellas', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living']
abstract: Elizabeth Turk imagined illuminated umbrellas spreading hope during the pandemic. A retirement community said yes, and became her canvas.
lead_paragraph: POMONA, Calif. — Deep within the verdant grounds of the Mt. San Antonio Gardens retirement community, the artist Elizabeth Turk was immersed in her latest project, an ambitious work of art that she could easily imagine but not yet see.

abstract: Mnuchin’s move and Shelton’s near-confirmation suggest a future of greater risks each time party control changes.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a divorced couple that simply can’t get along. They share custody of the children, but have completely different visions of how to raise them.

headline: Scientists: How Has the Pandemic Changed Your Work?
abstract: We want to hear from scientists whose work has been upended — positively or negatively — by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, the coronavirus pandemic has underscored for the entire world the value of science — not only for tracking the spread of a deadly virus and developing ways to stop it, but also for providing a rational method for understanding a frightening unknown.

headline: Jan Morris, Celebrated Writer of Place and History, Is Dead at 94
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: In more than four dozen books, Morris explored foreign lands, her own Britain and her experience as a transgender woman.
lead_paragraph: Jan Morris, the acclaimed British journalist, travel writer and historian who wrote about history’s sweep and the details of place with equal eloquence and chronicled her life as a transgender woman, died on Friday in Wales. She was 94.

headline: Stress-Free Stews
abstract: Thanksgiving is coming up, but you still have to eat dinner. Here are some thoughts.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. My Thanksgiving menu is still far from finalized, which is out of character for me, and frankly I’m feeling a little unmoored. Generally I spend weeks thinking about it in an idle way, a pleasing diversion from whatever else I’m supposed to be doing. But this year — I don’t know. Beyond the turkey I’m making, I haven’t reached any decisions. Should I make pie? What kind of pie? Mango pie? A lemon tart? Should I prioritize stuffing? Mashed potatoes? You see: unmoored.

headline: Behind the Cover: Trump’s Liability
abstract: A look at the potential criminal liability facing Donald Trump as he leaves office — and the historic dilemma America will face as a result.

headline: Uncool Can Beat Flashy Tech
abstract: Focus more on the boring stuff. It can make a profound difference in our lives.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

Biden Jr. promised transgender and gender-nonconforming people in the United States and around the world that he would fight for their dignity and safety, signaling a stark shift in policy between the incoming administration and the Trump White House, which has worked to weaken protections.

headline: Gianni Bernardinello, Baker Who Fed Neighbors Amid Pandemic, Dies at 76
abstract: The Milanese baker would leave out baskets of bread for people hit hard economically by the coronavirus pandemic. Now the disease has claimed his life.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Sometimes Our Favorite Sports Need to Love Us Back
abstract: Fans are there for soccer when it needs us. But we expect the favor to be returned.
lead_paragraph: Clutching his phone in one hand and his passport in the other, Ruben Gabrielsen sprinted through his apartment. Duty had called, and he would answer. He had even tied a makeshift cape around his neck for the occasion. He would be the one to save his country in its hour of need.

lead_paragraph: President Trump will huddle with the Republican leaders of the Michigan Senate and House of Representatives Friday afternoon at the White House, a meeting that raised questions about the Michigan officials’ earlier pledges to respect the will of voters and award the state’s 16 electoral votes to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., as Mr. Trump continues to try to subvert the election results.

headline: When Sharks Turned Up at Their Beach, They Called in Drones
abstract: A goal of the SharkEye project is to one day produce automated “shark reports” for beachgoers to help them gauge levels of risk.
lead_paragraph: Once rare off Southern California beaches, great white sharks are beginning to show up more often. The newcomers are mostly juvenile sharks, which prefer the warm waters closer to shore. That means many beachgoers who are now spotting sharks have never seen the predators before.

headline: When New York City Schools Reopen, About 700,000 Students Won’t Be There
abstract: It is unclear when in-person instruction will restart, but the number of children who will return to classrooms has fallen short of the mayor’s predictions.
lead_paragraph: Several weeks before Mayor Bill de Blasio shut New York City’s school system, the nation’s largest, amid a surge in coronavirus cases, he handed parents a daunting deadline: They had only a few weeks to decide if their children would return to classrooms this school year, and likely until at least next fall.

abstract: When a children’s book tour goes virtual, high jinks ensue.

headline: ‘Supernatural’ Lays Its Weary Head to Rest
abstract: The CW’s shockingly long-lived horror series bids its fans goodbye after 15 seasons of slaying.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for the final episode of “Supernatural.”

headline: Love Letter: Swapping Roles With Grandma
abstract: Plus: A long-awaited wedding date.
lead_paragraph: Many grandparents play an important role in the lives of their grandchildren and that is true for Rachael Cusick, the writer of this week’s Modern Love essay. Ms. Cusick was 6 when her mother died of cancer. Her 65-year-old grandmother quickly became a surrogate parent to her and her four siblings. Years later, when her grandmother’s doctors found a tumor in her kidney, it was Ms. Cusick’s turn to put on a brave face and step into the supportive role that her grandmother once held.

headline: What Did 2020 Sound Like for You?
abstract: The Daily wants to know.
lead_paragraph: Whether it was the sound of kids in your Zoom calls, the way masks muffled voices or the quiet of stadiums that were once filled with fans, we want to hear what the world around you sounded like. Please fill out the form below, and we may contact you if we’d like to ask you more questions.

headline: Which States Have Certified Presidential Vote Totals
abstract: Here’s a look at how many electoral votes have been certified — or made official — so far.

headline: Bring the Apple Cider Doughnuts to You
abstract: You may not be able to take a day trip to the apple orchard, but you can still bring those beloved treats home.
lead_paragraph: Light and fluffy, bursting with tart cider flavor, and boasting an undeniable cinnamon-sugar aroma: Cider doughnuts are a fall staple at apple orchards and farm stands everywhere. But these sweet beauties are not just the stuff of day-trip dreams. They’re achievable at home with this flexible baked, not fried recipe that’s perfect as breakfast the day after Thanksgiving, or as a special treat to mark the changing of the seasons — even if both are significantly different this year.

headline: Uganda Releases Opposition Leader After Clashes Kill at Least 28
abstract: Two days after police took him into custody, presidential contender Bobi Wine resurfaced on Friday in court where he was charged with flouting coronavirus rules and released.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Ugandan authorities on Friday charged an opposition leader and presidential contender with breaching coronavirus rules and then released him from jail, two days after his arrest sparked protests nationwide that led to the deaths of at least 28 people and almost 600 arrests.

headline: Introduction to ‘Picture Prompts’
abstract: Want to learn more about this feature? Watch this short introduction video on using Picture Prompts to strengthen literacy skills and give students a voice.
lead_paragraph: Besides written articles, The Times also offers a rich collection of visuals — photos, illustrations, graphics, GIFs and short videos — that are accessible to learners of all levels. Since 2016, we’ve been featuring these images in our daily Picture Prompts.

headline: The Latin Grammys, Still Over the Top in the Shadow of the Pandemic
abstract: The 21st annual awards show brought impressive performances and meaningful spotlights on unity across regions and generations.
lead_paragraph: Even in a pandemic, the 21st annual Latin Grammys didn’t stint on spectacle. On Thursday night, the most consistently over-the-top American music awards show stayed that way, with luxuriant fashion, bustling dance routines, a full salsa big band, arena-scale smoke and lights and mostly real-time performances that reached for emotional peaks.

abstract: Claudia Tenney seemed poised to avenge her 2018 defeat to Rep. Anthony Brindisi, a Democrat, but her election night lead has shrunk to roughly 100 votes.
lead_paragraph: A tight House rematch in Central New York between a first-term Democrat and an outspoken Republican supporter of President Trump has gone to the courts, with only 100 or so votes separating the two after a prolonged absentee ballot count.

headline: ‘The Mandalorian’ Season 2, Episode 4 Recap: Old School
abstract: Baby Yoda played the class clown while the rest of this week’s installment played like a “Star Wars” greatest hits.
lead_paragraph: The latest chapter of “The Mandalorian” is practically a greatest hits of “Star Wars” visual motifs. Do you like high-speed chases through canyons? Big guns fired from rotating turrets? Characters creeping along narrow ledges, perched above steep drops? Long shots of Imperial Star Destroyers flying overhead? Then this week’s episode, “The Siege,” was made for you.

headline: Andrew White, Virtuoso Saxophonist and Coltrane Scholar, Dies at 78
abstract: A man of, in his words, “various artistic gifts of excess,” he amassed a trove of self-released recordings, books and musical transcriptions.
lead_paragraph: Andrew White, a profusely talented and proudly eccentric musician and scholar best known in jazz circles for transcribing more than 800 of John Coltrane’s saxophone solos, died on Nov. 11 at an assisted-living facility in Silver Spring, Md. He was 78.

headline: Toronto Raptors Will Play Home Games in Florida Because of Pandemic
abstract: The Raptors will begin the season based out of Tampa, Fla., amid concerns about the coronavirus in Canada. The team’s president suggested they could return at some point.
lead_paragraph: The Toronto Raptors are heading south for the winter — at least for the start of it.

keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Clinical Trials', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Nursing Homes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: A large team of regulators at the agency will take about three weeks to review an application spanning thousands of pages.
lead_paragraph: The drug maker Pfizer said on Friday that it had submitted an application to the Food and Drug Administration to authorize its coronavirus vaccine for emergency use, setting in motion an accelerated regulatory process that could allow the first Americans to get a vaccine by the middle of December.

headline: Tracey Davis, Chronicler of Ups and Downs With Her Famous Father, Dies at 59
abstract: In two books, she described Sammy Davis Jr.’s negligent parenting but also celebrated the intimate moments she shared with him toward the end of his life.
lead_paragraph: Tracey Davis, who turned her often painful experience as the child of  the entertainer Sammy Davis Jr. into a tale of reconciliation across two memoirs, died on Nov. 2 at her home in central Tennessee. She was 59.

headline: Find a Little Light This Holiday Season
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Religion and Belief', 'Clergy', 'Candles', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Prayers and Prayer Books', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: At the end of a tough year, spiritual leaders offer some ways to prepare yourself for whatever comes next.
lead_paragraph: Saying that 2020 has been a tough year is a little like saying it’s been a tough match for a boxer whose opponent is using a baseball bat. Every time you look up, new punches just keep coming. Some days it feels as if the headlines batter your very soul.

headline: Review: Open Chat Windows and Closed Cases in ‘Citizen Detective’
abstract: With its latest show, the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles has cornered the American market on long-running, agreeable online theater.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 2, 1922, the body of the Hollywood director William Desmond Taylor, shot once in the back, was found on the floor of his plush Los Angeles bungalow. The crime remains unsolved — until you log in.

headline: Len Barry, 78, Dies; Soulful Voice of ‘Bristol Stomp’ and ‘1-2-3’
abstract: He had success as the lead singer of the Dovells and later as a solo artist. But he was always a reluctant performer, most comfortable as a songwriter and producer.
lead_paragraph: Len Barry, the lead singer of the Dovells on their danceable early-1960s hits “Bristol Stomp” and “You Can’t Sit Down” and later a solo artist whose career peaked with his infectious love song “1-2-3,” died on Nov. 5 in a hospital in Philadelphia. He was 78.

headline: ‘People of Color’ Do Not Belong to the Democratic Party

abstract: It’s past time to start seeing voters the way they see themselves.
lead_paragraph: Every immigrant arrives in this country with an implied debt. This country was nice enough to let you in, handed you a bag of rights and will now leave you alone to make your fortune. Left and right might disagree on how many people to let into the country or how to treat them when they’re here, but both sides expect a return on their good will.

headline: 17 Recipes for a Small Thanksgiving Dinner
abstract: Perfectly suited for an intimate celebration, these dishes deliver deliciousness without leaving too much leftover.
lead_paragraph: The safest choice this Thanksgiving is to cozy up to — and cook for — the people you live with. These lower-yield recipes don’t sacrifice on satisfaction. For even more festive options, you can cook your way through Melissa Clark’s menu for two, or explore this larger collection of Recipes for a Small Thanksgiving.

headline: Texas Board Revises Sex Education Standards to Include More Birth Control
abstract: For the first time since 1997, Texas’ education board made major changes to its sex education standards, allowing the teaching of contraceptive methods to middle school students.
lead_paragraph: CONROE, Texas — For the first time in more than two decades, Texas’ Board of Education voted Friday to make major changes to the state’s sex education standards, expanding the teaching of birth control beyond abstinence-only education for middle school students.

headline: Why Trump Will Fail in Michigan
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Constitutions']
abstract: His only success will be in ruining what should be the celebration of a successful election under highly challenging circumstances.

Yet President Trump has chosen a state he lost by more than 150,000 votes — more than 14 times the size of his 2016 victory in Michigan — to try to subvert the election.

headline: Take a Trip to the Museum of Smells
abstract: A nostalgic experience for the senses.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. If your regular Thanksgiving plans have been put on hold this year, might I suggest watching Melissa Clark make an entire holiday meal for three using just one pot, one pan and one oven set to 400 degrees (in under three hours)? Her make-ahead gravy alone makes the prospect of cooking a small, low-key Thanksgiving dinner seem not only manageable but a welcome respite from massive dirty-every-dish productions.

abstract: Time to learn about reverse takeovers, kids!
lead_paragraph: A business trying to make money off mansions full of TikTok influencers has gone public on the stock market through an unusual deal. It involves a former Chinese health care company, and if that sounds confusing, well, we can explain.

headline: No, Trump’s sister did not publicly back him. He was duped by a fake account.
abstract: The president shared an article that said his sister, Elizabeth Trump Grau, was supporting his claim that he had won the election. But the article was based on posts from an impostor Twitter account.
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning, President Trump shared a seemingly innocuous article on Twitter. The piece said that his sister, Elizabeth Trump Grau, had publicly voiced her support for her brother amid his baseless claims that he won the 2020 election.

headline: Justice Department Sues Jeffrey Lowe of ‘Tiger King’ Over Treatment of Animals
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Wildlife Trade and Poaching']
abstract: Mr. Lowe took control of the animal park owned by another of the show’s main subjects, Joseph Maldonado-Passage, better known as Joe Exotic.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Lowe, the man who took over the animal park at the center of the popular Netflix documentary “Tiger King,” was accused on Thursday of violating the Endangered Species Act and Animal Welfare Act, prosecutors said.

headline: Democratic Leaders in Brooklyn Mingled at a Party. Few Wore Masks.
abstract: As New York reinstitutes tough virus restrictions, local Democratic leaders had to apologize for socializing at a birthday party without masks.
lead_paragraph: As Democratic leaders in New York institute more stringent restrictions to combat the coronavirus and urge people to follow them, one group of local Democratic power brokers did not seem to get the message.

headline: Fred Hills, Editor of Nabokov and Many Others, Dies at 85
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: A longtime editor at Simon & Schuster, he brought to market both commercial hits and literary prizewinners and edited more than 50 New York Times best sellers.
lead_paragraph: It was 1958, and Fred Hills, a graduate student trying to earn some extra cash, was selling books at the Emporium department store in San Francisco. He picked up a copy of Vladimir Nabokov’s “Lolita,” which had just been published in the United States, and read the opening: “Lolita, light of my life, fire of my loins. My sin, my soul.”

headline: 8 People Hurt in Shooting at Mall Near Milwaukee
keywords: ['Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The shooting, which happened at the Mayfair Mall in Wauwatosa, Wis., injured seven adults and one teenager, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Eight people were hurt in a shooting at a mall near Milwaukee on Friday afternoon, the authorities said.

headline: Signs of Recent Volcanic Eruption on Mars Hint at Habitats for Life
abstract: Not thought to be volcanically active, Mars may have experienced an eruption just 53,000 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Mars was once home to seas and oceans, and perhaps even life. But our neighboring world has long since dried up and its atmosphere has been blown away, while most activity beneath its surface has long ceased. It’s a dead planet.

headline: Mark Meadows says he won’t run for Senate in North Carolina in 2022.
abstract: Lara Trump, the president’s daughter-in-law who is eyeing a run for Senate in her home state of North Carolina in 2022, is already freezing the field for another Trump loyalist looking for a political future of his own.

abstract: An Argentine who relocated to France, she drew acclaim with “A Very Curious Girl” and other films about female characters who empowered themselves.
lead_paragraph: Nelly Kaplan, whose witty, satire-tinged French films about female empowerment and revenge made her a distinctive voice in a male-dominated era, died on Nov. 12 in Geneva. She was 89.

headline: Trump Campaign Lawyers Step Up but Are Swiftly Knocked Down
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The race to file lawsuits challenging the election results has forced lawyers into mistakes and uncomfortable court appearances.
lead_paragraph: In a chaotic effort to overturn the election results, President Trump and lawyers representing his campaign have spent weeks claiming without convincing proof that rampant voter fraud corrupted vote tallies in many battleground states.

headline: Mnuchin Cites Principles in Clawing Back Fed Money. Democrats See Politics.
abstract: Trump’s Treasury secretary said Congress wanted key economic supports to end by Dec. 31, a view he expressed only after the vote count in the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin broke sharply with the Federal Reserve this week, choosing to end a variety of programs aimed at helping markets, businesses and municipalities weather the pandemic and asking the central bank to return the funds earmarked to support those efforts.

headline: A Final Try by Trump to Cut Drug Prices May Stumble in Court
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A new rule would base the price Medicare pays for certain drugs on the lowest price paid among similar countries. But a rushed process means legal challenges are likely.
lead_paragraph: Health officials on Friday finalized a policy that would base the price Medicare pays for certain drugs on the lowest price paid in some other developed nations. It is the most ambitious of several drug-pricing rules issued in the final months of President Trump’s term, but is likely to be vulnerable to legal challenges.

headline: Met Opera Seeks Pay Cuts in Exchange for Pandemic Paychecks
abstract: The Met is offering many employees their first paycheck in months if their unions agree to long-term cuts.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera has offered to start paying many employees who have been furloughed without pay since April up to $1,500 a week in exchange for new union contracts that include long-term pay cuts, the company’s general manager said in a meeting with staff on Friday.

headline: Tucker Carlson Dared Question a Trump Lawyer. The Backlash Was Quick.
keywords: ['Television', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: The president’s allies quickly closed ranks behind Sidney Powell and her pro-Trump conspiracy theory, accusing the Fox host of betrayal.
lead_paragraph: For more than a week, a plain-spoken former federal prosecutor named Sidney Powell made the rounds on right-wing talk radio and cable news, facing little pushback as she laid out a conspiracy theory that Venezuela, Cuba and other “communist” interests had used a secret algorithm to hack into voting machines and steal millions of votes from President Trump.

headline: Donald Trump Jr. tests positive for coronavirus. He has been isolating since Monday.
abstract: Donald Trump Jr., the president’s son, tested positive for the coronavirus at the beginning of the week and has been isolating since Monday, a spokesman for Mr. Trump said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump Jr., the president’s son, tested positive for the coronavirus at the beginning of the week and has been isolating since Monday, a spokesman for Mr. Trump said on Friday.

headline: Republicans in Congress Stay Largely in Line Behind Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Nearly two weeks after President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. was declared the winner of the election, leading congressional Republicans remain unwilling to recognize his victory, keeping silent on Friday even in the face of President Trump’s increasingly brazen attempts to subvert the results.

headline: Trump’s Legal Team Sets a Precedent for Lowering the Bar

abstract: President Trump and his lawyers are engaged in a spectacle that would be funny if it weren’t so dangerous, and if the stakes weren’t so high.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, who said there would be so much winning in his White House that Americans would grow tired of it, is of a different mind-set these days. He is not, apparently, tired of losing.

headline: A Push Emerges for the First Native American Interior Secretary
keywords: ['Native Americans', 'Federal Lands', 'Land Use Policies', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Environment', 'Drilling and Boring', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']

Biden Jr. to nominate one of Congress’s first Native American women to head the Interior Department, putting an American Indian in control of vast swaths of the continent and the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

Biden Jr. “Very dangerous for our democracy,” said Senator Mitt Romney, Republican of Utah.

Biden Jr. on Friday announced new staff appointments and met with Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the minority leader, maintaining his focus on the economy and the coronavirus pandemic while ignoring President Trump’s continued efforts to subvert the election results.

headline: Senate Republicans could be an obstacle for Biden’s Cabinet nominees.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. was certified as the winner in Georgia, and Michigan Republicans said they had no information that would change the tally in a state Mr. Biden also won.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — President Trump’s attempt to undo the election results was undercut twice by fellow Republicans on Friday, as Georgia became the first contested state to certify Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory and Michigan lawmakers — after meeting with the president — said they would not intervene in their state’s election certification process.

headline: Business and World Leaders Move On as Trump Fights to Reverse Election

abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is seizing the moment, not to aggressively confront the president he defeated, but to act presidential in his stead.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Inside the wrought-iron fences that surround the 18-acre White House complex, the 2020 election rages on, with President Trump angrily refusing to concede. But the rest of the world — and President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. — is moving on.

headline: Pharmacist and Drug Dealer Sentenced to Prison in Plot to Firebomb Rival Pharmacy
abstract: The Nebraska pharmacist was sentenced to nine years and the Maryland drug dealer was sentenced for 14 years for the plot.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 21, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 21, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the political system in Bosnia 25 years after the Dayton Accords misspelled the given name of a woman whose husband was killed during the fighting in Prijedor. She is Zdravka Karlica, not Zvadka.

headline: Humdingers
abstract: Sam Ezersky’s Saturday puzzle, it’s got a few.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I’m a lefty, which means less and less as life modernizes around me, but I still do every weekend grid on paper, in ink, and I call a puzzle like this a lefty special. I had about 90 percent of the right half of this grid totally finished before I wrote a single letter on the left — nothing to smudge. That’s certainly not to say that the right side of this grid was easy for me, but it was a bit less steep a scramble, I guess.

headline: U.S. records 12 millionth case as virus surge gathers speed.
abstract: The United States passed 11 million total coronavirus cases on Sunday, and its caseload has now soared past 12 million. New daily cases are approaching 200,000: on Friday, the country recorded more than 198,500, a record.
lead_paragraph: The United States passed 11 million total coronavirus cases on Sunday, and its caseload has now soared past 12 million. New daily cases are approaching 200,000: on Friday, the country recorded more than 198,500, a record.

headline: Two Chinese port cities mobilize after finding a handful of cases.

lead_paragraph: Two of China’s largest port cities, Shanghai and Tianjin, have announced locally transmitted coronavirus infections, renewing worries about whether the country can continue to keep out the virus after coming close to eradicating it over the summer.

headline: Designed to Deceive: Do These People Look Real to You?

abstract: The people in this story may look familiar, like ones you’ve seen on Facebook or Twitter or Tinder. But they don’t exist. They were born from the mind of a computer, and the technology behind them is improving at a startling pace.

headline: As Pompeo Prepared to Meet Afghan Warring Parties, New Attack Struck Kabul
abstract: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, in Doha, Qatar, met with representatives of the Afghan government and the Taliban, who are at an impasse in peace talks.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Saturday visited the Gulf nation of Qatar, where he met with Afghan and Taliban negotiators who are trying to break a deadlock in their stalled peace negotiations. He landed hours after a deadly rocket attack in Kabul, the latest evidence of the violence spiraling across Afghanistan.

headline: Saudi Arabia and Human Rights Activists Fight Over Kingdom’s Image at G-20
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: As the summit’s host, the kingdom hopes to showcase its advances, while critics see an opportunity to pounce. But the virtual event will have a lower profile.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For Saudi Arabia, hosting the Group of 20 summit in Riyadh this year was supposed to cement its global stature. Heads of state from the world’s richest nations were to be wowed by the kingdom’s rugged beauty and changing society — and encouraged to let its war in Yemen and murder of a prominent journalist drift into the past.

headline: How a Man With a Van Is Challenging U.K. Drug Policy
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Politics and Government', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: A former drug user turned activist is addressing Scotland’s alarming drug death crisis by running the nation’s first drug consumption room — and risking arrest to do it.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — Every Friday for the past two months, Peter Krykant has parked his white van on Parnie Street in central Glasgow, around the corner from a games shop and several art galleries, and waited for people to come by and inject illegal drugs.

headline: You Don’t Have to Fake It Through Thanksgiving
abstract: The need for joy and celebration cannot erase loss, even during the holidays.
lead_paragraph: A mental health professional might describe the period immediately after the death of my husband as shock. Anyone else would have described it as The Holidays.

keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Thanksgiving Day']

keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Book Trade and Publishing']

keywords: ['Kimchi (South Korean Food)', 'Korean Food (Cuisine)', 'Autumn (Season)', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Rural Areas']

lead_paragraph: GOESAN, South Korea — The family van was loaded with a precious cargo — 11 brown plastic boxes filled with 150 pounds of kimchi that Ha Si-nae, her husband and three daughters had made with their own hands.

headline: How One Airline’s Pandemic Hurt Becomes Everyone’s Pain
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Airports', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Virgin Atlantic doesn’t act alone to fly passengers. It relies on a constellation of companies employing people around the globe — all of whom are touched by the disappearance of travelers.
lead_paragraph: After more than a decade working at Manchester Airport in the northwest of England, Tracey Moore finally got the job she wanted — at Virgin Atlantic’s passenger check-in desk. Then, at 3:30 p.m. on Oct. 22, after about a year on the job and months on furlough, she returned to the airport and handed in her uniform.

headline: 1 America, 1 Pandemic, 2 Realities
abstract: Journeys through two states found Americans leading starkly different lives in the pandemic. New Mexico feels at a standstill. In South Dakota, life is going right on.
lead_paragraph: In one pandemic reality, restaurants are packed. There are no coronavirus limits at college-town bars. No social-distancing dots speckling the floor. Some people are wearing masks, but even a weak proposal to make it a requirement in one city prompted an outcry. Welcome to South Dakota.

headline: Antibodies Good. Machine-Made Molecules Better?
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Antibodies', 'Proteins', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Research', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-health']
abstract: With help from computer algorithms, researchers designed proteins from scratch that can trounce the coronavirus in lab animals.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus might be new, but nature long ago gave humans the tools to recognize it, at least on a microscopic scale: antibodies, Y-shaped immune proteins that can latch onto pathogens and block them from infiltrating cells.

headline: This American Mess
abstract: Thanksgiving is here. Unfortunately, America is all over the place.
lead_paragraph: After a record-setting election and record-setting unemployment claims, within a frightening pandemic and between strict diets of misinformation and disinformation, America is ready to have a great meal with loved ones, put our feet up and breathe … on each other.

lead_paragraph: When the screenwriter John Ridley pitched “The Other History of the DC Universe,” a five-part comic book series that looks at pivotal events through the perspectives of several nonwhite DC heroes, he knew Black Lightning would be at its center. Ridley was 11 when he met the hero in 1977.

headline: How to Cook French Cuisine at Home
abstract: It may be a while before you’re able to travel to France again. So grab some butter and try to recreate the country’s delicious meals in your own kitchen.

headline: 18 Five-Ingredient Thanksgiving Recipes
abstract: Keep the holiday grocery list short.

You could make Samin Nosrat’s buttermilk-brined turkey breast (above) as your centerpiece, and Samantha Seneviratne’s drop biscuits and Sarah DiGregorio’s slow cooker cranberry sauce on the side. headline: I Broke My Lease. Do I Still Have to Pay the Rent?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Tenants are on the hook when they break a lease — but only if the landlord makes a reasonable effort to re-rent the apartment. How do you know if they’re doing that?
lead_paragraph: Q: Over the summer, my husband and I broke the lease on our Chelsea apartment and moved to the suburbs. Our landlord told us that we could only get out of the lease if a replacement tenant were found. We completed the walk-through, handed in the keys and have continued to pay rent every month while the landlord looks for the replacement. But how do we know if he found someone? Is it possible that the apartment has been rented and we’re still paying rent?

headline: For Netanyahu and Israel, Trump’s Gifts Kept on Coming

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon bring us a feathery, toothsome puzzle.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — After all these years, it’s just sinking in that Team Cox/Rathvon would definitely have a bird mascot; many of my favorite acrostics are ornithological or at least bird-adjacent, with affection. Today’s puzzle corresponds with Thanksgiving, but the excerpt concerns the way that birds eat nuts, rather than vice versa.

headline: Ending Obesity, and Its Stigma
abstract: Readers discuss coming to terms with body image, and doctors offer their perspectives.

headline: Duty or Party? For Republicans, a Test of Whether to Enable Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Electoral College', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In pushing his false claims to the limits and cowing Republicans into acquiescence or silence, President Trump has revealed the fragility of the electoral system — and shaken it.
lead_paragraph: For the next three weeks, the integrity of American democracy is in the hands of people like Norman D. Shinkle, a proud Michigander who has, until recently, served in relative obscurity on the state board that certifies vote results.

headline: Trump Using Last Days to Lock In Policies and Make Biden’s Task More Difficult
keywords: ['Presidential Transition (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Economy', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: At a wide range of departments and agencies, Mr. Trump’s political appointees are going to extraordinary lengths to try to prevent Mr. Biden from rolling back the president’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Voters have decided that President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. should guide the country through the next four years. But on issues of war, the environment, criminal justice, trade, the economy and more, President Trump and top administration officials are doing what they can to make changing direction more difficult.

headline: Jan Morris, a Distinctive Guide Who Took Readers Around the World
abstract: Morris, who died on Friday at 94, was an inveterate traveler who wrote acclaimed books about Venice, Hong Kong, New York and many other places.
lead_paragraph: Jan Morris was, one suspects, more prepared for death — to face that moment when one’s agent becomes one’s executor — than are many others. For one thing, she lived a long and eventful life, dying on Friday in Wales at 94. For another, she was forward-thinking enough to leave a book behind to be published upon the news of her pegging out. That manuscript, she cheerfully told an interviewer in 2012, is “with the publishers, waiting for me to kick the bucket!”

headline: Who Will We Be Without Donald Trump?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: He lost. We’ll have to stop obsessing about him.
lead_paragraph: A friend was all worked up about the possibility of Trump 2024.

headline: America Is Letting the Coronavirus Rage Through Prisons
abstract: It’s both a moral failure and a public health one.
lead_paragraph: As Americans grapple with how — or whether — to gather with loved ones this holiday season, the roughly two million people confined in the nation’s prisons and jails face an even grimmer challenge: how to stay alive inside a system being ravaged by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Lines Form at New York Testing Centers Ahead of Thanksgiving
abstract: Long lines, some forming before coronavirus testing sites opened for the day, grew outside locations across New York City ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday, as cases of the virus continued to soar nationwide.
lead_paragraph: Long lines, some forming before coronavirus testing sites opened for the day, grew outside locations across New York City ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday, as cases of the virus continued to soar nationwide.

headline: Choose a Gift That Changes Lives
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Children and Childhood', 'Women and Girls', 'Education (K-12)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Cataracts', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Foster Care', 'Gifts', 'Holidays and Special Occasions']
abstract: Educate a girl. Send a young person to college. Restore a person’s sight.
lead_paragraph: This will be a painful holiday season in many households, with fewer people hugging and handing out gifts. But if you’re feeling that the holidays have been “canceled” and you’re struggling to find hope and meaning this season, have I got some uplifting ideas for you!

headline: Sorry, but a negative test does not give you a green light for Thanksgiving.
abstract: This year, as they prepare to let turkeys brine and pie crusts thaw, people across the country are waiting for something extra: a coronavirus test they hope can clear them to mingle with loved ones.
lead_paragraph: This year, as they prepare to let turkeys brine and pie crusts thaw, people across the country are waiting for something extra: a coronavirus test they hope can clear them to mingle with loved ones.

headline: 52 Years Later, IBM Apologizes for Firing Transgender Woman
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Apologies', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Discrimination', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: Lynn Conway was one of the company’s most promising young computer engineers but after confiding to supervisors that she was transgender, they fired her.
lead_paragraph: In August 1968, Lynn Conway, a promising computer engineer at IBM in Sunnyvale, Calif., was called into the office of Gene Myron Amdahl, then the company’s director of advanced computing systems.

headline: Fighting the pandemic and healing its economic damage dominate talks at the G20 summit.
abstract: Proposals discussed by the world richest 19 countries and the European Union included agreements on global vaccine distribution and debt relief for poor countries hard hit by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Discussions on how to tackle the coronavirus pandemic and deal with the global economic damage it has wrought dominated the Group of 20 summit, which began on Saturday and is being hosted virtually by Saudi Arabia.

headline: Arthur Imperatore, Founder of a Critical Ferry Service, Dies at 95
abstract: He steered New York Waterway through financial straits. He also reveled in moments of glory, notably when his boats rode to the rescue on Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: Arthur E. Imperatore Sr., a blunt entrepreneur who parlayed a trucking fortune into a dubious ferryboat operation that grew to be a critical link in New York City’s transit network, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Politics, Science and the Remarkable Race for a Coronavirus Vaccine
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Clinical Trials', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Public-Private Sector Cooperation', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The furious race to develop a coronavirus vaccine played out against a presidential election, between a pharmaceutical giant and a biotech upstart, with the stakes as high as they could get.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The call was tense, the message discouraging. Moncef Slaoui, the head of the Trump administration’s effort to quickly produce a vaccine for the coronavirus, was on the phone at 6 p.m. on Aug. 25 to tell the upstart biotech firm Moderna that it had to slow the final stage of testing its vaccine in humans.

headline: Hong Kong and Singapore put their planned travel bubble on hold.
abstract: The governments of Hong Kong and Singapore have temporarily scrapped a plan for a travel bubble, as Hong Kong grapples with a spike in coronavirus infections. The delay underscores the challenges of reopening international travel routes as efforts to control the virus remain unstable across the world.
lead_paragraph: The governments of Hong Kong and Singapore have temporarily scrapped a plan for a travel bubble, as Hong Kong grapples with a spike in coronavirus infections. The delay underscores the challenges of reopening international travel routes as efforts to control the virus remain unstable across the world.

headline: It All Adds Up
abstract: Alex Eaton-Salners, your Sunday puzzle: Do the math.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — There is no rebus in this grid today, if that’s why you're here, although I certainly don’t blame you for wondering. Alex Eaton-Salners is the constructor who slipped a single rebus into his last Sunday puzzle, back in September; his constructions are always intricate, often surprising, and usually complex in their creation (check his notes for more on that). Today’s theme is extremely clean, but made for a messy presentation on my paper solve, a good lesson in loosening up a bit.

headline: The latest virus wave appears to have crested in Europe, but the struggle is far from over.
abstract: The latest wave of the coronavirus has inundated Europe after a summer in which many of its countries appeared to have brought the pandemic under control more effectively than the Americas did.
lead_paragraph: The latest wave of the coronavirus has inundated Europe after a summer in which many of its countries appeared to have brought the pandemic under control more effectively than the Americas did.

headline: Judge Dismisses Trump Lawsuit Seeking to Delay Certification in Pennsylvania
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Absentee Voting', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: In a scathing order, a federal judge rejected the Trump campaign’s claim of widespread improprieties with mail-in ballots, removing a major legal hurdle to certifying Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory there.

headline: F.D.A. Grants Emergency Authorization of Antibody Treatment Given to Trump
abstract: The treatment, made by the biotech company Regeneron, is a cocktail of two powerful antibodies that have shown promise for people who get it early in the course of the disease.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has granted emergency authorization for the experimental antibody treatment given to President Trump shortly after he was diagnosed with Covid-19, giving doctors another option to treat Covid-19 patients as cases across the country continue to rise.

headline: The F.D.A. grants emergency authorization of the coronavirus antibody treatment given to Trump.
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration has granted emergency authorization for the experimental antibody treatment given to President Trump shortly after he tested positive for  the coronavirus, giving doctors another option to treat patients as cases across the country continue to rise.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has granted emergency authorization for the experimental antibody treatment given to President Trump shortly after he tested positive for  the coronavirus, giving doctors another option to treat patients as cases across the country continue to rise.

headline: Protesters in Guatemala Set Fire to Congress Building Over Spending Cuts
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'ARSON']
abstract: After two hurricanes displaced thousands of people and wrecked infrastructure, a bill that cut spending on health and education and bolstered lawmakers’ meal stipends touched off a wave of anger in the capital.
lead_paragraph: ANTIGUA, Guatemala — Thousands of protesters took to the streets in Guatemala’s capital on Saturday, setting fire to the nation’s congressional building in a show of anger over a budget bill passed this week that cut funding for health care and education.

headline: South Dakota and New Mexico offer a snapshot of the alternate realities in the U.S. pandemic.
abstract: Known coronavirus cases in the United States have now surpassed 12 million, and the daily routines of a vast number of Americans are now shaped by their ZIP codes and governors and beliefs about the virus. Do they wear masks? Go to school in person or online? Eat out? Get exposed to the virus?
lead_paragraph: Known coronavirus cases in the United States have now surpassed 12 million, and the daily routines of a vast number of Americans are now shaped by their ZIP codes and governors and beliefs about the virus. keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Art', 'Philanthropy', 'Content Type: Service', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Finances', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Theater', 'Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers', 'Turkeys', 'Handicrafts', 'Thanksgiving Day']
abstract: Spend this holiday week experimenting with turkey bones, painting botanical art or running a virtual race.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia is in isolation after testing positive for the virus.
abstract: Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia, a Republican who is campaigning in a high-stakes runoff election that could determine control of the Senate, is isolating after testing positive for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia, a Republican who is campaigning in a high-stakes runoff election that could determine control of the Senate, is isolating after testing positive for the coronavirus on Friday evening and then receiving an inconclusive result on Saturday, a campaign spokesman said.

headline: Scatter Paper Leaves to Dress Up Your Table
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Newspapers', 'Handicrafts', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Tableware']
abstract: With a little paint and accordion folding, your newspaper can become décor for your Thanksgiving table.
lead_paragraph: This Thanksgiving, whether you’re hosting guests or sharing a meal via Zoom, it’s worth the effort to dress up your table to make the day feel different, special even. Fall leaves are an obvious and lovely decorative element but if yours have withered or blown away, create a few leaves of your own from accordion-folded paper.

headline: Settle In for the Season With These Films
abstract: As the cold weather descends, warm your heart with a sports movie or get your blood pumping with suspenseful thrillers.
lead_paragraph: We’ve reached that time of year when the small screen is filled with Christmas movies, populated by happy folks in coats and scarves, frolicking in the snow. This will not be a list of those kinds of films. This collection is more for all of you who love the chilly weather, but who can’t stand “Jingle Bell Rock.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: Dolly: Country Music Legend, Songwriter, Pandemic Hero
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 22, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Shakespeare may have written King Lear during the plague, but Dolly Parton funded a Covid vaccine, dropped a Christmas album and a Christmas special.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 22, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 22, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the political correspondent Abby Phillip misstated the year CNN hired her. It was 2017, not 2018.

headline: On Running While Black, With More Hope Than Before
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Running', 'Whites', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: As Black Lives Matter signs popped up in recent months, our columnist grew less wary of running in predominantly white neighborhoods. But is that optimism premature?
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The bloom of the Black Lives Matter signs. That is what my son and I saw as we jogged through our mostly white neighborhood. Everywhere we looked, we could see what felt like change.

headline: Dear Jets: There’s Hope to Be Found in a Winless Season. Take It From Someone Who Knows.
abstract: For one thing, you are leading the race for the top draft pick. But seriously, even finishing at 0-16 can yield valuable resilience. So says Hue Jackson, who coached the winless 2017 Cleveland Browns.
lead_paragraph: Only two N.F.L. teams in history have gone 0-16 since the regular season expanded to 16 games in 1978: the Detroit Lions in 2008 and the Cleveland Browns in 2017.

headline: ‘I Was on My Sunset Walk When I Came Upon a Gorgeous Ballerina’
abstract: A dancer at the water’s edge, seeing a scary movie and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Even Harry Styles in Jorts Can’t Save Gucci’s Mini-Series
abstract: Neither could Billie Eilish. Or Gus Van Sant. “Ouverture” was a stab at an art house fashion film that doesn’t quite come off. But Guccifest was a different story.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, back when most live fashion shows got canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic and digital shows took their place, I had a moment of hope. I thought that maybe fashion brands would seize the moment to do something new.

headline: Along Russia’s ‘Road of Bones,’ Relics of Suffering and Despair
abstract: The Kolyma Highway in the Russian Far East once delivered tens of thousands of prisoners to the work camps of Stalin’s gulag. The ruins of that cruel era are still visible today.
lead_paragraph: The prisoners, hacking their way through insect-infested summer swamps and winter ice fields, brought the road, and the road then brought yet more prisoners, delivering a torrent of slave labor to the gold mines and prison camps of Kolyma, the most frigid and deadly outpost of Stalin’s gulag.

headline: New York City Hit a 3% Positive Test Rate. Or Did It?
abstract: The city and state use different approaches for calculations. That has led to confusion and has a big impact on which restrictions are adopted.
lead_paragraph: Three percent.

headline: Hollywood’s ‘We’re Not in Kansas Anymore’ Moment
abstract: The announcement that “Wonder Woman 1984” will be released in theaters and on HBO Max on Christmas Day is the clearest sign that streaming is now central to the film industry’s business model.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In explaining why WarnerMedia had decided to release the much-anticipated big-budget “Wonder Woman 1984” simultaneously in theaters and on the streaming service HBO Max on Christmas Day, the company’s chief executive, Jason Kilar, invoked the classic Hollywood film “The Wizard of Oz.”

headline: Newsmax, Once a Right-Wing Also-Ran, Is Rising, and Trump Approves
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'News and News Media', 'Television', 'Cable Television']
abstract: A once-niche conservative cable network, owned by a longtime friend of the president, lures audiences by refusing to declare an electoral winner.
lead_paragraph: Flanked by aides in the Oval Office on Wednesday, President Trump dialed up a friend in the news media with a message: Keep up the good work.

headline: How Trump Hopes to Use Party Machinery to Retain Control of the G.O.P.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2024', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ronna McDaniel, a close ally of President Trump, wants to remain head of the Republican National Committee, worrying party members who believe the president will try to use the group to keep control of the G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: As President Trump brazenly seeks to delay the certification of the election in hopes of overturning his defeat, he is also mounting a less high-profile but similarly audacious bid to keep control of the Republican National Committee even after he leaves office.

headline: Can We Make Our Robots Less Biased Than We Are?
keywords: ['Artificial Intelligence', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Facial Recognition Software', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: A.I. developers are committing to end the injustices in how their technology is often made and used.
lead_paragraph: On a summer night in Dallas in 2016, a bomb-handling robot made technological history. Police officers had attached roughly a pound of C-4 explosive to it, steered the device up to a wall near an active shooter and detonated the charge. In the explosion, the assailant, Micah Xavier Johnson, became the first person in the United States to be killed by a police robot.

headline: Fatal Shooting of 2 Black Teenagers by Florida Deputy Is Under Investigation
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Relatives are demanding answers about the shooting deaths of Angelo Crooms, 16, and Sincere Pierce, 18, by a sheriff’s deputy in Cocoa, Fla.
lead_paragraph: The authorities are investigating the fatal shooting by a Florida sheriff’s deputy of two Black teenagers who were in a moving car during an encounter with law enforcement.

headline: Thanksgiving, Coronavirus, Presidential Transition: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: This Is Getting Awkward
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: The Trump administration is drawing down pandemic aid, but the economy needs all the help it can get.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weirdest Thanksgiving week ever. Whether you’re staying home — an excellent choice — or taking your chances by traveling, be safe, and keep your gathering small. (Remember, that means more pie for you.) — Charlotte Cowles

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Man to Man’
abstract: Wil S. Hylton’s cousin was his hero. Until the day that cousin tried to kill him.
lead_paragraph: For years, Wil S. Hylton had been drawn to his cousin’s strength and violence. He was pulled in by the archetype that he embodied and was envious of the power he seemed to command.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Senator Kelly Loeffler is in isolation after conflicting virus test results.
abstract: Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia, a Republican who is campaigning in a high-stakes runoff election that could determine control of the Senate, is isolating “out of an abundance of caution,” a campaign spokesman said Sunday, after a series of coronavirus tests delivered mixed messages about whether she had contracted the disease. The latest results showed that she had tested negative.
lead_paragraph: Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia, a Republican who is campaigning in a high-stakes runoff election that could determine control of the Senate, is isolating “out of an abundance of caution,” a campaign spokesman said Sunday, after a series of coronavirus tests delivered mixed messages about whether she had contracted the disease. The latest results showed that she had tested negative.

headline: N.Y.C. says 3 percent of its coronavirus tests reveal infections. Why does the state disagree?
abstract: A 3 percent positive rate in coronavirus testing is a critical threshold for New York City. It is the point at which the mayor shut down public schools last week. The governor says that a sustained 3 percent level in the city will result in banning indoor dining, closing gyms and hair salons, and placing a 25-person cap on attendance at houses of worship even as the holidays approach.
lead_paragraph: A 3 percent positive rate in coronavirus testing is a critical threshold for New York City. It is the point at which the mayor shut down public schools last week. The governor says that a sustained 3 percent level in the city will result in banning indoor dining, closing gyms and hair salons, and placing a 25-person cap on attendance at houses of worship even as the holidays approach.

headline: Machine-made molecules fight the coronavirus in lab animals.
abstract: A team of researchers at the University of Washington has designed and built from scratch a molecule that, when pitted against the coronavirus in the lab, can attack and sequester it at least as well as an antibody does.
lead_paragraph: A team of researchers at the University of Washington has designed and built from scratch a molecule that, when pitted against the coronavirus in the lab, can attack and sequester it at least as well as an antibody does.

headline: Guitar Center Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: The filing by the nation’s largest retailer of musical instruments highlights the growing gap between the strongest and weakest companies in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Guitar Center, the country’s largest retailer of musical instruments, filed for bankruptcy protection late Saturday night.

headline: John Belushi in Focus: What a New Film Gets Right and What It Misses
abstract: After Bob Woodward’s “Wired” focused too much on the comic’s death, this documentary looks fondly at the star’s life. But his comic genius deserves more.
lead_paragraph: In his brief six years on the national stage, no comic was more popular than John Belushi. At the height of his fame, in the late 1970s, he eclipsed even Steve Martin and Robin Williams by starring in the top-rated new phenomenon, “Saturday Night Live” and what was then the highest grossing film comedy ever, “Animal House,” while his band, the Blues Brothers, had the country’s No. 1 album, “Briefcase Full of Blues.”

headline: 2 Sonic Drive-In Workers Die in Nebraska Shooting
abstract: Two other employees were injured in the shooting on Saturday night. A man was arrested, but a motive for the episode was unclear.
lead_paragraph: Two employees of a Sonic Drive-In were killed and two others were injured in a shooting on Saturday night in Nebraska, the authorities said.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: It’s the run-up to Thanksgiving, and time to start preparing for the meal, even if it’s a bit smaller this year.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. This is a big day for Thanksgiving preparations even if all you’re going to be doing is making these turkey cutlets Marsala (above) that I learned to cook while reading and writing about Elizabeth David. (They’re good with vegetable risotto and roasted brussels sprouts.) You’ve got to secure the ingredients, after all, and you really ought to make a plan for what the table’s going to look like on Thursday, how you want the meal to go, smaller than usual, in this most curious year.

headline: Drag Proms and Comfort Food With Truffles
abstract: And: Georgina Bloomberg on being the child of a politician.
lead_paragraph: With the New York charity circuit on hiatus, here is how some philanthropists and society figures are spending their time and resources during the pandemic.

headline: Abandon Your Thanksgiving Script
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parties (Social)']
abstract: This year, we have a chance to build a different kind of holiday.
lead_paragraph: This is the year for an improv Thanksgiving.

headline: A Brazilian Writer Saw a Tweet as Tame Satire. Then Came the Lawsuits.
keywords: ['Ministers (Protestant)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The writer J.P. Cuenca calls it “Kafka in the tropics.” Evangelical pastors have filed at least 130 suits against him over a tweet, part of an increasingly common strategy against critics.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The acerbic tweet came naturally to the Brazilian novelist and journalist J.P. Cuenca, who was several months into a quarantine doom-scrolling routine.

headline: Getting Ready for a Pandemic Thanksgiving
abstract: Readers offer cautions for those determined to celebrate in the usual way.

abstract: The Anti-Defamation League supports legislation that would “enhance the accuracy” of F.B.I. statistics. Also: Exit Trump.
