headline: Words of Gratitude From New Hampshire
abstract: The New York Times asked poets laureate from across the country what the people in their states had to be thankful for in this difficult year.
lead_paragraph: In New Hampshire, residents are grateful to look outside their parenthesis of social distancing and after all that Zooming, all those Google classrooms, see Mount Washington in their living room window. Real trees brush the outside of their green screens; the lakes region and ocean are quickly accessed on either side of gadgets. We appreciate the beauty of the natural and the virtual world, the virtual for giving us our hyphens of connection. The lonely winter light hitting the brick buildings of mill towns. The stone walls that are everywhere in New Hampshire, echoes of the resilient people who tackled the rocks of difficulty before us, rolled up their sleeves, and survived.

headline: A Poem of Gratitude From Mississippi
abstract: The New York Times asked poets laureate from across the country what the people in their states had to be thankful for in this difficult year.
lead_paragraph: Grateful for old men, white and Black, weathered as the sweet potatoes they hawk from the beds of their pickups at every other highway exit. Grateful for the sweet-potato-colored dirt those tubers are pulled from. Grateful for bales of hay, both blocky like Legos and round like sushi. Not grateful for sushi in Mississippi, but for 16/20 gulf shrimp sold in coolers at Texacos. Grateful for the mystery of tamales. For fireflies, bald cypress, magnolia green jumper spiders. Grateful to launch ruby-throats over the gulf each autumn. Grateful to be their welcome mat come spring. Grateful to be counted on: One Mississippi, Two. Grateful for the word y’all. Grateful for the emphatic all y’all. For all y’all in this state of hospitality: Grateful.

headline: Words of Gratitude From Utah
abstract: The New York Times asked poets laureate from across the country what the people in their states had to be thankful for in this difficult year.
lead_paragraph: These past months, I’ve seen something unusual: crowds in the canyons. The pandemic has forced people out of gyms and into our mountains and parks. It’s made our wild spaces more multiracial; I now get stopped regularly by Latinx and Pacific Islander families asking about the nearest trailhead. Children cluster on trails to exclaim over a tarantula or a coyote whisking into the brush. An influx of red squirrels has swelled the raptor population in Salt Lake, and now strangers collect at sunset to bird watch. We think of nature as escape, but now it’s a safe place to be together. Our mountains have become a respite from our solitude, and for that, I am grateful.

headline: Words of Gratitude From California
abstract: The New York Times asked poets laureate from across the country what the people in their states had to be thankful for in this difficult year.
lead_paragraph: It’s not hard for Californians to know whom to thank in 2020. Four million acres of the Golden State went up in flames this fall. We thank — profoundly and prodigiously — the fire, police and emergency personnel, as well as the prison volunteers, who risked their own safety to protect us. My wife and I had to evacuate twice this year. When we finally returned to our smoky house (which had just been repaired from last year’s inferno), we didn’t take for granted that it was still there. On behalf of 40 million Californians, let me utter a humongous gracias.

headline: Words of Gratitude From Florida
abstract: The New York Times asked poets laureate from across the country what the people in their states had to be thankful for in this difficult year.
lead_paragraph: Florida’s too flat and too hot; it voted for Trump and would again if given a chance. It ranks at the bottom in teacher’s pay. We live in St. Petersburg, the lightning capital of the world. We have a royal palm tree growing right next to our house, probably deposited there by one of the exotic birds, an ibis or great white egret, strutting around here. Writers and artists flock to Florida with the other immigrants, giving us good conversations and plenty of unknown cheap restaurants from distant countries. When we plant something it starts growing immediately. Maybe we love it because it’s not boring, or just boring enough.

headline: The Weekend of Personal Leftovers
abstract: It’s a good weekend for tying up loose ends.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. The weekend after Thanksgiving is, for many of us, time for leftovers, when the turkey and sides are summoned for their encore: as sandwich fixings, as stuffing croutons, as turkey pho. Of course, Thanksgiving was likely a smaller affair this year, so leftovers might be in short supply in the kitchen.

headline: Assaults and Occupations in Wartime
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Revolutionary War, American (1775-83)']
abstract: Two new books look at men in battle and civilians under occupation.
lead_paragraph: Academic histories are all very well, but at times it is a pleasure to sit back and wallow in an old-school military tale of flinty-eyed men doing battle. That is what James Holland, a seasoned craftsman, offers in SICILY ’43: The First Assault on Fortress Europe (Atlantic Monthly Press, $30). He doesn’t wade into gender issues, “periodization,” patriarchism or other currently fashionable matters. Rather, he simply gives us a history of Anglo-Saxon males slaughtering one another while Italians mainly try to get out of the way. Academic historians like to call a certain optimistic type of approach “Whig history.” By contrast, I’d call Holland’s book “Tory history” — and mean it mainly as a compliment.

headline: Words of Gratitude From Maine
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Poets Laureate']
abstract: The New York Times asked poets laureate from across the country what the people in their states had to be thankful for in this difficult year.
lead_paragraph: Gale-force winds along the coast in the morning, gusting up to 60 miles per hour. A Norway maple comes down in our backyard, falling on both cars, taking down the power line, and ripping the cable and electrical meter right off the side of the house. We call the power company. There are power outages throughout Maine and the crews have to wait until the wind dies down. Around 9 p.m. we hear the bucket truck pulling up. Two men, one just starting out, the other a veteran, get out, turn their head lamps on and work in the dark, lifting the line and reattaching it. We thank them, these men doing their jobs. Line by line, through the woods, off miles of two-lane roads, power gets restored. “You’re our last stop for the night,” one says. “We’re going home for supper after this.”

headline: Words of Gratitude From Alabama
abstract: The New York Times asked poets laureate from across the country what the people in their states had to be thankful for in this difficult year.
lead_paragraph: In Alabama, we’ve been grateful for a long, beautiful spring, a not-too-hot summer and a fall that’s been about as perfect as fall can be in the South, enabling us to see friends and family in safer, outdoor settings. A statewide mask mandate, in place since July, helped further slow the spread of Covid-19. In a state that loves its college football, schools have been able to hold at least some games, making life feel a little more normal to many. People here rally to help each other out in times of crisis, while those fighting to end systemic injustice have persisted in their efforts. One, the environmental health advocate Catherine Coleman Flowers, was recently named a MacArthur Fellow for her work to improve the lives of rural Alabamians.

headline: Words of Gratitude From North Carolina
abstract: The New York Times asked poets laureate from across the country what the people in their states had to be thankful for in this difficult year.
lead_paragraph: In this season of uncertainty and collective heaviness North Carolinians are proud of the many ways we have gathered together to take care of each other. From state and local governances to essential health care workers; there are innovative community farms, front yard potlucks feeding thousands over a weekend, and virtual arts, cultural and political programming that remind us to remember who we really are as a kind, generous and humble people who thrive close to the land and hold family close.

headline: Words of Gratitude From Montana
abstract: The New York Times asked poets laureate from across the country what the people in their states had to be thankful for in this difficult year.
lead_paragraph: In February, after 125 years, the Little Shell Tribe of Chippewa Indians was finally granted federal recognition. In October, the flags of eight tribal nations of Montana were permanently mounted next to that of the U.S. and Montana state flags at our Capitol. After the recent election, Montana can boast of having the highest percentage of American Indian representation in a State Legislature, making Montana one of very few states to reach racial parity. Our Indian Education for All Act provides for a statewide curriculum that expands understanding and awareness of American Indian history for all students. Here in Montana, we have much to celebrate.

headline: Words of Gratitude From Maryland
abstract: The New York Times asked poets laureate from across the country what the people in their states had to be thankful for in this difficult year.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, there have been more people than ever introduced to poetry via Zoom, remote communications and virtual meetings — people chose to shine light into isolation. You can’t hold back light. Workshops, gatherings, readings flourish online. Poetry is spirit and can’t be stopped by calamity. We’re grateful that poetry has come down off Mount Olympus, and 2021 will start with many more courageous, eager to write — to discover who they are, and to discover their antecedents. Everybody has a story. We learned that this year and, thankfully, next year we’re going to expand on it.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Invisible Americans’ and ‘Hunter’s Moon’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: INVISIBLE AMERICANS: The Tragic Cost of Child Poverty, by Jeff Madrick. (Vintage, 240 pp., $16.95.) In an “exception” to the complex proposals routinely suggested by so-called experts, Madrick offers an idea “so simple that even a child could understand it”: a government-funded allowance to families with children under 18 that would equal $4,000-$5,000 per child each year. As Alissa Quart, our reviewer, put it, “it would be unconditional, like love.”

headline: A Pinwheel Pie as Appealing as Her Fashion Designs
keywords: ['Vegetables', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Pies', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Laura Kim shares a recipe for an updated version of a dish her mother used to make to entice her to eat vegetables.
lead_paragraph: When Laura Kim was a child, her mother used all kinds of tricks to get her to eat. “She made it a sort of theater,” says the formerly finicky Kim, who, along with Fernando Garcia, is co-creative director of both Oscar de la Renta and Monse (the label she and Garcia launched in 2015). In a nod to Kim’s childhood nickname, Tokki, which is Korean for “bunny,” rabbit-shaped egg dishes often turned up on her plate and, she says, “My lunchboxes would always have fruit and vegetables cut up like animals inside.” Clearly, Kim’s mother already knew that her daughter was a visual person. Somewhere along the way, Kim also became a food person and, by the age of 9, was honing her skills at making duk gook, a Korean rice cake soup.

headline: Theaster Gates Turns the Stain of the Past Into Art
abstract: In his show at Gagosian, he merges the language of abstract art with the legacies of racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: Theaster Gates, a social practice installation artist based in Chicago, is turning the history of Black labor in America on its head. Born in 1973 to a father who was a roofer, Mr. Gates embraced, too, a life of working with his hands. After graduating from Iowa State University with a degree in urban planning and ceramics, he proceeded to Japan to study pottery. In “Black Vessel,” his first New York solo show at Gagosian on West 24th Street, he succeeds in celebrating the rugged, hard work of artisans today.

abstract: For months, demonstrators have kept up their demands for resignations and reforms.
lead_paragraph: There is something noble and inspiring about masses of people rising up to demand democracy. Such movements may not always succeed in ushering in better government — witness Hong Kong, or the Arab Spring — but even when they do not, they deliver an indelible message that elemental freedoms cannot be forever denied.

headline: Dena Dietrich, Who Found TV Fame as Mother Nature, Dies at 91
abstract: In a long acting career she was best known for wreaking havoc in a series of margarine commercials, warning, “It’s not nice to fool Mother Nature.”
lead_paragraph: Dena Dietrich, the kindly face and fearsome power of Mother Nature to American television viewers in the 1970s, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. She was 91.

headline: In ‘This Is Your Time,’ Ruby Bridges Urges a New Generation to Keep Fighting
abstract: The trailblazer’s best seller is intended for a middle grade audience, but her message of persistence is relevant to people of all ages.
lead_paragraph: VISIBLE GEM This has been a bittersweet month for Ruby Bridges, the civil rights icon who was the first Black student to integrate an all-white school in New Orleans. On Nov. 10, four days before the 60th anniversary of her first day at William Frantz Elementary, Bridges’ mother died at the age of 86. Lucille Bridges was known for escorting her 6-year-old to school under the guard of federal marshals while protesters chanted and threw eggs. This went on for a full school year.

headline: This Wrongly Convicted Man Spent 25 Thanksgivings in Prison
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Throat']
abstract: This holiday, he says he’s thankful. Are you?
lead_paragraph: In 1995, I was a 25-year-old Brooklyn father of a one-and-a-half-year-old son. I had recently joined The Times and had become the paper’s youngest newsroom department head since a man named Lester Markel was named Sunday editor in 1923.

headline: A Turkey Recipe for 2020
abstract: How to feel better about this horrible year.

headline: James D. Wolfensohn, Who Led the World Bank for 10 Years, Dies at 86
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: He was a force on Wall Street before taking the reins of the bank in 1995, then proceeded to shake it up. He did the same at both Carnegie Hall and the Kennedy Center.
lead_paragraph: James D. Wolfensohn, who escaped a financially pinched Australian childhood to become a top Wall Street deal maker and a two-term president of the World Bank, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Biden Urges Unity: ‘We’re at War With the Virus, Not With One Another’
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In an emotional address, he pleaded with Americans to “hang on” and cited the death of his son to say that he understood the loss in the nation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday delivered a raw but optimistic address to Americans in his first nonpolitical speech since winning the election, pleading with the nation to “hang on” and have hope even with the number of coronavirus cases spiking across the country and a hard winter on the horizon.

headline: Biden’s Cabinet: Whom He’s Picked So Far
keywords: ['Presidential Transition (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The makeup of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inner circle is becoming clearer as the transition to his administration begins.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the Trump administration having authorized the beginning of the formal transition process, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is slowly naming the individuals he hopes will guide him through his first term as president and help shape his thinking in the years ahead.

headline: Sewage may offer early signs of coronavirus outbreaks.
abstract: People infected with the coronavirus may shed extremely high amounts of virus in their stool even before they show symptoms — if they ever do — suggesting that testing wastewater may offer health officials a way to spot budding community outbreaks early, researchers have found.
lead_paragraph: People infected with the coronavirus may shed extremely high amounts of virus in their stool even before they show symptoms — if they ever do — suggesting that testing wastewater may offer health officials a way to spot budding community outbreaks early, researchers have found.

headline: The Best Books to Give This Year
abstract: What better way to spread joy than with books? We've rounded up 62 new titles, from thrillers to cookbooks to photography books and more, for every type of reader.
lead_paragraph: What better way to spread joy than with books? We've rounded up 62 new titles, from thrillers to cookbooks to photography books and more, for every type of reader.

headline: How Not to Overspend This Black Friday
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Shopping and Retail', 'E-Commerce', 'Gifts', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Holidays and Special Occasions']
abstract: Have a list, a budget and some patience.
lead_paragraph: In a year characterized by an unremitting and unfortunate strangeness, it’s no surprise that Black Friday and Cyber Monday 2020 fit right in. Black Friday “preview” promotions started weeks early in mid-October, hot on the heels of Amazon Prime Day, which had been bumped from its traditional mid-July time slot to Oct. 13 and 14. Retailers began a rotating slate of sales, trumpeting that the best Black Friday deals were actually the early deals.

headline: Quotation of the Day: As Surge Spreads, No Corner of Nation Is Spared
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 26, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Covid didn’t care what I believed.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 26, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 26, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about the Kolyma Highway in Russia misstated the surname of a rocket scientist who survived political imprisonment and later helped put the first man in space. He is Sergei Korolev, not Kovalyov.

headline: One Nation, Under Maradona
abstract: Images from the life of one of soccer’s — and Argentina’s — biggest icons.
lead_paragraph: The Uruguayan writer Eduardo Galeano once called Diego Maradona “the most human of the gods.” Argentines were happy to edit that down, to the singular version of the last word.

headline: Babe in the Woods
abstract: Neville Fogarty stretches the bounds of reality.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — First, on behalf of the New York Times Games team, I would like to wish you all a peaceful holiday, no matter how you might be celebrating it this year. We know that there are many crossword puzzles and online games to be played, and we are thankful that you chose The New York Times.

headline: Two Texas Men Charged With Scheme to Sell 50 Million Nonexistent N95 Masks
abstract: The Houston-area men charged a foreign government more than $317 million for the masks, about five times the public list price, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Two Houston-area men have been indicted by a federal grand jury on charges that they negotiated a deal to sell 50 million nonexistent N95 masks to a foreign government in an attempt to defraud it out of over $317 million, federal officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Maradona, Covid-19, Macron: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New Rule Would Allow U.S. to Use More Methods for Executions
abstract: The rule, which would permit methods including firing squads and electrocution, comes as the administration rushes to execute five more prisoners before President Trump’s term ends.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has created new regulations allowing for the use of more methods for federal executions, including firing squad and electrocution.

headline: Biden Brings the Gang Back Together
abstract: The Obama administration, Part 2, takes shape: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: The stock market surges as the transition moves ahead — and progressives have a clear message: Don’t forget about us. It’s Wednesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: N.F.L. Week 12 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
abstract: Baltimore’s game against Pittsburgh is delayed until at least Tuesday and the Broncos have to play New Orleans without a quarterback as the N.F.L.’s struggles with the coronavirus continue.
lead_paragraph: A pair of blowouts on Thanksgiving served as a fairly entertaining start to a week that includes must-watch matchups like the Kansas City Chiefs facing the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Tennessee Titans playing the Indianapolis Colts. Meanwhile, the league is still struggling mightily with the coronavirus. Baltimore’s game against Pittsburgh has been delayed until at least Tuesday, and Denver will not have an active quarterback on their roster for a game against New Orleans.

headline: Splitting 5 to 4, Supreme Court Backs Religious Challenge to Cuomo’s Virus Shutdown Order
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Places of Worship']
abstract: Justice Amy Coney Barrett played a decisive role in the decision, which took the opposite approach of earlier court rulings related to coronavirus restrictions in California and Nevada.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court late Wednesday night barred restrictions on religious services in New York that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had imposed to combat the coronavirus.

headline: Trump Brought Back Michael Flynn for the Finale, Fallon Says
abstract: “Seriously, there’s a name from the past,” Jimmy Fallon said of Flynn on Wednesday. “Even Michael Flynn was like, ‘Damn, I totally forgot about Michael Flynn.’”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Many of us are stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: South Korean Mastermind of Exploitation Chat Rooms Gets 40 Years in Prison
keywords: ['Extortion and Blackmail', 'Pornography', 'Child Pornography', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Cho Joo-bin was convicted of blackmailing young women into making sexually explicit video clips that he sold online.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — He preyed on young women looking for high-paying jobs through social media platforms. He lured them into making sexually explicit video clips, promising big payouts. Then, prosecutors said, once he got ahold of the compromising images, he used them as blackmail.

headline: Verses vs. Virus: What These Poets Laureate Are Thankful For
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Poets Laureate', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Two Thousand Twenty']
abstract: It’s been a difficult year in every corner of the land. But there are still neighbors and family, breathtaking landscapes and gratitude for the ‘bend without the break.’
lead_paragraph: As Americans gather for Thanksgiving in a nation battered and brought low by rampant disease and division, you may ask: What in this of all years do we have to be thankful for?

headline: N.F.L. Teams Are Restricting Crowds. The Dallas Cowboys Want More.
abstract: The team’s owner, Jerry Jones, is pursuing “a continued aggressive approach to having fans” at home games, even as coronavirus cases rise in the area around the stadium.
lead_paragraph: Texans love to brag that everything is bigger in their state. The land, the food and, this year, the size of the crowds at Dallas Cowboys games.

headline: The Birds Are Outside
abstract: One bird feeder became two, then three. Months passed.
lead_paragraph: Me, my wife, our teenager and our 5-year old, we knew nothing about birds before the lockdown sent us inside in March. Our cramped home was suburban-convenient before the pandemic hit, nestled a few blocks from a school we don’t go in and a train downtown we won’t ride, and now it is just small.

headline: A Thanksgiving Myth Debunked: People Aren’t Fighting About Politics
keywords: ['Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Families and Family Life', 'Thanksgiving Day']
abstract: Smaller gatherings mean fewer chances to talk to relatives you disagree with. But most Americans prefer to skip partisan debates altogether, no matter how big the turkey.
lead_paragraph: With millions of Americans choosing not to visit loved ones this Thanksgiving out of caution over the coronavirus, a lot of small rituals will get passed over in the process.

headline: The Heir to the Manning Quarterback Legacy Isn’t on TikTok
abstract: Arch Manning, 16, nephew of Peyton and Eli, has a protective family to steer him from the perils of fame and expectation. And a grandfather, Archie, who texts him reminders to “have fun.”
lead_paragraph: Last summer, while reading a list of Louisiana’s top college football recruiting prospects, Archie Manning noticed that only one of the high school players did not have a Twitter account. It happened to be his grandson and namesake Arch, a nephew of Peyton and Eli.

headline: This Lockdown, England’s Theaters Know What to Do Online
abstract: The first coronavirus shutdown caught playhouses unawares, but they learned lessons that stood them in good stead when the shutters came down again.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — What a difference a lockdown makes. By way of proof, consider the terrific lineup of actresses brought together for “Little Wars,”  an imaginative if overly arch play by the American writer Stephen Carl McCasland that is streaming online through Dec. 3. Its run finishes the day after England’s second coronavirus shutdown is scheduled to be lifted, at which point theaters in most regions will, with luck, be open again.

headline: In Argentina, Maradona’s Death Sets Off a Vivid Display of Public Grief
abstract: For many Argentines, Diego Maradona, who died on Wednesday, was no mere soccer superstar. “I feel like a member of my family just died,” said one.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — People laid flowers and lit candles below the mural of Diego Maradona outside the stadium here that bears his name. A man cried inconsolably.

headline: Turkey Jails Hundreds for Life Over 2016 Coup Attempt
keywords: ['Politics and Government', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Those accused of being ringleaders were among the many sentenced in one of the most important mass trials relating to the plot.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A Turkish court sentenced the accused ringleaders and hundreds of others suspected of involvement in the failed 2016 coup to multiple life terms on Thursday, at the culmination of one of the most important mass trials in the plot to overthrow President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

headline: Giving Thanks in 2020
abstract: It’s been a difficult year. It’s OK to keep it simple.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a difficult year. It’s OK to keep it simple.

headline: Claudia Rankine Wishes More Writers Thought About Whiteness
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: “Racist ideas continue to shape our consciousness.”
lead_paragraph: When the poet and essayist, whose latest book is “Just Us,” finishes reading novels, she stores them in her guest room “or in a bag by the door to be given away.”

headline: In the Face of Challenges, ‘Thinking of Yourself in a Higher Light’
abstract: For New Yorkers starting new chapters, the struggles of the coronavirus pandemic took on additional intensity.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, Demetria Mack was elated to be starting at Howard University. She was not only gaining the independence of a college student, but as she moved into her dorm room, she was also entering a new chapter in her journey out of foster care.

headline: Pope Francis: A Crisis Reveals What Is in Our Hearts
abstract: To come out of this pandemic better than we went in, we must let ourselves be touched by others’ pain.
lead_paragraph: In this past year of change, my mind and heart have overflowed with people. People I think of and pray for, and sometimes cry with, people with names and faces, people who died without saying goodbye to those they loved, families in difficulty, even going hungry, because there’s no work.

headline: Musical Travel Companions for a Year of Going Nowhere
abstract: The composer John Luther Adams combines immersive sound worlds with environmental activism.
lead_paragraph: In the early spring of 1989, the composer John Luther Adams set up camp near the confluence of the still-icy Tanana and Yukon rivers in Alaska. For days he held a solitary vigil, nursing heavy thoughts about his romantic and professional lives, in both of which he felt at a crossroads.

headline: 2nd Coronavirus Wave Hits Buffalo Area ‘With a Vengeance’
abstract: The positive test rate in Erie County has remained above 5 percent for almost two weeks.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO, N.Y. — Over the past month, the number of coronavirus cases has increased tenfold in the upstate city of Buffalo and its surrounding suburbs. Hospitalizations already have surpassed the levels seen in the spring. And the Covid-19 hotline for Erie County, where Buffalo is situated, is getting “annihilated,” the health commissioner said, with 1,500 calls in one 24-hour period this week.

headline: A Soaring Monument to Beauty in China Is Stirring Passions. Mostly Anger.
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'Poverty', 'Local Government', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: As China fights to end extreme poverty while also recovering from the economic damage of the coronavirus, the supposed wisdom of building huge statues in poorer areas to grow tourism is coming under harsh scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: JIANHE, China — Yang Asha smiled serenely down at the craggy emerald landscape, her hand outstretched in welcome. She appeared unmoved by the fierce condemnation her presence has ignited in China — she is, after all, made of gleaming stainless steel and bigger than the Statue of Liberty.

headline: What You Need to Know Now About Travel Insurance
abstract: A spate of new travel insurance policies have begun covering Covid-19, just as many international destinations begin to require it. Here’s what to look for.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic struck, many travel insurance policies failed to cover Covid-19-related trip interruptions and cancellations, often because they excluded pandemics. But in the intervening months, the travel insurance industry has introduced a spate of new policies covering the disease just as many foreign destinations begin to require them.

headline: I Was a Child Refugee. Another War in Ethiopia Is Forcing More Children Into the Camps.
keywords: ['War and Armed Conflicts', 'Tigrayans (Ethnic Group)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Abiy Ahmed, the country’s prime minister, has become the protagonist of a familiar story in Africa, which is written in blood by politicians in pursuit of their ideologies and power.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 6, an Ethiopian friend messaged me on WhatsApp: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed had ordered airstrikes against the regional government in the country’s northernmost Tigray Province, bordering Eritrea and Sudan. I looked up from my phone screen in a daze. My friend was raging at the return of violence. “Why don’t these men give us a break?”

headline: N.J. Governor Wants Schools Open. Local Officials Have Other Ideas.
abstract: The tensions point to the difficulty governors across the Northeast have had in persuading districts to reopen — decisions that often require school boards to buck powerful unions.
lead_paragraph: SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J. — Gov. Philip D. Murphy has urged New Jersey school districts to open for some face-to-face instruction, repeatedly noting that the coronavirus spread among teachers and students was far lower than expected.

headline: Patients of a Vermont Hospital Are Left ‘in the Dark’ After a Cyberattack
abstract: A wave of damaging attacks on hospitals upended the lives of patients with cancer and other ailments. “I have no idea what to do,” one said.
lead_paragraph: At lunchtime on Oct. 28, Colleen Cargill was in the cancer center at the University of Vermont Medical Center, preparing patients for their chemotherapy infusions. A new patient will sometimes be teary and frightened, but the nurses try to make it welcoming, offering trail mix and a warm blanket, a seat with a view of a garden.

headline: She Dived More Than 300 Feet Under the Sea. Can She Go Deeper?
keywords: ['Records and Achievements', 'Free Diving', 'Lungs', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Alenka Artnik of Slovenia recently set a record in free diving. But her race to the bottom may not be over.
lead_paragraph: One morning this month, on the warm waters of the Red Sea off the coast of Egypt, Alenka Artnik donned a thin purple wet suit and a monofin, secured a four-pound weight around her neck, and fastened herself to a thin line she held loosely in one hand.

headline: Why This Billionaire Will Never Leave New York
abstract: For the cosmetics mogul and philanthropist Leonard Lauder, the city, with its museums, public transit and parks, is an explorer’s delight.
lead_paragraph: Why on God’s green earth would anyone choose to live somewhere besides New York City?

headline: They Were Worried About Finances. This Is How They Got Help.
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Unemployment', 'Savings', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: “I have never seen this much anxiety and fear about money,” one financial counselor said.
lead_paragraph: The prolonged pandemic has forced many New Yorkers to reassess their finances, bringing wrenching decisions on how to get by despite lost jobs or reduced work hours. Others have managed to save more than usual, as quarantine restrictions have pared their spending.

headline: Their Teeth Fell Out. Was It Another Covid-19 Consequence?
abstract: People who already have dental problems may see them aggravated by encounters with the coronavirus, some experts suggest.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Farah Khemili popped a wintergreen breath mint in her mouth and noticed a strange sensation: a bottom tooth wiggling against her tongue.

headline: A Fight Over Agriculture Secretary Could Decide the Direction of Hunger Policy
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Food Insecurity', 'Endorsements', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: The delicate proxy clash has pitted Democrats eager to emphasize issues like hunger and nutrition against traditionalists who believe the department should represent rural America.
lead_paragraph: An unlikely fight is breaking out over President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s choice for agriculture secretary, pitting a powerful Black lawmaker who wants to refocus the Agriculture Department on hunger against traditionalists who believe the department should be a voice for rural America.

headline: Missing ‘The Nutcracker’? How to Get Your Holiday Fix at Home
abstract: Many seasonal mainstays have been reimagined for online viewing this year. Here are some of our favorites, from “A Christmas Carol” to Handel’s “Messiah.”
lead_paragraph: We all have our holiday traditions. Maybe yours is seeing the Rockettes at Radio City Music Hall and gazing at the Rockefeller Center tree, all done up in lights. Well, this year “The Christmas Spectacular” is canceled, and that Norway spruce is just sorry looking (though organizers swear the tree will be beautiful by the time of its lighting on Dec. 2).

headline: Best Art Books of 2020
abstract: The art critics of The Times select their favorites from this year’s crop of art books.
lead_paragraph: The long stretches of pandemic lockdown this year have afforded the chance to spend as much time reading about art as looking at it, which may account for the number of text-intensive recommendations on our lists. At the same time, with access to “live” art still limited, images on the pages of some books below will let you create your own private museums-at-home, and they’ll be pretty glorious. — Holland Cotter

headline: New Jersey’s American Dream Mall Is Still Waiting to Fully Open
keywords: ['Shopping Centers and Malls', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: After more than 15 years, the Meadowlands complex began a phased opening in late 2019, but before customers could shop at its stores the pandemic hit and completely upended the retail industry.
lead_paragraph: When the American Dream mall, a massive shopping and entertainment complex next to MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., finally opened its doors to the public last October, its owner, the Triple Five Group, was eager to prove naysayers wrong.

headline: ‘The Crown’ Stokes an Uproar Over Fact vs. Entertainment
abstract: Dramatic liberties in the latest season of the Netflix series, covering the turbulent 1980s, are annoying Britons who wrote of that period, even among those who disparage the royals.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a Saturday night in July 1986, a band of bureaucrats in raincoats — one contingent from Buckingham Palace, the other from 10 Downing Street — converged on a newsstand in a train station to snap up The Sunday Times, fresh off the presses with a bombshell headline: “Queen dismayed by ‘uncaring’ Thatcher.”

headline: Gratitude in Six Words, From Our Readers
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I invited readers to send us six words describing what made them thankful in 2020. It’s a form of writing — the six-word memoir — popularized by the author Larry Smith.

headline: ‘Kill It and Leave This Town’ Review: Grotesque, Bleak and Endless
abstract: One viewing is enough for this animated feature debut by the Polish director Mariusz Wilczynski.
lead_paragraph: It’s difficult to describe the Polish artist Mariusz Wilczynski’s debut film, “Kill It and Leave This Town,” because the animated feature — plotless, gloomy and surreal — is more a direct translation of feelings and sensations than a traditional work of storytelling.

headline: ‘Mosul’ Review: In Iraq, This Time It’s Personal
abstract: A rogue Iraqi SWAT team fights the Islamic State in Matthew Michael Carnahan’s action thriller.
lead_paragraph: “Mosul” dramatizes a 2017 story in The New Yorker that chronicled a self-directed Iraqi SWAT team’s efforts to fight the Islamic State. Counting both Condé Nast and the “Avengers: Endgame” directors Anthony and Joe Russo among its producers, this Netflix movie balances admirable ambition (it’s an American film, but the characters speak Arabic) with the cruder goosing strategies and red-meat dialogue of a revenge picture.

headline: ‘My Psychedelic Love Story’ Review: On the Run With Timothy Leary
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'LSD (Lysergic Acid Diethylamide)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: This Errol Morris documentary explores the relationship between the LSD guru and Joanna Harcourt-Smith, a woman who likened herself to Mata Hari.
lead_paragraph: To induce dread in a paranoiac, one need only invoke two acronyms: C.I.A. and LSD Along with a third and a fourth — U.F.O. and J.F.K. — these were key ingredients in the alphabet soup of conspiracy theory for more than half a century.

headline: ‘Superintelligence’ Review: Melissa McCarthy Has to Save the World
abstract: In this comedy from Ben Falcone, McCarthy plays the world’s most average human, picked to save the world by an A.I. entity with the voice of James Corden.
lead_paragraph: In this new Melissa McCarthy comedy, directed by her husband and frequent collaborator Ben Falcone (who has a supporting role), she plays Carol, described by another character as “the most average person on earth.” This pronouncement catches the ear of a roving artificial intelligence — one that travels from smartphone to TV to rice cooker at will — which decides on Carol, a former Silicon Valley star turned do-gooder, as its test subject.

headline: ‘Stardust’ Review: A Week With David Bowie, Unaccompanied by His Music
abstract: A more accurate title for this movie, set in the early ’70s, would be “Johnny Flynn Sings Jacques Brel.”
lead_paragraph: This motion picture, in which an unusually coiffed performer, accompanying himself on acoustic guitar, sings some Jacques Brel songs, purports to be a story about David Bowie.

headline: ‘Zappa’ Review: Portrait of a Rock Star and a Nation’s Hero
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The documentary, directed by Alex Winter, portrays the musician and composer Frank Zappa as a sort of noble.
lead_paragraph: This documentary directed by Alex Winter opens with a portrait of the ostensibly outrageous musician Frank Zappa in a moment of nobility. It is footage shot in Prague in 1991, two years before Zappa’s death from cancer at the age of 52.

headline: Times readers shared what they’re thankful for in six words.
abstract: Last week, David Leonhardt invited readers of his Morning newsletter to send six words describing what made them thankful in 2020. Here is a selection of their responses:
lead_paragraph: Last week, David Leonhardt invited readers of his Morning newsletter to send six words describing what made them thankful in 2020. Here is a selection of their responses:

headline: As N.F.L. crowds decline, the Dallas Cowboys keep the gates open.
abstract: Tens of thousands of fans are expected to be at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, on Thursday, when the Dallas Cowboys, as they have nearly every year since 1966, play at home on Thanksgiving, this time against the Washington Football Team.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of fans are expected to be at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, on Thursday, when the Dallas Cowboys, as they have nearly every year since 1966, play at home on Thanksgiving, this time against the Washington Football Team.

headline: Supreme Court blocks New York’s virus-imposed limits to religious services.
abstract: The Supreme Court late Wednesday barred restrictions on religious services in New York that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had imposed to combat the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court late Wednesday barred restrictions on religious services in New York that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had imposed to combat the coronavirus.

headline: Merkel outlines Germany’s plan to extend restrictions through December.
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Thursday detailed measures to extend and tighten the country’s partial lockdown.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Thursday detailed measures to extend and tighten the country’s partial lockdown.

headline: New Jersey’s governor wants schools open. Local officials have other ideas.
abstract: Gov. Philip D. Murphy has urged New Jersey school districts to open for some face-to-face instruction, repeatedly noting that the coronavirus spread among teachers and students was far lower than expected.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Philip D. Murphy has urged New Jersey school districts to open for some face-to-face instruction, repeatedly noting that the coronavirus spread among teachers and students was far lower than expected.

headline: Ethiopia’s Leader Escalates Assault on Tigray Region, Putting Civilians at Risk
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'War and Armed Conflicts']
abstract: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed said that a deadline for the region’s dissident leaders to surrender had lapsed. The conflict threatens to destabilize the entire Horn of Africa.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Just over three weeks ago, Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia unleashed his military forces in an attempt to subdue the country’s northern region of Tigray, whose rebellious governing party was until recently the dominant force in Ethiopia’s central government.

headline: South Korea reports its biggest one-day jump in cases in eight months.
abstract: South Korea reported 583 new cases of the coronavirus on Thursday, the biggest daily caseload since early March, as health officials struggled to contain a third wave.
lead_paragraph: South Korea reported 583 new cases of the coronavirus on Thursday, the biggest daily caseload since early March, as health officials struggled to contain a third wave.

headline: Why Is My Uncle So Mad About Student Debt Forgiveness?
abstract: A reader wonders how to talk to a salty boomer about progress.
lead_paragraph: I am a recent college graduate. I am also drowning in student debt. On my salary, there is no way I can save money or think about buying an apartment while I make large payments on these loans. This will continue for 15 years at least. The pandemic “pause” on payments has been a huge relief. And I’m excited by the possibility of our new president doing something to forgive some of my student debt. But when I talked to my uncle about this, he got angry and took it very personally: “No one forgave my student loans!” I didn’t know how to respond or if I should have. But it’s awkward now. Any advice?

headline: What We’re Thankful for This Year
abstract: Health, family and the internet.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. It’s Thanksgiving, and for many of us it’ll be smaller and quieter than in years past. I recommend taking a minute to read Mark Vanhoenacker on how he’s fending off sadness at not being with family for the holiday; it might broaden your perspective. And check out Sam Sifton on adding new flavors to your Thanksgiving dinner — in the absence of a crowd, you too might veer from the traditional menu and “play the deep cuts.” (I like the sound of a pumpkin layer cake with caramel buttercream.)

headline: ‘A Love Letter to Detroit,’ on Vellum and Chrome
abstract: An exhibition at the Detroit Institute of Arts highlights the relationship of art and car culture over the past 70 years.
lead_paragraph: Of the myriad treasures that might draw a sightseeing car lover to Detroit, one potential attraction is notably missing: a major public museum collection dedicated to the automobile. America’s Motor City offers many compelling reasons for a visit, but it really has nothing like the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles, the LeMay in Tacoma, Wash., or the well-known car displays in Reno, Indianapolis or Philadelphia.

headline: Delta announces ‘quarantine free’ flights from Atlanta to Rome.
abstract: For the first time since the coronavirus pandemic swept across Europe and the United States, a pilot program will allow a limited number of passengers to travel across the Atlantic from Atlanta to Italy without having to quarantine upon arrival, according to a Delta Air Lines news release on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since the coronavirus pandemic swept across Europe and the United States, a pilot program will allow a limited number of passengers to travel across the Atlantic from Atlanta to Italy without having to quarantine upon arrival, according to a Delta Air Lines news release on Thursday.

headline: The Most Popular Listings of October
abstract: All but one property on the month’s list are affordable only to the wealthy, or super-wealthy, in the case of the $88 million former home of Jeffrey Epstein, the convicted sex offender who died in jail last year.
lead_paragraph: The most popular listings on The New York Times’s Find a Home site in October all carried forward from the roundups of previous months; and all but one, a $359,000 co-op in Inwood, are expensive, from $1.295 million up to $88 million.

headline: Immanuel Quickley’s Path to the Knicks Started at the Foul Line
abstract: Quickley, a guard out of Kentucky, is an exceptional free-throw shooter, a skill he learned from his mother. He had the third highest free-throw percentage in Division I last season.
lead_paragraph: Even with all of the basketball skills that are hyped and parsed at an N.B.A. draft — scoring, 3-point shooting, rebounding, rim protection, playmaking — it was striking to hear television analysts so focused on Immanuel Quickley’s free-throw shooting last week.

headline: Can the Mainstream Catch Up to Rico Nasty?
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Women and Girls', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The 23-year-old Maryland rapper has built a cult following with her mixtapes of playful but bruising scream-rap. Now she’s releasing her major-label debut.
lead_paragraph: When the rapper Rico Nasty talks about falling in love at first sight, she doesn’t mean with an individual, but with a feeling. She’s talking about her first time on a real stage, and not even as a performer, but as a hanger-on in the wings. Still, that night, everything was moving in dreamy slow motion.

headline: Wedding Rings Lost in Shipwreck Will Be Returned to Migrant Couple
abstract: The owners of the two rings, which were found in a backpack in the Mediterranean, survived the capsizing of their vessel as they crossed from Libya to Europe.
lead_paragraph: The red backpack had been floating for two weeks in the central Mediterranean between Libya and Italy when a rescue boat came across it. Inside, along with clothes and some notes in Arabic, was a simple treasure: two wedding rings engraved with hearts and the names Ahmed and Doudou.

headline: Halima Aden Chooses Faith Over Fashion
keywords: ['Muslim Veiling', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Models (Professional)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Discrimination', 'your-feed-selfcare', 'your-feed-fashion', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: The well-known model shared via Instagram that she’s taking a break to set some boundaries in the industry.
lead_paragraph: Halima Aden, a model, is taking a step back from the fashion industry to focus on herself and her faith.

headline: Thanksgiving Is a Celebration of Freedom
abstract: The origins of the national holiday have little to do with Pilgrims and Indians.
lead_paragraph: As with so much in our lives, Thanksgiving has become a cultural battleground. Politicians and pundits debate whether we should use the day to memorialize the tragedy of the Indians or to celebrate the new liberties of the Pilgrims in America.

headline: The Rotting of the Republican Mind
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right']
abstract: When one party becomes detached from reality.
lead_paragraph: In a recent Monmouth University survey, 77 percent of Trump backers said Joe Biden had won the presidential election because of fraud. Many of these same people think climate change is not real. Many of these same people believe they don’t need to listen to scientific experts on how to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: In Praise of Janet Yellen the Economist
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: She never forgot that economics is about people.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to overstate the enthusiasm among economists over Joe Biden’s selection of Janet Yellen as the next secretary of the Treasury. Some of this enthusiasm reflects the groundbreaking nature of her appointment. She won’t just be the first woman to hold the job, she’ll be the first person to have held all three of the traditional top U.S. policy positions in economics — chair of the Council of Economic Advisers, chair of the Federal Reserve and now Treasury secretary.

headline: Oh, Brother! Tears for Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: No arguments — or turkey — this Thanksgiving. Just a cocktail.
lead_paragraph: This Thanksgiving, I’m going to make myself a French 75 and toast the end of a very bad, horrible, no-good year. I’ll be the only one in our family following Dr. Fauci’s advice to “bite the bullet” and skip our large holiday gathering. No doubt, my Trump-loving family will pour one out for the president. In that spirit, my brother, Kevin, offers the following threnody for Donald Trump.

headline: Taylor Swift Illuminates ‘Folklore’ in a Stripped-Down Studio Concert
abstract: Playing her latest album for the first time with two collaborators who helped make it, Swift heightens the songs’ sense of pristine contemplation.
lead_paragraph: “Folklore: The Long Pond Studio Sessions” is straightforward and cozy. Taylor Swift and her two main collaborators and producers for her album “Folklore” — Aaron Dessner (from the National) and Jack Antonoff (a linchpin of Bleachers and fun., and a producer for Lorde, Lana Del Rey and others) — play through the album’s 17 songs at Dessner’s Long Pond Studio, a rural haven in Hudson, N.Y. Conversations between the collaborators introduce each song; birds and insects chirp.

headline: In Need of a Film About Romantic Possibility? Try ‘In the Mood for Love’
abstract: Wong Kar-wai’s influential drama, along with his “Chungking Express,” are part of a new retrospective of the Hong Kong director’s work.
lead_paragraph: Gateway Movies offers ways to begin exploring directors, genres and topics in film by examining a few streaming movies.

headline: Betty Jones, Founding Member of Limón Troupe, Dies at 94
abstract: She created the Desdemona role in José Limón’s best-known dance, “The Moor’s Pavane,” and became a respected teacher.
lead_paragraph: Betty Jones, a dancer known for memorable performances as an original member of José Limón’s famed company and later a respected dance teacher, died on Nov. 17 at her home in Honolulu. She was 94.

headline: E.U. Border Agency Accused of Covering Up Migrant Pushback in Greece
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: Frontex is under fire for letting Greece illegally repel migrants as the agency expands to play a more central role at the bloc’s external borders.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Mounting evidence indicates that the European Union’s border agency has been complicit in Greece’s illegal practice of pushing back migrants to Turkey, according to documents obtained by The New York Times and interviews with officials.

headline: Cuomo Attacks Supreme Court, but Virus Ruling Is Warning to Governors
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Disease Rates', 'Places of Worship', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Quarantines']
abstract: The court signaled that if unconstrained religious observance and public safety are sometimes at odds, then religious freedom should win out.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — As the coronavirus pandemic has deepened and darkened in recent months, the nation’s governors have taken increasingly aggressive steps to curb the current surge of infections, with renewed and expanded restrictions reaching into people’s homes, businesses, schools and places of worship.

headline: Families Have Been Torn Apart by Politics. What Happens to Them Now?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Families and Family Life', 'Absentee Voting', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Unlike 2016, when conflicts emerged over political choices, this time many are centered on the legitimacy of the result itself.
lead_paragraph: Tho Nguyen’s parents, who immigrated from Vietnam, were always Republican. They are Catholic and oppose abortion. Four years ago they voted for Donald Trump.

headline: Edward J. Perkins, 92, Dies; First Black U.S. Envoy to South Africa
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Apartheid (Policy)', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: He also held ambassadorial postings in Liberia and Australia and, as director general, helped diversify the elite, mostly white Foreign Service.
lead_paragraph: When Edward J. Perkins was a student at a segregated school in Pine Bluff, Ark., his history teacher taught the class about the brutal racial oppression in South Africa. It was even worse, the students were told, than what they as Black people were experiencing in the American South.

headline: ‘Loser’: How a Lifelong Fear Bookended Trump’s Presidency
abstract: The president’s inability to concede the election is the latest reality-denying moment in a career preoccupied with an epithet.
lead_paragraph: In the now-distant Republican presidential primaries of 2016, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas handily won the Iowa caucuses. This was determined by a method that has lately come under attack but at the time was considered standard: elementary math.

headline: Paolo Gabriele, Pope’s Butler in ‘Vatileaks’ Scandal, Dies at 54
abstract: He admitted to stealing files and giving them to a journalist as a way to expose Vatican corruption and protect his boss, Benedict XVI.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Paolo Gabriele, who as the butler of Pope Benedict XVI was convicted of leaking internal Vatican documents to the news media in an extraordinary breach of church secrecy — the so-called Vatileaks scandal — died on Tuesday in Rome. He was 54.

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Happy Thanksgiving to our American readers. Our recommended books this week include a presidential memoir, a couple of looks at the culture of big tech (in Silicon Valley and in rural China), a remembrance of a road trip with Jorge Luis Borges and a graphic novel about Syrian refugees in America, among others.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Theater', 'Dancing', 'Music', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Children and Childhood', 'Jazz']
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
lead_paragraph: If your children have had their fill of turkey and tradition, you can offer them more exotic fare — the cinematic kind — from nations far away. From Saturday through Dec. 6, the Brooklyn Academy of Music is presenting a cultural tasting menu in the form of the Best of BAMkids Film Festival 2020, an hourlong video-on-demand program of short animated works from 10 countries. For families who couldn’t go to the full festival in February, this virtual event presents 12 highlights to sample at home.

headline: Here’s What the Thanksgiving Parade Looked Like in Pandemic New York
abstract: The holiday ritual was limited to a block, with parts pretaped for television and barricades to keep people away. Still, a few curious spectators showed up.
lead_paragraph: It’s a yearly Thanksgiving Day tradition: Millions of spectators crammed onto long city blocks, hanging over barricades and balconies or pressed against the windows of towering office buildings to watch giant balloons, depicting cartoon characters like Pikachu, hovering just a few feet above the street.

headline: Dr. Mary Fowkes, 66, Dies; Helped Science Understand the Pandemic
abstract: She performed autopsies in New York that found blood clots in vital organs, suggesting how much the virus spreads through the body.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Mary Fowkes, a neuropathologist at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan whose autopsies of Covid-19 victims early in the pandemic discovered serious damage in multiple organs — a finding that led to the successful use of higher doses of blood thinners to treat patients — died on Nov. 15 at her home in Katonah, N.Y., in Westchester County. She was 66.

headline: Midnight Ruling Exposes Rifts at a Supreme Court Transformed by Trump
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: The justices issued six opinions, several of them unusually bitter, in upholding challenges from churches and synagogues to state pandemic restrictions on religious services.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A few minutes before midnight on Wednesday, the nation got its first glimpse of how profoundly President Trump had transformed the Supreme Court.

headline: Video of Police Beating Black Man in Paris Fuels Debate on Filming Officers
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Footage from security cameras and bystanders suggested the officers had lied about the beating, bolstering critics of a new bill that would restrict circulating videos of security forces.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Video of police officers beating a Black man in Paris caused an outcry in France on Thursday, fueling criticism of a new bill that would place restrictions on sharing footage of security forces as the French authorities grapple with longstanding accusations of police racism and brutality.

headline: Geoffrey Palmer, Judi Dench’s Sitcom Co-Star, Is Dead at 93
abstract: Their show “As Time Goes By” was a hit in Britain and had a following in the U.S. “When you acted with him,” Ms. Dench said, “you’d just feel very safe.”
lead_paragraph: Geoffrey Palmer, a British character actor whose career peaked during the long run of “As Time Goes By,” the romantic BBC sitcom in which he and Judi Dench played lovers reunited after 38 years apart, died on Nov. 5 at his home in Buckinghamshire, near London. He was 93.

headline: Venezuela Raids Food Charity, Interrupting Meals for Children
keywords: ['Food Insecurity', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Politics and Government', 'Food Banks and Pantries']
abstract: The charity, Feed the Solidarity, often provides the only meals children receive each day. The government accuses it of subversion, with no evidence.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Government agents have raided the offices and frozen the bank accounts of a major Venezuelan food charity, threatening a lifeline for thousands of children during one of the world’s deepest humanitarian crises.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: This long Thanksgiving weekend, check out a great concert, a craft show for kids and a reboot that’s better than the original.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense Production Act', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Public-Private Sector Cooperation', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump talks about efforts to deliver the coronavirus vaccine to millions of Americans eager to return to their normal lives, he often says he is “counting on the military” to get it done.

headline: Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade Is Scaled Down in a Pandemic
abstract: The threat of the coronavirus led planners of the annual parade in New York City to drastically revise plans, including reducing the route to a single block down 34th Street, near the flagship department store.
lead_paragraph: The threat of the coronavirus led planners of the annual parade in New York City to drastically revise plans, including reducing the route to a single block down 34th Street, near the flagship department store.

headline: Leonard Kamsler, a Dissecting Golf Photographer, Dies at 85
abstract: He pioneered the use of strobe photography to break down a golfer’s swing. He was also innovative, even crafty, in documenting P.G.A. tournaments for decades.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Kamsler, a photojournalist whose award-winning pictures of professional golf for nearly 50 years pushed the envelope of sports strobe photography as he amassed a trove of more than 200,000 images on the PGA Tour, died on Nov. 18 in Bethel, N.Y. He was 85.

headline: England’s Lockdown Will Lift, but Many Pub Doors Will Stay Closed
abstract: Some Conservative lawmakers are calling Boris Johnson’s plans to continue restricting most of England’s bars and restaurants “authoritarian.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Under fire from critics over the economic and social cost of his coronavirus restrictions, Prime Minister Boris Johnson will bring a grueling, second, national lockdown in England to an end next week.

headline: Senate Democrats Face Power Struggle for Top Judiciary Job
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senators Richard J. Durbin and Sheldon Whitehouse are vying to be the top Democrat on the panel that controls judicial nominations, reflecting a broader debate among activists about how to wield power.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As soon as Senator Richard J. Durbin of Illinois learned officially on Monday that there would be a Democratic opening at the top of the Judiciary Committee, he was on the phone to his colleagues trying to nail down their support for the position.

headline: U.S. Border Agency Settles With 2 Americans Detained for Speaking Spanish
abstract: In a video of the 2018 incident in Havre, Mont., a Border Patrol agent is heard telling the two American women he detains that speaking Spanish in the small city is “very unheard-of.”
lead_paragraph: Two women who were detained in a small town in Montana after a Border Patrol agent heard them speaking Spanish at a convenience store have settled for an undisclosed amount after filing a lawsuit against U.S. Customs and Border Protection, the A.C.L.U. of Montana said on Tuesday.

headline: In Argentina, Thousands Wait in Line for Maradona’s Wake
abstract: Tens of thousands of people stood in line on Thursday, including Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina, to bid farewell to the soccer legend Diego Armando Maradona, as his body lay in repose in the presidential palace.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people stood in line on Thursday, including Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina, to bid farewell to the soccer legend Diego Armando Maradona, as his body lay in repose in the presidential palace.

headline: Argentina, and Latin America, Mourn Maradona as a Man of the People
abstract: Known for siding with leftist leaders and causes, the soccer legend’s life, and his politics, never strayed far from his impoverished roots, and his fans loved him for it.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The tens of thousands of fans who gathered on Thursday to pay their last respects to Diego Armando Maradona, Argentina’s soccer legend, as he lay in state in the presidential palace were often the first to say their idol was a genius with the ball, but he wasn’t perfect. He never pretended to be.

headline: A Poem of Gratitude from Oklahoma
abstract: The New York Times asked poets laureate from across the country what the people in their states had to be thankful for in this difficult year.
lead_paragraph: We are thankful for okla-humma, for our people, for this land.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Electoral College', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Taking questions from reporters for the first time since Election Day, the president also said he would travel to Georgia to support Republican candidates before two runoffs that will determine control of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: President Trump said on Thursday that he would leave the White House if the Electoral College formalized Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s election as president, even as he reiterated baseless claims of fraud that he said would make it “very hard” to concede.

headline: Six U.S. Oil Executives Are Convicted of Corruption in Venezuela
abstract: The so-called Citgo 6, who had been lured to Venezuela three years ago for a business meeting, were immediately sentenced to prison.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — A Venezuelan judge on Thursday found six American oil executives guilty of a wide-ranging corruption scheme and immediately sentenced them to prison.

lead_paragraph: “So often the art was hiding in plain sight, within 20 miles of the museum. I was knocking on doors in suburban Detroit, and the sketches were coming out of dusty boxes.”

headline: U.N. Panel: Technology in Policing Can Reinforce Racial Bias
keywords: ['Artificial Intelligence', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Racial Profiling', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The use of artificial intelligence and facial recognition programs may lead communities to lose trust in law enforcement, human rights experts say.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Police departments across the United States have been drawn to the use of digital technology for surveillance and predicting crime on the theory that it will make law enforcement more accurate, efficient and effective. The alarming reality, United Nations human rights experts warned on Thursday, is that they risk reinforcing racial bias and abuse.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know.

headline: Ravens Game Against Steelers Is Moved Again, to Tuesday Night
abstract: Lamar Jackson, the N.F.L.’s 2019 M.V.P., was among more than a dozen Baltimore players to have reportedly tested positive for the virus.
lead_paragraph: For the second time this week, the N.F.L. has rescheduled the matchup between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Baltimore Ravens, moving it to Tuesday night from Sunday, after the coronavirus outbreak in the Ravens’ clubhouse spread further on Thursday, the original day of the game.

headline: Classic British Rock Group
abstract: Robyn Weintraub offers us a marvelous way to work off our holiday meals.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Tell me, my friends, is there a better way to celebrate the holiday weekend than with a Robyn Weintraub puzzle? At the very least, the tug of war you will encounter herein has to be good for working off your Thanksgiving meal.

headline: Wildfire Smoke Is Poisoning California’s Kids. Some Pay a Higher Price.
abstract: Fires are making the state’s air more dangerous. How much that hurts depends largely on where you live and how much money your family has.
lead_paragraph: Fires are making the state’s air more dangerous. How much that hurts depends largely on where you live and how much money your family has.

headline: Escaping the Virus, Almost
abstract: How a planned two-week trip to Sydney from Melbourne stretched into a five-month drive across Australia dictated by lockdowns and coronavirus restrictions.
lead_paragraph: In early July, I drove to Sydney from Melbourne for what I had planned as a two-week holiday on Australia’s east coast.

headline: Australian Military Moves to Dismiss Soldiers After Killings in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: A scathing report revealed that members of the special forces had waged a campaign to cover up unlawful killings of Afghan civilians.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — One week after the release of a damning report that revealed Australian special forces had unlawfully killed helpless Afghan civilians and waged a campaign to cover up the slaughter, the military has begun proceedings to dismiss 13 soldiers serving in the force.

headline: Junk Food Was Our Love Language
abstract: To feel close to my father, a man I never fully knew, I eat chicken nuggets.
lead_paragraph: It’s autumn again, the eighth since my father died, and I’m craving chicken nuggets.

headline: ‘Black Beauty’ Review: A Melodrama in Need of Rougher Edges
abstract: Set in the present day, this adaptation of the classic children’s novel forgets why the story of a horse surviving the maliciousness of humans has endured for so long.
lead_paragraph: Written in 1877, Anna Sewell’s classic children’s novel “Black Beauty” warned against the abuse of horses. The pristine adaptation streaming on Disney+ is a melodrama in need of rougher edges. Directed by Ashley Avis (a former competitive equestrian), the movie is set in the present-day United States and features two female protagonists: the fiery mustang Black Beauty (voiced by Kate Winslet) and the recently orphaned Jo (Mackenzie Foy), now living with her uncle John (Iain Glen), training horses at Birtwick Stables.

headline: Gift Books for Children (That Adults Will Also Love)
abstract: Upside-down fairy tales, a neon periodic table, the art of Ramona Quimby and more.
lead_paragraph: TELEPHONE TALESBy Gianni Rodari Illustrated by Valerio VidaliTranslated by Antony Shugaar 212 pp. Enchanted Lion. $27.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

headline: Job Interviews Without Interviewers, Products of the Pandemic
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Software', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Video responses to set questions, online games that measure a person’s traits and skills: The future of interviews is coming to a wider variety of professions in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: So much of our work lives has moved online during the pandemic: group meetings, chats with the boss — even interviewing for a new job. The pandemic has also led companies to conduct “interviews” without an interviewer. Job applicants are being asked to video record answers to set questions about their experience, skills and personal qualities, rather than speaking with a recruiter by phone or video chat.

headline: This Year’s Black Friday Designer Fashion Sales May Not Be What You Think.
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: A group of brands and retailers have been trying to reset expectations.

headline: Brexit Is Nipping at London’s Role as a Financial Powerhouse
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: Britain and the European Union don’t trust each other much, and global banks are caught in the middle.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For Britain, its exit from the European Union is supposed to be the start of a new era as a “Global Britain,” an open, inviting and far-reaching country. For the European Union, Brexit is an opportunity to repatriate some business from across the English Channel and further bolster the continent’s economic standing in the world.

headline: A Mother, Her Son — and Their 1,500-Mile Search for Home
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Millions of people have been displaced by the pandemic. Jessika and her 6-year-old, Sebastián, are among the many who have yet to find a home.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — A little boy charges along the highway, his red plastic shoes glowing in the twilight. The suitcase he pulls weighs almost as much as he does. A truck throttles by, threatening to blow him off his feet. But Sebastián Ventura, who at just 6 has already taken on the role of family cheerleader, urges his family on.

headline: How Did the North Korean Defector Cross the Border? Loose Screws
abstract: South Korea said its sensors had malfunctioned, allowing a North Korean to defect undetected, in the military’s most embarrassing border security breach in years.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — It’s the most heavily fortified border in the world.

headline: A Job for Life, or Not? A Class Divide Deepens in Japan
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Income Inequality', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Two court rulings threaten to further entrench distinctions in Japan between “regular” workers and the growing ranks of nonregular employees, many of whom are women.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For more than a decade, Setsuko Hikita spent her working days selling snacks and newspapers in the bowels of Tokyo’s bustling metro system.

headline: Sotheby’s and Christie’s Look to Luxury as a Coronavirus Antidote
abstract: The world’s two biggest auction houses are selling more watches, jewelry and handbags, but art’s still where the money is.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Twenty‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago, ‌Sotheby’s‌ ‌and‌ ‌Christie’s made money by auctioning‌ ‌art. ‌And‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌about‌ ‌it. ‌Now, ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌process‌ ‌fast-forwarded‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌coronavirus pandemic, ‌technology‌ ‌is‌ ‌transforming‌ ‌these‌ ‌venerable‌ ‌names‌ ‌into‌ ‌very‌ ‌different-looking‌ businesses. ‌Luxury‌ ‌is‌ ‌making that ‌difference. ‌ ‌

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Better Masks, a Sleep Benefit and Another Coronavirus Vaccine
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Masks', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Nicotine', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Medicine and Health']
