headline: Clicking Back Into Each Other’s Lives
abstract: Maxwell Sugerman and Maria Lopez, who met on a dating app in 2017, postponed their wedding five times before saying “I do.”
lead_paragraph: Maxwell Sugerman treasures Maria Lopez, whom he met after investing $4 on a dating app, Coffee Meets Bagel, in August 2017.

headline: Marty McFly and Beer Were the First Pairing That Day
abstract: Dyanna Quizon and Dane Volek were brought together by a ‘Back to the Future Day’ party. But their bond was cemented through Jane Austen.
lead_paragraph: Dyanna Villaluna Quizon prepared for her first date with Dane Clifford Volek the way most 31-year-olds in 2015 would: She looked him up on the internet. The trouble was, she couldn’t really find anything.

headline: As Qaeda Terrorist Leaves Prison, Victims’ Families Relive the Pain
abstract: The release of Adel Abdel Bary, 60, after 21 years of incarceration has left relatives of some bombing victims uneasy.
lead_paragraph: Edith Bartley knew the day would come.

headline: ‘Mr. Downstairs’ Had the Key to Her Heart
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living']
abstract: Elma Holder and Jerry Stallings met at a retirement community in Yukon, Okla. His apartment was directly under hers, one flight below.
lead_paragraph: Elma Holder couldn’t help feeling ridiculous on days when “Jerry Downstairs,” as she called him, would leave the retirement community building they lived in to visit his lady friend in town.

headline: Wasn’t It Winter Just Yesterday?
abstract: The pandemic has unmoored us from time.
lead_paragraph: In September, I bought a visual timer for Bert, my 8-year-old son. It’s just like a clock, but instead of hands, it has a red plastic film that turns the hour into a kind of pie chart. Set it to 15 minutes, and it silently counts down. Three beeps when it’s done.

headline: Which Nxivm Show Is Better? An Expert Investigates
abstract: The reporter who broke the story of the cult for The New York Times thought he was done with Nxivm. But he couldn’t resist seeing how “The Vow” and “Seduced” compared with his own experiences.
lead_paragraph: It was the comedian Judd Apatow who convinced me to invest a little too much of my time in the two recent documentaries about the sex cult Nxivm.

headline: Churches Step In Where Politicians Will Not
keywords: ['Protestant Churches', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Credit and Debt', 'Medicine and Health', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Personal Bankruptcies', 'Debt Collection']
abstract: Why do we need acts of charity to rescue Americans from crushing medical bills?
lead_paragraph: Vanessa Matos couldn’t believe what she was reading. “I was like, OK, this is a scam,” she recalled of the letter she received in February. Her husband, she said, had the same reaction: “Yeah, this isn’t real.”

headline: The Unexpected Message Revealed by Long Lines for Virus Testing
abstract: All over New York City, thousands spent hours waiting at clinics, motivated by a deep need to visit their parents.
lead_paragraph: Volumes have been written about the ways the culture of parenthood has changed over the past half-century — about the deep connection and mutual dependence forged between nascent adults and the people who raised them, devoted wardens and their ordained. Rarely do we get a physical image that makes the shift so apparent. Covid, strangely, has given this to us.

headline: Pregnant, Exhausted and Turned Back at the Border
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Trump administration’s restrictive immigration policies have not deterred pregnant women from seeking to enter the United States.
lead_paragraph: MATAMOROS, Mexico — Griselda was 38 weeks pregnant when she sneaked across the Rio Grande into the United States late one night last year. She started having contractions in a Border Patrol facility in McAllen, Texas, and was taken to a hospital where the medical staff gave her an injection to calm her pain and stop her from going into early labor.

headline: The Loneliness of One-Click Shopping
abstract: How did it become a patriotic duty to buy online?
lead_paragraph: One December day in 1991, a woman walked into a Bon-Ton department store in Ithaca, N.Y., in a state of high anxiety. Christmas loomed and she had yet to purchase a single gift. A clerk devoted herself to the customer’s cause, moving through the store with her to select something for each person on her extensive list.

headline: I’ve Been Wearing Masks for Months and I Still Have Questions
abstract: Should masks be stored with the underwear or with the socks?
lead_paragraph: Recently, at a funeral, I got to thinking about the lesser challenges of the mask. Not the should-you-or-shouldn’t-you, which is settled science at this point, but the specific problem of how to cry with a mask on. This was especially pressing for me because, as an incorrigible weeper — it doesn’t matter if I’m a third friend twice removed — I was streaming tears before the service had begun. But the mask posed a new challenge: How to blow my nose discreetly and with enough frequency that I didn’t wind up with a big wet splotch in the middle, surely a repellent look during a raging pandemic? How to lift my mask to do the requisite wiping without someone looking askance?

headline: Behind the Scenes, Romance Catches a Spark
abstract: Devin Keudell and Matt Polk, who are both in the theater industry, finally made a connection while working on “Rocky the Musical.”
lead_paragraph: Matt Polk got his first glimpse of Devin Keudell one day in the early 2000s, when Mr. Keudell was standing in a doorway at the Broadway League’s Spring Road Conference, an annual industry conference for theater on Broadway and across the country held at a hotel in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Can Cannabis Farms Weather Wildfire Season?
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Cannabis Foods and Products', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Wildfires', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Many marijuana crops are uninsured, which means that in the wake of disaster, farmers can face financial ruin.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, Joy Hollingsworth moved with her family from Seattle out to the country with a plan to build a cannabis business.

headline: Amazon Wants to Get Even Closer. Skintight.
abstract: In the pursuit of surveillance as a service, Jeff Bezos is intent on recording even our moods. How much personal data is too much to give to Amazon?
lead_paragraph: Here’s a tip: Don’t get into a car with your family and tell everyone that Jeff Bezos is listening through the device on your wrist.

headline: The Rich Kids Who Want to Tear Down Capitalism
keywords: ['Millennial Generation', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income Inequality', 'Wills and Estates', 'Philanthropy', 'Socialism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Socialist-minded millennial heirs are trying to live their values by getting rid of their money.
lead_paragraph: Lately, Sam Jacobs has been having a lot of conversations with his family’s lawyers. He’s trying to gain access to more of his $30 million trust fund. At 25, he’s hit the age when many heirs can blow their money on harebrained businesses or a stable of sports cars. He doesn’t want to do that, but by wealth management standards, his plan is just as bad. He wants to give it all away.

headline: He Stopped by Her Table, and Then Into Her Life
abstract: Bamba Sama left a lasting impression on Khrehaan Ebah, who was having lunch two years ago at a TGI Fridays, where Mr. Sama was the general manager.
lead_paragraph: Khrehaan Ebah’s chat with the restaurant manager who asked if she had enjoyed her lunch in March 2018 wasn’t for the benefit of her niece and dining companion, Yaheemah Ebah. But she used it to make a point about the importance of being cordial anyway.

headline: Why Did So Many Americans Vote for Trump?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: To the dismay of Democrats, the president’s strategy of ignoring the pandemic mostly worked for Republicans.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s disastrous mishandling of the coronavirus pandemic probably cost him re-election. Yet it seems mind-boggling that he still won more votes than any incumbent president in American history despite his dereliction of responsibility at a time of a once-in-a-century health crisis and economic devastation.

headline: How a Brooklyn Sisterhood of Black Women Became National Power Brokers
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Ten years ago, the Olori Sisterhood was a small-time “political sorority.” Now they’re ready for a seat at the table.
lead_paragraph: Last November, when Democratic presidential candidates were still jockeying for the nomination, before the coronavirus pandemic killed more than 250,000 Americans and fervent protests against police brutality swept the nation, Senator Kamala Harris of California appeared before a group of mostly Black women in South Carolina to file officially for the state’s critical primary.

headline: In Their 20s and Saving for Retirement: How It Started, How It’s Going
keywords: ['Savings', 'Retirement', 'Credit and Debt', 'Personal Finances', 'Millennial Generation', 'Generation Z', 'Content Type: Service', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Three savers learned some important lessons early on.
lead_paragraph: When Dray Farley was 15, he watched a video his favorite gamer had posted on YouTube. But it wasn’t about Call of Duty.

headline: The Exquisite Angst of Applying to College in a Deeply Anxious Year
abstract: The pandemic has changed everything about the stressful admissions process, adding even more strain on students.
lead_paragraph: As a new season for college applications begins, the coronavirus has upended the process, forcing millions of students to learn remotely, canceling college tours and standardized testing dates, and preventing legions of students from participating in sports and other extracurricular activities.

headline: In ‘Your Honor,’ a New Orleans Judge Breaks Bad
abstract: It was the best show idea the writer Peter Moffat had ever heard. Bryan Cranston loved it, too. Their new mini-series asks: How far would you go to protect your child?
lead_paragraph: “It’s the best premise anybody has ever said to me,” Peter Moffat said.

headline: Welcome to Homeownership
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: New Yorkers who left the city and bought country homes during the pandemic are discovering there’s a lot to learn (and spend) while taking care of a house.
lead_paragraph: Joe DeVito, like many other New Yorkers who wanted more space to weather the pandemic, headed north and bought a two-bedroom house in the Catskills in late July.

headline: How the Singer Patty Smyth Spends Her Sundays
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The frontwoman of the 1980s band Scandal talks about promoting her solo album during a pandemic and her 23-year marriage to the tennis star John McEnroe.
lead_paragraph: Patty Smyth, the husky-voiced lead singer of Scandal, known for its 1984 love anthem, “The Warrior,” would not have put out her first solo album of original songs in 28 years had she known the pandemic would last this long. “People ask me,” she said, “and I’m like, you think this is what I chose?”

headline: The Virus Won’t Stop Evolving When the Vaccine Arrives
abstract: The coronavirus is not a shape shifter like the flu virus, but it could become vaccine resistant over time. That prompts researchers to urge vigilance.
lead_paragraph: In a 1988 essay on pandemics Joshua Lederberg, Nobel laureate and president of The Rockefeller University, reminded the medical community that when it comes to infectious disease, the laws of Darwin are as important as the vaccines of Pasteur.

headline: Pushed by Pandemic, Amazon Goes on a Hiring Spree Without Equal
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'E-Commerce', 'Delivery Services', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The company has added 427,300 employees in 10 months, bringing its global work force to more than 1.2 million.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon has embarked on an extraordinary hiring binge this year, vacuuming up an average of 1,400 new workers a day and solidifying its power as online shopping becomes more entrenched in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Jailed, Exiled and Silenced: Smothering East Africa’s Political Opposition
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Political Prisoners', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Elections', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: In several countries, entrenched leaders are taking advantage of coronavirus restrictions and a world distracted by the pandemic to clamp down hard on prominent political opponents.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Since the presidential campaign kicked off in Uganda in early November, the most prominent opposition candidate, Bobi Wine, has been tear-gassed, arrested and beaten by the police, held in solitary confinement, and charged in court for holding campaign events in violation of coronavirus restrictions.

keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Workplace Environment', 'Virtual Currency', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Venture Capital', 'Start-ups', 'Corporate Social Responsibility']
abstract: Coinbase, the most valuable U.S. cryptocurrency company, has faced many internal complaints about discriminatory treatment.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One by one, they left. Some quit. Others were fired. All were Black.

headline: Her Antenna Is Tuned to the Quietest Voices
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'National Book Awards', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)']
abstract: Yu Miri won a National Book Award for “Tokyo Ueno Station,” a novel whose main character is the ghost of a homeless construction worker.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Walking on an autumn Saturday through Ueno Park, one of this city’s most popular attractions, the novelist Yu Miri was stunned by how beautified the grounds seemed since her last visit several years earlier.

headline: It’s the Winter of Backcountry. Here’s How to Start Safely.
abstract: The pandemic has many people wanting to avoid crowded slopes. Going into the backcountry requires avalanche knowledge or a guide. Here are suggestions for taking part across the United States.
lead_paragraph: Backcountry skiing and snowboarding have exploded into the mainstream this year. As ski resorts are limiting access because of the coronavirus pandemic, skiers are looking for alternative ways to recreate while staying physically distanced.  The backcountry boom is also being driven by a new generation of Alpine touring skis and snowboards that make it easier for newcomers to transition from skiing and riding at resorts to the backcountry. REI reports that sales of backcountry ski equipment have tripled since last fall (you can rent it too).

headline: Even From the Desert, Danny Lyon Still Speaks to the Streets
keywords: ['Photography', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Art', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The indefatigable photographer on the struggles of getting his new film to the next generation of activists.
lead_paragraph: BERNALILLO, N.M. — On Nov. 4, the morning after the election, hope and uncertainty mingled in the air outside the adobe house of the photographer and filmmaker Danny Lyon. Wind ruffled the branches of the golden cottonwoods he planted when he built the place in the early 1970s; it was sunny out. “I’m an eternal optimist,” he said. Mr. Lyon wore a Stetson hat, a blue button-down shirt, a face mask; green suspenders hitched up his jeans. In some parts of the country he has occasionally been mistaken for his University of Chicago classmate Bernie Sanders, for whom he stumped in 2019. “I just wave back at everybody,” he said.

headline: ‘Democracy Should Not Be Taken for Granted’
abstract: Readers around the world tell us about the global ripple effect of the U.S. election.
lead_paragraph: “Mr. Biden has vowed to turn the page on the ‘aberration’ of Mr. Trump’s foreign policy,” wrote Robert Malley and Philip H. Gordon in the Op-Ed “Trump Still Has 70 Days to Wreak Havoc Around the World.” But is that what people around the world really want?

headline: He Once Trafficked in Rare Birds. Now, He Tells How It’s Done.
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Wildlife Trade and Poaching', 'Smuggling', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Breeding of Animals', 'Birds', 'Parrots']
abstract: After a chance encounter in Brazil, Johann Zillinger became one of the world’s most prolific wildlife smugglers. Three decades and two prison stints later, he says he has gone straight.
lead_paragraph: WEIDEN AN DER MARCH, Austria — On a humid evening at the airport in Fortaleza, in northern Brazil, Johann Zillinger, a wildlife trafficker, was keeping a close eye on his new hire. He had recruited the 24-year-old farmhand as a smuggler a few days earlier, promising him a free trip to Europe and $2,000 in cash.

headline: A Black Friday Like no Other
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: It’s Black Friday, the typical start of the holiday shopping season. But as with so many other things, this year’s version will not look like it usually does.

headline: The military’s role in a vaccine will be strictly behind the scenes, despite Trump’s claims.
abstract: When President Trump talks about efforts to deliver the coronavirus vaccine to millions of Americans eager to return to their normal lives, he often says he is “counting on the military” to get it done.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump talks about efforts to deliver the coronavirus vaccine to millions of Americans eager to return to their normal lives, he often says he is “counting on the military” to get it done.

headline: The Baltimore Ravens’ star quarterback is said to have tested positive for the virus.
abstract: Lamar Jackson, the Baltimore Ravens quarterback and the National Football League’s reigning Most Valuable Player, on Thursday became the highest-profile player to test positive for the coronavirus as an outbreak of cases spread to more than a dozen players on the team, according to several media outlets.
lead_paragraph: Lamar Jackson, the Baltimore Ravens quarterback and the National Football League’s reigning Most Valuable Player, on Thursday became the highest-profile player to test positive for the coronavirus as an outbreak of cases spread to more than a dozen players on the team, according to several media outlets.

headline: England’s lockdown will lift next week, but many pubs will stay closed.
abstract: Under fire from critics over the economic and social cost of his coronavirus restrictions, Prime Minister Boris Johnson will bring a grueling, second, national lockdown in England to an end next week.
lead_paragraph: Under fire from critics over the economic and social cost of his coronavirus restrictions, Prime Minister Boris Johnson will bring a grueling, second, national lockdown in England to an end next week.

headline: They Beat Back the Virus (Again and Again and Again)
abstract: Hard-to-trace clusters, along with pandemic fatigue, have forced officials in Hong Kong, South Korea and Japan to keep recalibrating their responses.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — First, it was travelers and university students bringing the coronavirus back to Hong Kong from Europe and the United States. Then, sea crews and bar patrons were the ones spreading infections.

headline: HBO Documentary Has Competition. These Women Don’t Seem Worried.
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Television', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: These days everybody wants a piece of the nonfiction game. HBO’s documentary heads, Nancy Abraham and Lisa Heller, talked about how they’re navigating the evolving landscape.
lead_paragraph: With documentaries a central part of the national conversation, it’s easy to forget that not only were they once relatively hard to find but they also had a damning reputation as being good for you — the kiss of death in entertainment terms.

headline: Some Movies Actually Understand Poverty in America
abstract: The complex realities of subsistence escape “Hillbilly Elegy.” But as far back as Charlie Chaplin’s “City Lights,” filmmakers have been turning a discerning eye on destitution.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene in Ron Howard’s new “Hillbilly Elegy” that approaches the quiet dignity I wish the rest of the movie had. Glenn Close stands in a doorway. She’s playing Mamaw, the proud Appalachian grandmother of the high schooler who will eventually write the memoir on which the film is based. Mamaw accepts a free dinner from Meals on Wheels. And while it pains her to do so, she asks for more food. The delivery kid blinks, embarrassed. But he bends the rules a little and the two connect over a small but meaningful act of charity.

headline: How ‘The Crown’ Embraced ’80s Pop
abstract: Season 4 of the Netflix show takes viewers into a new decade, with a musical soundtrack to match, including artists like Stevie Nicks, Elton John and David Bowie.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The fourth season of “The Crown” enters a new cultural era: the 1980s. As the plot moves into the Margaret Thatcher years, and a younger generation of royals — including Prince Charles and Diana, Princess of Wales — comes to the forefront of the show, the creator Peter Morgan was eager to take the soundtrack in a new direction, too: pop music from the period. “Naturally, I was over the moon about it,” Sarah Bridge, the music supervisor on the third and fourth seasons, said in a telephone interview. “Stepping into the ’80s was a really exciting time. What an incredible decade of music to choose from.”

headline: India’s Economy Shrinks Sharply as Covid-19 Slams Small Businesses
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'Small Business', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: The latest data firmly establishes India’s position among the worst-performing major economies, despite government spending meant to blunt the pandemic’s impact.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — China has come roaring back from the devastation of Covid-19, and the United States, Europe and Japan are finding their feet. But the hundreds of millions of laborers and shopkeepers who keep India’s economy running still can’t find relief.

headline: Paul Smith on How to Sew Patches in a Traditional Japanese Stitch
keywords: ['Do It Yourself', 'Sewing', 'Content Type: Service', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: In the latest installment of our Designer D.I.Y. series, learn how to breathe new life into old clothes with a classic sashiko stitch.
lead_paragraph: What to do with a beloved jacket in which the elbows have gone or a shirt with frayed cuffs? The British designer Sir Paul Smith, known for his sharp suits and signature rainbow stripes and who is celebrating 50 years in fashion, thinks you should look to a sartorial solution passed down through multiple generations of Japanese laborers.

headline: All That We Have Lost
abstract: Part of Diego Maradona’s enduring appeal is testament to his genius. But part of it, too, speaks to a sense of nostalgia for what he represented.
lead_paragraph: There was a commotion over in the corner of the Krestovsky Stadium in St. Petersburg. A whole section of fans seemed to have turned its eyes away from the field and trained them instead on a glass-fronted suite. They stood on their seats and craned their necks and peered over shoulders to try to get a better view.

headline: How Will Co-Living Survive the Pandemic?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The coronavirus drove vacancies up in co-living buildings, but companies are offering rent deals and flexible leases to bring demand back.
lead_paragraph: The core benefits of co-living took a big hit when the coronavirus struck New York City.

headline: Groups Trying to Open Golf to Young People Are Struggling Themselves
abstract: Even as more young men and women in need want to play, the pandemic has made it more difficult for nonprofits to raise money.
lead_paragraph: Golf has been having a boom year since courses that were closed in the pandemic reopened in June.

headline: As Winter Arrives, Heaters Become a Survival Tool for Businesses
abstract: A rise in demand for heating equipment has left some products back-ordered for months, possibly jeopardizing prospects for some businesses of getting through the pandemic intact.
lead_paragraph: The must-have accessory for many businesses this winter is basic, but lately it has been hard to find: the humble space heater.

headline: Iranian Diplomat Accused of Plotting to Bomb Dissidents Goes on Trial in Belgium
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Prosecutors say the diplomat, Assadollah Assadi, was carrying out a plan organized by Iran’s intelligence services against an overseas opposition group.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The bomb was handed over at a Pizza Hut in Luxembourg. The intent, prosecutors say, was to blow up a rally in France of a prominent opposition group to the Iranian government.

headline: Trump Gave W.H.O. a List of Demands. Hours Later, He Walked Away.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: When President Trump quit the health organization, he left a list of seven demands on the table. Here they are.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — In late May, the American ambassador in Geneva, Andrew Bremberg, went on a rescue mission to the World Health Organization headquarters. He told its director general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, that despite weeks of threats that President Trump would quit the health organization, the relationship could still be salvaged.

headline: Marching to the Beat of Their Own Drum
abstract: Inspired by this year’s protests against racial injustice, this Derek Fordjour painting reimagines the stars and stripes of the American flag.
lead_paragraph: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at a painting by Derek Fordjour, whose solo show at the Petzel Gallery, “Self Must Die,” is on view through Dec. 19.

headline: Iran’s Top Nuclear Scientist Killed in Ambush, State Media Say
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: U.S. and Israeli intelligence described the scientist, Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, as the force behind what they call Iran’s covert push for nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Check here for further details.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Put your Thanksgiving leftovers to work, in touriéres, in a sandwich, in soup, or in a panzanella.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. So how’d that go? Weird, right? Not unpleasant, I hope, plenty delicious and fun. But strange indeed to have years of tradition upended by the need to stay safe amid a pandemic, for sure. And boy howdy the leftovers. I wanted to cook a smaller bird. But I ended up with a 17-pounder and, well, I’ve got a lot of cooked turkey meat just now. It’s time, this weekend, to do something about that. You may be in a similar position.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: “Are you OK?” asks Meghan, Duchess of Sussex. The chameleon of leftovers. The legacy of Mayor David Dinkins. And more.
lead_paragraph: “Are you OK?” asks Meghan, Duchess of Sussex. The chameleon of leftovers. The legacy of Mayor David Dinkins. And more.

headline: Ghost Ships
keywords: ['Sailboats and Sailing', 'Skiing', 'Boats and Boating', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: My sister was my other half until we tacked in different directions, making our own life choices.
lead_paragraph: “We’re jumping in here?” I ask my sister, as we rush to jam fins on our feet and sling snorkels over salty ponytails. Nervousness lodges in my throat as I consider the blue deep that goes on forever under the catamaran’s rolling hull.

headline: Plagued by delays, the American Dream mall finally opened in October. Then the pandemic hit.
abstract: It took more than 15 years for the American Dream mall to begin opening its doors in October 2019. The massive shopping and entertainment complex in East Rutherford, N.J., faced numerous delays as it cycled through developers and billions of dollars in funding.
lead_paragraph: It took more than 15 years for the American Dream mall to begin opening its doors in October 2019. The massive shopping and entertainment complex in East Rutherford, N.J., faced numerous delays as it cycled through developers and billions of dollars in funding.

headline: Biden’s Plan for Seniors Is Not Just a Plan for Seniors
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Domestic Service', 'Long-Term Care Insurance', 'Home Health Care', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Nursing Homes', 'Elderly', 'Family Leaves', 'Child Care', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: The incoming administration aims to tackle child care, elder care, preschool and more in one ambitious aid program.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has no shortage of ideas about how to transform caregiving. One striking feature of his team’s plan: It does not address elder care separately from child care, or divide plans to support family caregivers from those for paid caregivers. Rather, it takes on Medicaid benefits for older and disabled adults, preschool for toddlers and better jobs for home care workers, all in one ambitious, $775 billion-over-a-decade package.

headline: Empowered by an Odds-Defying Win, Susan Collins Is Ready to Deal
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The senator from Maine has emerged from the toughest re-election battle of her career more influential than ever, and ready to play a crucial deal-making role in a divided Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The calls began pouring in even before Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, bounded onto a makeshift stage in a snowy parking lot in Bangor to declare victory in a race she was supposed to have lost.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The late-night hosts took the holiday off, and all seemed thankful earlier in the week that there were still plenty of White House antics to discuss.
lead_paragraph: The late-night hosts took the holiday off, and all seemed thankful earlier in the week that there were still plenty of White House antics to discuss.

headline: It’s 2020, So of Course Mike Tyson Is Boxing Again
abstract: The return offers started coming when videos of Tyson sparring at age 54 gained steam online. They landed on a bout with Roy Jones Jr., another champion from long ago.
lead_paragraph: Mike Tyson is back for a pay-per-view fight. Well, not exactly a fight. (“It’s an exhibition bout between two former champions,” said a seemingly exasperated Andy Foster, the California State Athletic Commission executive officer. “I don’t know another way to put it.”)

headline: Talking About the 10 Best Books of 2020
abstract: On a special episode of the podcast, taped live, editors from The New York Times Book Review discuss this year’s outstanding fiction and nonfiction.
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Royal Watchers Wonder: Do the Royals Watch ‘The Crown’?
abstract: A lack of hard facts has not prevented plenty of speculation as to whether Queen Elizabeth and the other members of the royal family ever watch their fictionalized selves.
lead_paragraph: If there were a TV show that portrayed your family as a clueless bunch of snobs and philanderers who helped drive a mentally fragile young princess to despair, would you watch it?

headline: Is There a Lockstep Mentality on the Left?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Readers react to a column by Bret Stephens arguing that “groupthink” is blinding progressives.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Looking for Better Ways of Running Elections
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'States (US)', 'Education', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia']
abstract: A reader endorses a bill that includes automatic voter registration. Another says we should keep our electoral system decentralized. Also: A broader view of education; the flag isn’t partisan.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Chilling Question Divides Europe: Open Ski Slopes or Keep Them Closed?
abstract: Leading up to the Christmas season, France, Germany and Italy will keep slopes shut, but Austria and Switzerland have vowed to reopen theirs, in Europe’s latest struggle to coordinate a pandemic response.
lead_paragraph: Weeks before the coronavirus pandemic swept across Europe in February, some of the first virus clusters on the continent appeared in ski resorts in the Alps, leading to cascading outbreaks as ski enthusiasts returned home.

headline: The Coziest White Bean Stew
abstract: Thousands of readers can’t be wrong about Colu Henry’s roasted tomato and white bean stew.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Margaux here, filling in for Emily this week. I hope you had a lovely Thanksgiving, whatever that looked like for you this year. Mine was small and different, but kind of perfect? It’s been a challenging several months in so many ways, and yet I’ve also never felt so thankful.

headline: Did John McCracken Make That Monolith in Utah?
abstract: It is a riddle, wrapped in a mystery, buried in the desert: His dealer says yes. His son says maybe. His artist buddies, like Ed Ruscha, say, no way the sculptor created this tall, silvery object.
lead_paragraph: At first it sounded like a plot twist from a science-fiction novel by Philip K. Dick. A tall, silvery slice of metal, about 10 feet high with an aura of strangeness about it, is spotted in the red-rock canyons of the Utah desert. State employees who found it while surveying the land for bighorn sheep say they have no idea who drove the slab of metal into the rock floor. And in the days since, the riddle of what it is and how it got there has proved irresistible.

headline: ‘Remain home and stay on the good list,’ say N.Y.C. SantaCon organizers.
abstract: New York City streets will officially be devoid of throngs of the jolliest — and perhaps most inebriated — St. Nicks this year. SantaCon, the daylong bar-crawling event that some people love, and many love to hate, has been canceled.
lead_paragraph: New York City streets will officially be devoid of throngs of the jolliest — and perhaps most inebriated — St. Nicks this year. SantaCon, the daylong bar-crawling event that some people love, and many love to hate, has been canceled.

headline: Covid Overload: U.S. Hospitals Are Running Out of Beds for Patients
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hospitals', 'Shortages', 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Doctors', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Rural Areas', 'Disease Rates', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: As the coronavirus pandemic surges across the country, hospitals are facing a crisis-level shortage of beds and staff to provide adequate care for patients.
lead_paragraph: In excruciating pain with lesions on her face and scalp, Tracey Fine lay for 13 hours on a gurney in an emergency room hallway.

headline: U.S. coronavirus infections shoot past 13 million as officials plead with Americans to spend Black Friday online.
abstract: The number of coronavirus infections in the United States shot past 13 million on Friday, worsening the world’s largest outbreak. The milestone came as Americans embarked on a Black Friday that looked different from holidays past.
lead_paragraph: The number of coronavirus infections in the United States shot past 13 million on Friday, worsening the world’s largest outbreak. The milestone came as Americans embarked on a Black Friday that looked different from holidays past.

headline: I Don’t Want to Be the Office Grandma
abstract: Advice for getting back into the work force at 60, dealing with shame and co-workers, and how to cope with losing all motivation for working from home.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, even if you want them withheld. Letters may be edited.

headline: E.P.A.’s Final Deregulatory Rush Runs Into Open Staff Resistance
keywords: ['Presidential Transition (US)', 'Environment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Air Pollution', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: As President Trump's Environmental Protection Agency rushes to complete its regulatory rollbacks, agency staff, emboldened by the Biden victory, moves to stand in the way.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s Environmental Protection Agency was rushing to complete one of its last regulatory priorities, aiming to obstruct the creation of air- and water-pollution controls far into the future, when a senior career scientist moved to hobble it.

headline: Britain Set to Leap Ahead in Approving Vaccines
abstract: Regulators may approve the troubled AstraZeneca vaccine and the American-made Pfizer shot weeks before the U.S. does so.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain asked its drug regulator on Friday to consider AstraZeneca’s coronavirus vaccine for emergency approval, forging ahead in the face of considerable uncertainty about the vaccine’s effectiveness as the government tries to corral a pandemic that has killed more than 66,000 people in the country.

headline: ‘The Mandalorian’ Season 2, Episode 5 Recap: Baby Yoda Has a Name
abstract: Mando gets a new task from a complicated ally. Baby Yoda gets a back story.
lead_paragraph: Baby Yoda has a name!

headline: Love Letter: Craving Comfort and Connection
keywords: ['Love (Emotion)', 'Marriages', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: And how to do a solo holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Since the onset of Covid-19, many people have found themselves feeling nostalgic for more certain times. For C Pam Zhang, the writer of this week’s Modern Love essay, her quick cure for heartache, grief and the isolation of the pandemic is the simple pleasure of her favorite childhood treat — crispy, golden chicken nuggets. The calming properties of processed chicken have brought her both comfort and a deeper connection to her father, who died eight years ago.

headline: Swiss to Vote on Tougher Responsibility Proposal for Companies
keywords: ['Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Referendums', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: A referendum on Sunday, if approved, would make Swiss companies liable for human rights violations and environmental damage by their subsidiaries abroad.
lead_paragraph: For several months, orange flags printed with “Yes!” have hung from balconies across Switzerland, encouraging the public to vote Sunday in favor of an initiative to make Swiss companies liable for human rights violations and environmental damage committed by their subsidiaries abroad.

headline: A Second Sudden Exit for a Hard-Charging Artistic Director
keywords: ['Theater', '#MeToo Movement', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Actors and Actresses', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: Ari Roth founded Mosaic Theater Company after being fired by Theater J. He resigned under pressure after complaints from staff.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Ari Roth was fired six years ago by the Jewish theater he led here, where he had staged plays raising challenging questions about Israel, some of the nation’s leading directors and dramatists rallied to his defense — even as officials at the theater insisted that his dismissal had nothing to do with politics.

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach Was Canceled, but the Show Goes On
abstract: As coronavirus deaths rose, museums and galleries rolled out new shows. The socialite Libbie Mugrabi is planning a dinner for the ages. Is Miami’s art world clueless?
lead_paragraph: Call it the zombie version of Art Basel Miami Beach. The annual fair, originally scheduled to unfold next week with the contemporary art world converging in South Florida, was canceled in September by its Swiss-based organizers — a cultural casualty of the coronavirus. Over a dozen Miami satellite fairs followed suit, all mirroring Basel’s pivot to online “viewing rooms.” The art circus, it seemed, was not coming to town.

headline: How Toronto Plans to Keep Schools Open Amid Its Second Lockdown
abstract: Ontario’s education minister announced a program to test schools’ asymptomatic students and staff in four of the province’s hardest-hit areas, something critics have been demanding for months.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — On Monday, as I was writing a news article about Canada’s enthusiasm for keeping schools open during the second wave of the coronavirus, an email arrived from my daughter’s high school alerting me that a student had tested positive and a grade-12 class had been asked to self-isolate.

headline: In Harsh Rebuke, Appeals Court Rejects Trump’s Election Challenge in Pennsylvania
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: “Voters, not lawyers, choose the president,” a judge for the Third Circuit Court of Appeals wrote in the 21-page repudiation of Mr. Trump’s legal effort to halt Pennsylvania’s certification process.
lead_paragraph: In a blistering decision, a Philadelphia appeals court ruled on Friday that the Trump campaign could not stop — or attempt to reverse — the certification of the voting results in Pennsylvania, reprimanding the president’s team by noting that “calling an election unfair does not make it so.”

headline: Debra White Plume, Defender of Her Tribe, Is Dead at 66
keywords: ['Native Americans', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Keystone Pipeline System']
abstract: She championed the rights of the Oglala Lakota in South Dakota and was a leader in protests at Wounded Knee and oil pipeline sites.
lead_paragraph: Debra White Plume, a prominent Native American activist who faced down police bullets, uranium mining companies and oil pipeline projects in trying to protect the traditional Oglala Lakota way of life, died on Nov. 10 in Rapid City, S.D. She was 66.

headline: Bruce Boynton, Plaintiff in Landmark Civil Rights Case, Dies at 83
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Discrimination', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Interstate Commerce', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: He was a Black man who wanted to sit in the white section of a bus terminal restaurant. The case reached the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: “All he wanted was a cheeseburger,” Judge Myron Thompson of United States District Court in Alabama said at an event two years ago honoring Bruce C. Boynton, “and he changed the course of history.”

headline: Pictures of a Thanksgiving That No One Pictured
abstract: To retain the essence of the holiday in a pandemic-scarred year, many Americans found themselves having to bend Thanksgiving traditions into unexpected shapes.
lead_paragraph: Whether they carved turkeys at outdoor picnic tables, connected with family through video calls or ate stuffing in the break room of a hospital coronavirus ward, many Americans found themselves marking this Thanksgiving in ways they hardly could have foreseen a year ago.

headline: Pentagon Chief Visits Somalia Ahead of Expected Troop Cuts
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)']
abstract: Acting Defense Secretary Christopher C. Miller met with troops and commanders in the region as turmoil bedevils the nation with approaching elections and an enduring threat from the Shabab.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Acting Defense Secretary Christopher C. Miller met with American troops and diplomats in Somalia on Friday, the first Pentagon chief to visit the strife-torn East African nation. He may also be the last.

headline: McKinsey Proposed Paying Pharmacy Companies Rebates for OxyContin Overdoses
keywords: ['OxyContin (Drug)', 'Opioids and Opiates', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Consultants']
abstract: Court filings reveal consultants’ talk of a records purge during the opioid crisis, and shed new light on sales advice given to the billionaire Sackler family and their drug company, Purdue Pharma.
lead_paragraph: When Purdue Pharma agreed last month to plead guilty to criminal charges involving OxyContin, the Justice Department noted the role an unidentified consulting company had played in driving sales of the addictive painkiller even as public outrage grew over widespread overdoses.

headline: Coronavirus Hospitalizations, Iran, Black Friday: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: For the World Economy, a Grim Slog Tempered by New Hopes
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Recession and Depression', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: The emergence of vaccines has taken the edge off the worst fears, but a meaningful economic recovery probably remains distant.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year into a pandemic that has ravaged the global economy like no time since the Great Depression, the only clear pathway toward improved fortunes is containing the virus itself.

headline: Gunmen Assassinate Iran’s Top Nuclear Scientist in Ambush, Provoking New Crisis
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Iran expressed fury over the killing of Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, blaming it on Israel and the United States. His death may complicate President-elect Biden’s intention to restore the Iranian nuclear deal.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s top nuclear scientist, long identified by American and Israeli intelligence as the guiding figure behind a covert effort to design an atomic warhead, was shot and killed Friday in what the Iranian media called a roadside ambush as he and his bodyguards traveled outside Tehran.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 28, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 28, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about President Trump’s exchange with reporters in the White House on Thursday misstated the last time a Democrat won Georgia in a presidential election. It was 1992, not 1996.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Scathing Ruling Sinks President in Pennsylvania
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 28, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Voters, not lawyers, choose the president. Ballots, not briefs, decide elections.”

headline: Says Too Much
abstract: Nam Jin Yoon’s Saturday puzzle rolls off the tongue.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — A week ago, we got a taste of hyperdifficulty. This puzzle, Nam Jin Yoon’s second construction for us and his Saturday debut, is like a soft cozy sweater compared with Sam Ezersky’s, um, horsehair shirt (or whatever itchy garment you can imagine). There are loads of great culture references, mingling with gently funny puns and hardly any noticeable glue. There are even a couple of prompts for what to read and watch, assuming you’re still holidaying.

headline: Macron Says Images of French Police Beating Black Man ‘Shame Us’
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron called for reaffirming “the link of confidence that should naturally exist between the French and those who protect them.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France said on Friday that video images showing police officers beating a Black man “shame us,” and he condemned violence both by and against the police.

headline: Beijing Takes Its South China Sea Strategy to the Himalayas
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Territorial Disputes', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: China built a village in territory also claimed by the kingdom of Bhutan, echoing its aggressive tactics at the border with India and in places much farther away.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for its National Day in October, China completed construction of a new village high in the mountains where the Chinese region of Tibet meets the kingdom of Bhutan. A hundred people moved into two dozen new homes beside the Torsa River and celebrated the holiday by raising China’s flag and singing the national anthem.

headline: Los Angeles Bans Almost All Public Gatherings to Stop Virus Surge
abstract: Los Angeles County is now seeing almost 5,000 new virus cases a day. The order, which even restricts functions in private homes, takes effect Monday.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — The Los Angeles County Department of Public Health on Friday called on residents to stay home as the virus continues its rapid surge, barring gatherings both in public at private homes if people are from different households.

headline: What to Watch When Mike Tyson Fights Roy Jones Jr.
abstract: Is this for real? Yes. Sort of. Just expect more spectacle than high-level boxing.
lead_paragraph: Mike Tyson will box Roy Jones Jr. on Saturday night. (No, we haven’t entered some kind of time warp.)

headline: Ohio State Cancels Football Game Against Illinois Amid Virus Outbreak
abstract: The university announced the cancellation hours after reporting that the coach of the fourth-ranked Buckeyes, Ryan Day, had tested positive for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Ohio State on Friday night called off its football game scheduled for Saturday at Illinois after coronavirus testing revealed an increasing number of cases on the team. The cancellation was announced hours after the university revealed that Ryan Day, the head coach of the fourth-ranked Buckeyes, had tested positive and would not travel to the game.

headline: As Hiking Surges During the Pandemic, So Do Injuries
abstract: Novice hikers and climbers have flocked to the outdoors, but some are unprepared for the dangers on the trails.
lead_paragraph: Outdoor activities have become a popular pastime during the coronavirus pandemic as adventure seekers and couch surfers alike take to hiking trails for a bit of a reprieve.

headline: How Democrats Suffered Crushing Down-Ballot Losses Across America
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'State Legislatures', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Police Reform', 'Global Warming', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: In statehouse races, suburban voters’ disgust with President Trump failed to translate into a rebuke of other Republicans, ensuring the party’s grip on partisan mapmaking.
lead_paragraph: WEXFORD, Pa. — Just a few seats shy of a majority in the State House of Representatives, Democrats in Pennsylvania this year zeroed in on Republican-held suburban districts, where disdain for President Trump ran hot.

headline: Arizona Settles In to Life as a ‘Magenta’ State
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Elections, Senate', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Voting and Voters', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Democrats made historic inroads. But it’s a deeply divided place, and some say a “blood bath” is on the horizon in 2022.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In the moonlight, dozens of people hollered and embraced, dropping the rules of social distancing as they celebrated a win after a long year: hundreds of thousands of Latino voters registered, calls made and doors knocked amid a pandemic that had devastated their communities. Though it would be days before the final result in Arizona was clear, the people working to shore up Latino support for Democrats in the state were already convinced that they helped shape history. They had come through the crucible of a pervasive anti-immigrant sentiment and a decade later, flipped the state and delivered wins.

headline: The World’s Most Glamorous Quarantine Project
keywords: ['Diamonds', 'Hope Diamond', 'Models and Replicas', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: While you’ve been binge-watching Netflix and peering anxiously at your sourdough, John Hatleberg has been working on replicas of the Hope Diamond and its earlier incarnations for the Smithsonian.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of the pandemic, diamonds (at least newly mined ones) may have lost their luster. But in the studio of his New York apartment, John Hatleberg is betting it will soon be back.

headline: My Neighbor’s Dogs Are Driving Me Crazy. What Can I Do?
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Dogs', 'Noise', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: Incessant barking is the top complaint to animal-control centers. As always, it’s better to start with a personal approach.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a quiet suburban neighborhood in Metuchen, N.J. Neighbors whose backyard abuts ours have two very large dogs that they leave outside all day, and the dogs bark incessantly and loudly. Six months into this pandemic, my other neighbors and I are stretched to the limit, as we are working from home and the noise diminishes our quality of life. What recourse do we have?

headline: Sometimes, It’s OK to Bark in Meetings
abstract: Some of our favorite new colleagues are four-legged and furry.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: What We Can Learn From Solitude
keywords: ['Meditation', 'Prayers and Prayer Books', 'Loneliness', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Content Type: Service', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'your-feed-selfcare']
abstract: Contemporary hermits are reaching out to people struggling with isolation. Their message: Go inward, and get outside.
lead_paragraph: Since the beginning of the pandemic, Paul Fredette and Karen Karper Fredette have made some changes to their lives: Ms. Fredette stopped attending her local exercise class, and the couple whittled their interactions with their neighbors down to waves.

headline: Top Contenders for Biden’s Cabinet Draw Fire From All Sides
keywords: ['Presidential Transition (US)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Liberalism (US Politics)']
abstract: Lists of names of those the president-elect is said to be considering are flying across Washington, prompting lawmakers and interest groups to raise questions about some top contenders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are leading candidates and dark horses. There are potential roadblocks from progressives and conservatives. And there are competing factions hoping to be part of the next president’s inner circle, all jockeying for influence.

headline: A.A. to Zoom, Substance Abuse Treatment Goes Online
keywords: ['Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Telemedicine', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: It began as a stopgap way to get through the pandemic, but both participants and providers say virtual sessions have some clear advantages and will likely become a permanent part of recovery.
lead_paragraph: Until the coronavirus pandemic, their meetings took place quietly, every day, discreet gatherings in the basements of churches, a spare room at the YMCA, the back of a cafe. But members of Alcoholics Anonymous and other groups of recovering substance abusers found the doors quickly shut this spring, to prevent the spread of Covid-19.

headline: Hollywood’s Obituary, the Sequel. Now Streaming.
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Box Office Sales']
abstract: In the 110-year history of the American film industry, never has so much upheaval arrived so quickly and on so many fronts.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Hollywood’s like Egypt: full of crumbled pyramids. It’ll never come back. It’ll just keep on crumbling until finally the wind blows the last studio prop across the sands.”

headline: Pedophile Scandal Can’t Crack the Closed Circles of Literary France
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: The scandal surrounding the writer Gabriel Matzneff was not limited to his pedophilia. It also opened a window on the entrenched and clubby nature of many of France’s elite institutions.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — One of France’s most prestigious literary awards, the Renaudot can change a writer’s career overnight. Prizewinners jump onto best-seller lists. Publishers earn bragging rights in a nation that places literature at the heart of its sense of grandeur and global standing.

headline: How to Build a Guitar
keywords: ['Guitars', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Wood and Wood Products', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: For The New York Times for Kids, the photographer Christopher Payne visited the Martin Guitars factory to see how humans and machines make music.
lead_paragraph: When a guitarist plucks a guitar string, it starts to quiver back and forth — setting off a cascade of vibrations along the length of the instrument. The vibrations travel down the strings to the top of the guitar, called the soundboard, and then displace the air inside the body. The air bounces off the stiff wooden back and sides and bursts out of the sound hole: a musical note.

headline: There’s No Better Time to Clear the Air
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Carbon Monoxide', 'Mold', 'Air Pollution', 'Radon Gas', 'Paint']
abstract: It’s discomforting to realize that air pollution can be coming from inside your home. Here’s how to identify and rid yourself of the risks.
lead_paragraph: Think about the phrase “air pollution.” Are you picturing black plumes curling out of factory smokestacks and the tailpipes of idling vehicles? Something to worry about outdoors, that is, not inside your home? Not so fast: Air pollutants could be within your own walls too, seeping from your furnace, your basement, even that new couch, and their threats range from eye irritation to an increased risk of cancer, and maybe even death.

headline: Plastic Dividers and Masks All Day: What Teaching in a Pandemic Looks Like
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting']
abstract: As school districts diverge on handling the pandemic, Baltimore City Public Schools are slowly trying to get students back in the classroom. It has not been easy, but neither has remote learning.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Zia Hellman prepared to welcome her kindergarten students back to Walter P. Carter Elementary/Middle School this month the way any teacher would on the first day of school: She fussed over her classroom.

headline: ‘From the Front Lines,’ Stories of Resistance and a Movement for Black Lives
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: In an interview, Saidu Tejan-Thomas Jr., the creator of the podcast, Resistance, talked about the movement unfolding in Nigeria, with regular demonstrations against police brutality.
lead_paragraph: The hashtag #EndSARS first surfaced in 2017 as activists in Nigeria sought to abolish a federal police unit called the Special Anti-Robbery Squad that residents said had misused its power. Known as SARS, demonstrators accused the unit of inflicting violence on residents.

headline: As Iran Threatens Payback After Assassination, Germany Urges Restraint
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The killing of Iran’s top nuclear scientist, which Tehran blamed on Israel, raised fears of an escalation in violent retribution.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s leaders threatened on Saturday to retaliate over the assassination of the country’s top nuclear scientist, blaming Israel and pledging to continue the work of the man who American and Israeli officials believe was the architect of what they call the country’s secretive nuclear weapons program.

headline: Closing Time for a Village’s Last Pub?
abstract: With a deadline looming, locals scramble to raise enough money to buy the White Horse Tavern — and save the soul of their community.
lead_paragraph: STONESFIELD, England — Seven pubs in this tiny village in West Oxfordshire have closed over the years, and some residents here still talk about each as if it were a beloved relative who had expired last week. The Black Head? Turned into a private home. Rose & Crown? Demolished and replaced with a row of houses. The Boot Inn? Kaput.

headline: 47 Recipes for Thanksgiving Leftovers
abstract: They’re quite possibly the best part of the holiday.
lead_paragraph: Did you go too big with your turkey? Have stuffing for days? Don’t worry, we have lots of suggestions for what to do with it all. You could make Sohla El-Waylly’s Thanksgiving leftovers sandwich (above) or her stuffing dumpling soup, or Samin Nosrat’s turkey tikka masala. Kids and adults alike will love Margaux Laskey’s leftovers enchilada pie. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: Tony Hsieh, Longtime Chief of Zappos, Is Dead at 46
abstract: In the early days of online retailing, he realized that the key to success was making people feel comfortable and secure shopping on the internet.
lead_paragraph: Tony Hsieh, the technology entrepreneur and venture capitalist who built Zappos into a $1 billion internet shoes and clothing powerhouse, died on Friday in Bridgeport Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn.  He was 46.

headline: Pandemic-Proof Your Habits
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Habits and Routines (Behavior)']
abstract: Too many people are still longing for their old routines. Get some new ones instead.
lead_paragraph: I attended a Thanksgiving dinner several years ago where the hostess, without warning family and friends, broke with tradition and served salmon instead of turkey, roasted potatoes instead of mashed, raspberry coulis instead of cranberry sauce and … you get the idea.

headline: Biden Aides’ Ties to Consulting and Investment Firms Pose Ethics Test
keywords: ['Presidential Transition (US)', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Defense Contracts', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Some of the president-elect’s choices for top posts have done work for undisclosed corporate clients and aided a fund that invests in government contractors.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One firm helps companies navigate global risks and the political and procedural ins and outs of Washington. The other is an investment fund with a particular interest in military contractors.

headline: 19th-Century Ship Is Revealed by Storm Erosion in Florida
keywords: ['Shipwrecks (Historic)', 'Coast Erosion', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Archaeology and Anthropology']
abstract: Researchers believe the vessel is the Caroline Eddy, a ship built during the Civil War and wrecked in 1880. “It was a sea like a mountain,” its captain recounted at the time.
lead_paragraph: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. — Not long after the Caroline Eddy set sail in 1880 from Florida with cargo bound for up the coast, a powerful hurricane nearly tore it apart, casting the crew, clinging to the rigging, adrift for two days before the wreck washed ashore.

headline: A video in a hospital courtyard captures an 81-year-old Italian’s serenade to his dying wife.
abstract: Because of coronavirus restrictions in Italy, thousands of people have not been able to visit loved ones in hospitals, regardless of their ailment.
lead_paragraph: Because of coronavirus restrictions in Italy, thousands of people have not been able to visit loved ones in hospitals, regardless of their ailment.

headline: Assassination in Iran Could Limit Biden’s Options. Was That the Goal?
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The killing of Iran’s top nuclear scientist is likely to impede the country’s military ambitions. Its real purpose may have been to prevent the president-elect from resuming diplomacy with Tehran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The assassination of the scientist who led Iran’s pursuit of a nuclear weapon for the past two decades threatens to cripple President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s effort to revive the Iran nuclear deal before he can even begin his diplomacy with Tehran.

headline: Guns, Drugs and Viral Content: Welcome to Cartel TikTok
keywords: ['Drug Cartels', 'Propaganda', 'Social Media', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Mexico is set to shatter another murder record, but that grim reality is nowhere to be seen on the TikTok videos that go viral by showcasing drug cartel culture.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Tiger cubs and semiautomatic weapons. Piles of cash and armored cars. Fields of poppies watered to the sound of ballads glorifying Mexican drug cartel culture.

headline: Virus Deaths Approach Spring Record Amid Changing U.S. Crisis
abstract: On April 15, more Americans were reported dead of Covid-19 than on any other day of the pandemic. The daily toll is growing close once more.
lead_paragraph: On April 15, the United States reached a grim nadir in the pandemic: 2,752 people across the country were reported to have died from Covid-19 that Wednesday, more than on any day before or since.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Sam Ezersky helps us work off the turkey with an invigorating variety puzzle.
lead_paragraph: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Sam Ezersky manages to get two 15-letter puns into a very substantial puzzle this week, as well as some very jubilant smaller entries and a couple of stumpers. I’m leaving out the anagrams this time and linking to spoilers, and if you are new to “Panda” puzzles, use this excellent little glossary as you solve with us. This being a Panda, expect some variation.

headline: Ohio State cancels a game after a coronavirus outbreak, potentially imperiling its Big Ten chances.
abstract: Ohio State has called off its football game scheduled for Saturday at Illinois after coronavirus testing revealed an increasing number of cases on the team. The cancellation was announced hours after the university revealed that Ryan Day, the head coach of the fourth-ranked Buckeyes, had tested positive and would not travel to the game.

headline: Protests Over Security Bill in France Draw Tens of Thousands
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Demonstrators accused the government of drifting toward repressive policies with a measure that would restrict the sharing images of police officers and strengthen government surveillance tools.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Tens of thousands of people took to the streets across France on Saturday to protest a security bill that would restrict sharing images of police officers and strengthen government surveillance tools, the latest sign that anger over recent cases of police violence is galvanizing opposition.

headline: U.S. coronavirus cases pass 4 million for the month of November, doubling the record set in October.
abstract: The total number of coronavirus cases in the United States for November surpassed four million on Saturday, more than double the record set in October of 1.9 million cases. And the sharp escalation is likely to continue — or grow even steeper.
lead_paragraph: The total number of coronavirus cases in the United States for November surpassed four million on Saturday, more than double the record set in October of 1.9 million cases. And the sharp escalation is likely to continue — or grow even steeper.

keywords: ['Border Barriers', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Land Use Policies', 'Environment']

lead_paragraph: DOUGLAS, Ariz. — Four years ago, President Trump took office with a pledge to build a towering wall on America’s border with Mexico — a symbol of his determination to halt immigration from countries to the south and build a barrier that would long outlast him.

headline: Sarah Fuller, With a Kickoff, Is the First Woman to Play Football in a Power 5 Game
abstract: Fuller, a goalkeeper for Vanderbilt’s women’s soccer team, was asked to play because the football team’s kicking unit could not practice because of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Fuller became the first woman to play during a regular-season game in one of college football’s Power 5 conferences by booting a kickoff on Saturday for Vanderbilt to start the second half against Missouri.

keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Minimum Wage', 'Taxation', 'Productivity', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: One of the great successes of the Republican Party in recent decades is the relentless propagation of a simple formula for economic growth: tax cuts.

headline: Six-Pack
abstract: Eric Berlin puts the squeeze on with a muscular Sunday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you’re into solving unusual variety puzzles, you’re hopefully familiar with Eric Berlin — he’s behind two new creations in The New York Times this year as well as Puzzlesnacks, an ongoing series of inventive puzzles for children and adults. I was surprised to find that it had been a couple of years since we’ve had a Sunday puzzle from Mr. Berlin. (His most recent was the “Escape Room” contest puzzle from 2018 — I have to remember to ask if there’s a contest this year.)

lead_paragraph: It was his own personal sandbox, a real-life Sim City that he spent $350 million to build in a neglected corner of Las Vegas, just north of the flash and crowds of the Strip.

lead_paragraph: The raid alone was brazen enough. A team of Israeli commandos with high-powered torches blasted their way into a vault of a heavily guarded warehouse deep in Iran and made off before dawn with 5,000 pages of top secret papers on the country’s nuclear program.

keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Energy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: The assassination of Mohsen Fakhrizadeh isn’t about stopping a bomb — it’s about preventing diplomacy. Joe Biden doesn’t have to let it work.

headline: That Mysterious Monolith in the Utah Desert? It’s Gone, Officials Say
abstract: The metal structure has been removed, Utah officials said on Saturday, adding that they had not taken it down.
lead_paragraph: As mysteriously as it arrived, a metal monolith that was discovered last week by Utah public safety workers is now gone, officials said on Saturday.

headline: Learn a New Cookie Recipe or Make Invisible Ink
abstract: This week, listen to the music of Billie Holiday, attend a fashion workshop or get your tarot cards read.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Listen to Indigenous People
abstract: Expand your understanding of Native history issues beyond the fourth Thursday of November. Here are some Indigenous podcasters recommending their favorite Native-made audio.
lead_paragraph: The Indigenous people of the land now called North America are often only brought up in the past tense in primary school classrooms. The fact is they are a growing population, an increasing demographic in the country and in Congress, yet most Americans are woefully uninformed about their histories and present-day struggles. Podcasts can help fill in the gaps, and there are plenty of shows made by Indigenous people. Don’t know where to start? Native podcast-makers recommend their favorites.

headline: Shut Down Your Computers, Kids, and Lace Up
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Content Type: Service', 'Children and Childhood', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Parenting', 'Social Media', 'Jump Rope', 'Running', 'Hikes and Hiking', 'Yoga']
abstract: Teens and tweens need exercise, period. Many parents are finding informal, creative and encouraging ways to get their isolated offspring outside safely.
lead_paragraph: As any parent overseeing homeschool knows: Zoom P.E. is hardly a hard-driving Peloton class. It’s more like your kid lying on the floor of the living room doing halfhearted leg-lifts by the light of her laptop.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 29, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 29, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about dividend payouts misstated the amount that American corporations have sold in bonds this year. Through Nov. 10, they sold $1.6 trillion, not billion.

headline: Barroom Trivia Slayer? Get Your Quiz On Digitally
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Games']
abstract: Though many bars are under lockdown restrictions, pub quiz companies still operate online. You provide the booze, they provide the brainteasers.
lead_paragraph: In the spring, just before lockdown hit North Carolina, Steve Bahnaman met some friends at a Cider Brewery, just outside Raleigh, for an evening of bar trivia. His team, Covid Operations (this was back before Covid-19 puns were “super tired,” he explained), won the competition that night. The prize: $40 in bar cash. “Which I’m probably never going to use,” said Mr. Bahnaman, who hasn’t visited a bar or played another game in-person since. “That is very sad.”

headline: Turn Articles Into Poetry
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Writing and Writers', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Handicrafts', 'Books and Literature', 'Newspapers']
abstract: A cento is a poem written using borrowed lines, like ones from this publication. Don’t forget to give credit.
lead_paragraph: Imitation is the best kind of flattery. All creative people, whether they be writers, artists, dancers, singers or actors, know that. Think about the performers on a TV show like “The Voice,” who sometimes perform the song of a judge they are targeting. Sometimes, it is imitation that gets them on the team of their dreams. It is the same with poetry.

headline: Diego Maradona’s Long Shadow
abstract: From Ariel Ortega to Lionel Messi, dozens of players have been hailed as the next Maradona, the heir to his famed No. 10. But the fit was never perfect.
lead_paragraph: It was nothing more, really, than a ruffle of the hair and a kiss on the cheek. There was no pomp or circumstance that day in 1994, no words of wisdom whispered in the ear or sweeping gesture made for the crowd. Diego Maradona left the field, and Ariel Ortega replaced him on it. But that was all it took. The torch, it was decided, had been passed.

headline: The College Athletes Who Are Allowed to Make Big Bucks: Cheerleaders
abstract: Because cheerleading is not governed by the N.C.A.A., its participants can sign lucrative endorsement deals that would lead to punishment for most college athletes, including soon-to-be N.F.L. and N.B.A. millionaires.
lead_paragraph: During the three years Jamie Andries spent as a member of the University of Oklahoma cheerleading team, she cheered at two Big 12 championship football games, the Orange Bowl, the Sugar Bowl, the Rose Bowl and the 2016 Final Four.
