headline: Bah, Pandemic! How Theaters Are Saving ‘A Christmas Carol’
abstract: Seasonal stagings often underwrite the usual fare. But even without indoor audiences, the tradition lives on — by mail, by screen, by car and by radio.
lead_paragraph: For all his flaws, that cranky old miser Ebenezer Scrooge has been a godsend for American theaters. Through recessions and blizzards and other upheavals, he has drawn small children and big money to his redemption story in “A Christmas Carol.”

headline: The Lost Days That Made Bergamo a Coronavirus Tragedy
abstract: The northern Italian province became one of the deadliest killing fields for the virus in the Western world. But a Times investigation found that faulty guidance and bureaucratic delays rendered the toll far worse than it had to be.
lead_paragraph: BERGAMO, Italy — When Franco Orlandi, a usually hale former truck driver, arrived in mid-February with a cough and fever at an emergency room in the northern Italian province of Bergamo, doctors determined that he had a flu and sent him home. Two days later, an ambulance brought the 83-year-old back. He couldn’t breathe.

headline: Dave Prowse, Man Behind Darth Vader’s Mask, Is Dead at 85
abstract: Mr. Prowse went from being a weight lifting champion in Britain to helping portray one of the most memorable villains in movie history. But his voice did not make the edit.
lead_paragraph: Dave Prowse, the British actor who gave the imposing physical presence — but not the voice — to Darth Vader in the original “Star Wars” trilogy, died on Saturday in a hospital in London. He was 85.

headline: The Beat at the Heart of ‘Lovers Rock’
abstract: Steve McQueen’s new “Small Axe” anthology includes a film that centers on an offshoot of reggae that represented big shifts in the music, and in Black British culture.
lead_paragraph: The lovesick kiss-off “Silly Games” and its indelible high note play a pivotal part in “Lovers Rock,” one of five pieces in the director Steve McQueen’s new “Small Axe” anthology, which examines Black British life across the ’60s, ’70s and ’80s.

headline: Democrats made inroads in Arizona. But it’s a deeply divided place.
abstract: PHOENIX — In the moonlight, dozens of people hollered and embraced, dropping the rules of social distancing as they celebrated a win after a long year: hundreds of thousands of Latino voters registered, calls made and doors knocked amid a pandemic that had devastated their communities. Though it would be days before the final result in Arizona was clear, the people working to shore up Latino support for Democrats in the state were already convinced that they helped shape history. They had come through the crucible of a pervasive anti-immigrant sentiment and a decade later, flipped the state and delivered wins.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In the moonlight, dozens of people hollered and embraced, dropping the rules of social distancing as they celebrated a win after a long year: hundreds of thousands of Latino voters registered, calls made and doors knocked amid a pandemic that had devastated their communities. lead_paragraph: WEXFORD, Pa. — Just a few seats shy of a majority in the State House of Representatives, Democrats in Pennsylvania this year zeroed in on Republican-held suburban districts, where disdain for President Trump ran hot.

abstract: Their meetings used to take place discreetly in the basements of churches, a spare room at the Y.M.C.A., the back of a cafe. But when the pandemic hit last spring, members of Alcoholics Anonymous and other groups of recovering substance abusers found those doors quickly shut.

lead_paragraph: Art Basel Miami Beach, the annual fair that usually draws the contemporary art world to South Florida and was scheduled for this week, has been canceled — a cultural casualty of the coronavirus.

headline: Watch a Lunar Eclipse, or at Least Try To
abstract: Penumbral eclipses are subtle, but there are good reasons to try to notice one.
lead_paragraph: This evening as you sneak some late-night Thanksgiving leftovers, take a moment to marvel at the full moon. Do you notice anything different? It’s subtle, but on early Monday (Sunday night if you’re on the west coast), the full moon should appear a bit darker than usual. That’s because you’re witnessing a penumbral lunar eclipse, a celestial occurrence in which the moon dips behind Earth’s faint, outer shadow, or penumbra.

abstract: DOUGLAS, Ariz. — Four years ago, President Trump took office with a pledge to build a towering wall on America’s border with Mexico — a symbol of his determination to halt immigration from countries to the south and build a barrier that would long outlast him.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Keep the good eating going with a caramelized onion galette to pair with leftover turkey, a simple spaghetti al limone, or a baked risotto with greens.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The eggnog’s flowing where I stay, garlands rising, Christmas music playing, all the markers of holiday cheer. It’s a little out of character. But we’re building a bulwark against the strangeness of 2020, maybe? We’re anyway re-nesting in a nest that’s been largely the same since March. It’s been nice. And with Thanksgiving behind us, we’re baking like mad.

headline: Leadership of U.N. Human Rights Body Becomes Proxy Battle for World Powers

abstract: A fight over the council’s presidency is seen by some as an effort by China, Russia and Saudi Arabia to put a more compliant state in control ahead of greater involvement by the Biden administration.

headline: Trump Looms Large Now, but Maybe Not Forever
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: One-term presidents generally don’t leave big footprints. And the last four years may be seen as a reaction to the game-changing presidency of Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s critics warn that history will look unkindly on his effort to overturn a democratic election. This forecast, while understandable, may be wrong. History rarely looks on one-term presidents at all.

headline: Saweetie, City Girls and the Female Rapper Renaissance
abstract: Streaming, social media and the tireless work of trailblazers have helped change the hip-hop landscape.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s and 1990s, it often felt like hip-hop would only allow one female rapper to thrive at a time, maybe two. The genre was rife with systemic sexism, and limited resources all around made it even more challenging for women to break through.

headline: New York City Will Reopen Elementary Schools and Reduce Hybrid Learning
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced an abrupt shift in managing schools during the pandemic. Officials had faced criticism that they prioritized activities like indoor dining over children’s well-being.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Sunday that he would reopen public elementary schools, abruptly shifting policy in the face of widespread criticism that officials were placing more of a priority on economic activities like indoor dining than the well-being of New York City’s children.

headline: Offices of Diego Maradona’s Doctor Raided Over His Death
abstract: The authorities searched the home and offices of the soccer hero’s doctor as part of an investigation into the circumstances of his death last week.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The authorities searched the home and offices of Diego Maradona’s personal doctor on Sunday as part of an investigation into the circumstances surrounding the soccer star’s death last week.

headline: How Joe Biden Can Unify the Country

lead_paragraph: We had asked readers what they thought was the greatest challenge facing the president-elect and what advice they would give him. We published several responses on Saturday. Below are a few more, reflecting the most common answer: the need to heal a divided country.

headline: ‘I Have Never Seen So Many Toadstools.’ A Bumper Crop of Mushrooms in Ukraine.
abstract: Hunting for mushrooms deep in the forest is the ideal socially distanced pastime.

headline: Nike and Coca-Cola Lobby Against Xinjiang Forced Labor Bill
keywords: ['Forced Labor', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Business groups and major companies like Apple have been pressing Congress to alter legislation cracking down on imports of goods made with forced labor from persecuted Muslim minorities in China.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nike and Coca-Cola are among the major companies and business groups lobbying Congress to weaken a bill that would ban imported goods made with forced labor in China’s Xinjiang region, according to congressional staff members and other people familiar with the matter, as well as lobbying records that show vast spending on the legislation.

headline: Afghan Leader Digs In on Peace Talks Despite Progress, Officials Say
abstract: President Ashraf Ghani is holding up a tentative agreement on the talks’ framework, some officials say. His aides say no agreement was near.
lead_paragraph: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan has refused to let peace talks move forward even though the Taliban and government negotiators have reached a tentative agreement on the talks’ guiding principles, Afghan officials say, further stalling the process despite nearing an apparent breakthrough after months of effort.

abstract: Patients are usually most infectious two days before symptoms begin and for five days after, a new analysis finds.
lead_paragraph: People with Covid-19, the illness caused by the coronavirus, are most infectious about two days before symptoms begin and for five days afterward, according to a new analysis of previous research.

headline: ‘Because She’s a Girl’: Lockdown Exposes Gender Gap in U.K. Sports

headline: A Theater Duo’s ‘Last Gasp’ Doesn’t Look Like the End
abstract: As Split Britches, Peggy Shaw and Lois Weaver have made off-kilter theater for 40 years. Memory loss, and a pandemic, haven’t stopped their creating.
lead_paragraph: Back in March, Peggy Shaw and Lois Weaver, of the theater duo Split Britches, were in Britain, developing a new show, when Covid-19 exploded. It made more sense to stay put than to scamper back home to New York, which looked pretty scary at the time. Weaver, who has spent part of the year in London for nearly two decades, teaching performance at Queen Mary University, had a shared place there, but Shaw’s accommodations across town were an issue.

headline: Recount in two Wisconsin counties reinforces Biden’s victory.
abstract: The conclusion of the recount adds yet another loss in the Trump campaign’s effort to upend Mr. Biden’s win.
lead_paragraph: Wisconsin’s two largest counties have concluded recounts requested by the Trump campaign, with the results slightly increasing Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s margin of victory and reaffirming his win over President Trump in this month’s election.

headline: A Season of Footnotes Limps to Its Conclusion
abstract: The wheezing college football show goes on without some star players and highly paid coaches and with, in one case, a female kicker.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Fuller has been in far more demanding circumstances than she was on Saturday. Just last week she was in goal for the Vanderbilt women’s soccer team during its victory in the Southeastern Conference tournament championship game. But when Fuller took the field with the Vanderbilt football team on Saturday and chipped the second-half kickoff about 30 yards downfield against Missouri, she became the first woman to play in one of college football’s top conferences.

abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. visited an orthopedic specialist in Newark, Del., on Sunday afternoon after he twisted his ankle playing with his one of his dogs over the holiday weekend, according to his office, an injury that his doctor said resulted in hairline fractures that would require him to wear a boot for several weeks.

abstract: Nothing greases the gears of government quite like pork.

Lawmakers now have a duty to hunker down and find ways to make progress on critical issues. But with both chambers of Congress narrowly divided and ideologically polarized, coming together on even the most modest deals could prove daunting.

headline: For Trump, Past Is Prologue
abstract: He has always tried to weave a reality different from what is actually true.
lead_paragraph: If you are having a hard time fathoming how Donald Trump could deny reality, attempt to force-feed America his fictions, fight truth with conspiracy and concoction, and try to spin a loss into a victory, you shouldn’t. You need only be open to a fair analysis of Trump’s life. There is nothing new about this man’s behavior. This is what he has always been: a liar, a con man and a grifter.

headline: What We Learned From Week 12 of the N.F.L. Season
abstract: The Titans demolished the Colts, the Chiefs won again and the Broncos, with no quarterback, were crushed in a week defined as much by the coronavirus as the action on the field.
lead_paragraph: With the coronavirus sweeping through the N.F.L. at a greater extent than it had all season, Week 12 had an uneasy edge to it, and several teams had to cobble together solutions to problems brought by player absences resulting from positive tests and close contacts. The league soldiered on, however, getting all 12 of Sunday’s games in regardless of the issues. But a Tuesday game in which as many as 20 Ravens players could be out because of a coronavirus outbreak still looms.

headline: 1918 Germany Has a Warning for America

Yet watching President Trump’s “Stop the Steal” campaign since Election Day, I can’t help but see a parallel to one of the most dreadful episodes from Germany’s history.

He had few options. He was undocumented, did not speak much English and needed money badly. He owed months’ worth of rent, and his family in Mexico needed help.

headline: Barbra Streisand, Patti LaBelle and Dolly Parton on Their Most Memorable Performances
abstract: The legendary singers share their favorite moments captured onscreen over the years.
lead_paragraph: T’s Dec. 6 Holiday issue honors three American divas — Barbra Streisand, Patti LaBelle and Dolly Parton. Since the ’60s, when their careers began, each has, as Hanya Yanagihara writes in her Editor’s Letter, become “synonymous with an iconic American musical style: the Broadway show tune (Streisand), country (Parton) and soul (LaBelle),” bringing us infinite delight through their “music, acting and sheer force of personality.” Below, we’ve rounded up clips of each artist’s most treasured performances — or most memorable moments — that, when presented altogether, showcase their range, their brilliance and the indelible mark they’ve made on the culture.

headline: Celebrating Three of America’s Most Beloved Divas
abstract: Patti LaBelle, Dolly Parton and Barbra Streisand may each be synonymous with a different musical style, but they are alike in their ability to bring joy.
lead_paragraph: I had just begun writing this letter when my downtown Manhattan neighborhood erupted in sound: people yelling, cars honking, noisemakers blowing. It was Nov. 7, 2020, and the presidential election had finally been called for Joe Biden.

headline: The Grit and Glory of Dolly Parton
abstract: More than 50 years into her legendary career, she’s still capturing America’s particular mythology — its dreams and its disappointments — like no other.
lead_paragraph: IN JUNE OF 1967, Dolly Parton sat down for an interview with a Nashville writer named Everett Corbin. Parton was 21, and had yet to release her first solo album, but the surviving audio recording reveals that she was already shaping her account of herself with the editorial finesse of a one-woman P.R. firm: “I was born — we’ll start with when I was born, OK? — I was born on January the 19th, in 1946, in Sevier County, in Sevierville, Tenn. It’s a little town between Knoxville, Tenn., and Gatlinburg, Tenn. And you might shorten it by saying, ‘the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains.’” Parton dutifully answers Corbin’s questions (telling him she most enjoys writing and singing “real strong, pitiful, sad, crying ballads”), before steering the conversation toward a topic he hasn’t asked about, but should have: “Well, I have a new album out, I didn’t mention — or it’s not out, but … it should be out by the end of this month. But it’s called ‘Hello, I’m Dolly.’”

headline: Teaching in the Pandemic: ‘This Is Not Sustainable’
abstract: Teacher burnout could erode instructional quality, stymie working parents and hinder the reopening of the economy.
lead_paragraph: At Farmington Central Junior High in rural Illinois, classes still start at 8 a.m. But that’s about the only part of the school day that has not changed for Caitlyn Clayton, an eighth-grade English teacher tirelessly toggling between in-person and remote students.

headline: Barbra Streisand Is, as Ever, Firmly in Control
abstract: Since her breakout in the 1960s, she’s been able to convince the world around her to listen — not by chasing trends but by remaining always and fully herself.
lead_paragraph: THE DAY I arrive at Barbra Streisand’s property, she is on the phone with the Christie’s auction house in London. Outside, it’s a brilliantly sunny California afternoon in October, the skies clear of the ash cloud that recently blanketed Los Angeles.

Business was so good that owner Nina Kaiser, a psychologist, had just renovated and moved into a bigger space with the goal of doubling revenue.

headline: Patti LaBelle, the Doyenne of Philadelphia Soul
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Music', 'Gospel Music', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'RHYTHM AND BLUES (MUSIC)']
abstract: At 76, she is the embodiment of success, the personification of warmth and an artist who changed the landscape of American music.
lead_paragraph: PATTI LABELLE’S superpower is a spellbinding scream — a refined shriek, really — that makes hairs stand at attention, bones shiver and spines twist. It was 1975 when I first heard it. I was 10, in my parents’ South Bronx tenement, where the radio station WBLS — offering “the total Black experience in sound,” as the promos said — was always on during our morning rush to school. That’s when it hit me — “Creole Lady Marmalaaaaade,” the last word of those titular lyrics, which debuted the year before, filling the air. My first Patti LaBelle moment. There have been many such moments since — like hearing “Love, Need and Want You” (1983), which I put on the very first slow-jam tape I made as a teen — and with each one, the only logical reaction is to throw up your hands, kick off your shoes and, on occasion, break out in a praise dance.

headline: How to Build a Better Post-Pandemic New York City
abstract: Permanent outdoor dining is a no-brainer, but the city could do so much more.
lead_paragraph: It took a pandemic, but New York City is seeing more clearly than ever that its roadways can do more than move cars and trucks.

headline: Hidden in Plain Sight: The Ghosts of Segregation
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Photography', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: Vestiges of racism and oppression, from bricked-over segregated entrances to the forgotten sites of racial violence, still permeate much of America’s built environment.
lead_paragraph: The six faded letters are all that remain, and few people notice them. I would never have seen them if a friend hadn’t pointed them out to me while we walked through New Orleans’s French Quarter. I certainly wouldn’t have realized their significance.

headline: When an Enemy’s Cultural Heritage Becomes One’s Own
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Destruction of Cultural Antiquities and Heritage', 'War and Armed Conflicts', 'Mosques', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Armenians', 'Churches (Buildings)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'World Heritage Sites', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)', 'PANTHEON (ROME)']
abstract: Could the cease-fire in Nagorno-Karabakh offer new hope for the preservation of threatened monuments everywhere?
lead_paragraph: Since its origins in the ninth century, Dadivank Monastery has withstood Seljuk and Mongol invasions, Persian domination, Soviet rule and, this fall, a second brutal war between Armenia and Azerbaijan. Now the majestic stone complex — which includes two frescoed churches, a bell tower and numerous medieval inscriptions — faces something that could be even worse: a dangerous peace.

headline: New York Shifts Its Thinking and Reopens Elementary Schools
abstract: Middle and high schools will remain closed for now, said Mayor de Blasio, who signaled  changes in managing the system during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: How Much Do You Know About Grenada?
abstract: Can you find Grenada on a map? What else do you know about this island nation with a population of about 112,500 people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find Grenada on a map? What else do you know about this island nation with a population of about 112,500 people?

headline: When and How You’ll Get a Vaccine
abstract: Multiple inoculations for the coronavirus are making their way through the approval process. Here’s what we know about the plan for their distribution.
lead_paragraph: For Americans, months of collective isolation and fear could soon be winding down. A viable coronavirus vaccine may be just weeks away.

headline: On TikTok, Fans Are Making Their Own ‘Ratatouille’ Musical
abstract: Thousands of TikTok users, including musical theater professionals, are creating a Broadway-style adaptation of the animated Disney film about a rat with culinary aspirations.
lead_paragraph: With Broadway and theaters across the country idle because of the coronavirus, some actors, producers and prop designers have found an unlikely outlet for their talents: a musical version of the animated film “Ratatouille” that is playing out in exuberant 60-second increments on TikTok.

headline: The Path of Virus Deaths
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: The number of Covid-19 deaths in the U.S. has dropped in the last few days, but there is reason to think the decline is a statistical mirage — and that deaths are on the verge of surging again.

headline: Most Republicans Say They Doubt the Election. How Many Really Mean It?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Survey research tries to sort out the typical partisan reactions to a loss from an erosion of trust that may be more lasting.
lead_paragraph: Since the election, surveys have consistently found that about 70 percent to 80 percent of Republicans don’t buy the results. They don’t agree that Joe Biden won fair and square. They say the election was rigged. And they say enough fraud occurred to tip the outcome.

headline: Moderna Applies for Emergency F.D.A. Approval for Its Coronavirus Vaccine
abstract: The first shots could be given as early as Dec. 21, if authorization is granted.
lead_paragraph: The drugmaker Moderna said it would apply on Monday to the Food and Drug Administration to authorize its coronavirus vaccine for emergency use.

headline: Biden Moves on to Economic Hires
keywords: ['Presidential Transition (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Some of his foreign policy choices present an ethics test: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Fauci warns of a surge “superimposed” on the one we’re already in, while Biden’s foreign policy team faces a test on ethics. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Australia Condemns Lurid Tweet by Chinese Official as ‘Disgusting Slur’
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Politics and Government', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: The post, with a doctored photograph showing an Australian soldier with a knife to the throat of an Afghan child, sent relations between the two countries to a new low.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Labeling it a “disgusting slur,” Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia denounced on Monday what he called a fabricated image posted to Twitter by a Chinese official that showed an Australian soldier with a knife to the throat of an Afghan child.

headline: Companies Bet Big on Working From Home
abstract: Salesforce’s approach for Slack is a sign of things to come.
lead_paragraph: Salesforce has approached Slack about a deal, DealBook hears, confirming a report in The Wall Street Journal. A takeover could be announced as soon as this week. The potential deal is a bet on remote working, an area that bankers tell us will be a hot spot for consolidation in the months ahead, as highly valued software companies look to roll up the fragmented market for collaboration tools.

headline: 4 Officers in France Are Charged Over Beating of a Black Man
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Police', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Law and Legislation', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Assaults']
abstract: The violence against Michel Zecler, a 41-year old music producer, caused a national outcry and fueled longstanding accusations of police brutality and racism.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Four police officers have been charged over the beating of a Black music producer in Paris this month, the authorities in France said on Monday, in a case that has shocked the country and forced the government to reckon with persistent accusations of police brutality and racism.

headline: Noah Hawley Isn’t Done with ‘Fargo’
abstract: “The show has always been about the American experience, and there’s still a lot to say about it,” said the creator of the FX crime drama, which wrapped up its fourth season on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: When the third season of “Fargo” ended in 2017, the concept of “alternative facts” and “fake news” were clearing the way for what became the Trump presidency’s challenge to reality. The themes the creator Noah Hawley explored in that season seemed oddly prescient, all the way down to Russians and disinformation, but he shrugged it off: “You can never predict the zeitgeist,” he said at the time. “I just managed to land in it.”

headline: Brady Puts Up a Fight, but It’s Mahomes and the Chiefs’ Day
abstract: Tyreek Hill had a career day against the Buccaneers with 13 receptions for 269 receiving yards and three touchdowns.
lead_paragraph: Tom Brady floundered for most of Sunday’s game against Kansas City’s incandescent quarterback, Patrick Mahomes. If the game was seen by some as a chance for a passing of the torch from one quarterback to another, from an N.F.L. legend to his heir apparent, that torch — if passed by Brady at least — very likely would have been intercepted.

headline: More Restrictions as the Covid-19 Surge Continues
abstract: Monday: Any break you might’ve been hoping for over the long weekend was cut short.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: As Iran Mourns Nuclear Scientist, Officials Vow to Find His Killers
abstract: “We chase the criminals to the end,” the Iranian defense minister said at the funeral of Mohsen Fakhrizadeh.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian defense minister vowed on Monday to find and punish those responsible for the assassination of Iran’s top nuclear scientist, while another senior official offered an account of the attack radically different from initial reports in the Iranian state news media.

headline: What You Get for $3 Million in California
abstract: A Tudor Revival with seven bedrooms in Berkeley, a Craftsman house with five bedrooms in San Diego and an Italianate home with four bedrooms in Napa.
lead_paragraph: A Tudor Revival with seven bedrooms in Berkeley, a Craftsman house with five bedrooms in San Diego and an Italianate home with four bedrooms in Napa.

headline: $3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Tudor Revival with seven bedrooms in Berkeley, a Craftsman bungalow with five bedrooms in San Diego and an Italianate house with four bedrooms in Napa.
lead_paragraph: This house, in the Claremont neighborhood, was built by Walter H. Ratcliff, a London-born architect who designed a number of Bay Area buildings in the English Tudor style. The home has undergone several transformations: A second gable was added in the 1920s, and in the mid-20th century, interior walls and bathrooms were added so it could be used as a boardinghouse. The current owners turned it back into a single-family residence and updated the plumbing, electrical and HVAC systems. The house is about two blocks from the Clark Kerr Campus of the University of California, Berkeley; the school’s main campus is 10 minutes away. Monkey Island, a small park, is across the street.

headline: Amid Workplace Complaints, New York Road Runners Parts Ways With Its C.E.O.
keywords: ['Running', 'New York City Marathon', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Michael Capiraso led the organization that puts on the New York City Marathon to record revenues but became the subject of anonymous complaints about the organization’s attention to diversity and social justice.
lead_paragraph: The New York Road Runners, the club that puts on the New York City Marathon, announced Monday that its chief executive would depart at the end of the year, amid complaints from current and former employees who questioned the organization’s commitment to diversity and social justice.

headline: G.M. Scales Back Alliance With Electric Truck Start-Up Nikola
abstract: A new agreement, supplying hydrogen fuel cell technology from General Motors, is less sweeping than the strategic partnership outlined in September.
lead_paragraph: General Motors and Nikola, a high-profile start-up aiming to produce electric trucks, said on Monday that they had reached an agreement to work together only on hydrogen fuel cells, replacing a broader alliance they originally outlined in September.

headline: There’s Another Runoff in Georgia, and the Winner Gets a Month in Congress
abstract: The winner of Tuesday’s runoff will have the distinction of succeeding John Lewis, a giant of the civil rights era, and closing out what would have been the final days of his 17th term in Congress.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Kwanza Hall and Robert M. Franklin Jr. have been campaigning for months, planting signs in grassy medians along busy Atlanta roadways and onto windows of popular brunch spots.

headline: Median Home Price Sets New Record in California
abstract: The pandemic paused the housing market for a few months, but it has been on a rebound that has pushed the median price over $700,000.
lead_paragraph: Fueled by low interest rates and a historic housing shortage, California’s median home price in September reached $712,430, closing out four straight months of record highs.

headline: ‘Trump Is Better’: In Asia, Pro-Democracy Forces Worry About Biden
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States International Relations', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Faith-Based Initiatives']
abstract: The president-elect’s aim of restoring foreign policy norms has spooked human rights defenders in Asia, who praise President Trump as someone willing to confront dictators.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A dissident once branded Enemy No. 1 by the Chinese Communist Party is spreading conspiracy theories about vote-rigging in the American presidential election.

headline: Bitcoin Hits New Record, This Time With Less Talk of a Bubble
keywords: ['Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Virtual Currency', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Gold', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Currency']
abstract: The crazy cousin of traditional currencies, which fell below $4,000 in March, passed $19,783. More investors now are buying it for the long term.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin is back. Again.

headline: Dorie Greenspan’s Amazing New Cookie
abstract: A riff on lemon meringue pie, her latest recipe layers a shortbread sablé with lemon curd and shards of meringue.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Dorie Greenspan introduced me to the mystery novelist Louise Penny this weekend, in a delightful column in The New York Times Magazine that begins in Penny’s fictional Three Pines, a village in Quebec “with a good boulangerie; a bookstore that smells like tea and flowers; a bistro with an excellent chef; and a community of fascinating eccentrics.” Penny’s hero, Chief Inspector Armand Gamache of the Surêté du Québec, appears to be one of those brilliant, gentle investigators in the vein of Martin Walker’s Benoît Courrèges, locally known as Bruno, Chief of Police. And, as with Bruno, food plays a big role in his life. I ordered “Still Life,” the first of the Gamache series as soon as I finished Dorie’s piece.

headline: London A.I. Lab Claims Breakthrough That Could Accelerate Drug Discovery
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Clinical Trials', 'Science and Technology', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Proteins', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-health']
abstract: Researchers at DeepMind say they have solved “the protein folding problem,” a task that has bedeviled scientists for more than 50 years.
lead_paragraph: Some scientists spend their lives trying to pinpoint the shape of tiny proteins in the human body.

headline: Angry Farmers Choke India’s Capital in Giant Demonstrations
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Politics and Government', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Tens of thousands have arrived in tractors and trailers, many traveling hundreds of miles, to block roads into New Delhi and protest recently passed pro-market agricultural policies.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Mewa Singh said he wasn’t going anywhere.

headline: Australia Demands Apology After Chinese Official’s ‘Repugnant’ Tweet
abstract: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia condemned a Chinese official’s tweet that showed an Australian soldier with a knife to the throat of an Afghan child, labeling it a “disgusting slur” and demanded an apology.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia condemned a Chinese official’s tweet that showed an Australian soldier with a knife to the throat of an Afghan child, labeling it a “disgusting slur” and demanded an apology.
